reviews.review:
Well worth a visit. Absolutely beautiful park. Well worth a visit. It is hard to believe you're in a city.
Small cost to enter but do not let this out you off. Make sure you see the rose garden and the greenhouse.

Central Park of Tokyo. If you have time for a leisurely stroll or want to sit on the grass and relax this is the spot. An oasis in the middle of a very hectic and busy neighborhood. Japanese gardens are the best. Few options for snacks...probably to maintain the premises clean and a small entrance fee.

One of the best park. One of the best park in Tokyo ! Easy to get there by public transport. Park located in Shinjuku area and has a few entrances ! Nice Place for walking and jogging ! Very popular by locals !

Well worth a visit. If you like gardens then this one is a must if you are visiting Tokyo. The gardens are beautifully maintained. Allow two or three hours to see it all and make sure you get there early as they close about 4.30pm.

An Oasis of Tranquillity in Busy Shinjuku. This was a beautiful, spacious garden hidden behind busy Shinjuku Street. I spent 3 hours wandering around in the afternoon for the equivalent of 2 US dollars (!) and still did not see everything. Make sure you check this out on your trip.

Hanami and Ancient Japan tradition. I have been here in 2012 and 2014 for Hanami. It was so beatiful to walk while cherry trees surrounded you with a rain of petals. You must try, you must live the experience of Japan Cherry Blossom at Shinjuku Gyoen

Lovely - central park in Tokyo. Really loved walking through the park, there are so many great picture opportunities plus there is a lot of history within the park its self and the tea houses make a nice place to stop. Its very well worth the entry fee and they provide maps in english. If you go in summer or september I would recommend taking insect repellant as there was a lot of small flying bugs around.

Lovely gardens. These gardens are like an oasis is the desert. So unexpected in a bustling city such as Tokyo. There were a variety of gardens --- Japanese, French, English --- all showing aspects of garden design and plant varieties. There is a wonderful Greenhouse that is really large with many different types of plants.We wandered the gardens for over 3 hours without realising how long we had been there.They are well worth the 200yen per person to visit!

Gorgeous. Spent a quiet day here with my wife. Nice to see lots of people enjoying the sunshine, taking a nap on the grassy hills. You pay a couple bucks to get into this place, but it's very much worth it.

Fabulous!. It is really worth taking 1-2 hours to explore and relax in this garden in Shinjuku.It is very cheap to enter, and the gardens are beautiful - well kept paths, lawns, lakes and bridges. It is gorgeous.The greenhouse is also excellent with a large collection of tropical plants and trees, well labelled in English.There is also a a cafe.A haven of tranquillity in the centre of Tokyo.

Beautiful . A peaceful haven just minutes away from the hustle and bustle of central Shinkuju. There is a small fee to get in, but it's worth it for some down time. It says "no food on the grass" everywhere, but most people were having their lunch and snacks while we went! Very pleasant.
Beautiful Green Space. This is a beautiful space in the middle of the city. The cherry blossoms in spring and the fall colours are beautiful. It's a very nice place to spend an afternoon.
Very peaceful!. If you need a break from the busy streets then take a walk around this lovely Park with freat colours and great nature! I highly recommend
Amazing.... Worth the time to check this out - stunning. A nice peaceful few hours can be lost here regardless of the time of year.
Nice way to spend a few hours. Beautiful well kept gardens. Easy to find. Most signs in Japanese only but good English pointer signs.

Nice garden to take a walk. Honestly, there isn't much attractions or any sight-seeing in this garden (except the cherry blosom season because there are a few sakura trees in there). But it's a nice park to take a relaxing walk, given it's convenient located in the city centre Shinjuku.
Beautiful colors. I went there during winter and was lucky enough to still see some of the autumn colors, just beautiful. Do not forget to go to the greenhouse.

Peaceful place. It was cherry blossom season when I was there, and therefore full of crowds, but that was definitely part of the fun. It's rather large, and a total oasis in busy Shinjuku. I really enjoyed my visit, and wished I could stay longer (alas, more of Toyko was calling my name!).
beautiful. Recommend it for everyone! Such a beautiful place to walk around and just enjoy the good weather or enjoying your day!

Nice and large garden. - Peaceful garden, entrance fee is reasonable.- If you come in the afternoon, I suggest you begin with the greenhouse, as it closes 30 minutes earlier than the garden.- We enjoyed the numerous areas where you can step and rest freely on the grass.- As everywhere in Tokyo, garbage bins are in limited numbers, use the big ones at the main entrance.- Public toilets inside the park are clean.- During closing time, some gates are shut down, if it happens to you, wait for the guard on bicycle, he should open the gate to let you out. Distance from one gate to another is quite long.

Another great garden. This is a very popular garden with lots of visitors on a Sunday. The traditional garden is very pleasant, and to be able to walk through groves of tall trees in the middle of a large tree is somewhat surprising.

Handy way to spend a few hours . Very pretty park inside, also has a greenhouse full of different plants. Cost 200 yen to get in which was fine. Plenty of plants to see plus nice water features. Nice place to chill out
Absolutely beautiful!. Was lovely to walk around the beautiful gardens. Different areas of the park have different themed gardens. Near to nothing cost to get in. Would recommend.

A little piece of solitude in the middle of Tokyo!!. Beautiful area to walk with nature or sit on the lawn feeling as if you are out in the country with only a subtle reminder of the massive city buildings peaking over the surround trees! Highly recommend a visit for decompressing from city travel!

Something for all Nature Lovers. Beautiful gardens and the greenhouse is well worth a visit. Lots of different areas to offer something for many different nature lovers, Japanese water area, French & English garden sections etc. Not really anything to do for kids though as ball games etc not allowed. The gardens cover a huge expanse so be prepared to walk a lot if you want to cover it all.

Tokyo's Central Patk. Beautiful park that has Japanese, English and French gardens. The buildings that tower over the park almost make it look like Central Park. The Japanese garden and Mother and Child forest are beautiful and worth exploring, the English and French gardens were a little disappointing. Great place for picnic and a relaxing spot to rest from the bustling city.

Great for late blooming blossoms. Having visited a number of parks and gardens in Tokyo, Shinjuku Gyoen remains my favourite. My best visit was in April. If you miss the peak of the cherry blossom season, you can still enjoy the gorgeous late blooming varieties in the park. Note, no alcohol allowed during Sakura season. At this time of year bags are checked at the entrance.

Beautiful Park and Gardens. There are three gates that access the gardens Shinjuku Gate, Okido Gate and Sendagaya Gate, make sure you visit each of these as part of your tour of the gardens.It you love nature, plants and wildlife you will have a very happy time here :)
Park. MANY gardens . Excellent plants.you could spend days here. Very reasonable entrance. Reasonable refreshment stands huge difference with city around Park.
Lovely park in middle of Tokyo . Well worth a visit. It had different garden styles and was a place to relax after the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.

Beautiful!. A five minute walk from Shinjuku Station, you'd never guess you are right next to the busiest station in the world! Serene, quiet, and beautiful. We took family photos in the park and have beautiful memories of the gardens.

Peaceful garden in Shinjuku. I think this garden is such a beautiful and peaceful place in Shinjuku. I only visited the Japanese garden, but there are also English and French gardens. The Japanese garden grounds had a temple, various paths, tea houses and ponds. I decided to walk up to the temple structure, however I forgot my insect repellent. BIG mistake! It was worth it because my photos from the temple were absolutely beautiful.There is nominal fee to visit, but it is worth the expense.
Cool relief on a hot day. A serene park to stroll through to escape the surrounding hustle and bustle. Allow yourself at least an hour to walk all around.
An absolutely gorgeous park. A must for an visitor to Tokyo. Kms. of beautiful trees, including 100s of cherry trees spectacular during the cherry blossom period

Go there early and join the government sponsored Imperial castle visit. This large patch of green in the middle of tokyo is stunning. You can just walk around the area for 2-3 hours. A great place .......They have sponsored tour inside the imperial building (i don't know the exact days). We joined a group of travellers for this visit and it was excellent. But, make sure that you ask for a translator.
GREENLAND. It's worth coming here for a walk, very green very nice and tranquilin the heart of Tokyo.It was very hot but plenty of shade too by the trees.
Pretty park, but lots of mosquitos. The park itself is very pretty but the fact that we were assaulted by a bunch of mosquitoes really put a damper on things.

Absolutely stunning. Central Tokyo and an escape with space and fresh air in beautiful landscape gardens with wonderful water features. If you want to switch off from the hectic surroundings of Tokyo day to day life the garden is the perfect spot for tranquillity. Consider checking out the Sumo wrestling and Tokyo fish market which are amazing.

An Imperial and Chillaxing Walk. We visited this grandiose park as a typhoon was approaching. The park itself is a gem among the towering city skyscrapers. Everywhere we went - the evergreen lawns, the greenhouse and everything verdant - was pleasant to the mind and body. Maybe next time when we're back, having a picnic will be a good idea!

Nice Break. Me and couple friends ended up here when we decide to take a stroll after a heavy meal. Cost 200 Yen for entry and they have maps in English. It's a nice resting spot away from the city. Went to all the sites but didn't really see a lot of special things. The greenhouse was probably the nicest site in there. Bugs hater should stay away. Alot of spiders hanging around the trees. Also friend got bit by some mosquitoes. Normal city park.

A relaxing experience. A long walking through this park was a pleasant way to deal with jet lag. It is a lovely, quiet Park but I had come with greater expections. Many areas were in need of maintance. The green-house was the high-light for us botanically. The entrance fee was very reasonable so all in all, well worth the visit. Would Love to see it in different seasons.

Beautiful garden. We arrived at the garden soon after it opened and it was very quiet, but offered beautiful scenery. After about a half hour, the garden became busier and it became difficult to take pictures without someone else in the picture also. Worth the price to get in.

A nice place for some quiet. This is a large green quiet oasis amidst the hubbub of the Shinjuku district of Tokyo. It is certainly worth a stroll by the ponds, under the trees and by the tea houses. Don't expect a perfectly manicured Japanese garden. It is a nice city park with trees and big grassy areas for picnics. Admission was 200 yen.

Very Quiet and Serene. This park is close to Shinjuku and great for a quiet serene walk away from the city hustle bustle. It's got a nice traditional Japanese garden. However there is no wow factor. Just like any other big city park.

Nice oasis in the middle of the city. This is a very beautiful and green oasis in the middle of Shinjuku area. Lots of ponds, fishes, birds, flowers and trees. Well worth spending a couple of hours, a perfect half day experience.

Very relaxing. A really nice garden to walk around probably any time of year and I used it as a morning walk to wake up and plan the day in the outside and relative quiet (strange how quiet it was when it's smack bang in the middle of shinjuku).

Green escape in busy Shinjuku. Great expenses of perfectly manicured lawn and trees. Just take a stroll in the early morning to feel completely relaxed and forget all about the craziness of Tokyo outside the park's gates. The entry fee is not much but i wanted to go everyday even for a short walk so it's something to consider. It closes quite early at 4, so do give yourself plenty of time to relax and enjoy the different gardens, it is not a place rush but take a walk maybe sit down a bit to take in the views and then walk some more, repeat. The most relaxing thing you can do in Tokyo. Highly recommended but need sufficient time to appreciate it.

Nice park to chill, walk the grounds and picnic at for around $2. Nice grounds. Lots of beautiful ponds lined with lovely trimmed bonsai style trees. Huge grounds to sprawl out with friends and family for the day, very relaxing to say the least.

Peaceful sanctuary in the heart of the city. This really is a treasure. We luckily went on a Tuesday, my daughter told me that she has been at a weekend and it is noisy and busy then, but in the week days it was tranquil and the gardens are excellent. There were groups of people doing water colour paintings and it w easy to see how inspiring it was for that. The day we went the hot house was cooler than outside! There are places to sit on the grass or to eat. Certainly worth a trip

Amazing, Mind blowing in sakura season. This park is really amazing tranquil place in the heart of busy shinjuku, its hard to realize when inside that you are in one of the busiest areas in the world, am a fan of Japanese landscaping and this park is the perfect example.in the sakura blossom season this park look so amazing that it leaves you speechless.
Beautiful and peaceful. It was like walking through a rain forest and in the middle a big beautiful park where people were just laying about.
Garden surprise!. What a surprise it was to find this lovely national park in bustling shinjuku. If you need a break from the busy streets then take a walk around this lovely Park, a hidden gem

Idyllic. Surrounded by a big city, sits this peaceful garden that was most enjoyable. Different themes: Japanese traditional garden, English French, a wonderful place to walk. Ended the day with an ice cream. Lovely

Lovely place to spend an afternoon. This is a beautiful and peaceful park, with several formal gardens and plenty of spots to have a drink or snack and clean public restrooms. My only issue was the mosquitoes - if you are here in the warm months bring some bug spray.

Excellent for an afternoon stroll. Entered via the Shinjuku entrance, entry fee is 200 yen. You get a map of the gardens also. I was impressed by the greenhouse, although small it is impressive with many micro-climates and a waterfall. The architecture and exterior design is unique. We stopped at a small rest point down the hill from the greenhouse and had an ice-cream and iced tea in a pleasant creek side garden. We then slowly walked around to the French garden and then to the traditional Japanese garden, spending around two hours before turning down the path at the side of store in the Japanese garden to take us back to the Shinjuku entrance. It was an approximately 15 minute walk back to Shinkjuku train station, the trip back to Tokyo was 200 yen.Shinjuku has many restaurants and stores however it is very, very busy. Great if you like that type of thing :-).

An Enjoyable Afternoon. With various gardens that scatter the area, the Shinjuku Gyeon National Park is number one on trip advisor for a reason. Try some green tea in one of the tea houses for a break from the heat or humidity, and try some of the ice cream too while your at it. A must do in the greater Tokyo area!

" Beautiful, Peaceful Japanese Gardens ". Our family spend a few hours walking around this Beautiful, Peaceful, and Gorgeous Japanese Gardens called the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden in Tokyo , Japan. Wandering around the magnificent grounds taking pictures everywhere of the ancient and beautiful trees, and the Japanese gardens and the stone pagodas. You can take your time and spend the day relaxing as you can walk around everywhere to see the picturesque gardens. Don't forget your camera at this must see spot in Tokyo Japan.

A sanctuary within the hustle and bustle. Highly recommended for those needing a bit of a chill out. For the Y200 admission, you can feel as if you're in the countryside, listening to birds, and insects, walking the lake, and visiting the gardens and green house. Its amazing how quiet the park is considering its location.
Beautiful Gardens. Went there on a very hot (33C day) but well worth the trip. Garden is separated into different areas, French, English,Japanese etc.make sure you take your camera

Loved this beautiful garden. Spent hours wandering around the magnificent grounds and enjoying the ancient and beautiful tree. Only down was that I was there at the very beginning of autumn so missed out on seeing autumn leaves and flowers

Beautiful!. When it's a nice day, it's lovely to come here, walk around and relax.
Lovely to see the Japanese gardens and the stone pagodas. Very picturesque.
You can take your time and spend the day relaxing.

Urban park with walking trails. This is a very well manicured park. We visited this park after we arrived on a very early morning flight and could not check into our hotel for 8 hours. You can cover about 2 or 3 miles by walking the paths through the park. There is also a very modern looking glass greenhouse. You may want to bring some bug repellent, as I was bitten by some kind of insect that set off an allergic reaction, resulting in multiple itchy hives. There were plenty of bathroom facilities throughout the park. There is a cafe at the entrance serving meals and drinks. The entrance fee was ¥200 per adult.

Beautiful Gardens. popped in here on one of our days in tokyo wandering around. It has some really beautiful gardens and its right in the middle of the city. we spent about an hour wandering through different gardens.Well worth a visit.

Lovely green oasis in bustling Tokyo. This is a refreshing change from the pace of Tokyo and a great retreat.There are a range of garden styles represented but I favour the traditional Japanese garden.

Amazing Park. Park is amazing with a very nice lake to just chill out near, great spot to get away from the hustle and bustle of the urban landscape of Japan.Spent over 3 hours here just walking around and enjoying the scenery.

Tranquility in the middle of a busy city. The Gyoen national garden is a beautiful place, particularly the traditional Japanese garden. Unfortunately we didn't have great weather and it was extremely humid. It would be stunning in spring when in flower
Garden stroll. Beautiful, peaceful, not crowded and worth the stroll. Bathrooms and food available in the park area.

Tranquil walk in the middle of the city. Bit out of place in the busy city but a lovely place to visit. Costing 200 yen per adult, it's a nice place to sit and relax. Note... Remember mosquito spray! We got bitten 20 times between us!

Beautiful and peaceful. We were there in late March, and though it was still a bit chilly in the city, there were a lot of sunny places in the gardens. Many flowers were still blooming, and we actually saw more cherry blossoms blooming here than we did in Ueno park during its Hanami festival. I would definitely recommend it for any nature lover.
great garden relaxing. located in the middle of shinjuku with all the busy streets. it is a great place to relax, maybe little bit crowded inside, but it was great to walk around.
Excellent way to pass time. Just what it says above. Bring bug spray, though. The mosquitoes can be annoying, but you don't even know until after you leave this beautiful place.

The beautiful French Garden :). Went in from Shinjuku Gate of the Park somewhat late in the afternoon and it didn't take long to get to the English Tea Garden (really just a big spacious lawn) & the French Formal Garden (with beautiful multi-colored flowers, mostly roses); saw a big glass building too which probably is a conservatory or a greenhouse. Overall, it was a pleasure to walk through this park and was more or less impressed by the beautiful flowers at the French Garden, and yes there's a fairly big & peaceful lake too (maybe more than one, but I only saw one) in the Park.Shinjuku Station (a lot of train lines & Toei Shinjuku & Oedo Lines for subway) is just about a 10-minute walk away from Shinjuku Gate at the northwest of the Park; and if you're going to Meiji Jingu afterward (like I was), you might want to do like I did which is walk through the park from northwest to southeast (I guess like a diagonal way) and exit from Sendagaya Gate at the southeast of the Park, then get back onto the main road (outside Sendagaya Gate is just a small lane, so you'll have to first get back onto the main road parallel to that small lane) and turn right and just go straight on that road for about 10 minutes and you'll be at Yoyogi Park & at the north entrance gate of Meiji Jingu Shrine (the Shrine itself is another 5 to 10 minutes' walk from that gate).

Beautiful. It was a sunny beautiful experience. We were here on a Sunday, so it was quite crowded, but still plenty of space to walk/sit/relax/eat. Actually I would recommend going on a sunday, because then you are really around its inhabitants. I had a blast, just looking at other couples and families. There are different areas in the parc, I went to the French part and it was full with roses, really beautiful. I also went to the Japanese Tea House; you can have a green tea and traditional snack for €5, but I would not recommend that. It just did not feel authentic..
Good scenery!!. Shaped object of Japan was very beautiful ! Shinjuku was fresh and is also surrounded by green . .

Cherry Blossoms everywhere ..... Yes ... if you come in the precise time, late March to early April of the year, like us. Plan your visit and don't miss the beautiful scene ...if you into Spring Scenery. Of course "everywhere" is exaggerated, some area are just a forested park, but as a paid garden, this Shinjuku Gyoen Garden is value for money. Just a minute walk from Shinjuku station, we get a tranquility and such a beautiful view ... not stuck in bustling urban Tokyo.To make our visit worthy they provide an information center and don't forget to make a visit to a nice green house inside the garden.For always hungry people don't be anxious, there is a restaurant as well.

Beautiful picnic spot. This is a really tranquil spot in the heart of bustling Shinjuku, perfect for a break from the noise of the city and to enjoy a picnic. It closes fairly early at 4pm and is quite big so arrive earlier to enjoy it in dull, the rest of Shinjuku goes to bed late! I only had time for the Japanese garden part but it was really beautiful and tranquil.
a vast and beautiful park. a must see park in shinjukuyou can view the whole park from the top of takashimayaand you can take great picture from the top of takashimaya building

Cherry Blossom Heaven. We visited at the end of March just as the Cherry blossoms were out and it was truly breathtaking! The park itself us lovely, but as he blossoms burst into life it's truly special.

Peace in busy city. Went for walk through park just few hours before they closed looked like we missed the crowds! Cherry blossom weren't in full bloom yet but still just beautiful views from so many different spots in the garden! Wish we could have spent more time there. Stop at as many gardens as you can while on your visit they provide nice calm to the balance the lights and sounds and busy feel of the city.

Best during Spring/Fall Season. Huge park in the middle of a very busy area. Just 5 min walk from the nearest metro station, this park offers wonderful time to just sit, relax, play around and have a moment with nature.Best time to visit this place will be during Spring (Hanami) and Autumn season where the leaves change color.
Huge garden. Quite a big Japanese garden. Need to pay ¥200 for entrance. Good for a sunny day. Some mozzies so prepare repellent spray if needed.

Tranquility in the middle of a big city. It was a very hot day, I almost faint & die dried over the heat but thanks to the umbrella & vending machine, I could have a nice drink. Everything changes after I arrived in the park gate. The sound of nature calls & soothen the day. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is very beautiful. You can easily explore the area and enjoy the beauty it has to offer. I'd suggest you spend 2 hours in this garden, sitting on the grass & have a good rest (maybe snacks too?).

Nice Shinjuku get-away. Beautiful park slash garden. Such a nice escape from the busy Shinjuku area. You have to pay a small fee and be aware that the entrance to enter the park closes at 16.00h. After that you still have an hour to stroll.

Tranquil Beauty. Japanese gardens are copied all over the world. Here it is in the original form, and it was absolutely beautiful. It is in the heart of the city, but doesn't feel that way at all. It has authentic Japanese architecture to be seen, and depending on the season, magnificent plant life.
Beautiful gardens . Beautiful gardens in the centre of town. Escape the hustle and bustle of the city. Definitely worth a visit.

Inner city escape. A magical place to balance out the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. A large beautifully designed garden to explore. Grab a bento box and have a romantic picnic by one of the many beautiful ponds

Space to breath. You can barely hear the traffic here. Some skyscrapers do loom on the outskirts of the park, but they only make this place more peaceful. We packed snacks and drinks and started to wander after paying the entrance fee (worth it). While there are French and English style garden, the overwhelming highlight was the Japanese winding paths through towering trees amid the ponds and bridges. We took shelter during a brief downpour and enjoyed our food, watching and listening to the bird life, cicadas and wind through the trees. Wear good walking shoes and take your time. The city isn't going anywhere.
Beautiful walking park. If you want a respite from the teeming masses in Tokyo spend an hour in natur in this park and rejuvenate!

Very pretty & relaxing. Very pretty, quiet gardens. Roses were not in season but we enjoyed walking around the formal gardens. Large lawn for picnics, nice Japanese garden as well. Lots of snack options inside the park. They don't allow things like frisbees or guitars, so it's a really nice quiet break from Tokyo chaos :)
Springtime is optimal, not fall. We went in fall-- of course all the 1300 cherry trees were nice and green but not exactly interesting to look at.
Great Park. It is a lovely park, very large, different areas to see. Worth the small admission fee. A cool place to go in the middle of crazy Shinjuku.
Lovely park. A very nice park for walks and picnics. Enjoyed the japanese tea garden the most. It also has nice greenhouse. The greens in the city makes the city breathable.

Shinjuku Gyoen Park-- A huge oasis in Shinjuku. Shinjuku Gyoen Park is not a traditional "play park", but is, instead, a beautiful and peaceful oasis in the middle of crazy-busy Shinjuku. Balls, kites, bikes, skateboards, frisbees, rollerblades and pets are not allowed in order to foster a calm and serene environment. The park is split into 3 different areas--a Japanese garden, a French formal garden and an English garden. The Japanese garden my personal favorite, as it is a great place to have a picnic and enjoy the Japanese trees and landscape .  During the two short weeks of Sakura season (in March), the cherry blossoms in Shinjuku Gyoen are absolutely stunning. During this time, the park is insanely busy. My friends and I stood in line for 40 minutes just to get our admission tickets and enter the park. The lines are for a good reason: 1500 cherry trees in one park make it the perfect place for hanami, which is the traditional "flower party" picnic each family has under a cherry blossom tree during Sakura Season. I would not avoid Shinjuku during this time of year just because of the crowds-- the sheer volume of families having hanamis at the same time is part of the whole amazing sakura experience. It is such a huge part of Japanese culture, and its an image of Japan you will never forget. The canopies of cherry blossoms are absolutely breathtaking, so do not hessitate to go to Shinjuku Gyoen in March if you get the chance!!!The teahouse: My son and I went to the japanese tea house in June for some matcha. The atmosphere and overall experience was nice, but it was not a miniature tea ceremony, as I had expected. An elderly woman wearing a yukata simply escorted us into the old tea house room, sat us at our table, and brought us our matcha and sweets. No frills, no ceremonial movements, it was all very straight forward and simple, but still, it was nice to sip tea with my son in an old Japanese tea house. With all the walking you will do, it is nice to know there are vending machines and a snacks bar in the park. They even serve sakura ice cream at the snack bar in March. Knowing the hours of the park is important: We found out the hard way that the park closes its gates daily at 4:00 pm (much earlier than I expected a park to close) and it is closed all day every Monday. Also, there is an admission price of 200 yen per person.
A little serenity is a good thing in a busy city. Beautiful and serene, just what you need in a harried day of sightseeing. Take photos of the well for good luck!

Beautiful gardens, a must visit.. We really enjoyed spending a couple of hours in this beautiful garde. Cool and refreshing on a warm day. Greenhouse a must too, so well done and love the technology !

Great garden. We arrive to early to book in to our motel room and went for a walk and found the gardens just up the road. They had just opened so we spent 2 hours having a leisurely stroll around the beautiful and peaceful paths. Very relaxing and beautiful.
Beautiful, manicured garden. This is a beautiful garden and space. If you have to choose between this and Meijijingu, then I would go to Meijijingu. It is much quieter and cooler in the summer heat.

Beautiful. We walked through the garden on our first day in Shinjuku while waiting for our hotel's checkin time. It is gorgeous! I laugh at the reviews that say it’s quiet here as the sound of the cicadas is deafening at times. The only other thing that was a bit disappointing were the tea houses. I expected them to be more authentic. They had refrigerator displays selling junk food and soda. But otherwise, well worth a walk to decompress from the Shinjuku craziness.
Possibly our favorite spot in Tokyp. There is a small entrance fee but it is worth it to escape from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. We spent a very wonderful morning here walking around in the heat.

Wrong season to visit?. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is in the middle of Shinjuku. It is a large green area and a good place to relax and reflect. We went at the end of August so flowers were limited and lots of trees and green grass. The high point of my visit was the green house. It has many varieties of plants. The garden was quiet when we visited. There were not many people around. A few tourist and photographer taking advantage of the peaceful surroundings. There was one man eating his lunch in the garden. I can only compared this garden to St. James park in London. St. James park is more lively and has more birds and better for people watch. Each park has its good points but Gyoen National Garden is not for me. Gyoen national garden also charges a small entrance fee while St. James park is free. It is nice to have some green space among the congested shopping Shinjuku area. This is a gem for those who needs some peace and quiet during a busy work day.

Very beautiful gardens ! . The national gardens are well worth exploring in such a great place and great city . Feels like the Hyde Park of Tokyo. Great to experience and get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo and see what a beautiful place this is . If doesn't take a long time to walk the perimeter is the park, see the English garden landscape , the French gardens and traditional Japanese gardens.
Nice Garden. Any Garden deserve to visit in Tokyo. However this one is not in the first rank; probably 3rd. The Japanese part is better than the French and English part.
Beautiful garden in Shinjuku. Beautiful garden in Shinjuku, but you have to pay an entrance fee for 200Y. All the things were well treated.
Anniv Vacation. Great place to be for a relaxing garden view. Just be prepared to walk as the garden is big. Don't miss to see the green house garden.

Scenic quiet yet central garden. Located right smack in Tokyo nightlife central Shinjuku. It was early in the sakura season. Scores of office workers queuing up to get in for a well deserved lunch break. There is an entrance fee but well worth it. Beautiful lake in mid park. Sakura various species differing stages of bloom. Have your camera ready. Hard to believe you're in central Tokyo. I love Japan they just choose to excel in everything they do.

Great Japanese Garden. Shinjuku Gyoen" is the place you should visit if you want to enjoy Japanese garden.It's 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station.It opens from 9 AM so you can see the garden before going shopping at Shinjuku.
Delightful in Summer. Autumn and Winter are somewhat dreary so visit in spring and early summer. Spring is pleasant as the vegetation turns greener and the blossoms appear.

Perfect for the kids. Such a nice place to go with the kids. it's probably one of the best parks or gardens that they have been to. it was a bit hot, but they still enjoy the trip there so we would recommend for families with kids

Pretty garden- escape from city bustle. Nice gardens, not very ornamental or unique, but had open spaces, a tea house ($7 for tea and small sweet). Entrance fee to park was $2 an adult, worth going if you need some green space, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. Japanese gardens in US Smithsonian are much nicer than this (only reference I have).

Serenity in Tokyo. This an absolutely gorgeous garden right in the middle of Shinjuku neighborhood in Tokyo. Just outside of the garden are busy streets and roads, crowded place. And Gyoen's location is just perfect for those who want to break or escape the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. My review is a late review as we went there in the fall of last year. It was gorgeous with all the colors!!! There was a part in the garden where the trees's leaves had fallen way earlier than the other trees and looked gothic -- creepily beautiful. - perfect place for photoshoots esp prenup
Great place to escape the buildings and crowds of Shinjuku (Tokyo). This park's main draw is its size - it's huge. You can walk and walk and feel very removed from the busy streets of Tokyo.
Simply beautiful. It's amazing how they've managed to build a garden with so many different and attractive spaces that looks as it was always there and the city was built around its forest
Beautiful gardens. The gardens are big enough to escape the crowds without being too big so you get bored. The gardens are a great retreat from the busy Shinjuku shoppers.

An Oasis in busy Shinjuku. This park doesn't rate as one of the must see things in Tokyo, but for a tourist visiting the city, I highly recommend it as a quick visit on a morning before you head out to do other things in Tokyo. There is a small admission charge. But after you tour the park you will say that it was money well spent. There are basically 3 garden areas within the park. The English garden with its expansive lawns, the French garden with its beautiful symmetry and the Japanese garden with ponds and manicured trees. Spending an hour or so here will relax you before you hit the concrete sidewalks of Tokyo for the day.

Beautiful garden in the center of Tokyo. Great way to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. It was beautiful and relaxing. A great way to spend a morning. 200 yen entrance fee for adults. Restrooms, ready areas located all around. Very well kept. Loved the green house!

Well worth a look. It'll take a few hours but these gardens are well worth the time to get away from the city. This whole area of Tokyo is thriving with great eateries etc.The gardens themselves have a British landscape garden which is large and as boring as it sounds however the Japanese and French gardens are real nice. Only 100Y to get in too.
THE garden, my garden . I love this parkVery nice, very quiet We forget that we are in Tokyo, a big cityYou can go many times and it's always different I am feeling like home inside

Beautiful public garden. We found the garden worth while finding. We packed some lunch and a mat as everyone has their lunch on the main ground. It has a lovely green house which you can go in and view tropical plants and also view a traditional Japanese garden.
Beautiful and serene.. Only 200 Yen for an all day pass. Wonderful park, nice escape from the hustle of Shinjuku. Plenty of restrooms and drinks available.
Must do. Take a break from hustle and bustle. You won't regret it. Thoroughly enjoyed the tranquil gardens. There is room for picnics or just a pleasant walk.
Sakura. End of March it's sakura bloom, you can see many type of sakura color, the most beautiful, fresh air.

One of the best gardens in Japan. By featuring a mix of Japanese, French, and English gardens, Shinjuku Gyoen is more interesting than most Japanese gardens. I went around 10am on a weekday and it wasn't too crowded at all; plenty of room to walk around and take it all in.

Strongly recommend for your refreshment. My cozy park next to busy Shinjuku area. Cherry blossoms in wide variety are excellent in spring and many other flowers would relief your tired spirit any time of the year.

Lovely place to relax and wonder around. This is a good sized garden and takes a while to walk around. In the middle of summer there was not much in the way of flowers, but it was so nice to walk around the green space after the hustle of the Shinjuku district. Take time to sit and relax on one of the many benches, plenty of shade, spot the turtles and fish in the lakes. The Japanese tea house is worth a visit, tea and a sweet, in a tranquil setting.
Remarkable. Can easily spend a couple of hours in this park. Pretty amazing. We went in March, and the weather that day was nice and sunny. It cost 200¥ for adult ticket.

A calming oasis. We visited the garden as part of a tour we arranged with a wonderful member of the local "Goodwill Guides" (retirees with civic pride who do tours for foreigners for no charge, except their travel costs, their admission prices and any meals). We spent about 90 minutes in the Gardens - after our Guide picked us up at our Shinjuku hotel, we walked there. He gave us a great real-time lesson in the elements of a Japanese garden, and conjured for us how beautiful the park is in the spring, with the cherry blossoms in bloom. It was late July, so it was hot - but we found sufficient shade during our visit - and happily, it was a partly cloudy day. All in all, we found it a serene, calming, gloriously green oasis in a bustling, busy metropolis. I highly recommend visiting the gardens as part of a trip to Shinjuku.

Immense, tranquil beauty. Just a few steps away from a bustling Shinjuku station you will find an incredible peaceful respite. nestled in amung the legendary density of the urban core these gardens are amazing.We arrived promptly when they opened and essentially had the entire place to ourselves. Be sure to visit the conservatory and the various pavilions through out. Spend a day or an hour here and you will be recharged!

Not such a great place to visit . I do not think this park worth to be the first choice of things to do in Tokyo. There is not much to see apart some alleys, fields of grass, muddy lakes and a pagoda. It might be more beautiful during a different season, but in August it was quite dry and noisy due to chickadees.

Beautiful garden to relax yourself . 200¥ per entry for adult. There are three types of garden - English Landscape Garden, French Formal Garden & Japanese Traditional Garden. The ponds have lots of big fishes, begging for food. There's also a greenhouse with various tropical plants which made us feel at home. The Avenue of Sycamore Trees was great to stroll especially during hot summer day.

Don't go in august. Unless you're willing to sweat a lot and can handle it. My husband and I went to the Japanese and French garden. Unfortunately we weren't blown away. I'm so sure that this place is gorgeous in the spring and fall... Just not in the dead heat of summer.

nice place amidst d hustle & bustle of the city. nice place in tokyo, was about 15 min walk from our hotel in shinjuku
nice walk in d garden
nice japanese garden and french garden
all in all nice must visit place inn tokyo
amazing gardens. picturesque park, serene escape in the middle of the City. great flower hot houses. amazing icibana. we went in the rain with children (8,5) and they still had a great time
Typical Japanese garden. Vast garden with various flower theme. Not many flowers during the summer season except the rose garden.
Beautiful Respite in the middle os a bustling city.. Beautiful Respite in the middle os a bustling city. Classical Japanese style. Not far from Shinjuku station.

Mid-August probably not the ideal time to visit. While there is a lot of shade, and no expansive paved areas to radiate heat, if it's hot in the city it's going to be hot in the gardens even with a breeze. The park is very walkable, well-maintained and probably has more public restrooms than in all of Iceland. The roses in the French Garden were about the only thing in bloom and one cannot smell them because they are fenced off with a hedge around the entire perimeter. They were labeled with their names in English and Japanese. The trees that were labeled had their names in Japanese and Latin. There was also what appeared to be their Japanese name in English characters. I got to the greenhouse about 3:32 and learned that it closed at 3:30. It looks great from the outside and I was disappointed that I didn't know of its hours in advance. In my opinion you can spend as little as an hour in the garden or all day.Thanks for reading.If you found this useful I'll appreciate a helpful vote below.
Beautiful. Reflective garden with all the classical features. Various vistas give a different feel. The garden does not feel large like English gardens Do not expect to see many flowers.

Close to shopping district !. Entrance Fee is ¥200. Really good location to have a picnic or some shade away from the sun. It is so close to all of the major department stories and shops so a nice haven from all of the noise.

Without a single doubt the best garden / park I visited in my life. There is no way to review Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. You have to experience it yourself to understand the quiet, the beauty and the peace of this place. It's not the biggest nor the more spiritual park in Tokyo, but it's without a doubt my favorite.

Well worth the Y200 fee!. This is an extensive park with a traditional Japanese, a French, and an English section (the last of these seems to be mostly just lawns). The French section has a large variety of roses, which were still hanging in there when I visited, but this garden is probably best-known for its late-flowering (non-Japanese) cherries, which are at their best in April. A great place to laze away an afternoon while your other half is shopping. It is, of course, full of people playing Pokemon Go - including my daughter!
Beautiful and serene. . A beautiful garden to visit. Well worth the 2km walk from our hotel (even in humid 31C heat!). There is a small charge on entering (¥200).
Beautiful and peaceful garden. Feel very peaceful strollingl in the park and enjoying the fresh air. The scenery is stunningly beautiful with the lush green trees and enchanting pond.

Nice garden for relaxing walk in the busy city!. Have a pleasant time walking in this huge garden. There were people drawing the skyscraper from the garden, enjoying sitting in this beautiful place for a short while watching them and relax at the same time in this busy city. Great place for picnic also. Worth a visit if you like walking in garden.

Nice park. Pretty Japanese park / gardens conveniently located in Shinjuku. Very pleasant for a relaxing walk and lots of nice photo ops. We got bitten by midges here so might be worth preparing with bug spray before visiting.
Amazing! . If you are looking to escape the madness of Tokyo for a few hours, look no further. The gardens are beautiful, with an array of wildlife.
What a relaxing visit. Great big park with cool gardens. Small entry fee, great walk, nice plants and flowers and trees and fish. Possibility to have lunch or picnic.

Beautiful garden in the rain!. Lovely oasis in the busy city even in the rain! Worth the entry fee and just a great place to relax and walk around. The skyscrapers are visible but you could be a million miles away!
Pokemon-Go. The Park was full of people playing Pokemon-Go! Is was very special. If you leave the places where there play you can have a nice walk alone. Opening hours differ from season to season

Wonderful place to relax and enjoy Japanese park near Shinjuku. Whether you picnic on the small patch of grass before the entry gate or venture in for JPY 300 and explore the butterly house and enjoy the blossoms in March/April it is a wonderful place to just rest and recharge your batteries - 5-10 min walk from Shinjuku station.

Huge spacious garden. Unfortunately, we attended in March when the grass was brown but three of the sakura trees were in bloom, which was amazing to see. I couldn't image how beautiful it would be with all of them in the spring. Gardens are absolutely huge and very well thought out - many places to bring a picnic and sit in the sun. I would recommend bringing a small lunch or snacks and something to drink - LOTS of walking!

Beautiful trees and funny Pokémon crowd. This park is wonderful. As i first walked in i was in awe at all the diversity inside and was pretty sure everyone else around me was too because they were taking lots of pics on their phones.. oh no..they were catching pokemon! It must be an amazing place for it because people were barely looking up to enjoy the beauty of the ature around then to catch imaginary monster. All in all, a very interesting experience! Totally recommend it.

Lucky to be here at the best time. Romantic Sakura Sakura Sakura
People said Apr-May are the best months to visit Japan, and that's very true
The weather and the scenery are perfect, just exactly like what u see on the movies
Wish I wouldn't have had to leave :(

Pokemon hunting. Yes this is where you find Pikachu in Tokyo. So there is this, also though it is an extremely beautiful and tranquil park smack in the middle of Shinjuku. There are quieter and more exclusive parks such as the one in the museum in Omotesando but for 200 yen this parks entry fee is very reasonable for a lovely walk with well kept trees, grass, rest areas and lakes. If you're sick of shopping walk 5 minutes here and chill for a while. Only downside is that it closes very early.

Large and varied park. Small fee to enter this large and varied park which has French, English and Asian style gardens. Parts of it make you feel as though you aren't even in the city. Great way to escape and full of Pokemon Go players and stops!

A viewing and relaxing park - not for play. Shinjuku Gyoen is nice big park to stroll through at any time of the year. You can take a picnic blanket and relax, even have a nap. It's a great place for toddlers to toddle about in the grass. Do not however pull out a frisbee or a ball. Games are not allowed. Alcohol is not allowed. The gates are locked at 17:00 so the announcements to leave start playing over loud speakers at 16:30. It also costs a small fee to enter. All of this keeps out the riffraff, which makes the park popular with families with small children, groups of old ladies, photographers catching that perfect blossom, and people painting or sketching scenery.

Gorgeous retreat nestled within Tokyo's bustling 'hoods.... Arguably the best ancient gardens tucked away amongst Tokyo's numerous historic shrines, Gyoen doesn't disappoint while delivering timeless 'Kodak moments' sprinkled throughout its awe-inspiring grounds. I recommend taking a moment to absorb the culture and spirituality resonating within this area, and vow to never forget it...
An escape from the hustle and bustle. Good day escape if weather permits and you want to do something a lil more relaxing. There's plenty of toilets, and icecream/drink stations.

A gorgeous park. Very clean, serene and beautiful. It can be romAntic as you can go for a nice walk away from the crowds towards the rise gardens. Or you can watch people playing and sunbathing or having a picnic. It is worth going here to get a bit of respite from Tokyo's concrete and crowds.
Mr. great nice day fos walking and relaxing , having obento and beer in the park and enjoying the Japanese culture

Oasis in the City. The Garden is very accessible. Walking distance from the Sinjuku station. They have flowers for all the season of the year. Big selections of flowers. Very Nice rose garden. The cherry blossom is good. Clean rest rooms. Lots of benches to rest. Entrance fee is very affordable.

Beautiful Gardens!. We were in Tokyo for the Cherry Blossom season. This park is an absolute must during blossom season! It was my wife's favourite thing to do in Tokyo! The gardens are immaculate and the attention to detail is fantastic. The cherry blossoms made the park all that more spectacular! I would highly recommend a tour of the park. You can tour it in less than an hour but might find you spend a little more time there!

Beautiful and relaxing. After a week of site seeing and so many train stops, overwhelming flights of stairs and so much people, it is very nice to go for a walk at Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. It was very relaxing and beautiful. entrance is only 200 yen . You can spend the whole day here if you want there lots to see or you can just lay on the grass and realax.

Vast beautiful garden with so much greenery in the middle of the city. Located next to Shinjuku-Gyommae station which lies beside the Shinjuku Gyoen (garden). The entrance tickets to the garden were only 200JPY per person and we ended up exploring the garden for next 2 hours. Take a slow stroll all around the park to explore different areas. Dont miss the area by the Tea House as well as different lakes on this vast garden.-Milespointstravel.com

Beautiful. Shinjuku goyen is the place I recommend first when a friend is going to japan. Its not the most well known place nor does it attract the most tourists, but its the most peaceful and calm place I have ever been to in my life and I don't think there is a place like it in the world. The park itself is beautiful it is like a completely natural environment, everything is seamless and every trail and plant seems perfectly placed. Highly recommend, don't miss out on this gem in the city.
Garden area. Nice activity for the family . Small entrance fee. Variety of different gardens . Restrooms and eating areas available .

Beautifully kept & nice break from busy streets. If you like nature, beautiful trees, ponds, green house & flowers AND oh yea, looking for a break from the busy streets of Tokyo, then you should definitely put this on your list of places to visit.It was definitely needed after being in Japan for 2 weeks and being on the go! I sat on a bench for an hour doing nothing and it was very peaceful. You can pack a picnic lunch, take a book, stroll...etc.Price is 200YYou can get an English map from the Visitor's Centre.There is a restaurant in the park as well as a tea house (two I believe).Oh yea, and apparently there's a Pokemon Stop in the park (hilarious!)Have a great time!

Neat and Lovely Place. If you want to see Japanese Zen-style park, this is the perfect place for you especially when it's spring because you can see the beautiful cherry blossom tunnel and feels like in a J-Dorama or romantic Anime. Definitely a must if you're in Japan.

Early morning walk is so wonderful. I stayed in a hotel near this place and I go there every morning for 4 days. The surrounding creates a positive vibe on me throughout the day. The air is clean and fresh. How I wish I have even a small garden like this at home.

You Forget You are in the big city. It is the center of the city, and You just remember that because you can see some of the skyscrapers of Shinjuku. It is a very pleasant and relaxing garden, with tranquil sceneries. You have different kind of gardens, the main gardens are the english, the french and the japonese. A house tea and a bridge makes you feel a true japonese. Make sure you take comfortable shoes and mosquito repellent. Near the lake you’ll have some mosquitos. It is a terrific spot for a fantastic picnic, so you should bring some snacks. Don’t forget your camera! Beautiful scenery not to miss! It worths the symbolic entrance fee.

Getaway in town. It's an impressive 'garden' experience in the middle of a metropolitan. You can surely relax and have a calm walk in the greenery. It's a good chance that you 'clean' your lung after exposing in the city for some time. The walk even from Shinjuku isn't too long.

Beautiful park. This park is beautiful, even in the rain. I visited in July and the park was lovely and green, a great antidote to the hustle and bustle of the city. It must be wonderful when the cherry blossoms are out or in Autumn when the leaves are turning. Allow yourself a couple of hours here at least as there are plenty of places to sit. There are two teahouses, you can get tea and a sweet for 700, which is not really worth it. Plenty of toilets too!

Beautiful relaxing walk around garden but make sure you have mosquito repellant!. We visited on a beautiful hot day and enjoyed wandering around the greenhouse and gardens. For 200 yen entrance fee there was a lot to see. Do ensure you listen to the advice given and either cover up or wear insect repellent as I got several nasty bites that have swollen , but that will certainly not put me off returning!
beautiful walk. A beautiful walk in the cultured wilds in the center of Tokyo. Extremely serene and relaxing experience. If you enjoy this you should really try to get to Nara

beautiful park. This is one of the park in Tokyo where you need to pay for entrance, but with such small fee $3 you won't regret. It is right in center of Tokyo close to Shinjuku station. There are quite few restaurant just outside park along street serving some yummy foods as well. Park is not crowded and very well kept, one of my favor in Tokyo.

Pretty to look at and fun to walk around. Imagine all those nice pictures of Japanese gardens; this is a perfect example of one. Charming ponds with little bridges, lines of trees, a huge variety of plants..... even in winter, it was nice to walk around, though I imagine it would have been far nicer in the warmer months.
Great Place to visit... Lovely place to visit.. There are few day tours available to see some of these interesting places..Very replacing and peaceful place..

peace within the hustle & bustle.... A beautiful & serene park in the middle of the chaos that is Tokyo. It is huge & comprises of 3 different gardens, forested areas & lawns. There is also a greenhouse with beautiful flowers. One can spend half a day here exploring or enjoying a picnic. Would be great to come during the Sakura festival or in autumn when the leaves change color. A must do in your list.
Beautiful place for a stroll. A quiet refuge in the middle of Tokyo. Lovely gardens and trees. Nice place to let the kids run around.
Nice park. Really nice park to visit, especially around the cherry blossom. Great views, nice to walk around, have a picnic.

A world away. The gardens are a world away from the bustling metropolis of Tokyo; it is an oasis in the city. The gardens have well marked paths that will take you through a number of differently themed gardens and past wide expanses of lawns. Some of the trees tower over the grounds, whilst other plants are small and well manicured. There are bursts of colour as well, and an interesting greenhouse. The onsite restaurant is nothing flash, but has basic and edible food, very friendly and attentive staff, scrupulously clean toilets, and welcomed air conditioning. There are some very lovely views in the park (including great contrasts between adjacent skyscrapers and the greener) and the atmosphere is relaxing. There are better gardens to visit in Japan - but I would highly recommend spending at least a couple of hours here. It is a large and expansive space, and it has a completely different feel because of its unique location. It is easily accessible by the rail system and then you can continue on foot from the park to some of the high class shops in the area (and spend a small fortune or just look). There is an entry fee but it is very reasonable and good value for money.

Fantastic View: Sakura watching, Sunbathing, Walking Around, Picnicking. I came here everyday during my stay in Shinjuku. The view is of course absolutely amazing. The ticket prize of 200 yen is worth it. At 2 - 4 PM, it is ideal to go for a picnic and enjoy the sun (during fall - winter).
Beautiful gardens. I'm sure it's much prettier in the spring with all the cherry blossoms. But we did enjoy the beauty of the trees and greenery. The greenhouse was gorgeous. A must see.
Break from the city. Beautiful and serene even on a rainy day! I know a lot of the gardens are free, but I thought the 200 yen admission fee was worth it.

Great gardens. You do have to pay to go inside this park, but when you see the gardens I think you will understand why. This was my favorite green space in Tokyo that I visited, and it was a pleasant walk even in the rain.Useful info: The greenhouse is included with the admission. The Taiwanese pavilion (I don't remember it's exact name) is a great place for nice views of the Japanese garden area. The tea house I visited did NOT have any view of the park or gardens.
a peaceful garden in the city. an ancient, beautiful place nearby shinjuku. you can see beautiful green trees, old temples out there. a good place to rest after walking at shinjuku

Really beautiful garden . Really beautiful and diverse garden to visit. There were plenty of shady spots to rest from the heat. Lots of lovely lakes to spot turtles. Really relaxing to walk around and enjoy the nature after all the tall buildings and traffic of Tokyo. Wear mosquito repellent and sunscreen! I got bitten all over. But it was a small price to pay for all the beauty.

Must be really amazing during spring. Just after a short 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku station you will find this great park. The entry is not free, it's cheap however, just 200 yen. The park during summer, provides a peaceful oasis from the Tokyo "madness". The park is not comparable to other parks I've visited (the Retiro park for example in Madrid), however it's really well mainteined and we really enjoyed walking over the bridges, with the small lakes and the amazing trees. The French garden and the British one are great as well. If you have some free time, I would recommend going here, you won't regret it!

Spacious and tranquil. We arrived at our Shinjuku hotel late in the afternoon anticipating an evening stroll in Shinjuku Gardens, but were disappointed to discover that it is only open from 9am until 4pm. As our next morning was limited, we made sure to be at the gate at opening time and we were well rewarded for our effort. This is the most spacious and peaceful of all the gardens we visited in Japan.

Serene oasis. Its a few minutes and a world away from Shinjuku station.The thing to do - grab an ekiben (bento box) from the station, wander over to the garden, and hang out for as little or as long as you want. Its quiet, peaceful, and awesome, all at the same time!You'll also find random things going on - e.g. Yoga, badminton, J-pop practice, whatever...

Magical on a rainy day!. It was wet and cloudy when we visited, but it added to the magic of the place. Free people, lots of bird life including crows, doves, swallows and sparrows. The green house was beautifully maintained. The Rose garden was enthralling! Great to visit on a rainy day in the summer - no mosquitoes!

Not much seatings. It is very well maintained and a huge park to spend a day stroll around but definitely not on a hot day. However, I would suggest to increase more seatings in the park, considering for the elderly folks.

Just relaxing. On our first day in Tokyo, we decided to visit the Shinjuku Gyoen Garden. It was just so relaxing and beautiful. You just cannot go wrong visit the Garden. It is well maintained and give you a sense of the Japan culture.

Nice escape from the city. Beautiful park with walking distance of Shinjuku Station. Great place to have your lunch break or a picnic. Huge lawn area to sit down and eat or take a nap. This park is really popular during Cherry Blossom season. Japanese gardens, exotic plants, green house, inexpensive food options. I stop at least once a month to enjoy the beauty and get some exercise. If you're a frequent visitor I'd recommend getting the season pass. Inexpensive 2,000 yen. Side note: no alcohol allowed at this park.
Very peaceful and beautiful park . Spent three hours just walking around the park and enjoying the scenery. Don't miss out on this one!! Best park in Tokyo!

Visita occasionale in estate. I had been in this park during the sakura (1st week of April) and the experience had been unique. So I wanted to visit it again, this time in July: Not even comparable.The park is a nice green park, with nice pagodas and lakes but nothing exceptional, there were just few flowers and not so many kinds.Just a nice park, my advise is to spend time here only if you have some, unless is Sakura period

End of March is the perfect time for the Cherry Blossoms. We visited the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden at the suggestion of a fellow traveler and loved it. There is a small fee to enter the park (around $10 USD) but it is worth it. Indigo Falls: 392 Red Mountain Rd, Dallas, GA 30157There are several gardens in the park including the English Landscape, French Formal and a Japanese Traditional (with teahouse). In late March cherry blossoms are stunning! Outside food is allowed, but alcoholic beverages are not. Food is also available for purchase in the park.
A grand garden of seasonal variety. A must visit place during sakura season. It also offers grandeur in a pleasant setting. The green house is a must see thing.

Lovely park with great walks. The park is located right near the hustle and bustle of the city, it is surprising that as soon as you are in there it is so peaceful and quiet. I was surprised you had to pay to get in, but soon learnt that this isn't unusual for Japan. It wasn't my favourite park in Tokyo, but it certainly had it's own charm and is certainly worth a walk around.

A must-visit and breathtaking garden . Oh my word. What a lovely National Garden! As a floral enthusiast, it is needless to see I have been dying to go to the garden and wow, it did not disappoint. The national garden is so spacious and huge that it will take a day to walk every corner! There is a really cool greenhouse you can first visit at the entrance of the national garden. There are also different areas of the park you can visit. Like a French style inspired garden or other styles parks. We spent around 3 hours at the park and my sister and I did yoga poses and took loads of pictures. If you like, you can have a picnic at one of the spacious grass areas and there are also cafes! The area I love the most is where it reminds me of forests and have lots of tall trees. It's just breathtaking and if you are lucky, you get to see some cute animals! Overall, a must visit destination.

Beautiful anytime of the year. It always surprises me how many locals and visitors neglect visiting this beautiful oasis in the city. Absolutely breathtaking in the spring when all is blooming especially the cherry blossoms. Take your time and explore this expansive park and there is not charge. Bring a picnic.
Simply stunning. We've visited these gardens at various times of year and there is always something beautiful to see and be delighted by. An oasis of calm and serenity in a fast moving, full on city.

Very beautiful park. Well worth the cost of admission. Go early to avoid the crowds. We really enjoyed all the gardens and the rest area to have a cool drink before we moved onward to check out other areas.

So Serene and Peaceful. We were in Shinjuku and decided to explore the park. There is a minimal fee for it but the park is vast and beautiful. Mosquitos are everywhere though so use repellent! When we were there the garden just opened for the day and most of the shops and places were still closed. Still, we enjoyed the nature and slow stroll.

Beautiful, even in late winter. Beautiful grounds. Well maintained and clean. Well worth the nominal fee to enter. Visited during late spring/early spring. Would love to return when the flowers were in full bloom.

One of the largest gardens in Tokyo. The garden is extremely large and has so many themes, scenes and venues. Hours might pass without even notice. I would recommend families and couples to give it a visit and have a snack out there

Beautiful park. It's amazing that there is a big and beautiful part in the middle of city
walking distance from Shinjuku station, takes 10 mins
full of trees, grass and garden
When I visited the park, there aren't not many flowers
It was good enough, but it would be better in sakura season

Huge garden. It is surprising that such a huge green is found in the middle of Tokyo. Shinjyuku Gyoen is maybe comparable to Central Park in New York, but the former is better maintained. If the weather is nice, it is very pleasant to take a walk inside. It is not free, but the entrance is just about $2. Inside the garden, you should not miss the greenhouse for tropical plants. It is really beautiful.

Beautiful Park and so nice to walk around. Well even the with the of 90 fahrenheit/33degrees celsius this is a great Park to visit.All kind of different of gardens, japanese, french, others but if you want to relax or kids want to play go for it and you will have a great time!
Best during the Sakura season. When it is already lined with the pink trees in full bloom, and every gentle breeze sends a shower of cherry blossoms.

I give this score for summer in the heat. This would be a heap nicer during the autumn season and surely a 4 then. It has a great set out for that season and a vast expanse to walk around- exactly why it isn't great in summer but I can still see people enjoying it if you have plenty of miles left in your boots free for the day
Scenic. We made a quick visit. It is beautiful and tranquil, but probably avoidable if your not into the scenery.

A beautiful park and a nice walk!. The garden has a very low entry price, which is really good, and is really beautiful and well-kept! It was a very good start to our day taking a leisurely stroll through the garden!
Beautiful garden. Well maintained. Japanese, English and French garden areas. The Japanese area full of bonsai, ponds and pagodas. Plan to spend an hour minimum to walk the whole garden.

A relaxing atmosphere walking distance from the Shinjuku Train Station. The Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is a comfortable, and not overly strenuous, walking distance from the Shinjuku train station. The garden is not - entirely - what one would call a Japanese Garden. It does not - predominantly - feature miniature trees, or the eloquent detail one would expect to find in what is usually referred to as a Japanese Garden. However, it is a beautiful, and relaxing garden, suitable for a stroll along the various paths, walk on the bridge that takes you over a nice lake, or just take the opportunity to have a picnic in one of the many shady spots. The greenery, to all directions, is stunning and if you have children that enjoy playing with a ball, plenty of space to enjoy a kick of a ball in small or larger groups.

Beautiful Park. We walked around this lovely park our first day in Tokyo. We were lucky to be able to enjoy the beautiful cherry blossom trees here and we enjoyed our stroll through the park. It was a lot less crowded compared to some of the other parks in Tokyo which was good as we didn't have to fight with the crowds. It's also close to Shinjuku which is another plus.
Stunning. Very peaceful , large park with lovely Japanese garden , very pretty and peaceful. Take time to walk the whole grounds and take some time out from the busy streets. I highly recommend it.

Respite among the city!. A beautiful garden in the center of city. The grounds are well cared for and lends itself to taking your time....relax and stroll. The Sendagaya Gate allows you to connect to the Harajuku area to pick up the pace and do some shopping!

Calmness within a storm. We stopped off in the park on our first day in Tokyo. We weren't sure what to expect but we found people enjoying their lunch and having picnics with friends and family on the grass. It was lovely to get away from the hustle and bustle of downtown Shinjuku and relax for a couple of hours. Ideal for a romantic stroll. Entry was 200 yen.We found their take on a English garden amusing!

A relaxing day at the park. It's ¥200 to enter and worth every yen. There's a greenhouse, a traditional tea house, and different gardens to explore. A great place for a picnic anytime and a fantastic spot for cherry blossom viewing if you go early enough to avoid the crowds.
Yuiijrw. There are great park. I'm feel good when i went there for relax. It convenient to go because located near Shinjuku station.

A japanese garden walked from shinjuku downtown. It takes only 10 min walking from the shinjuku station. The garden is quite big with english, french, japanese types of gardens, some woods, as well as a tea house, glass house, and other things to see. They also plant the trees and flowers so that there always blooming flowers to see, except in winter. It is a favourite ohanami location in spring though, no alcoholic drinks are allowed in the garden. There is also a small restaurant as well as kiosk selling food and drink. It is a pleasant place to spend few hours in tokyo.

Shinjuku Gyoen. Of all the parks and gardens in Tokyo, Shinjuku Gyoen evokes to me the most Central Park in Manhattan. It's not the size (it is less than one fifth of Central Park) but rather how the park is completely encased by the maddest section of the city yet feels peacefully detached from it. Minutes after you enter either through the Shinjuku or Okido gate, the wide and flat plane is laid out and you are instantly in a different world. Yet the juxtaposition of skyscrapers in the background, particularly that monstrosity NTT Docomo Yoyogi Building, is a reminder that the hustle and bustle is never too far away.As you pass through the vast French Formal Garden and English Landscape Garden, meander cross the duck ponds and delve deeper into the smaller and denser sections the park, the city starts to fade away. Looking out to the Japanese Garden from Taiwan Pavilion and sitting lazily watching the warm afternoon sun idle by, now I own this park all to myself. I visited in mid-Jan, three days after a rare snowstorm in Tokyo, and it looked and and felt like early fall when the pines are blue enough and the grass softly tanned.Shinjuku Gyoen was constructed on the site of a private mansion belonging to an Edo era feudal lord. It was first completed as an imperial garden in 1906 and then was opened to the public as a national garden after the Second World War.Y200 entrance fee (this less than $2 fee is in fact what keeps this park rather sparse, so please oblige), open everyday except Monday, best to enter and exit through either Okido or Shinjuku gates and walk the entire park. Shinjuku gate is 5min walk from Shinjuku Sanchome station, Okido gate is 10min walk from Shinjuku Gyoenmae Station.

Beautiful, peaceful garden in the heart of Shinjuku. Come to see the Garden after i watched the anime drama film “”The Garden of Words“言の葉の庭. It is peaceful, beautiful and nice Garden in the heart of Shinjuku. Very good place to have a 1 hour walk. After that you can walk to Meiji Jingu.

Excellent garden to enjoy nature in the middle of the city. We went to the garden to try and see if we could catch any early Cherry Blossoms. This garden is an easy walk from the Shinjuku station and takes you through several shopping areas and bustling areas in the city. The garden is a nice refuge away from the city. There were only a few trees that had some opened cherry blossoms but we did manage to see some other beautiful trees and plants. The weather was overcast so it was nice to walk around and not get too warm. This is a large garden so you could easily spend a day wandering around and enjoying the greenery.

Beautiful when the leaves are changing. My partner and I went here at the end of October-- just as the autumn colors had started to appear. It was a lovely walk, I wish we had more time to spend there but it was just the perfect juxtaposition next to the sky scrapers of Shinjuku.

One of the best parks in Tokyo. Definitely have to spend an afternoon at the this beautiful park with rose garden. The rose garden has names after celebrities. Peaceful and many many acres of walking space and a well deserved break from getting squished in the subway. We went once but could have gone several times just to bring things down a notch. Great relaxation!
Relaxing . A little corner of paradise. After a long day in Metro and crowd, it is so good to decompress in this park for a long walk. Very nice and quiet. 200yens only the entrance.

Loved it!. Exceptionally well maintained! There are three gardens at this location; traditional Japanese garden, English landscape garden, formal French garden. The traditional Japanese garden is well manicured and has a few ponds stocked with large fish. They poke there heads out of the water as you walk by in anticipation of being fed. The English garden is a large open space of really nice grass, but not much else to it. The French garden was my favorite. It has beautiful roses in many, many colors. The rose bushes are quite hardy and mature.

My favorite park. Shinjuku Gyoen is truly a great Park. It is totally worth the 200 yen for the entrance. There are so many different areas and it actually takes at least 1h30 to see everything (longer if you truly enjoy, stop sometimes and go slowly). I love the "natural" part as well as the elegant Japanese gardens. The greenhouse is worth it too. It is also perfect for picnics. I usually stop, and spend a day reading near the Japanese trees. Beware of the crows. They won't attack you, but do not play with them or let your kids chase them etc. They can defensively attack humans when they are nervous about nurturing.

beautiful well maintained park. Beautiful well maintained garden, where you can easily spend half a day there enjoying the greenery and have a picnic under the cherry blossom trees. A must go if you are in Tokyo!

Beautiful park, liked the variety of areas. Much as I love Japanese gardens, I also liked the different sections of this park. I'm not a big fan of roses but the rose garden was spectacular with lots of varieties. The pavilion was serene and I liked the avenues of plane trees with their lovely bark. As usual in Japan, there were lots of toilets and it was beautifully looked after with not a speck of litter. Well worth a visit.

Lovely. We had an extra few hours in Tokyo and came across this beautiful garden while wandering the city. There is heaps to look at, with a few little temples around, lots of gardens and bridges, lots of wild life, and heaps of people just hanging out and enjoying the sunshine.We quite enjoyed some people watching for the afternoon after grabbing a bite to eat at one of the nice restaurants that are throughout the park.There is a number of clean bathrooms available, lots of vending machines for food and drinks plus the restaurants. Great chillaxing spot.
Green & peaceful. A real bonus to find this place in the middle of hectic Shinjuku. Just a great place to chill and relax.

Quiet and beautiful. We visited the Gyoen National Garden on our last morning in Tokyo before flying home in the afternoon. What a beautiful way to relax and reflect on all the sights we had seen throughout Japan. The gardens, like everywhere else in Japan, were spotless - no trash or graffiti anywhere! The landscape and flowers are lovely and you just take your own time walking through as many different gardens as you have time for. Lots of benches under the trees to stop and reflect. I would recommend going in the mornings, because as the day went on it became more crowded. It was also cooler in the morning. Enjoy!

Very Nice. IT was very interesting.The parks were all very nice but i went there in the summer so it was quite hot .The air was very clean and there are free tours from volunteer guides.THese voulenteer guides will end at one of the best place to get a vew. walk across the bridge and go to the other side.when i went there and there was the amazing view and the constant water fkiw was amazing must try it . :) cheers

Especially good for Sakura shooting. I spent two days photographing cherry blossom here. I heard a lot of Cantonese being spoken here, mostly by large tour groups from Hong Kong. One group from Hong Kong, however, was a professional wedding dress shoot group, bride and groom, two lady photographers with a Nikon D4 each and a couple of dressers carrying outfits and shoes. I wonder what the fee for that operation is.

The Enchanted Garden. Experience :-I marked this place as one of my must-visit during my trip in Tokyo for the Sakura Season and was not disappointed.I sat on one of these bench, watching the Sun slowly rise; people start coming. Most laid a mat on the grass and sat while chatting about their lives and sipping their tea , admiring the Cherry Blossoms. There were others doing Yoga.The scene with the Garden as a backdrop was very serene and relaxed.The Garden has a lot to offer in term of the varieties and very well maintained indeed.Advice :-1) Admission Fee (200 yen) is chargeable to enter but definitely worth it.
