Camera is fine but tripods should be avoided if possible (it is actually one of the prohibited item listed.2) There is no particular steep climb of any sort in the walk-through, so this attraction is definitely recommended for all3) Preferable time to visit? Personally, I was among the first to enter when it was less crowded. As the crowds start gathering steam when I left 2 hours later, the Garden (huge) was still plenty spacious for a good time. You can probably do this after some vigorous sight-seeing and just needed somewhere to get away from the buzz. Wayne’s ratings (as ticked):-1) Must-GO!2) Recommended ✔3) Nay.. or best go as a fillerIn general, I would not put this as a deliberate must-go destination but more of somewhere that should be weaved in after a vigorous itinerary. It is recommended for all who are into greenery/flowers/nature or for people who are seeking a breather from the buzz.

Perfect sunny day exploration. We found the garden on the was to the Samurai Museum and decided it would be a great place to kill a couple of hours before it opened. The park charges a small entrance fee but boy was it worth it, could have spent the entire day here and still not seen everything.In typical Japanese style the garden was meticulously laid out and maintained.Well worth your time to visit
Beautiful peaceful park.. If in Shinjuku, a visit to the gardens should be on your list. Very peaceful and relaxing. I would imagine that in Spring the flowers are spectacular.

A Beautiful Park in the Center of Tokyo. Only 10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station, this was a very nice place to spend about an hour walking through the gardens. There is a place where a woman made us Matcha tea and wagashi (small sweets). This is worth a visit.
Huge garden. Really nice garden, busy but still enough space for you to just relax nice japanese garden at the back end of the garden

Definitely Worth A Trip. This is a beautiful park. It's not far from the Shinjuku station, so it's worth doing if you need to go through Shinjuku anyway. It's very peaceful with a beautiful Japanese garden. There are also English and French gardens on the premises. It's a stark contrast from the bustling city which surrounds it!

Beautiful..but don't go on Monday. One our first day in Tokyo, we took three metro trains and navigated, with the help of friendly locals to finally find the gardens, an hour after setting out from Minato. I was a little puzzled and perturbed to find the park closed. Why close a park ?! We made it back two weeks later on our penultimate day in Japan. It was well worth the visit. We were pushed for time so just walked through the Japanese Traditional garden. The areas around the Kamino-ike (Upper pond) and Kyo-Goryo-Tei (Taiwan Pavilion) are spectacular. The park must be amazing in cherry blossom season

Memorable day. My fiancé proposed to me at the rose garden in front of the peacekeeper Roses. It was a lovely day and the view was just amazing. We went in June and it was a perfect weather for picnics and tanning. We also checked out the green house and saw plants from different climates.
Beautiful serene park . Would highly recommend a leisure afternoon here enjoy the gardens, greenhouse and overall park setting. Only 200 yen entrance fee is super doable.

Breathtaking. This is a location that must be visited during the fall and cherry blossom season. Its very organised, not crowded, vast and honestly a very nice place to spend some romantic time with the wife / gf etc... I'm adding a photo that I took earlier in 2015 when I visited the location during Cherry Blossom season
beatiful. really lovely park, i like it thể i spent many hours just walking around the park. very very big and cool

Beautiful garden . I was one week late for the sakura bloom! However it's still a beautiful garden. It's also really massive. A stroll from end to end can easily take an hour or more. During sunny days, remember to apply sun block, other than that enjoy the wonderful view. Lay on the grass and just relax!
Sgng. Cost 200 yen to get in its quite large, numerouse ponds a break from the busy shinjuku, theres a little refreshent shop to cool off after the long walk
Beautiful. Loved this! The gardens were gorgeous and it was such a nice place to take a break in the bustle of the city. Well worth the few dollar fee

A little Japanese Tea!. Wonderful park! Rose gardens, lakes, ponds, bridges, and more! Lovely way to spend a Sunday afternoon with friends! The tea room was delightful! The garden is a national treasure for sure!
very nice. very nice green lung in the heart of a busy area, its 200 yen to get in, and I think worth it. Beautiful plants and flowers, and nice water areas. worth a visit
beautiful serene place. strolling through the garden, watching birds, smelling flowers, taking it all in. I felt like Central Park, a mini version of it.
Just a strawl. Worth seeing, nothing exciting, tea houses have awfull sweets with the tea they serve @ 700yen. Great example of how japanese people care about their gardens.

Beautiful garden. Be sure to visit this amazing garden! Lovely lakes, trees, hydrangea's, rose garden, tea house, bridges, koi, and perfect place for a relaxing picnic with loved ones! Beautiful place and setting for gorgeous pictures!!

Great park. Want to enjoy a little Peace and quiet?
This is the place. Good people-watching. The dog park is some of the best entertainment EVER! Pure fun!

Peaceful park away from the crowds. We came here on our first day in Tokyo, slightly jet lagged after a 13hr flight and needed somewhere to just adjust and unwind. We bought along our food purchases from Isetan's food hall and sat in the park. It's quite a big park and lovely to roam around and admire the neatness of a typical Japanese garden. You do have to pay to get in but it's not much (I think it was a few pounds). They have a mini glasshouse hosting exotic plants/flowers. It's just a lovely park in a middle of a hectic city.
Garden lover must visit. Traditional garden landscape where you will find out more about Japanese culture and their creative in landscape design

Gardens. We visited the gardens on two days as we felt there was more to see than on our first visit, we loved these gardens they are beautifully kept, the rose garden was delightfull very nice to spend time strolling and enjoying the varies ares within these gardens

Wonderful relaxation place. This a great place to take a stroll and admire the beauties of the different gardens available in the park. Do be prepared to walk abit and take lots of photographs. The park is nicely maintained. For seasonal flowers, do check out the timing before you drop a visit. This is also a popular destination even for locals.

Beautiful park, nice break from it all. We stopped at Isetan's fabulous food court for our gourmet picnic provisions and made the walk over tho Gyoen National Gardens. It was Golden Week, so quite crowded but it made the experience even better as we got a real feel for what the locals do on their holidays. Beautiful meandering paths, gardens and wonderful spots to have a picnic and take a little rest. Note for ladies: the public restrooms are squat toilets and have no paper towels so bring some hand sanitizer and maybe wear a skirt this day to make things easier!

Great Place for Sakura in April, but also Great for Any Season. This traditional garden managed by the Japanese emperor's office is a very peaceful place, not only for the Sakura season in April, but any season.Even though they will charge you some fees to enter, it's worse paying for. Also, please be aware that no alcohol is sold inside the park. However, you could bring some if you like, but this is not a place to get drunk.Japanese gardens, rose gardens, and you'll enjoy the park if you want to touch the heart of Japanese culture. Enjoy!
Plants. They have a gorgeous selection of tropical plants, including various carnivorous plants, entrance is not free but it is very cheap and not too far from shinjuku

Beautiful gardens. Worth a visit if you have a free day, our trip was quick and we just saw what we really wanted to but the scenery is beautiful. Love the contrast between the traditional Japanese gardens with the city high risers in the back ground.Just a nice little park to wander and relax in.

A peaceful, picturesque respite . When you've had just about enough trains, traffic and people, head here for a wonderful wander through nature. The park is very large, and took over an hour to fully explore, with plenty of nooks and crannies. There's a small fee for entry.

holiday. we were lucky to visit these gardens on the first Sunday in June 2016 and it was free to enter. they were lovely and tranquil, it was really good to see all the different designs of the different countries gardens, and families enjoying picnics on the grass areas.
Wonderful. This was one of the most impressive gardens I have had the pleasure to visit. If you only visit one garden in Tokyo, this is the best one to see, in my opinion.

Well worth a visit. These gardens are lovely, with lots of variety on offer - from formal roses in the 'French' garden, huge trees amidst rolling fields in the 'English' garden, a fantastic array of succulents, cacti and orchids in the greenhouse, and of course a beautiful Japanese garden, complete with a picturesque Taiwanese pavilion that appears to float over the pond.

Its just a park. after visiting this park because it was listed as the number 1 thing on trip advisor, I really really couldn't figure out how it got that ranking. It's just a big park. Theres nothing wrong with that, the gardens are well maintained and theres alot of green space but why is this the top thing in tokyo when theres so much culture to see!!! We were all trying to figure out the appeal because it just seems like another standard asian style garden

Beautiful and relaxing park. The Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is a calming break from busy Tokyo life. We found the park easy to navigate with signs in English posted frequently. The park was massive, with many ponds, gardens and forests. The park was not at all crowded. There are bathrooms, waterfountains and vending machines in the park. Admission was 200 yen.
Beautiful peaceful park to take a stroll around!. Really stunning grounds here - if you have a chance take a wander some pictures and visit the tea rooms!

Beautiful Japanese Gardens. I lived in Tokyo eight years, but I had never visited Shinjuku Gyoen because I mistakenly believed the gardens were nothing special. Now I understand why the gardens are so popular among Tripadvisor users. The purpose of my visit was taking a nap on the lawn, but I also enjoyed strolling around Japanese garden areas.

Pretty even when the Cherry blossoms had not fully bloomed. It's the best park to see Cherry Blossoms in Tokyo... But man it can get crowded. It's very close to the Shinjuku station so you get a good mix of nature and urban feel at the same place. Huge array of pretty trees and scenic ponds and mini parks inside.

Great on a Nice Day. We were able to walk from our hotel in Shinjuku. The gardens were lovely and we liked the quiet in the middle of the noisy city. Also there were some nice photo opportunities contrasting gardens with city. Not the best garden in the world, but a good stop if close by and needing a break or some quiet.

Must See in Tokyo. You come to Tokyo, you see the lights, the hustle, the crowds, the noise and in between it all is this park. Why stop and see this park?For one, its very picturesque, my wife took some great pictures, you can walk around the entire park within an hour. There are many places to stop, sit and relax and enjoy the environment around you.Take a moment, stop and visit this park.

Large, peaceful garden with fewer crowds. Due to the small entrance fee (200 yen) this garden has fewer crowds than many other Tokyo tourist attractions. It is also very large, with many different themes (English Garden, Japanese Garden, French Garden, Greenhouse). You can easily spend several hours here just strolling around and taking in the beauty around you. Just make sure you get an English map when you enter to help you navigate around. This garden is definitely a recommended stop for any Tokyo trip itinerary.

Great place for some serenity after harrowing Shinjuku crowds. We didn't have to pay admission the weekend we were here. The government issued two days free for environmental day celebration. That was a welcome bonus.We did have tea and snacks at the tea house to help contribute to the economy.Lovely serene place to enjoy in the middle of busy city.We wish we had brought a blanket to sit in one of many green spaces to take it in even further.
Relaxing and beautiful . A mixture of classic Japanese garden, and Tokyo's version of Central Park or Green Park. A great place to walk or just hang about under a tree. Worth visiting.

Wonderful park in the city center!. The park was just walking to the station and we decided to visit this. It's lovely park in the city center and definitely worth a visit, a good way to escape from the very buzy city!

Spacious garden with lots of picnickers. Visited the national garden on a Sunday and was pretty awed by how spacious the national garden is. We arrived in Japan after the cherry blossom season has passed, so we only saw lush green trees around. There are a couple of restaurants scattered here and there but most of the visitors here are families/couples enjoying a quiet picnic in the field or by the pond.

Lovely walk through a beautiful park in the middle of the city. A short walk from Shinjuku Station -- we decided to go on a nice sunny day after having a particularly difficult time finding a breakfast spot recommended by one of my favourite magazines (Monocle) called Mimet. The park was definitely a nice way to destress after being lead astray by Google twice. The park was lovely and full of people out with their families, or couples strolling through the many gardens and fields. Plenty of tourists also, but lost of locals it seemed as well. Unfortunately we just missed the cherry blossoms which seemed like they would have provided a magnificent sight. As it is, they were all littering the ground beneath the trees. But this did not take away from the peaceful and lovely atmosphere. Highly recommend taking some lunch and eating it at the park, and then topping it off with an ice cream cone from one of the vendors in the park as you stroll around. Lots of opportunities for photographers, so pack your camera if you're into that. It was a nice break from the walks around the other parts of Tokyo. The price of entrance was minimal, and totally worth it.

Massive city escape . This park is a perfect way to escape the city for a bit. Leafy walk ways, beautiful gardens, nice lakes and huge open grass areas make it perfect for every activity! There is an admission fee but you won't be disappointed!

Green oasis amidst the concrete and bright lights of Shinjuku. Shinjuku Gyoen, a park on lands fomerly belonging to the feudal Naito family, is one of the few parks in Tokyo to charge an entrance fee (200 yen or a little lesss than 2USD at current rates per person) which discourages "non-serious" visitors. There are also strict about not allowing dogs (sorry, dog walkers !) and no alcohol (they have recently started checking bags and confiscating alcoholic beverages found during the peak sakura / cherry blossom season). All these rules mean that the park is great for families and kids who have not yet learned or fallen for the other brighter charms of Shinjuku. In other words, it is great for those want some "clean" and "peaceful" fun. For those who want to hold a beer while on the grass or are seekig to enjoy the company of cannine friends, Elvis Presley lookalikes and daredevil skateboarders, the bigger and more lively Yoyogi Park to the west is a better option. For nearby residents the annual pass (sold only at the park's Shinjuku gate for 2,000 yen) is a good bargain if you intend to make more than 10 trips in a year. Note that the annual pass (or "passport" as it is called in Japanese) is not sold for a month in spring (March 25 to April 24) and two weeks in autumn (November 1 to 15) possibly to discourage out of towners to "game" the system during peak times of the year in the park's calendar (more on that is below). The park is dividend into sections, including some nicely laid out French, English and Japanese gardens and also has a large park in the center with some magnificent trees at its edges, including some cherry blossoms. On summer weekends, areas of the park that gets some shade are highly sought after for picnics while winters see people finding spots on the sunnier parts. The park also has a greenhouse (recently renovated and improved) where they grow tropical plants (perhaps the only place in Tokyo to see bananas and papayas growing on trees and not on supermarket shelves) and patches of flowering plants that vary from season to season (the pamphlet at the entrance or when you buy tickets shows which flowers are in bloom during which month). The park really is at its most crowded during the spring cherry blossom viewing season but the policy of not allowing alcohol, barbecue sets, karaoke systems and not allowing prior staking of prime viewing spots means sober and less raucous crowds. Many photographers and tourists choose to come here as a result. Autumns and winters are a good time for seeing (and photographing) migratory birds (e.g. Siberian ducks, etc) who make a brief stop here to experience Tokyo city life on their way further down south. The bird numbers vary from year to year and in lean years one may have to hang around the watering areas for quite a while to spot the rarer visitors. The park has several toilets and good signage (in both English and Japanese) and also one or two places selling candy, ice creams and soft drinks. Vending machines for canned coffee, tea, etc are also situated at easy to find locations. There are designated smoking areas (close to the toilets). Since the park closes at 17 pm, the stategically placed speakers all over the park start announcing the closing time and playing BGM or Auld Lang Syne from 16:30 onwards (the greenhouse does not allow visitors to come in after 15:30) and soon after the music starts, park guards wearing green jackets come out (not sure where they hide all day) riding bicycles to start exhorting kids, lovey dovey couples and stragglers out of the park ! On summer days when the sun is still out, one wishes the guards would let people be or that the park management decided to keep it open for a bit longer... but this being Japan rules need to be followed... and as one steps back out into Shinjuku, Yotsuya or Sendagaya (depending on which gate one comes out of) one feels more thankful and amazed that this oasis has survived in the midst of all the concrete and glass that is all around.

Amazingly Beautiful!. We visited this park several times during our stay in Tokyo as it was near our hotel. We went there at the end of the cherry blossom season and it was magnificent. Highly recommend to visit this garden.

Acres of green within a metropolis. Shows the Japanese people's attention to details. So beautiful, so perfect. Every plant, including it's shape, size, color and location is perfect. You do not need to have a formal lesson in photography to get excellent pictures for every nook and corner is picture perfect!

A beautiful garden . It was quite difficult to locate but was glad that we made a trip there. Alight at the subway, shinjuku-gyoenmae. After getting out of exit 1, turn right n walk down. Walk further down n cross a small traffic light to get to Shinjuku Gyoen (garden). Do bring along an insect repellent or wear a mosquito patch. The garden was very big and there were many opportunities where you could have a great photoshoot: on the big field, on benches and even smack right in the middle of nowhere. We noticed that the crows in Japan are really quite big (and menacing). Spotted a couple of artists here and there, sketching in the garden. We spent slightly more than an hour there.
Beautiful park. Park opens at ten in the morning and has a beautiful array of things to see. Go in the spring or fall when it is not too hot to walk around.

A beautiful park. What a beautiful park! My family and I packed our lunches and spent our day picnicking and walking around this park. The park has several gardens and a greenhouse. There are a lot convenience stores scattered around the park that sell picnic mats, drinks, ice cream, and all have rest rooms.
Must see while in Tokyo. This is a good stop for real in the busy life in Tokyo. We travel in the rainy season and everything was really green and fresh

Lovely picnic. My husband and I sat in the gardens for a lovely picnic to enjoy a bit of greenery amongst the incredibly built up metropolis that is Tokyo. It was an easy approx 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station and only a few dollars for entry. Would really recommend coming for a stroll here as you don't get too many similar experiences other than at the temples in Tokyo.
Good outdoor place for children. A good place to add on to your itinerary if you are bringing children. 300 yen admission fee but it was worth it when you see the smile on your kid.

quiet and peaceful big park. huge park but very quiet and peaceful, nice atmosphere. you have to pay 200yen and you can stay as long as you like.
There are so many beautiful flowers, trees and very tidy green grass fields.
we couldn't believe that we were in Shinjuku, the middle of the big city Tokyo.

Very nice garden. This was our first activity in Tokyo. We had a great walk here, the morning after our late arrivals into Tokyo the night before. We also had breakfast at the restaurant here, which is not too bad. Standard bento box and udon fares.

FOREST IN THE CITY. Woooouw and serene. this is a MUST place for plant and nature lover. There are many tall and old trees so when i walked under it, feel like in the forest more than a gatden. I love the traditional Japanese tree with the blooming azaleas. The colourful roses in french garden is so beautiful. And don't forget to visit the Green house. There are lots of beautiful and interesting plants there. Really enjoyed my visit.

NY Central Park equivalent... Wow. You will not be dissapointed and it is definitely worth 200Y entry fee. A short walk from the Shinjuku metro station, the Gardens are spectacular. There is wide variety of vegetation inside the park. The landscaping is just brilliant. The beautiful bridges over small water bodies are oh so spectacular...Overall, a must visit place in Tokyo. It lives up to its TripAdvisor rating of being one amongst the top rated attractions of Tokyo.

Holiday with family and friends . Beautiful grounds and garden with the cherry blossom earlier than expected. We visited in February this year and yet we were able to take lots of Sakura blossoms photographs. Garden was well maintained and really scenic.
Blossom. We thought we would be a little late for the blossom, but it was great. Picnic under the sakura was wonderful.

Well worth a vist.. This is a beautiful park with a great range of gardens, including a magnificent French rose garden that was in full bloom in May this year, Naturally the Japanese garden is what we were wanting to see and were not disappointed.

Absolute visit during sakura period. We went in April 2016 and paid 200JPY/person to visit this park inspired by many cultures. I can imagine that the park may get crowded in the weekend, so please take this into consideration. The sakura is absolutely amazing in this park.

Beautiful gardens . This beautiful garden is a must see if coming to Tokyo , the mature garden has a long history with mature trees and a very well kept grounds . In sprig when all the leaves and flowers are blooming is probably the best time to visit . Just relax and walk around this wonderful quiet place ,

Beautiful garden in the midst of an exciting city. The visit to this garden will remain forever in our memory, taken many pics; at the start of the cherry blossom season. On our last day of Tokyo stay, checked out from our hotel and spend a wonderful afternoon (for an entry fee of 200 Yen). It has within its huge manicured area a Japanese garden, English garden and a French garden; a beautiful pond with fish, many rest rooms and few cafes (didn’t use any café though). But the best of all was the amazing Green house.

Good respite from concrete jungle. The park opens from 9-4. Mondays are closed days. Good to check before you go cos if Monday was a public holiday, then it would be closed on Tuesday. The park has a few main areas. If you enter from Shinjuku gate, I suggest you turn to the right, walk past the mother and child garden to the japan garden. You can bring some things to feed the koi. Follow the path to the Taiwan pavilion. Nice photo op. Follow the path and cover the park in an anti clockwise manner. The is the French styled garden with lots of roses, and english portion, a nice greenhouse with plants like papaya and banana. Make sure you at aside some time to check out one of the houses. A refreshing change from the concrete jungle all around in Tokyo. Tip: give yourself about 2 hours to stroll.
Scroll in the park . Beautiful Japanese gardens. The park is big and great for a walk on a nice day. There is a tea house in the park that we haven't tried.
really nice garden. Was a really nice garden, the only thing is that you have to pay entry fees of 1000 yen. but it was worth it.

Brilliant. Having planned my trip a bit too late in the Sakura season, I was worried I would miss out on some decent views. This was the case in all the other parks but no Gyoen. It was a beautiful park (fairly large) with plenty of nice Sakura and other flowering trees/plants. We spent a couple of hours but you could quite easily spend more time here. Easily accessible by the subway, a must visit place in Tokyo.

Peaceful. You could get lost in this expansive garden. For JPY200 it gives you access to a peaceful oasis in a bustling city. Very well manicured I've visited a few times and it's beautiful all year round. I'd say the best time to visit is the summer.
Beautifull gardens!. The Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden includes a French formal garden, English landscape garden and Japanese garden. My favourite was the Japanese garden!
Absolutely beautiful . Cost $2.00 admission. Absolutely beautiful park w traditional Japanese gardens. Also has indoor botanical garden, formal English garden and French garden.

Maybe the best national garden in the world . This was my first port of call in Tokyo when I arrived for a 4 day visit. Entrance fee 200yen. I had heard great things about Gyoen National Garden and I wasn't disappointed and it beat other national gardens id seen in Asia and Europe hands down. So many picture perfect views in the garden itself and the some very exotic plants such as banana trees and coffee plants. It's easy to forget you are in one of the worlds most exciting and futuristic cities and it's so serene that I'm sure I would visit every week if I could. It would be a true pity not to come here in Tokyo.

An amazing place - must visit. A nice quick garden in the middle of a mad city. So peaceful, you get the feel of Japan. The gardens are well worth the time to walk around and see the work that has been done.

Peaceful place. Situated in the middle of the bustle and bustle of shinjuku lies this beautiful park.. Shinjuku Gyoen is home to many beautiful plants and trees and a must see during spring. I enjoyed having picnic under a tree at this park and hopefully find my way back to it soon!!

Sakura season visit . This is the first park we visited on our tour of Japan for the cherry blossom season. The park was beautiful. We tried the sakura ice cream which was very different and delicious. We also had proper Japanese tea in an authentic Japanese tea house. The tropical plant area in the greenhouse was a nice addition.

Great place for Cherry Blossoms Hunting!. To enter this place you have to pay ¥200, the garden is quite big but I suggest you to go along the route, my favorite part is the traditional tea house and the surroundings, thankfully I got to see cherry blossoms at that time, it was so pretty..actually the cherry blossoms were already fall in some places since I went there mid of April and I found it will be very blooming in the end of March or beginning of April :) but I was happy enough to go there and got to see cherry blossoms there

Simply Great. We arrived in Tokyo end of March, where the cherry tree blossom should start. This was the first real park / garden we visited and we were amazed.After spending half a day walking around, looking at the trees and flowers and everything, we bought a bento box and sat down to enjoy the scenery.We then decided to come back later that week with hopefully more trees blooming.And we were right. This time, way better prepared with food and drinks, we sat down in one of the grass areas and just enjoyed the sunny day with thousands of other people; it never felt overcrowded and the atmosphere was fantastic.When we walked around, we took plenty of pictures with the cherry trees as all the others are doing. Everyone seems very happy and it was just a joy being there and spend the day with all the people enjoying themselves.We stayed until the park closes and it was the best day we had in Tokyo.

Delightful gardens. On a beautiful sunny afternoon at the start of Golden Week we went to explore the nearby Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden.Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden was constructed on the site of a private mansion belonging to Lord Naito, a feudal lord of the Edo era. It was completed in 1906 as an imperial garden, and re-designated as a national garden after World War II and made open to the public. The gardens are 144 acres in size and blend three different styles: English Landscape Garden, French Formal Garden, and Japanese Traditional Garden. It is considered to be one of the most important gardens from Japan’s Meiji era.The garden has three aspects: English, French, and Japanese all with the own characters.The English gardens included some nice wooded areas that were shady and restful and it was very pleasant to just amble along amidst the Golden Week revellers who had also decided to enjoy the gardens.The French Gardens – manicured and ordered, included the plains trees that now look more like pines.The Japanese garden – at least during our visit – didn’t have many flowers in bloom and the trees, bushes, and plants were more sculpted, though not into specific shapes or figures like a topiary. There were also more stone features here than we found in the English and French gardens on the western side.The National Garden also has a large greenhouse whose history dates back to 1875. It has been built, razed, redesigned, and reconstructed numerous times during the years and is now an environmentally conscious greenhouse dedicated to the conservation and exhibition of endangered species. Inside there a many wonderful and exotic plants, trees, and flowers and the greenhouse has been designed so there is a winding path that takes you past and through everything there is to see.Entry to the gardens is only ¥200 so there’s definitely no excuse for anyone not to enjoy the wonderful grounds and landscapes of the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden when in Tokyo. We definitely recommend it.

Simply joyful.... We visited with our teens and elderly parents mid-April and was lucky to catch some late blooming cherry blossoms without the crowd. The teens enjoyed taking pictures and walking around. My parents just enjoyed the serenity of the place sitting on a bench looking at the trees. It was a good time to visit. We brought home with us beautiful pictures and memories, definitely one of the highlights of our Tokyo trip.

Stunning gardens (plural). This isn't one garden, it is many. The Japanese garden, Rose garden, English garden and others. Spent about 5 hours here, walking and some sitting, relaxing and enjoying the vista. Seems May is the pick of the month if you want to see the roses in full bloom

Best large garden in Japan. I've visited this garden in all five seasons (yes, they have five - the fifth is 'rainy season, from early June to mid-July, if you're not familiar with Japan), and I have to say my favorite times are mid-spring, after sakura, when the cherry blossoms bring out the masses, and autumn. In May, 2016, the rose garden was to die for, but I'm a gardener, and in October 2015, the sycamore avenue was a wonder. It's very close to other must-sees, too, so if you're a first-time Japan visitor, make it a point to get off JR's Yamanote Line at the nearby Yoyogi Station (not Shinjuku, you'll only get lost there), and take a day for a decent walkabout. One stop the other way is Harajuku Station, where you can't get lost on your way to Meiji Jingu Shrine, another must-see, although this year a lot of it was shrouded in construction/renovation curtains. Nonetheless, if you visit either of those places on a Saturday or Sunday chances are you'll see brides and grooms being photographed in their traditional finery, and you can join in the fun.
Deservedly famous. We went at peak cherry blossom time and so it was very popular. But its a big space and beautiful t this time. don't miss it.

Beautiful day at Shinjuku Gyoen. Completed in 1906 as an imperial garden, Shinjuku Gyoen represents the modern western-style garden in the Meiji era. There are 3 distinctly styles gardens: -* Japanese Traditional Garden* French Formal Garden* English Landscape GardenMy visited to Shinjuku Gyoen was on one of the weekends in May. There were many picnickers. Everyone was out to enjoy the nice spring weather.There are a few attractions in the National Garden not to be missed...the Greenhouse, Taiwan Pavilion, Old Imperial Rest House (only open on certain days of the week) and Tea House where you can enjoy delicious ocha and sweet. Its French garden is tastefully manicured and has many species of beautiful roses with vivid colours and celebrated names, like Mozart, Princess Aiko, Princess Anne, etc. The fragrance of the bloom permeated the air. I felt really happy to be there, even though it was filled with visitors. It's indeed worth a visit if time permits but allows at least 3-4 hours for exploring the exquisite Garden. The entrance fee is ¥200 per visit and ¥2,000 for a one-year pass.

Relaxing garden. The garden is quite large and is divided up into numerous different areas. The Japanese traditional garden and the French formal garden with its rose beds were our favorite parts of the grounds. For inly ¥200 per adult it is an excellent place to get away from the madness of the city.

Well maintained and pleasant. Not a big park, you can walk around in 45 minutes. It's good to have such garden in the middle of super bustling shinjuku area. Entrance fee was JPY 200 for adult and free for children. Many parents came with kids. The weather was so pleasant in May. The trees were properly trimmed and the whole park was properly maintained.

A Good Walk. Beautiful Japanese garden. A delight to walk around. Costing 200 Yen it was well worth it. Frequented by lots of locals who come with their picnics and lunch boxes. English garden was good as well.
Will Blow your mind!. To enter the park it cost 200yen so much sure you have some cash on you. the landscape of this place is like nothing you have seen before. make sure you have a camera handy!
Best Sakura Experience. This is one of the best places to experience Sakura. Very beautiful and magical indeed. The place is well- maintained and secured.

Green oasis in the middle of Shinjuku. This is an easily accessible garden just a short walk from central Shinjuku. Great place to get away from the urban environment for a breather and some open space. There is a French, English and of course Japanese garden to explore. The later was not as picture perfect as the East garden in the Imperial Palace grounds but still very peaceful and pleasant to stroll around in, especially if you are just after a break from the crowds. Take a picnic lunch and hang out for awhile, good place to people watch. Popular with young Japanese, especially mums and small children. Minimal entrance fee.

Rainy visit . Went there and found that there were no one else , small compared to plenty of parks we've been in other countries, without the cherry blossoms, it's just another good park to relax. Nice thing is the pleasure to be away from all the crowd.
A large park in the middle of the business district.. The park was full of children on school trips and adults taking photos of the flowers. This is a truly beautiful park and deserves a visit.

Perfect for a picnic or to relax. One of Tokyo's largest parks, Shinjuku Gyoen left me feeling so relaxed and pleased. I just wanted to sit under the trees all day, enjoying the soft breeze and calming sights. The park is separated into a few themed gardens and one of the highlights was the greenhouse, which served as a warm hideout when the weather gets too chilly.
Relaxing Time. Nice place to relax away from the hustle of Tokyo/Shinjuku. If you have free time & want to chill this is a great place to go.

Shame we missed the blossom . Whilst a nice garden it certainly lacks any wow factor as evidenced by my wife who said "where is the Japanese garden" ...after having just walked through it. That gives you some idea about just how special this place is! Nice for some quiet down time after mad shinjuku.

Beautiful. Out of the all gardens and parks in Tokyo, I totally recommend this as the number one garden in Tokyo.
This is the best place to see the beautiful Japanese garden.
You can also see some lakes that are surrounded by sakura trees.
During peak season (the time I visited this place) it was somehow crowded.

Catching the last of Cherry blossum season. We headed here mid April and found so many cherry blossums just beautiful - So glad we did this and saw so many cherry blossums as they were finishing throughout Japan...
Clean to Japanese standard. . Great Park. You have to pay a few yen to get in but it's a lovely quiet Park with a big pond that has massive koi fish in!
Stunning at Cherry Blossom time. This was my favourite park of many we visited. Go early to avoid the crowds, although it does seem quite a tranquil place even with them.

Big and great garden. You can enter almost garden in Tokyo with free ticket but shinjuku is NOT.. It makes shinjuku diffirent, it always crowed people at the weekend but it is so big so you dont worried. It is so beautiful with alot of tree and small old traditional house.. It is good place for hangout, taking photo, it is near shibuya, so you can go some where near here.
Lovely oasis in bustling Shinjuku. The garden is beautiful with lovely walks. It is a great escape if you are overwhelmed by the bustle and noise of Shinjuku.

Memorable garden. Cherry blossom was not in full bloom when we visited the park this year. But there were other beautiful flowers. Our daughter's boyfriend found a quite & romantic place to propose..... Two years earlier we celebrated our grandson's 1st birthday when cherry blossoms were in full bloom. This in one of my favorite gardens in Tokyo.
Clean. Very clean. Hard to find a litter bin though. 200 yen adult admission about $2. Shade if you need relief from the sun. Short walk from Shinjuku station.

Lovely park to unwind. Beautiful blossoms abound in the park during late April when we visited. The best time to visit is in the morning to avoid the crowd. We spent almost two hours getting lost and found in the labyrinth of garden and flowers and had a lovely stroll. However, please be noted that the park has an entrance fee of 200Y and is close on Monday.

How a beautiful garden. love the Japan green house. Spent few hours relaxing on the garden was useful for us. Witnessing the cherry blossom was just another way to admire the nature. Strongly recommend

No1 thing to do in Tokyo? I agree!. Picked this place in April as the main spot for sakura hanami. It was a very good choice. The garden must be spectacular in all seasons, but I think I saw it at its best. For a ridiculously cheap price, I spent 3-4 hours of walking, taking pictures, sitting by the ponds in awesomely beautiful environment. It has an English (large open areas, most packed with picnicking people), French (mostly represented by symmetric plant arrangements) and Japanese (ponds, bridges) garden and a tropical planthouse. Don't just run through it, enjoy for long hours.

Beautiful place!. This was one of the first things I saw in Tokyo. Such a lovely spot right in the middle of the busy Shinjuku area. We were there in April and the weather was just perfect. Wish I had thought ahead and I had brought a blanket and some snacks.

Very popular garden. Very busy garden as we visited during golden week. 200y entry fee wasn't expensive but seemed unnecessary. We didn't really experience the quiet serene environment that other tourists have described given how busy it was during or visit. Probably more worthwhile during sakura season but really not too much to see at other times of the year.
Beautiful escape from the city . A beautiful garden to walk through and explore. A small cost but worth it especially on a warm day to escape the heat and enjoy some peaceful greenery.

Gorgeous retreat in the heart of Shinjuku. When you need a break from the crowds, this is an excellent place to come. We hit it at the tail end of cherry blossom season, and it was gorgeous. Highly recommended and very little cost.

Beautiful and huge. The garden is beautiful and have a lot of places to rest or have picnic on the grass. The best part of course is Japan garden with water, clones and flowers. Nice and well spend time after day in Tokyo.
Nice place to get out of the hustle and bustle. Beautiful gardens and park - there is an entry fee though, so wouldn't be my first choice when in Tokyo.

A must see. We hoped to get to the Gyoen garden in time to see the cherry blossom but we missed it. However the garden was beautiful and well worth a visit. It was my favourite attraction out of everything I saw in Tokyo.

Beautiful garden in Shinjuku. Went here with my family and managed to catch a few late blooming sakura trees. Do make a trip to this park if you are in Shinjuku and have no time to go to other parks. For a minimal fee for 200 Yen this is a great place to have a picnic!

Little oasis within Shinjuku. It's a lovely and peaceful garden with large sprawling open spaces that are perfect for picnics and little children to run about. It's a little piece of oasis in the buzy Shinjuku area. Perfect for a tranquil afternoon.

Immense gardens, great for a picnic . We visited on a sunny Sunday afternoon, the park was crammed full of local families enjoying picnics and activities. There are several themed gardens and green houses. The Japanese gardens are the most impressive by far, lovely ponds with coy and turtles. Diverse range of plants including some impressive bonsai and orchids. Only 200yen per adult to enter, ticket machines are in English and easy to use.

A Large Park. We arrived here via the JR Yamanote train and exited at through the new south exit and walked about 10 minutes to this park. This park is so large. We walked around the park for 2 hours and still didn't see it all. We came for the sakura viewing. There were probably 5000 other people with the same idea. There's a small entry fee. Most of the local people bring a bento and sit under the trees to eat. We planned to buy a bento while at the park but they unfortunately had run out of bentos. The grounds are meticulous. We spent our time in the "Japanese" gardens. The park also has a rose garden, french garden, greenhouse, etc. We did not see it all.

Nice garden but why do you have to pay!. I managed to see this garden on my second attempt. The first time it was shut for no apparent reason. There was nothing in my guide book or on the signs to indicate this. It's a pretty space but I think it's crazy that they charge for this when they don't charge for places like the Imperial Palace gardens.

Park is beautiful during the flowering trees. Park is beautiful during the flowering trees . Entrance fee, but not expensive.on its territory there are several species of the park: Japanese, English and French.

The best park in Tokyo. This park is opened from 9 am to 5 pm and the ticket costs 200 ¥. It's the best park you can explore in Tokyo and it offers different gardens from different parts of the world: France, UK, Japan. At the beginning of April this is the best place to see the cherry trees in bloom. The size of the park is quite big so even during Golden Week you won't feel that is crowded. It's an oasis of peace in such a vibrant city like Tokyo. It's a must if you are in Tokyo.

beautiful scenery. went there in spring this year, it was beautiful.just sit and enjoy ur food while enjoying sakura.a bit crowded but i know that not only me but also japanese want to enjoy this beautiful garden

walk in the park. very peaceful with a beautiful waterfall and marvelous statues.They had flowerbeds in full bloom, but were tended to by handicapped people. An city program..Enjoyed it very much in such ahectic city as |Tokyo

Cherry bossom - so beautiful it took your breath away. We are fortunate to be in Tokyo at exactly the right time! There are no words to fully describe the beauty of over 1000 flowering cherry trees. Although there were a lot of visitors it did not feel overcrowded. Lovely to see the Japanese having picnics beneath the trees.

Beautiful and relaxing. Because of its size, Shinjuku Gyoen is a great place for experiencing a relaxing day of hanami without feeling crowded or touristy. We spent hours taking in beautiful nature and enjoying all the varieties of sakura. There is a very small entrance fee, and you're not allowed to bring in alcohol or exercise equipment.
So special . Even on a rainy May Day it was very peaceful and very pretty. Worth taking the time to go and make sure to not arrive too late and cut it close to closing time.

A must during sakura season. It is a must see park during the cherry blossom season. When we went there the blossom was in full bloom. It is amazing to see the bloom in this garden.The crowd is well managed. Must complement Japanese people for their neatness and orderlyness.Many groups were enjoying hanami parties and overall it was sublime and beautiful.Must visit, at least during sakura season.

An oasis of calm and peace, in the heart of the city. Beautiful landscaping, in communion with nature. A sprawling park in which I could stroll for hours on end and forget that I'm actually in Shinjuku, where the busiest train station in the world is also located. While it has it's fair share of visitors, especially on weekends, you'll have your space to enjoy the tranquility and beauty of this place. And take it from me : when it comes to landscaping, nobody does it as well as the Japanese.

Sakura Splendour. This is the perfect place to visit during sakura - it has a wide range of plants so the period over which you can view the flowers is quite long. It's also great because alcoholic drinks are not allowed so you won't be subject to the drunken revelry at some of the other sakura spotting sights. Even without sakura, it's a lovely place and has a glass conservatory for tropical plants. Pack yourself a couple of onigiri and (non-alcoholic) drinks put down a groundsheet and spend the day to soak up all the beauty. You'll thank yourself for it.

Buy your favorite OBENTO and visit. I love the place because it is just next to one of the most busy downtown in Japan Shinjuku. Whole through the year you can enjoy the space and sky but particularly, of course, the cherry blossom spring and the leaves turning to red autumn.

Paradise close to the action. Quite extensive, beautiful and well cured park with a lot of ponds and quiet corners, hills and trails with trees to discover. Also nice for jogging and power walkind. Entrance fee 200Yen.

Beautiful garden paradise in the middle of the city. This is a great place to visit to get away from the busy pace of Tokyo. It reminds me a lot of Central Park in NYC, except with much nicer grounds. Take a picnic lunch and have a walk around, it's beautiful and definitely worth the ¥200 admission.

Stunning. Possible to forget you are in the middle of Tokyo when you come here. I wish we had arrived earlier so we had more time, only spent 1.5 hours before they started asking people to leave at 4:30pm, I thought 1.5 hours would have been enough until I saw how beautiful it was.Bring some food and have lunch here, or there are a few snack places to have a coffee / ice cream.

Nice to get away from the city!. Walked around the gorgeous gardens of this park today, nice relief from the city. The traditional gardens make for some nice photos. Many Japanese families having picnics, quite a big area so get your walking shoes on!
relaxing and beautiful. Lovely park, nice for a walk, well maintained and just perfect to get away from the crowds of Shinjuku.

Enjoyable respite near the Shinjuku/ JR Yokohama terminals.. My husband and I enjoyed spending several hours walking about the gardens. The cost is minimal, 200 Yen or just a little under $2.00 per person. The park has several entrances, we arrived at the Shinjuku gate where their is a visitor center;you can purchase seeds and plants at very reasonable prices. Once inside the gate you will find a snack shack and restrooms located on your left. If you order food, you will be called back up to the counter when your order is ready. We had the ice milk at the snack shack near the Shinjuko entrance; it was pretty disappointing in taste and texture compared to other frozen treats we've had so far in Japan. A sign near the entrance recommends using bug spray, which is probably best, since their are several areas with water. The park has traditional tea houses and at least one green house. Many families and couples come to the park to picnic and relax in the sunshine. Wear comfortable shoes for lots of walking on sidewalks and trails. The park is located approximately 10 minutes from the Shinjuko train station by foot. From the south exit of Shinjuku, cross the street, turn left and walk down the hill until you run into the Shinjuku gate on your right. Numerous restaurants, shops and movie theatres in the area. Keep in mind that bicyclists may be using the sidewalks and ride within the pedestrian traffic; they ride very fast!

Sprawling. We went for a nice relaxing afternoon after spending the morning at the Tsuki fish markets. Very little c9st to get ib and as usual in perfectly organised Japan nice and easy to work out. The hot house was an interesting walk, not the most established or involved tgat I have seen but still interesting. We walked into the centre of the gardens to check out the Tea houses but unfortunately both were closed. We then went down to see the Koi island which was also closed. We decided it was a bit of a wash out and so got a tea out if the vending machine and caught the last of the afternoon sun and finished up.
Beautiful. Gorgeous green park next to the hectic hustle and bustle of shinjuku. Absolutely stunning, we tooka picnic. Cost 200yen to enter, good for families & all ages. Closes at 430pm.

Beautiful park. Beautiful place to visit for a quiet tranquil afternoon.It is a cheap entry fee and simply stunning areas. Great to go on a weekend for people watching and in April there is a beautiful patch of cherry blossoms that are worth the visit.

Beauty and peace in the heart of Tokyo.. Visited the garden with family at the start of second week of April with great anticipation.Amidst the hustle and bustle of the surrounding city it was so tranquil and peaceful. The whole garden looked amazing and the views of cherry blossoms falling and floating down like snow were magical. The sight of people having hanami parties under the trees and hearing to laughter all around are the kind of memories that stay with you long after the journey is over.The garden is very well laid out with lots of variety of trees and plants, ponds and excellent landscaping. It was worth heading straight to the garden after landing in Tokyo after a long flight.

Must see if you want after sakura. Beautiful during sakura season. we had the best viewing at this garden as it was sunny. It was very crowded because of the season. Also go for the green house you see many of international plants there.

Great meditation spots. The relaxed quality of this park contrasts with the great metropolitan city just outside it's gates. With easy access off the the metro stop, this tranquil park offers a respite to the hurried pace of the city. We were lucky to catch some cherry blossoms but the beauty of the park does not require them to be in full bloom. The traditional japanese gardens and ponds are a delight. There are ample benches to sit and reflect or enjoy a walking meditation along the paths.

Im sure its beautiful but it has only specific times open. we went there because it says in the japan guide that illumination is available until April 10. We walked farther for this park but unfortunately it was closed. That was around 4PM. So sad but im sure it was beautiful. Lesson learned, check more online!

Best blossom spot in Tokyo. Before planning my trip to discover cherry blossom season in Japan, Shinjuku Gyoen was mentioned as the best place to enjoy cherry blossom in Tokyo. That was simply the reason I visited it at first. I was not surprised that this garden looked amazing during cherry blossom. There were a lot of local people in the garden during weekend and enjoying their hanami party.If you go there alone, it would be still interesting. Cherry trees in every shape are waiting for you. This place was one of the best spots during my second visit to Japan.

Best Place to See Cherry Blossoms in Tokyo. One of our main goals when we went to Tokyo is to see the beautiful Cherry Blossoms. We went to this place 3 days after the start of the bloom season and we already saw a lot of trees that have bloomed.You have to pay 200 Yen to get inside (which is around $2 only!) but I would say that we got way more than what we paid for. We enjoyed walking around and taking photos. Everywhere is picture perfect. :) Please allow at least 2 hours to fully explore the area.Overall, I think this place should be included in everybody's list of places to go to in Tokyo especially for first-timers. This is surely the highlight of my trip!

Beautiful spot for sightseeing break. Great place for morning,afternoon chill. You can take a slow walk in the gardens or simply rest on the blanket and enjoy the peace and quiet. Great place for a picnic, but remember to take your own food - it will save you time searching for restaurants / bars around.

Nice garden. Huge and nice garden to visit if you are into that sort of thing.
There are separate "gardens" marked on their map. Get an English map from the information counter as you enter the gates after paying 200Yen.
On a nice day, this is a good place to visit.

Amazing gardens. Although we were told the main cherry blossom season was over for the year, we still managed to find lots of trees still in flower. Apart from cherry blossoms there were amazing azalea bushes in full bloom that were quite spectacular.
Fantastic. An amazing place. A must see gardens, within minutes you are tranferred from the comotion of the big city to the peaceful and quite landscape of the gardens. A definate must see.
Favorite place in Shinjuku. I loved this garden. I walked from my apartment and it was $2 US (200 yen) to get in. A wonderful stroll through the park and so many colors and nature. Highly recommend

Humongous. We spent hours enjoying this park. It is quite large and very pretty. Take your bento box to enjoy a picnic but no beer allowed. Bags are searched at gate. We were lucky to be in Tokyo during the cherry blossom season and the trees were just amazing. Everyone was congregated for photos with the trees as you first enter the park. Walk in further to avoid these crowds.

The top attraction in all of Tokyo -- for the money!. For the bargain price of 200 yen, it is possible to spend an entire day at this one-square-mile patch of Earth.We were able to blow 3 hours here one Friday morning. We could have stayed longer. Be sure to check out the "Greenhouse," the English Garden, and the Japanese Tea Garden.A beautiful Park and very close to our hotel, the Sunroute Plaza Shinjuku.

Beautiful Gardens - Especially in blossom period. My boyfriend and I went to Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden in search of some cherry blossom and Japanese culture. We loved the park. You needed to queue beforehand to get tickets to go into the park, but like everything Japanese this was very efficient and fairly easy to work out. The park was busy because of the blossom tree's being in bloom, but was still a beautiful park and not so crowded you couldn't enjoy it. It was calm yet had an atmosphere! We had matcha green tea and Japanese cake in one of the 'tea rooms' for 700 yen each. Which was an experience worth exploring. You're served by Japanese women in traditional dress; find the tea room which isn't open and next to a souvenir shop, it is the one which you go through a closed door and doesn't quite look open!
A wonderful park in the heart of Tokyo. Probably our favourite park in Tokyo, and definitely worth visiting, particularly during the cherry blossom season, though I feel it's a treat in any season.
perfect place for viewing cherry blossom. beautiful large garden, perfect for viewing the cherry blossoms. loved the Japanese Garden and the green house.

Start of Cherry Blossom. We went there at the end of March -still a little cold but the cherry blossoms were starting to bloom. The park is huge, spotlessly clean and beautiful. You can easily spend an entire day there. One tends to forget that one is in a big city in this park. We were staying in Shinjuku and we walked to the park.

Wonderful gardens. We thoroughly enjoyed our stroll through the gardens and the traditional tea service. The wisteria, 300 year old pine, and ponds were beautiful, and there were natural areas that were very calming. We barely saw the rose garden, as we sadly ran out of time. I would enjoy a longer trip there. We also loved the river cruise that brought us to the garden.

Peaceful morning walk. Give yourself a couple of hours at least to enjoy these gardens. Was a very peaceful place and beautifully presented. Lots of school kids around on class art trips, but still felt relatively uncrowned. Lovely sunny day on the morning we went.One of the highlights of our trip to Tokyo, if anything just because it was a step out of the busy city.
Fantastic Japanese Style Garden. Fantastic Japanese Style Garden in the heart of Tokyo city; Admission Fee: 200 Yens; - In the Peak Cherry Blossom season!!

A beautiful oasis in an urban sprawl. The Shinjuku Gyoen Garden is a wonderful escape from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo's Shinjuku distinct. We visited in peak blossom season and we treated to a spectacular show of natural beauty in a magnificent setting.There is a small charge (200 JPY) to enter but it is a very small price to pay for such a wonderful park. We spent most of the afternoon walking through the cherry blossom trees and enjoyed every moment of it.
Nice garden,sakura is almost gone. The garden 15 minute walk from jr shinjuku. Very nice garden, with a lot of flower, but too bad, the cherry blossom season is almost finish, not many with flower.
Lovely!. Beautiful park with lovely gardens. I especially enjoyed the traditional tea house where they served matcha green tea and a small tea dessert.

Cherry blossom is awesome. Cherry blossom attracts lots of people here - even on workays it is crowded. But we managed to get good pictures here. Not that much walking, but you see different lakes and even a pagoda. Entrance is free.It is not allowed to drink in the park, so guards at the entrabce smell all the bottles you bring in.
Amazing . An absolute must visit - the entire place is just a huge zen garden plan at least an afternoon there because you wont want to leave !!

Peaceful haven. Although there's a small entry charge for this garden, it is well worth a visit. Many mature trees, large ponds and sweeping lawns make it a place to meditate quietly away from the traffic and commercial bustle of Shinjuku. My visit coincided with a small exhibition of watercolours by an amateur group of botanic artists. The ladies were delighted to show a visitor around and kindly presented me with a botanic print to commemorate the occasion. I enjoyed the green quietness of Shinjuku Gyoen and felt revived by my stroll along the paths. One interesting section had bald cypress air roots protruding from the ground like pinnacles. It was a strange and somewhat bizarre sight. Be aware that Shinjuku Gyoen like some other parks, is occasionally closed when Tokyo is threatened by dengue fever. The shade and moist soil apparently harbour mosquitoes although I didn't see any at all on my visit. The park is easily accessible by public transport with the Shinjuku Gyoen subway station close by.

MUST VISIT FOR HANAMI IN TOKYO. The Sakura Blossoms here are awesome!! Highly recommended to drop by during Sakura season.It's just a short walk from Shinjuku shopping area and could enter the park via Shinjuku Gate.This garden is huge! And could easily spent hours strolling & admiring the beautiful flowers and trees here. Plan ur trip wisely as this park closed early at 4pm during my visit.

Early Cherry Blossom viewing in Tokyo City. Visited this beautiful vast garden as it was the nearest well designed park in the city to have cherry blossom trees in full bloom in late March 2016. Glad I arrived early to buy the entrance tickets because by mid morning the queue and crowd had swelled being a Sunday and the only day with glorious sunshine forecasted.

Beautiful. I loved the Japanese gardens and ponds in particular. I could have spent a whole day here looking around other gardens from around the world. Not free but I think the small entry fee is good value for these beautiful gardens.

Wonderful and Worthit. I went here because I was recommended by several people who have been to Tokyo, and it was worth it. I found out it is also where "Kotonoha no Niwa (The Garden of Words)" takes place, which made me even happier to go to locations from in the movie. End of March and beginning of April, so there are many different plants and flowers in bloom , so that is very worth it.

Gorgeous oasis in the heart of the city. Just a 5 minute walk from Tokyo's busiest station - Shinjuku. Entrance fee of 200 yen. The gardens were spectacular in the cherry blossom season but would be beautiful all year with lots of ornamental ponds full of carp and wide variety of plants, trees & flowers. We also enjoyed the greenhouse with its range of tropical plants. Highly recommended.

Very Big. Went there in April 2016 and luckily when I went there, the cherry trees were full blooming. The garden was very big and in my oppinion this garden is better than Ueno Park. You can find a lot of bento box here, and the taste was very nice.
We just love this park!. We just keep on going back to visit this beautiful park. Worth visiting and just sitting on the bench and watch the cherry blossoms around you.
Good park but not too impressed. Went for sakura season. Nice view due to sakura. But too touristy.Many parks like this at home in Vancouver.

So beautiful!. A lovely peaceful park in the city!It's large and well paved. Wonderful for strollers. The beautiful ponds and landscape is just picturesque. We were even lucky enough to catch the beginning of cherry blossom season. Don't miss this wonderful park! It's a great place to have a picnic and relax on the grass.

Crazy Beautiful. I have been here a couple of times now and blown away every time. The attention to detail here is incredible and super impressive during cherry blossom season. I love bringing a picnic lunch and relaxing here for a couple of hours. An oasis in a super busy city!

Beautiful!. Access to the park costs 200YEN per person but it is simply beautiful. We missed cherry blossom season but there were still many flowers blooming and it was worth paying the admission price to look around.

Absolutely beautiful. Don't miss walking around this lovely garden. Picturesque sites in every direction. Lovely flowering trees, ponds, weeping willow trees, Japanese bridges. Everyone is snapping photos like mad, but who can blame them? It's a beautiful spot.

Nice walk through the park. With the cherry blossom and light wind in my hair, it was a perfect afternoon in the park. It's a nice walk too. Done forget to bring on a blanket to have some quiet time. The fee probably keeps e crowd away so it's not heavily loaded with people and children playing.

Breathtakingly Beautiful. The place is very lovely. We were lucky to see the Cherry Blossoms even though the forecasts said "Petals are falling".
You'd need to pay 200 YEN for the entrance. But the cost is worth it. The place relaxes your soul.

Magnificent during cherry blossom season. Charming park, great during the cherry blossom season to just come there to relax. If you come during any other season, not so impressive. I would recommend to come here after doing some sightseeing or shopping in the Shinjuku area, previously having grabbed some food. Very relaxing to just lay on the grass there and stroll along the cherry trees.

Sooooo beautiful. We weren't really prepared to spend a leisurely afternoon or midday but saw enough to know that we were missing out. We came by train to check on something else in Harujuka and chose to stop off on our train ride back to Higashi-ikebukuro where we were staying for a few days.Much more enjoyable if you can bring a blanket and picnic lunch. Even with quite a few guests in the park, it was still worth the break from our scheduled trip before returning on the train back to where we were staying.
Worth the 200 Yen entrance fee. If you can go on a nice day, it literally is a breath of fresh air to escape the city. It has some really nice photo ops as well.
Spring in Tokyo. The flowers were in full bloom as we were there in mid April. Lovely place and a nice park for a picnic.

Fantastic fresh air and flowers. The sakura was really lovely and we had a fun time taking selfies and group photos. But I will never forget how fresh the air was. It's one of those places where you can go and just refresh your mind.

Beautiful place! . Tip: despite of the name of the garden, it is not near shinjuku station. Nearest JR station is sendagaya station. Admisson fee: 200 ¥It is worth if you have time, and depends on the season that you are visiting.Similars places as ueno Park can be visited without fee.
Stunning Garden In the Middle of the City. Definitely worthwhile walking through the garden if you have time in Tokyo. Price is very reasonable at only 200 yen for an adult.
Beautiful public gardens. We were lucky and caught the blossom in full bloom, absolutely stunning. Definitely a beautiful serene spot in the middle of a crazy city

Just beautiful! . I was a bit sceptical about going to a park in Shinjuku initially, despite it being rated as no.1 attraction on TA. This was because we'd just visited Kenroku-en Garden in Kanazawa, one of the top 3 most beautiful gardens in Japan. Scepticism unfounded! Shinjuku Gyoen is beautiful in its own right, more botanically varied than a pure traditional Japanese garden. It has sycamore trees, an English garden and a French formal garden as well. Admittedly, we were wild about the cherry blossoms that were still present during our visit. Our 5 yo had a wonderful time running around the garden and posing for shots in so many picturesque locations. I think it's wonderful that Shinjuku has an admirable sized green lungs that provides for a diversion from the hustle hustle of the cityscape.

love the hanami experience!. Visited March 2015 and enjoy a picnic with cherry blossom viewing. Beautiful park, with alot of people but NOT crowded at all. Will certainly be back for the next hanami or cherry blossom festival.

Must visit in spring or autumn. Must visit in spring or autumn--I say this because I went during the summer, and summers in Japan can be quite rainy. Rain and the outdoors generally don't go well together. I think the same would be true for bitter cold winters. The best time to visit really is during the most colorful seasons--spring and autumn. The park is huge and has a Japanese, French, and English garden. It's a popular spot for cherry blossom viewing.

Best Park for Hanami. The Park is located near the train station so its accessible. Alight at Shinjuku Gyoen Stn and follow the crowd, once you spot the trees you are certainly in correct direction..Take note that there will be 200yen entrance fee..There were luscious sakura everywhere during my visit. Its cloudy and the weather is chilly, very suitable for walking. The park itself is huge. There are snack shops around so you do not have to worry. Not too crowded during my visit so i had funnnn exploring..

Lovely Garden visit. One of the most beautiful gardens with all the major gardens: English Landscape, French Formal, Japanese Traditional. This is a great place to see the cherry blossoms blooming during March and April

Small nice garden. It's just a small garden behind the Govt building.Good for morning or evening walk.There is a small temple in it too.You can take pictures or just sit outside and walk people.Many locals take their dogs to stroll.

Amazing Place!!. I wanna spend my day everyday in this place. So peaceful and cozy. It's like paradise when spring come and sakura was bloomed. You won't regret it to come to Shinjuku Gyoen!! Super recommended!! :)

Large Beautiful Park. Most beautiful in the spring time. They have a large number of cherry blossom trees and the locals would bring sheets to sit on the grass in the sun. It can get pretty crowded throughout the day and the queue at the entrance can be as far as a whole block.

Peaceful. Beautiful gardens that are kept immaculately. There is a small botanical garden area but the real beauty of this park is the peaceful atmosphere as you stroll around. A real mix of tourists and locals here.

Beautiful Calm Peaceful best Sakura Garden. What can i say about this garden? I took close to photo's of the sakura blooms.It was a rainy day when we went and there would have been or so people there. Just so beautiful i am so glad i went, the gardens are well looked after, there are park gaurds all over to ensure they stay that way and one of the few places in Japan that alcohol is not allowed apart from public transport. Must do!

Beautiful Gardens in a very central location.. We only just caught the end of the cherry blossom season but the gardens were still beautiful! Would be a lovely place to go for a picnic or just to take a book and read. Very peaceful even though surrounded by high rise buildings.

A must see during  Spring visit. This garden as a variety of Cherry Blossoms. I only had the time to visit the Japanese garden (gates close at 4:30pm). Bring your own picnic mat and snacks to enjoy the peaceful atmosphere.

A beautiful park especially in Sakura season.. We went to Japan to see the Sakura and when we went to the national garden we were not disappointed. It is a large park where even with the number of people pouring in there still seemed to be plenty of space. While there are clearly plenty of different types of gardens throughout the space our highlight was the blossoms.
Gorgeous. The Cherry blossoms were still in bloom while we were here. A lovely part of Tokyo, still alot of people but easy to walk around and take lots of photos of the blossoms.

Sakura. We were there april 7 and cherry blossom are evrywhere. Its like a magical experience being under the trees and everytime the wind blows flowers are falling like snow. There are a lot of tourist strolling and having picnics but the park is sooo big we can still move freely. Too bad we didn't have enough time to go farther than the sakura trees we didn't see the beautiful pond (or river ) i saw in other blogs.I left my wallet in a bench and its very unfortunate i lost 70,000 yen plus all my credit cards and hotel key. We immediately went to the lost and found and the staff are all willing to help but its very hard to communicate i felt sooo disappointed and depressed at the same time. Anyway, I still want to thank them for being so helpful.An ice cream store and vendo machines can be found a few meters past the entrance on your right and one on the left before the exit.

Gooood!. From the upper floors you can enjoy a wonderful view . beautiful and organized structure . very courteous staff. Cleaning at the top . Placed near a busy area full of restaurants and shops . fantastic holiday . Thank you. I hope to come back.

Amazing place to visit!. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is a great place to go by yourself and/or with your family. It's all green and beautiful, you can definitely have a beautiful time over there. In march, the cherry blossoms can be seen, and in february some plum blossoms also can be found. The place is great. The view by the lake is beautiful and you can easily spend a whole day in the park.I strongly recommend it. :)

The Best Garden in Japan. I was born, raised, and currently live in Tokyo. I have traveled all over Japan and trust me, if there is one Japanese garden you should see, this is it. Take the afternoon that this deserves and enjoy the park.
Beautiful Garden. Most tourists won't visit this park. But it is really beautiful. It makes me to think of Central Park of New York City.

An Oasis of Calm. An oasis of calm & peace in this most frenetic of cities. Foreigners come to walk romantically through these delightful gardens. Young locals in same sex gangs or small family groups. Stunning in cherry blossom week.

Peaceful oasis next to busy Shinjuku. This park is a perfect jetlag-fighter and relaxation spot - we regularly walk here before leaving for the airport to soak up as much Japan as we can before returning home.Bring a few coins for the entry fee (though they have staff to make change) and leave your suitcases at the hotel so you're not dragging them along gravel paths.

beautiful place for viewing cherry blossom. very large beautiful garden for viewing cherry blossom!! also has a very nice green house worth a visit! Japanese garden is my favorite place to take a rest
Beautiful Sakura bloom venue. A lovely park to relax amongst the sakura bloom. Its big and worth a visit. We spent some time relaxing on the green grass amidst blossoming trees
Probably the most beautiful of all gardens during Sakura.. Probably the most beautiful of all gardens during Sakura. Its walking distance from Shinjuku station as well.

Good park, but unimpressive in Feb-end. It must be very pretty in spring/summer, but at the tail-end of winter (Feb-end), the trees were mostly bare and hardly any flowers either. It is cheap and a good place to relax if you have time. But, it was nothing special when we visited.

Wonderful place. Especially if you visit in the spring....when its time for the beautiful cherry blossom season....where you can find different wonderful colours everywhere....it is definitely worth visiting
Just beautiful. Shinjuku's escape. Beautiful. Plan to spend a lot of time here as a counter to the entertainment, sightseeing, shopping...
Sakura Everywhere. Go here during cherry blossom and you will be fascinated. Sakura bloom like nobody business. Come here during April - May for cherry blossom.

A true beauty in the city. What an amazing place. Very inexpensive to go in (it was 200 yen in April 2016) and the tranquility and sounds of nature just take you away. Cherry blossom trees are late bloomers in this park so when everywhere else is done, don't give up! It's only a 2 minute walk from the subway exit too.

We want twice and in the rain!. Amazing!! What a treasure to spend our morning there. It was my husband and I's favourite activity. The weather was warm thus making the place look lush and green. We were fortunate to see the cherry blossoms in full bloom. What a sight. My husband fell in love with this beauty. It rained the next day and we still went back. Amazing!
Beautiful Hanami. Beautiful Cherry Blossom all around the garden. I had a wonderful time taking pictures here, every corner looks great.The entrance from Shinjukugyeon mae station seems less crowded.

A beautiful park in the heart of Tokyo.. Shinjuku Gyoen is a large park in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo. The admission fee is 200 Yen per person for an adult day ticket. The park itself is beautiful, from the plants and trees to the sprawling fields that provide an ideal spot for a picnic.There is a greenhouse where you can view a variety of rare and exotic plants as well as a good number of rest areas with toilets and vending machines dotted around the park. The main appeal is the incredible scenic views, with the Tokyo skyscrapers providing a stark backdrop to the natural beauty of the park. Cherry blossom season in late March/early April is the best time to visit, with Japan's famous sakura trees in full bloom.

Pleasant escape from the city. This is a large park with established pathways through treed areas as well as having open lawns. It opens at 9am and costs 200 yen for an adult. I went early on Saturday and although there were some crowds around remaining flowering cherry trees, it was easy to find quiet corners to relax. It was getting busy in the afternoon. Possible to do bird watching although mostly just common city birds and some ducks when I was there. Worth the entrance fee to have a nice long walk with rest on benches. There is a tea room as well.

So much cherry blossom at Sakura time. Lovely big gardens of peaceful surroundings with a Yen200 entry fee. They could use some of,that money to upgrade the rest room facilities, one would hope. However at Sakura time, the cherry blossom trees here are simply gorgeous. So many different vsrieties. As well as whe. The Azalea season starts, you have a riot of colour. Worth a visit.

Sakura Viewing & Picnic!. Went on a sunny day & it was suprisingly cooling with all the sakura trees hovering our heads! It was blooming perfectly when we visited (8 Apr 16). Good place for my son to run about as well. Spend some time away from the bustling city just to picnic, enjoy the view & chat! You will find locals doing exercises, whipping their cameras to capture the pretty sakura bloom as well!

Excellent place to view Cherry blossoms. We spent out last day in Tokyo leisurely exploring this 150 acre park. The cherry blossoms were in full bloom and absolutely spectacular. The Greenhouse and Japanese formal gardens were highlights along with the Teahouse.

Beautiful.. A lovely garden with many tranquil areas.Very popular with locals and was very busy during the blossom time.A great way to spend an hour or two away from the hustle and bustle of the town.A must visit if you are there.
