Lovely. Pretty, tranquil gardens. There is an admission fee of 200 yen per person and park closes early (4.30pm). Although we visited during the cherry blossom season and the park was busy it still had the feel of tranquillity. Very pleasant way of spending a few hours.

beautiful blossoms. we went here for half a day - our last day in Tokyo. the blossoms were beautiful. Particularly liked the Japanese gardens. The French and English gardens were nothing in comparison. There was a small charge to enter the gardens, but it was worth it.

Great for viewing Sakuras.. Though we came after the peak season for cherry blossoms, there were still several ones in full bloom, and of different varieties. (14th April 2016) Not as many Somei Yoshino but enough to take photos with. Parents came here during the peak season last year and were captivated by myriads of blooming cherry blossoms. Costs 200 yen per entry.
Sakura. Worth a visit in Sakura (blossom season) Nice space away from the crowded Tokyo streets. It's a large park with lakes and a greenhouse, a sort of Japanese central park!

Nice sakura view but very crowded. Nice park with breathtaking view of cherry blossoms and other flowers/plants as well. We did the photoshoot in the park, even though it was crowded but worth the visit

Stunning anytime - but in Spring - wow.. It is almost unbelievable that this huge park is in the middle of a metropolis of over thirty million people, it is so peaceful, beautifully laid out and landscaped. The apartments of Shinjuku that overlook these gardens must pay a huge premium for the privilege.

Outstanding Sakura. Visited with family and friends, for a picnic under the cherry blossoms. Shinjuku Gyoen is always outstanding during Sakura season, very clean and well kept with plenty of open space for the kids to run around. Crowded at weekends but still plenty of space and beautiful views. Caution though because the last entrance is at 16-00 and the gardens officially close at 16-30, which is earlier than most people realise.

This is a 'must-see' in Tokyo; Beautiful.....breathtaking!. It is always lovely to see a huge, tranquil place with lots of nature, in the middle of a big city. The Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden does not disappoint (please note though, admission is not free, it costs 200 Yen/$1.85 USD per person). There are many places within the gardens where you can go to sit and relax and take in the cherry blossoms and pure nature all around you. There are so many nice views of the city (and their skyscrapers) all around you too, as well as little ponds, great open lawn, a greenhouse, and even a bit of forestry. It's a break from the city life and a wonderful reminder of the outdoors and how therapeutic and beautiful they can be. You've also got to appreciate the many people out and about socializing and enjoying each other's company. All in all, this is a must-do in Tokyo and highly recommended!
Better than expected. Very nice park in working distance from Shinjuku JR station. Entrance fee 200 yen. Perfect timing of cherry blossom . Visited on April 16th.
Sakura. Amazing during Sakura season. There were hundereds of varieties of sakura. I could have stayed there all day taking pictures of the beautiful trees.

Beautiful garden in Tokyo. It is a very nice garden in the middle of the skyscrapers. Beautiful sakura and a wide variety of them, nice arrangement of the trees and plants. The only minus is the voice that you can here from time to time from the speakers installed around it giving warnings without this one would have been a very nice place.

Experience Cherry Blossom in Tokyo. This public park is perfect for seeing cherry blossom. Very well-maintained. No pet, alcohol, bicycle allowed, so can enjoy the view peacefully. Ideal for lunch picnic under the sakura tree.

Pleasant surprise of Late Autumn. I chanced upon this park walking around Shinjuku after a business trip. Just about 10mins from the busiest Streets at Shinjuku station, Gyoen Park presents a scene completely unexpected filled with the colours of the autumn and the lush of the greenery. I would definitely recommend to pay a short visit if you are here for Winter or Spring.

Great Place for Hanami. This was one of the parks which I visited during our recent trip to Tokyo. Definitely prefer Shinjuku Gyoen over Ueno, though each has its own merits. More on that later.Getting to Shinjuku Gyoen is easy. There are 3 different stations via different lines near the park. I would suggest taking the Marunouchi line (I hope the spelling is correct) and alight at Shinjukugyoen Mae station. The park is just a couple minutes walk from the station. Adults have to pay 200Y for entry while kids below certain age get free entry. Once in, you will get to enjoy the vast grounds and serenity. Despite the huge crowd, we still get to find a spot for a picnic, and do what the locals do, enjoy the scenery and food. On the other hand, Ueno park is free for entry and they have pathways lined with endless Sakura. However, I find it less conducive for sit downs, and you don't get that sense of peace and serenity that you will get at Shinjuku Gyoen. And that's why Shinjuku Gyoen is tops in my mind.

Just past the peak of cherry blossom - still amazing. We walked through the garden in mid-April, just after the peak of the cherry blossom. Even so, this is a magnificent park and would still be worth visiting out of season.The entrance fee is very reasonable and it represents excellent value for money. I'd suggest it would take 2-3 hours to wander around the park. There are metro stations near all the entrances.

Beautiful and well maintained. The Shinjuku Goyen National Garden is a beautiful and well kept public park. There is a small fee to enter but it is well worth it. The grounds are clean and the landscaping is lovely. Walk through the park. Take pictures. Sketch. Paint. Meditate. Picnic. Enjoy!Try to get to this garden in the morning. We visited on a Friday at 10:30am and when we left at noon, there were about 300 people waiting to get in. There are places to eat within the park. A small shop near the entrance sells bento boxes, ice cream and drinks at very reasonable prices. There are a few sit-down restaurants further in the park. There are a few benches but I recommend bringing a mat or blanket if you want to sit. We visited at the beginning of the cherry blossom season in early April.
Beautiful blossums. Amazing array of cherry blossums. Many different varieties to see. It was raining lightly and this made the blossums more lovely.
Beautiful park. We enjoyed the walk inside the park, this time of the year the blossom is delightful.This place is worthy to visit,has a lot of beautiful views.Very peaceful and relaxing.
Relaxing. A gentle stroll through the gardens was a great way to start our stay in Tokyo. While we just missed the cherry blossoms, there was plenty to capture through the lens.

Spent a perfect morning catching the tail end of the Cherry Blossom!. We specifically visited Japan during this peak season to witness the famous Sakura Cherry Blossom Season, thankfully it did not disappoint!We somehow managed to arrive before the gates opened at 9am, I am glad we did as we managed to enjoy the park's tranquility for a few hours before it got swarmed with other tourists. Despite us only catching the tail end of the Blossoming season (in Tokyo atleast) many of the trees were still beautiful and not a barren wasteland as I had always dreaded! I can only imagine how beautiful the blossoms are during it's peak - for Tokyo, I believe it was literally the last week of March to the first week of April; we visited on the 7th of April.We somehow managed to spend 4 hours taking a very slow walk around the park (just the once), it was such a nice sunny day and the park itself were so beautiful I just did not want to leave (and I'm a guy!)
Catch the blooming Sakuras. A great place to view the pretty sakura trees but be prepared that it can get crowded during this season with locals and tourists all swarming here for the same reason.

An oasis of calm in the centre of the city. This garden is popular for picnics. There is a traditional Japanese garden in the middle that is absolutely beautiful.You stand in the gardens and you cannot see the city.I was there for Haname which is the Cherry Blossom celebration when families come to picnic and enjoy the blossom.There is a restaurant in the gardens and a souvenir shop.A must do for anyone visiting the area.

Gorgeous blooms. Went during sakura season, so lovely to see the flowers in full bloom. It was crowded but the park is large and you probably won't have any difficulty finding a spot to sit down and admire the blooms or have a picnic. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit!

Peaceful gardens a delightful oasis in Tokyo. Even though many of the cherry trees had begun to lose their color, there was still so much beauty here. The lovely walking paths are peaceful and lush greenery abounds. Find a bench or choose a lawn spot beneath a spreading tree and picnic or just veg for awhile. A welcome respite amid chaotic Tokyo.
Blossom season and beuatiful design. The gardens are excellent. The variety of colours was stunning. The greenhouse itself is excellent. Good facilities as well.

Nice place for viewing cherry blossom. Been here twice for viewing sakura blossom. Entrance fee is 200¥. The whole park is quite big. Bring your camera and dress up for photo shooting.
I'll come again.

Wonderful gardens, so peaceful. Tip: A map in English is available, but you have to ask for it at the entrance (we got one from the counter at the Shinjuku Gate).The park is a must-see. Got the chance to walk though the park whilst the blossoms were still there, and what a sight! Absolutely beautiful, so peaceful and very well maintained. The park boasts different areas: the Japanese Traditional Gardens, the English Gardens, the French Gardens etc. It also has a few tea houses if you need a rest. Toilets are also available throughout the park.

Beautiful gardens . We spent a good 1/2 day walking through parts of the gardens. Paths are good for elderly walking. Some parts need to be careful. Plenty of rest areas , toilet facilities throughout and drink areas. The cherry blossom were in bloom which were spectacular. Great venue for photography 200 yen entrance for adults well worth it

Excellent cherry blossom views!. Last week of March and 1st week of April this year are good times to visit this garden for cherry blossom views! The garden has admission charge of 200yen per adult. Do expect huge crowds especially during this season. Very expansive view of the cherry blossom and the surrounding city! Picnics are allowed on the grounds but alcohol are not allowed into the garden grounds with security checks at the entrance. The nearest subway station is Shinjuku Gyoemmae along the red Marunouchi line.

Well manicured, easily accessible & best place in bustling Shinjuku to unwind. It's relatively easy to get to from the nearby Tokyo Metro station exit about 350metres away, not too far off from heart of Shinjuku. Entrance fees was ¥200, and the guards at the gate search your bags. Noticed they don't allow tripods or large bulky camera bags/gears, so local photographers get around that by packing light, and using foldable camera gear (eg extendable monopods) in small wheeled bags. Do look at the main map near gate, and use that to plan your route. If the front grounds (where many cherry/plum blossoms trees are located), are too crowded for example, use the map to see which paths head to the lake or other areas. Signs are prominently placed, and at least bilingual (Japanese + English), though a few signs here & there have Korean and Mandarin.Do line up in the Q at popular scenic spots to take photos/selfies, and move on after taking a few shots. Some of the local elderly photographers are rather vocal & will buzz you off if you take too many shots, and make them wait long in the Q behind you. Trash bins are only located near main entrance/near the tea houses (quaint lil Japanese tea shops selling curios, snacks & beverages), and the locals don't take kindly to litterbugs.The tea houses are worth a detour off the main routes, as they've seats (only for customers who buy their stuff) to rest, and the main toilets are generally a short distance away.Many scenic spots, and the occasional large grass patch to rest & people watch. The locals dressed in their Spring best, to mingle around and take selfies/wefies, and consume meals/snacks in groups. Very safe locale as regular park rangers patrols make their comforting presence felt. They're also the ones who go after Q jumpers & litterbugs...Worth spending a few hours there, even if only to soak up fresh sun, breathe in fresh air, and admire the many scenic spots. Do avoid weekends due to the crowds, and put on a pair of good comfy walking shoes.. Enjoy =) !

Cherry Blossom Time. We arrived on a Friday and had a picnic in the park on Saturday just as the cherry blossom was coming out. We were amazed at the number of people - mainly locals doing the sameA highly enjoyable experience and naturally lots of photos
Beautiful Gardens. Very popular place for locals and tourists. Great place to see the blossoms in March/April. Large, beautifully landscaped gardens. Highly recommended.

Wonderful park with great atmosphere during weekend . What a wonderful park! We visited it last saturday and, besides the different gardens (traditionnal Japanese style, French style and British style), we'd like the ambiance. There were some small food stands and everybody was eating, sat on the grass.You can observe some people drawing, painting or taking pictures near the cherry trees. It's a nice photo spot for sure.Entry fee is 200¥.
Fantastic in spring . This was fantastic you need at least 4 hours to visit and lots of space on camera . It cost 200 yen to get in . We went by train from Shinjuku

Beautiful park. I went in the beginning of April, during sakura season and the park was so beautiful. There are tons of cherry trees and they were all blooming beautifully. Of course there were lots of people, but the park is so big you can easily find room there.

Good sakura viewing place. I went here on a weekend to view Sakura and it was quite crowded. The scenery here is very nice with the sakura in full bloom. The garden is easily accessible from the Shinjukugyoenmae Station. i could only spend about 3 hours there and thus did not have enough time to visit the French garden. For people who like flowers and parks, you can easily spend half a day inside slowly enjoying the flowers in the cool weather.
Peaceful Garden . Beautiful Garden especially during the Cherry blossom season .U can even go for a jogging as it's super quiet and far from the busy roads .
nie place to take a break. It was a nice garden to take refuge from the city. I teneded to walk everywhere so i nice place awary from all of the cars was welcome.

Perfect place for hanami. This park can really accommodate a very large amount of tourists because of its enormous area. The park is also well kept. We were able to enjoy the scenery especially the sakura/cherry blossoms despite the number of people in the park.

Cherry Blossoms WOW! Highlight of our trip!. Out of all of the things we did, walking and sitting in this national park was the highlight. I'm not even the kind of person who loves gardens, and I was totally blown away by the beauty and the perfection of this place. I didn't want to leave, and my girlfriend was on the verge of tears because of how beautiful it was. Perfectly cut grass, beautiful cherry blossom trees, cute kids running around, families enjoying their day, and couples cuddling on blankets. Visually stunning, and so peaceful. We felt as if sitting in the park, we'd achieved some kind of peaceful nirvana. It was clear that others felt the same, and that people were very slow to leave as the park was closing. The biggest surprise and biggest highlight of our trip!

A must visit place for everyone who loves gardens and flowers. This park is huge! It has more than 20,000 trees with special varieties never seen in Japan before e.g. tulips, plane trees and Himalayan cedar trees. It has over 1,500 cherry blossom trees so it's a must visit for all who came to see the Sakura bloom.

Cherry Blossoms are MAGNFICNT. Wow, what a beautiful park. There is plenty of open space for hanami picnics and parties and the part is very well managed. It is a short 10 minute walk from Shinjuku JR station of Shinjuku-gyomae Subway Station and very child friendly. A great place to recharge and read a book. Be warned that it is extremely crowded during Cherry Blossom Season (Late March-Early April) and there are lots of people having picnics at this time. Alohol is prohibited and there is a 200 yen entry fee per person.However, even if you just wanted to go for a stroll, this garden is highly recommended. Hard to believe that it is just moments from the busiest station in Tokyo!

Oasis in the middle of urban city - Central Park of the East. This is one of the four must visit Cherry Blossom parks in Tokyo, the other three being (1) Chiyoda, Imperial Palace, (2) Naka Megoru and (3) Ueno Park. We visited on the same day as Prime Minister Abe hosted his annual Cherry Blossom viewing. The park has more than a 1,000 cherry blossom trees and a large variety. Thus there are early bloom and late bloom trees and thus you can get a good selection during the entire season. Crowded with many people enjoying picnics in the wonderful spring season. Entry is Yen 200 per person. Bring your camera or smartphone and be prepared to take many wonderful photos

Japanese Traditional Garden - beautiful.. This is a must see destination in Tokyo - great in any season. Cool shady trees in summer, cherry blossoms by the score in spring, colourful foliage in autumn and inspiring landscaping in winter.

cherry blossoms. Very beautiful garden with lovely cherry blossoms in full bloom. Very nicely maintained - it has an entrance fee of 200 yen but it is definitely worth it. There were a lot of people there since it was the cherry blossom season but a not to be missed garden
Cherry Blossom. There were cherry blossoms even we were there in March 2016. Beautiful park. It was cold though, we enjoyed.
Nice place to see cherry blossom. One of the most famous place to see cherry blossom. Very big garden but just a few restaurant inside so eat something before go inside. Entrance fee 200yen

A beautiful spot at a bargain price. I was lucky enough to be able to see the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden during the height of cherry blossom season. It was a wonderful experience, though naturally, quite crowded. The walkways winding through the gardens are secluded enough to make one forget they're in the heart of the city. Extraordinarily well-maintained, quiet, and covered with flora. A great getaway from the hustle and bustle. Don't forget your camera.
Beautiful. This is a beautiful park in Shinjuku. We went during the rain so it was relatively quiet. The cherry blossoms were out and the place looked magnificent.
beautiful garden. easy walking distance from shinjuku station, 200 yen entrance fee, many different variants of cherry blossoms

First Stop @ Tokyo for Cherry Blossoms - Gyoen National Garden. Climate was cold those days, but we found some cherry trees on blossom. Recommended for early morning or after 2pm. This garden is big, including a greenhouse with exotic species, and has several doors, so take your precautions and don't get lost. It will be closed at 4:30pm.
Cherry blossoms!. went there only to see the cherry blossoms and i was not disappointed. the garden is beautiful, lush with greenery and peppered with brightly coloured cherry blossoms.
Central Park east. Nice Central Park type area. Very nice green area. Closed on Mondays but very nice area to visit . Recommended for families

Cherry Blossom 🌸. This park is stunning. Entry is 200¥ per person and there is no alcohol allowed into the park. When we got there about 11am there were big queues to get in, yet the park wasn't overly crowded and there were a few places where we were able to enjoy the cherry blossom peacefully. Ueno park was recommended to us for Hanami, but when we went there we were so disappointed because the place was so crowded. Shinjuku Gyoen was a much nicer experience.

An international feel. Maybe not what you'd look for in Japan, a garden inspired by others from around the world. Still, it is interesting to see the interpretation of one culture of another. Perhaps not the top of the list in Tokyo, but worth a visit if you have the time to spare.

Awesome place to admire sakura flowers. This is a very big park in the middle of the city. Because its large, there is enough space of people to walk unlike the other parks like Ueno where it is just too packed. The sakura flowers were so beautiful and it is in full bloom now. I suggest getting a bento set, picnic mat and find a large space. Was great just to admire the flowers, enjoy the weather and watch the world go by.

Beautiful and very peaceful place to view Sakura. Must visit place if we're leaving nearby. It has very beautiful scenery and cherry blossom views. You can enjoy whole day here with full of natural experience just in between of crowded city.
Sakura blossom. It's the best time to visit Sakura Blossom in Tokyo! Blooming at the best period of time! Should definitely give a visit and see the whole park blooming!!

Beautiful park smack right in the middle of Shijuku. This is a big beautiful garden in the city. It has several areas of interest in the park. The green house is full of tropical plants. The garden has hundreds, if not thousands, of cherry blossom trees all over the park. The Japanese styled garden is impeccable and has a few Japanese Teas houses. It also has a western styled garden on one side of the garden. It cost 200 Yen per person per entry and they do not allow alcohol in the park

Love the cherry blossom. Friendly with strollers, food around, walkable from train, love the cherry blossom. Super beautiful. I had tears in my eyes while those soft petals were falling that was finest nature graphic which were awesomest I ever seen. Love the softness quite atmosphere
WOW. amazing gardens, beautiful traditional tea house and hostess, a wonderful experience, a beautiful spot to laze the day away

Convenient location, nice stroll to see sakura. Went quite early on a Saturday so we were able to avoid long queue. There were many visitors already in by the time we came but still plenty of space available for everyone. Had a very nice walk with my elderly parents along the paths just watching sakura blooms and fallen petals.
Remember to pick the right season . All the best stuff to see are gonna be gone in late fall and winter. Go when everything is alive, it is very well taken care of at those times

Beautiful Cherry Blossoms. We visited this park twice in the last week, and it is so beautiful. The cherry blossoms are stunning, as are the many different flowers, trees and gardens in the park. We enjoyed lunch in the restaurant one day, and there is also a snack bar type cafe by the entrance. We loved that even in extremely busy Tokyo in cherry blossom season, we found quiet spots in this huge park for photos and to enjoy the scenery. A definite must visit while in Tokyo.
Stunning. A beautiful part of nature especially during spring. The cherry blossoms were amazing and as the wind blew it was like it was snowing. A must see
So Beautiful. in the heart of shinjuku an amazing peaceful and beautiful place to visit, especially during cherry blossom season!

Beautiful Gardens. Yet another beautiful garden in Tokyo. The Sakura were in full bloom during our visit and many locals were enjoying the park too. Within easy wlking distance to the Metro and a very cheap entrance fee are more reasons to include on your list of gardens to visit in Tokyo.

Beautiful well-manicured. Best in Spring. Love this park. I used to live in Yoyogi (just next door) and walk to this park almost daily. Its a lovely escape from the bustle of Shinjuku. I highly, highly recommend visiting here even if your just visiting briefly. Beautiful photo ops. The best in Spring! (Sakura season when the Cherry-blossoms are in bloom).

Cherry blossom season...'nuff said. Amazing garden and park, reason why it is #1 on things to do in this area.With the cherry blossoms in full bloom, it was spectacular. Highly recommend a stop here any time of season. A+

Beautiful Gardens. We arrived just before opening time (9am) and we were glad we did! It was wonderful being one of the first 50 to step into the gardens. We went during Cherry Blossom Season so there were a lot of people in the queue. The grounds are absolutely gorgeous. It was a wonderful start to our morning. We took a long walk to get there, enjoyed our time in the garden and then meandered through the rest of our morning.

Nice place to stroll around. Entrance fee is ¥100 and cannot bring alcohol into the park. It's a nice park especially if there're cherry blossoms. They even have a map to help locate the cherry trees.

Beautiful Sakura. This is a very large park, and I only saw part of it, but the cherry blossoms were in full bloom, with many families having picnics on the grounds. There is a lot to see in the park - different gardens, tea houses, lakes, and more.

Huge cherry trees! . Huge park with a lot of cherry trees! Always crowded. Be aware the closing time of 16:30. Entrance fee JPY200. No alcohols to be brought in to the park. Highly recommended especially Cherry blossom season! Just amazing!

Three gardens in 1 beautiful place. We visited during the last week in March and about half of the cherry blossoms were in bloom. Those that were in bloom, were stunning and everyone was taking pictures by the lovely trees.This garden is interesting because it has several different styles in one place. A Japanese garden with scenic bridge and pagoda as well as a very neat French garden as well. Interesting to compare the styles.There was a nice lawn by the Japanese garden where we sat and had a rice cake snack - was very relaxing and great for people watching! Our family had members from age 4 - 64 and we all enjoyed it.Beware that the park closes early - 4:30 pm - so try to plan this excursion on the early side of the day.

Wonderful / Beautiful. No need to pay expensive guided tour.. We went there during Cherry Blossom and it was quite fantastic. It was very easy to go there by Metro and only around 200-300 meter from metro station to the entrance of the park. We paid some Yen 400 in entrance fee. The garden is just wonderful and must be seen. Cannot describe it in words. There are some small coffee shops in the park and plenty of restroom facilities.We came early and stayed for 3-4 hours. Then it was really filling up with people.Later we saw advertisement for guided tour to the park at Yen 12,000 This seems not necessary at all since it is very easy to go there and once there you just want to walk around in your own pace. The main point is to see and enjoy the park.

Beautiful Cherry Blossoms. Visited at the end of March and cherry blossoms were in full bloom. Gardens were crowded, but since they occupy a large area, it was not a problem. Lots of family groups having picnics on the grounds. Overall, a pleasant experience. Volunteer guides were very helpful and made sure we received an english edition of their guide map.
Cherry Blossoms. The park is beautiful. We went when the cherry blossoms were in bloom. It was gorgeous. The tea house was terrific.

It is a must visit if you are in the Shinjuku Area. Cherrie Blossoms just were awesome, very nice to enjoy in a very short time. The park it is very nice to walk around and lots of places for photography .

Beautiful time of the year...for Cherry Blossoms.. Wanted to see more cherry blossoms so another park off our list. Got there in the later part of the day around 3:30pm. Didn't realize that the park closed at 4:30pm so we rushed a little but still got to enjoy the beauty of this park which is located just 10 minutes from Shinjuku Station.They are other gardens within the park so you have options like the Japanese Gardens, a very large greenhouse, as well as sculpted trees in the traditional bonsai style.

Spectacular Cherry Blossoms! A Beautiful calm Oasis in the middle of Tokyo.. Cherry blossoms in full bloom. Families everywhere. We were particularly captivated by a group of girls who visit at this time every year and had recorded these yearly visits in a scrap book. A lovely peaceful place.

Beautiful garden with cherry blossoms. Compared to other garden in Tokyo, this garden is less crowded due to its large space. There are many beautiful sakura around the area and 3 different themed landscapes in the garden. You have to pay an entrance fee (200 yen) to enter the garden.

Beautiful garden in the middle of the city - tranquility and peace. This was my first time in Tokyo and this garden, located in the middle of the city offers you a perfect spot to walk around and still have the quietness and peace you do not find in the crowds - barely noticing the city buildings in the back. Really great place to relax.

Beautiful at Cherry Blossom time. The cherry blossoms were fully out. Beautiful scenery . One did thing was that when it was closing time the tune Auld Lang Syne was played. However no clear indication that it was closing!
Beautiful garden. A beautiful place that should take about 4 hours. First week of April is a good time to see a full cherry blossoms. Bring a good camera!
Wonderful viewing in cherry blossom season . Went their with my family. Amazing cherry blossoms to be seen. Lots of locals enjoying the gardens. A wonderful experience.
Not to be missed. So fortunate to be here in Cherry Blossom time. About 1000 cherry trees, thousands of picnickers in the park on a spring day, kids everywhere, weddings (multiple). Joy.

Just amazing..!!. One of best place to visit japan when you want to see cherry blossom #sakura in Japan during spring season. There's a lot of sakura tree, many japanese people went there for a picnic.. so, it's very crowded during peak of spring. Better to visit this place between late march until early april

Amazing place to come for a relax. Couldn't be further from the hussle and bussle of Tokyo... beautifully laid out garden, sakura were in blossom when we were there which definitely added to the garden but is definitely worth a visit at anytime.

Tranquility.. I don't know about you but this place made me feel really peaceful. It's a really good place to just chillax or panic with your friends even though the sun was beating down on you but you don't feel the heat. We visited that day was still 9-10°C so we love the weather!

Cherry blossom!. March / April is great for cherry blossom! You see locals and tourists alike taking pictures or having a picnic under the trees. It is a lovely atmosphere and the garden itself is well maintained and beautiful. Entry is ¥200.

Wow . Even on a grey, wet day this place is just lovely. The blossoms are out and under every tree families gather to be together with rain gear, food and smiles. Just stunning to walk around in the quiet and tranquil oasis. Absolutely beautiful

An excellent oasis in the city. Wow what a peaceful and lovely park. We enjoyed our walk around this park in the middle of cherry blossom season.The greenhouse was an interesting bonus but avoid taking cameras in here as it is really humid and no photos look good here.With cherry blossom season the Chinese and Korean tourists were all crowding the trees and difficult to get a photo of the tree without a crowd in the background. The park is very wide and with such a minimal entrance fee it is totally worth the trip. I recommend visiting the tea houses there and small stalls for food. I highly recommend this park.

Wide open spaces great for Cherry Blossoms. Entered through the Shinjuku gate and found an English language pamphlet just to the right of the entrance. The crowds were somewhat challenging near the entrance but I found some more secluded places with a little hiking around. The blossoms are just getting into peak season. Interesting the blooms weren't as fragrant as I thought. Definitely worth seeing - fun to see so many families making a picnic of the day.

Excellent and Easiliy accessable Garden for Cherry Blossoms. Super garden for Cherry Blossom viewing. About 69 hectares in area with formal Japanese, English Landscape and French Gardens. The Cherry Blossoms were super so we visited twice. Very easy to access from Shinjuku station...about a 10 minute walk. Bring a picnic and enjoy the garden and cherry blossoms if you can.Also suggest you visit the Green House. Takes about 15 minutes to walk though. Very good collection of tropical and sub tropical plants. The second day visited was a rather cold day...do the warmth was very welcome. Would also recommend visiting the Mother and Child Forest. Most unusual sapling growth from the forest floor...very unusual.

Beautiful!. Very nice looking during the sakura season. Even thought there are many people, you can still get great pictures. Not expensive to enter (200 yens) and very close to a subway station. Good facilities and useful maps.

Sakura aplenty!. It is end of March, spring and it is the season for the Sakura! We were told Ueno park would have the best Sakura watching experience but upon arriving there, there were only a few trees at full bloom. We managed to get good photos neverthess.However, upon getting to Shinjuku Gyoen, it's a different experience altogether. The entrance costs 200yen and tickets can be purchased easily from the gate at the entrance. Queues are long but they move relatively fast. There were trees of all colours of Sakura and we managed to snap very good photos there. Many local Japanese, young and old, were there for picnics on the grounds. It was the same at Ueno park but the atmosphere at Shinjuku Gyoen felt more alive maybe because of the beautiful scenery of the Sakura all around us.The Gyoen is only a short walk from the shinjuku station. If you are at takashimaya, you are then very close so just keep walking onwards and ask anyone for directions as it is very easy to find.My husband has a sensitive nose and despite the beauty of the place, we could only stay for no more than 20mins before the pollens irritates his eyes and nose.I am not sure of how the place would look during other seasons of the year but during spring, it is not to be missed :-)

Beautiful gardens . Huge beautiful gardens, lovely place to spend extended time walking and relaxing. Japanese gardens with ponds are just gorgeous, beautiful cherry blossoms and a lovely greenhouse with exotic flowers.

Spectacular. Even in early Spring, before any significant cherry blossom bloom, this garden was spectacular. Multiple environments present themselves around every corner. each onesufficiently different and beautiful to evoke a sense of awe.

Beautiful garden. I went on 26th Mar morning whereby the cherry blossom had started to bloom... Very beautiful and calm place in a city whereby you feel the nature and the little birds flying around the cherry blossom trees.. For 200 yen, we spent about 3 hours in the park unexpectedly and we really enjoy this park.So visit the park early before noon to enjoy better without the large crowd.

Close to metro, and in shinjuku. There are two parks in Shinjuku - one I've never been to. Shinjuku gyoen national garden is the other one i visit every time i am in Tokyo, which may be twice a year.It is very large and there will be plenty of room for everyone, even in cherry blossom season! The lake and the bridge are very picturesque in the right season. The reflections on the lake (of the trees in full bloom in cherry blossom season) are spectacular.There are wide open spaces where you have a clear view of NTT Docomo Yoyogi Building, terrific when framed by branches of trees, bare or otherwise. Plenty of room on the grass for everyone to sit on and to soak in greenery and open spaces, in busy Tokyo.Generally a very pleasant way to spend 3-4 hours.
Worth an hour to visit.. We visited with the cherry blossoms starting to bloom. There were hundreds of people here taking advantage of the good weather. It is a feature well worth your time.

Blossoms galore. This has to be one of the most beautiful and ejoyable things i have experienced since coming to Tokyo. The sakura are absolutely gorgeous and the locals are out in force picnicing underneath them.

Oasis of calm in the midst of the city. We could see this park from our hotel window, and it looked like a beautiful destination, so one morning after breakfast we walked over and spend a couple hours wandering about. There is a 200 yen admission fee (inexpensive, yes, but we didn't expect the fee). The cherry blossom season was about to begin - one tree had already blossomed, and we encountered a number of people taking pictures of this one tree. There is, of course, a traditional Japanese garden, small lakes, bridges, paths, etc. We passed a couple of little teahouses where one could get a snack. Very enjoyable way to escape the bustle of the city for a bit.

Get in early!. Got to the park on a hot and sunny Thurs morning (10ish). It was busy but nothing horrific - not until noon when huge crowds starting swarming in. The park is beautiful. Once you've papped the blossoms, do yourself a favour and wander off to the furthest corners. There you can enjoy some peace and quiet as well as a more interesting, varied scenery, a world away from the blossom tourist hordes.

Go during spring . It's a lovely scenic park. We went 22nd March. The cherry blossom just started blooming and though it was a lovely park we feel we're missing the some of scenery. It gets busy so earlier the better and decent shoes

Pleasant and serene . It's a relaxing place to chill in Shinjuku. ¥200 is the entrance fee one has to pay to get in. The park is huge and nicely maintained. Sakura trees can be seen during its season. A nice place to picnic.

An Oasis of a Garden. Who would expect a great big beautiful garden of trees and flowers right in the heart of busy bustling Shinjuku? I'm so glad I read Trip Advisers' reviews of this place and made it a point to visit it on my last day in Japan. Boy, was I glad I did! The cherry blossoms were absolutely exquisite and we just couldn't take enough photos of the beautiful flowers. I just love this garden! The great thing is it is completely accessible from our hotel Gracery in Shinjuku.

More serene and natural landscape than Ueno Park. Having visited both gardens, we understand why Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is more highly rated than Ueno Park. It is more spacious, serene, natural and perhaps more central (2 stops from Shinjuku station). There are a lot more cherry blossom trees and many people brought foods and drinks here for picnic under these beautiful blooms. There is an admission charge of Yen200 and no alcohol is allowed here.

Quite retreat from the city with the city in the background. I visited in early March and there had been a few cherry blossom blooming really nice. I guess since it is still not the season, the park is pretty quite. Really enjoy walking in it for a morning by myself. I always like Japanese garden for its attention to details. This park also has European style garden, two tea house and a big green house. If you need a little time away from the city and relax, this is the place to go.
Amazing . Peaceful, sakuras ... The most beautiful garden I visited in my life ... Specially now with the sherry blossoms it s amazing ... It deserve the fist position in Tokyo for sure

Cherry blossom. It was lovely to walk through the park with the cherry blossom flowering. (21 March) One of the highlights was to take photographs of all the people taking photographs of themselves and the Cherry blossoms close up!

A respite from the City. I enjoyed a break from the busy city with time spent in this botanical garden. The park is filled with interesting areas to spend time in and beautiful during the cherry blossom festival.

Beautiful. We visited on our last day in Tokyo and it was beautiful. We were so pleased to see the cherry blossoms. It was busy but it didn't bother us. Wear practical walking shoes as there is a lot of ground to cover.
Nice place for a walk. The garden is fabulous, many kinds of plants, it is famous for the Sakura but this year it arrives late.

Time limited review.. Wednesday 30th March. Cherry blossom looking lovely and everyone is out to take photos. Access from Sendagaya gate at 9:30 was quite. By 10:30 the queue for security checks (no alcohol) at Shinjuku gate was 500 plus meters .
Calm, clean, fresh. I went there for a photoshooting session with some friends. The park is located in Shinjuku, not so far from the station. It is very clean, green, air is fresh and very calm.

Just Awesome!. A must see. The gardens provide a beautiful calm respite in the middle of the city. The waterways are full of fish that are about a foot long. The cherry blossoms are so much nicer than Vancouver as they have quite a few varieties.
Beautiful. Cherry Blossoms were beginning to Bloom, (March 5th) was lovely to walk through the park, great getaway activity from the busy city.
Tokyo's Cherry Blossom Spots Tour. It was covered as part of a 1 day tour. It is a short visit but this place has the cherry blossoms in full bloom. And the zen-like surrounding is really peaceful.

Access problem. this may be the most beautiful garden in the whole of Japan, BUT. If you cannot get in after 4 PM (at least in March) you've wasted a long trip and 1 km walk from the station. Some guide books don't mention the closing times!

Wide variety of sakura. Shinjuku Gyoen is known for the wide variety of sakura. We arrived about a week too early for optimal cherry blossom viewing anywhere in Japan, but near the end of our trip this place had some of the different varieties blooming. Be careful as there are opening and closing times. We arrived half an hour before closing and the strict guards at the gate would not let us in even though we said we would pay and just look at the sakura that were visible just inside of the gate. They also did not allow any alcoholic beverages (searched all of our bags and containers)... not sure if that is a permanent policy or just during the sakura viewing season.

Best garden in the middle of Shinjuku. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden built in 1906 formerly a imperial garden, designed by a Frenchman. It is composed of the English Landscape Garden, French Formal Garden and the Japanese Traditional Garden. The looks are different with each season. Admission is ¥200 per person. I enjoy the ¥ 700 green tea and sweet at the Tea House. No alcohol allowed. Wonderful place to visit.

Great park. This is a great park, it cost 200 yen to enter, but it is not so crowded. Beautiful trees and flowers and many places to relax. Much better than the Ueno park that tends to be very crowded.

Beautiful in blossom.. Large park with easy access. I was lucky enough to visit during cherry blossom season but it's worth a visit all year round. A myriad of photo opportunities and only 200yen entrance. If you're in Japan and don't visit you'll regret it.

Beautiful garden. This is a huge garden in the west of Tokyo where you can see cherry blossom, a greenhouse, a French garden and a Japanese garden
A good spot for cherry blossom
Only few trees when we were there the 27th of March so a lot of people under the ones with flowers

Great afternoon strolling. We spent a few hours strolling around the gardens on a lovely sunny spring day. The park was packed with blossom-hunting Japanese and the occasional wannabe fashion diva on a photo shoot with their boyfriend. All-in-all, it was for a very colourful and beautiful afternoon and we only left because we were exhausted from all the walking. There are bento box sellers in the park, so if you have a blanket with you, it would make for an awesome picnic. No alcohol allowed though.
Top Tokyo attraction. Lots of great cherry trees in bloom during late March, early April. Admission fee of ¥200 well worth it. Great photos and relaxing atmosphere.

Worth it.. Especially if you are there in late march/ early April when the Cherry Blossoms(Sakura) trees bloom it is amazing. The entrence is 200yen which isn't much at all. You can get some good shots here for sure, but don't expect to get much alonetime in front of the most popular trees/buildings/etcThere is also a greenhouse with more tropical plants and a neat Japanese tea house where you can get green tea for 700Yen.

Great place to visit. We really enjoyed our visit to the National Garden as it was two days into the Cherry Blossom period and whilst a number of trees were still to bloom a number of trees had already blossomed and were attracting visitors.We also enjoyed the quietness away from the noise of Shinjuki .We also liked the Greenhousevwhich houses some really attractive plants and flowers.There was also the opportunity to relax or take a walk.

Beautiful city garden. The cherry blossoms are just starting but the park is great anyway, with side paths and a huge grassy area, and pretty quiet despite being so close to Shinjuku. Well worth Y200.

Great park with great view. Come during most of flowers were blossom, it was full with people to have "picnic"Nice park, with a lot of big special trees make a half was not enough to enjoy it. During sakura blossom this is one of best park to go

In search of sakura. And at the time of my visit, there was only a single tree with the cherry blossoms in full bloom! I guess April would be a better month to see the cherry blossoms in the city. The rest of the garden is worth visiting still with 200 yen ticket price. Try to walk along the perimeter, it's almost a similar experience to Jardin Luxemburg. No surprise because the country assigned a Frenchman as the designer if I'm not mistaken.
Lovely. Gorgeous, peaceful park at the heart of Shinjuku. Brilliant having a stroll when the sun is out and seeing all the cherry blossoms :)

A beautiful gem in the heart of Shinjuku. These gardens are lovely and well worth the ¥200 entry fee. The plum blossom was out. Do not miss the greenhouse. You will spend more time than you think here. Take a picnic!
We flew home after our walk here - a lovely way to say goodbye to Japan.

Wrong season but very peaceful . If you want a break from Tokyo this is a great place.
On a sunny day you can loose yourself in the stillness and beauty.
I can only imagine how much nicer it must be with the blossoms and colours.
Lovely!. A very peaceful and relaxing park! Definitely worth the visit. Extremely relaxing and tranquil. Almost like a retreat or oasis in the middle of the city.

Great view. This place is a great way to relax and enjoy the beautiful gardens and it doesn't cost a penny
We visited and the sun was shing really relaxing day

Delightful. Is a great little park to take the kids and picture taking. We came in the 2nd week of March and managed to catch the 1st of the cherry blossoms. Very peaceful and lots of artists painting/drawing. There is a cost to get in - can't remember how much - but quite cheap. The greenhouse was beautiful. Our girls enjoyed the walk and getting to have a run around.
oasis in the middle of city. This park is lovely - an oasis in the middle of busy city. beautiful landscape, very clean and organized with great greenhouse.

Japanese Garden and cherry blossoms made it worth it to visit!. Hard to guess this lovely garden will offer some tranquility so close to the business of Shinjuku. Lovely Japanese Garden section with ponds, bridges and even some local artists painting cherry blossoms in the spring. Easy to get it and out if you are in a hurry, but worth the visit.

Should visit when the flowers have bloomed . I have came during mid March 16 and is lucky enough to see a few of the Plum and Sakura trees in the Park. The place Is huge and is a good place for couple and families to come for picnic. Entrance fee is required. About 15 mins walking distance from Shinjuku Station

Classic Contrast. I love the energy and vibrance of Shinjuku but this garden is the perfect foil. Great for a stroll. Great to see Japanese gardens.Plenty of space in a world of crowding. Wonderful at the beginning of Spring before the crowds set in. A trip to Shinjuku would be unbalanced without these gardens.

Beautiful garden in the heart of Shinjuku. We were hoping to find some Cherry Blossom trees. The grounds are beautiful and we had a great time enjoying the spring blooms. The green house offer warmth from the cold weather and good collection of more exotic plants.

Serenity in the heart Shinjuku. Very pretty and well maintained park in the heart of Tokyo, when we visited most of plum blossoms where in full bloom and some of the sakura had just started to blossom.

Even at the end of winter well worth a visit.. This was a beautiful garden with an amazing greenhouse. We were there in February but even then the blossoms were starting to come out. There were so many lovely features about this Garden, too many to mention here you need to go and see if for yourself.

Cherry Blossoms on a cold winter day. After 2 days in Shibuya, the gardens were nirvana. We woke up early to get to the garden when they opened, which was a good instinct, as the Tulip Trees, Cherry Trees and Forsythia had begun blooming and the photographers were out en mass. The gardens are beautifully maintained, with formal gardens, Japanese gardens, Chestnut Tree and Cherry Tree groves, as well as large open areas with plenty of places to take a rest. The wild area around the Cypress Trees looked suspiciously like my side yard in Florida.The gardens are a short walk from Shinjuku Station. We traversed the park and exited the opposite side of at Sendaguya Gate, turned right and within a 15 minute walk reached Meiji Gyoen/Shrine Gate. Do not go to Tokyo without visiting this garden. Plan to spend at least, a half of a day.

Gorgeous!. My husband and I were exhausted from the constant on-the-go activities so we decided to head to the Shinjuku garden and I'm glad we did. The grounds are much bigger than I expected and we spent a good few hours wandering around and sitting. There are many photo opportunities and even a large green house which I didn't expect. The grounds and green house are extremely well taken care of. This garden is definitely an opportunity you don't want to miss while you're in Shinjuku. Note that this garden is closed every Monday.

Nice gardens. We came here on our first morning in Japan. It was a nice gentle introduction. The gardens are pretty, and pleasant to stroll around, although we did see more spectacular examples elsewhere in Japan.
Beautiful!. Worth a visit! very relaxing to walk around and get some nice pictures! The gardens are kept beautifully maintained as you would expect in Japan.

All we expected from a formal Japanese garden. Not the best time of the year to see the gardens, but even in January it was impressive. Most curious thing was seeing Japanese people really keen on photographing mallards, which are two a penny in the UK. But we do the same with "exotic" breeds as well.
Nice bran park. Great place for a quiet walk and cool photos. When the cherry trees at in bloom it is quite a sight.

Go in Spring. Had a nice walk through the garden while on holiday in Japan. Beautiful Park however would be spectacular in Spring with all the cherry blossoms. Also take a walk though the greenhouse. Very nice! a great walk in the park. Nice and quiet and only ¥200 per person

Nice way to spend our last day in Tokyo. My fiance and I were exhausted by the end of our Japan trip so we decided to spend our last few hours in Japan at the Shinjuku Gyoen national garden. We left our bags at our hotel and walked 5 minutes to the garden. It was late February so the sakura trees had not blossomed yet but there were a few ume trees that were in blossom. It was a nice garden, very big but not that pretty since the sakura trees were still barren. We had visited the Hiroshima Peace Garden two weeks earlier (absolutely breath taking) so this garden paled in comparison.I imagine it would very nice during March/April and would recommend it for a relaxing day or to kill time if you're waiting for a reservation nearby.

"Greenspace" in the city. Early cherry blossoms were starting to bloom and a couple of other trees were flowering but other than that I thought that the park was more of an open grass park with a few ponds and structures than a botanical garden. The admission price is small (¥200) which includes a nice map with some interesting information about the park. Because of the time of year the vast grassy area was a curious straw colour and mostly a thin layer of soft mulch overtop a closely cropped lawn which was still nice to lie down in the warm spring sun. The park is a place for tranquility and quiet activities so no bikes, balls, frizbees or music allowed.

would be way nicer in spring . It was a big and beautiful park amidst the metropolis, but majority of the trees were not in bloom yet when we went there on the first week of March. Nevertheless, we were able to appreciate the little color and potential beauty this attraction had to offer. It's worth stopping by if you'd have the spare time and energy, and just want to "hang around". But would perhaps be a must-see in spring where it should be at its best. It's a little walk off the subway exit, but not hard to find as you only have to look for the densed trees as your guide. If you see the trees, then head towards that direction and find the nearest entrance which is located at each end of the block. We proceeded to the heart of Shinjuku after, which was a couple of blocks away. If your feet won't let you walk anymore, you might be better off taking a short subway ride instead. Either way, it's doable.

Beautiful parkland . Lovely large parkland for a decent stroll, lots of pretty garden areas, makes for lovely photos. A great way to spend an afternoon, although it shuts at 4.30 pm. Recommend a visit, feels like you are out of the city.

Huge Park in Tokyo . We went in the park to see some shrines but we got the wrong entrance. However we found our way to the shrines and got lost a couple of times. Great place for sports. I think you can also rent a bike
Serene. Another great break from the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku. Close for a stroll when you are over shopping or Kabukicho(ing)

All Season Garden. Have visited this garden at least twice (different seasons) on my visits to Tokyo. Was pleasantly surprised to find outstanding presentations each time. This garden is beautiful and this beauty is planned for all seasons.Excellent casual atmosphere. Many walking/strolling trails, just enough historic buildings and an oasis in the middle of the skyscrapers. The rest of the world seems to go away in the peace and beauty. Saw many people spread blankets for family picnics, photographers catch the beauty of the foliage and colors of the season and displays educating the public about the history and goals of the garden.Would recommend making time for a two hour visit which may become three or even four hours, depending on the season. Very low entry cost.

Pure Serenity! A must see in Tokyo!. We visited the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden in January and it was still definitely worth the visit. It's a beautiful place to stroll and breathe the fresh air at any time of the year. (But don't go if it's raining.) Make sure to wear good walking shoes and appropriate outerwear. There are many paths that meander this way and that, so you can spend a lot time there getting peacefully lost if you wish. The admission price is pretty cheap, and it's located near tons of restaurants for a quick bite.

Shinjuku National Garden. Nice place to spend and relax a quiet afternoon. The gardens are well maintained. Not so much people since the weather is a bit cold. This place will probably a good place to visit during spring time.

Peace and quiet. It's hard to believe that this place exists next to the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku. It's such a lovely place to visit and take photos. The blossoms were just showing on some of the trees and they looked beautiful against the green lush backdrop of the gardens. Please take an hour or 2 to visit if you are staying in Shinjuku.
THE garden. Focus is in nature. At the entrance the map highlighted spefic part in lue of the season. Y200 is very fairv for such a park.
Beautiful autumn leaves. I visited here early december and saw beautiful autumn leaves, the greenhouse, kyu-gokyu-sho. I love this place, relaxing and must visit again next time.

Cherry blossoms in February!. I visited this park during the final weekend of February and already the cherry blossoms were out! This is a peaceful park in the middle of the city and very close to public transport. If you don't have much time, head straight for the Japanese garden, it's the prettiest garden in the park.

Early spring . Have visited many times, it's always on top of my list when staying in Tokyo, today beginning of spring and the cherry blossom is just starting to bloom, very pretty. Main shinjuku entrance is a short walk from shinjuku JR station walk towards to lumine entrance and down the hill passed Times Square For 700 yen visit one of the two Japanese tea houses, green tea and Cake enjoying the view of the park I often go to the food area of takashimya or lumine buy takeout and enjoy lunch somewhere in the park. Don't miss the park.
Relaxing. Headed here for a stroll and a coffee before I flew out. Some really nice well looked after gardens. Even have a greenhouse that was really good although quite muggy.

Zen Garden. Incredible National Garden to leisurely stroll through. There were bridges and to walk across and wooden tea houses set against beautiful manicured trees, bushes and ponds. Amazing how this treasure is in the middle of the city not far from a subway entrance/exit. A must see on any Tokyo visit.

Great gardens. A wonderful stroll through beautiful gardens. I'm here at the start of March and the cherry blossom is brining the gardens to life. Allow a good 2 hours to work your way through the gardens.At the front gate one of the signs stated no cameras. However once inside there were cameras everywhere. Take your camera along, a snack and enjoy.

What a peaceful, relaxing and beautiful place for a stroll. We visited here and had a couple of hours walk around the gardens. There were beautiful sights to see. The grass was very dry though due to it being winter, however the gardens themselves were beautifully maintained. The cherry blossoms were starting to bloom and their smell was just to die for. It cost 200 yen to enter the gardens but it is well worth the visit. The peacefulness is great and it is amazing how peaceful it is considering it is in the hussle and bustle of the Shinjuku region. Would be lovely on a nice day for a picnic. Beautiful!

Big Japanese garden next to busy shopping. This is a very popular park with nice traditional Japanse garden but also other styles represented. It is great place for just relaxing in the middle of a busy shopping. The park is ok for picnic but drinking alcohol in the park is strictly forbidden. This is sad but understandable especially during the cherry blossom time. Especially that time there are lots of guards who will quickly catch those who break this rule.

Stunning gardens. Lovely gardens, especially in cherry blossom season. Very cute tea ceremony in center of park with traditional matcha tea and sweets served by geishas. A bit of a tourist attraction/trap, but we only had an afternoon free so it was a lovely, accessible taste of what real tea ceremonies would be like! (which i'm sure a much more lavish)I could spend hours in this park.. and especially given the lawns are so manicured and clean you really enjoy laying back under a tree with a book, its very cosy.

Amazing Amazing park. This was probably one of the most gorgeous parks I've been to. The care that the Japanese puts into everything they do is apparent by the upkeep. Almost every leaf and twig is meticulously kept as certain parts of the park almost looks "too perfect" giving a surrealness to it. There is a small entrance fee but it is absolutely worth it as you are transported to an amazing greenspace as you cut through downtown Shinjuku.

Oasis of calm once Shinjuku overwhelms you. This garden is an oasis of calm once you have reached overload in Shinjuku. In fact it is amazing how quiet it is after the hustle and bustle of nearby streets. The garden is divided into several different garden styles (e.g. French manor, English, Japanese etc) and interesting in its own right. Worth the small amount of yen you have spend to enter the garden.
Fine. This is a centrally located large serene and beautiful garden. Take time to walk around it slowly. There is much interest throughout the year. ..remember plum blossom comes before cherry.

Beautiful and Calm!!. This park is a great place to visit for a little break from the city-craziness. It is so calm and peaceful. Nice for a walk. The entrance cost about $2.00USD per person and it is worth it. I was at this place in the winter so not many flowers to see but I am sure in the spring and summer must be colorful and pretty.

Quiet park. This is a quiet park in town that we were able to sit and have a picnic. There were birds and flowers galore. The park allowed us to take a break from the hustle and bustle of the busy city.

Excellent Garden and find the waterfall. The garden itself is lovely, relaxing and tranquil, however most flowers are naturally not in bloom during a winter visit. Therefore a visit to the garden is a must during the spring Cherry Blossom Season, however there is still plenty to see regardless of the season. The ponds are simply one of a kind and sprawl across the park. Another must is to spend the time in search of the bamboo waterfall, which is simply amazing to stop and listen in the quiet. No trip to Japan is complete without a visit.

Simply beautiful. Located in the busy Shinjuku, the garden was tranquil and beautiful. We went at a time when plum blossoms were in season and the garden was absolutely beautiful. We had a great picnic there and yes, we will be back!

Proposal. Gyoen will always have a special place in my heart. Me and my girlfriend went there on a sunny morning in March. She was unaware of my intentions that day and enjoyed every moment in the park. I think we took a picture with every Sakura tree because I was so nervous. Eventually we went to the traditional Japanese garden and it was one of the most beautiful places we visited in Tokyo. It was picture perfect. So I grabbed my camera and asked my girlfriend if she could stand on the bridge so we could take a picture together. When she stood on the bridge, I pushed record on my camera and walked towards her and after a short story about how much I loved her and how lucky we were, I proposed. She said yes! It was so special and I have to thank Gyoen national garden for being so perfect. So, thank you Gyoen! I hope we can visit you again some day.
Beautiful Garden. Amazing garden, would be beautiful in Cherry Blossom Season. It is closed on Mondays and cost 200 Yen

Walking through it wonderful.... Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is another of my favourite parks in Tokyo. There is a belt of trees surrounding the park that blocks a large amount of the city sounds. There really is that contrast – standing in a really quiet area while knowing that a busy, noisy city is only minutes away. The park is divided into three distinctive gardens: 1) Japanese Traditional; 2) French Formal and; 3) English Landscape. All three are wonderful with their own characteristics.
nice park to visit. Watch out that you have the correct gate for entrance, because there is only one that is open. It is a nice park to visit. A little bit 'central park' of Tokyo

Amazing!. Shinjuku Gyoen is a large and beautiful park in Tokyo.There are more than 20,000 trees in the park, 1500 are Cherry Trees. You can easily spend an entire day roaming the park. At one time these were the Imperial Gardens. While wandering through the park, the trees and flora change resulting in very different impressions for each area. There is a small Tea House where you can enjoy a tea ceremony. There are moments that can be a bit startling. Occasionally while wandering around I would approach one of the park’s boundaries and realize that there were cars passing by or glance up and see the skyscrapers of Tokyo. It is easy to become lost in the peace and beauty of the park and this intersection with ‘the real world’ would break the spell. (Almost like snapping out of a daydream.)No one should visit Tokyo without allotting a day for this park. The entire park is handicap accessible.
Tranquility in the city. A great place to visit in Shinjuku. Made a nice contradictory stop before going on to the Robot Restaurant nearby.
Beautiful Tokyo, Fantastic Japan.. This is the Japanese traditional and conservative park. Everyting is beautiful. If you come here, you can look another Japan!
The lungs of Tokyo. A must-visit when travelling to Tokyo. Having a stroll here is really good for your soul and body.I absolutely loved it.
A photographer's dream!. Add this to your list of picture perfect locations. Quintessential Japanese culture. Tranquil. Magnificent.

Comfortable public park, cherry blossom recommended. Nice to walk around in ordinary seasons, but the most exciting is cherry blossom season in end of March or beginning of April. There are so many cherry trees, not only most popular Someiyoshino but also many other kinds end you can enjoy the graduation of cherry colors from almost white to pink, sitting on the green glass field.

Awesome park. This beautiful park is a must visit! I strolled around this park for hours all by myself and never got bored. Cool ponds and large grass area. Traditional Japanese flower gardens and shrines.

Not-so-secret garden in the middle of Tokyo. There's a minimal fee before visitors are allowed entry. Nevertheless, it's really breathtaking for a public garden. Great place to ruminate about life and stuff. Really enjoyed it!

Beautiful, even in winter. I went in January and the landscaping is fantastic. While it's not huge, it's a great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo and go for a leisurely stroll. There are a few nice winding footpaths and there is very good signage in English that describes the building and statues in the garden. Great site!

Nice to feel seasonable changing. Not far from Shinjuku-station.
Very good to visit specially in Spring & Autumn.
To feel Japanese garden sprits in any season.
It has a lot of types of cherry blossom flower trees. So you’ll be able to enjoy Sakura-season a bit longer than other place.
mesmerizing sakura. Visit Shinjuku Gyo-en at the peak of Cherry Blossom and you will be treated to the most spectacular display of colours as if in a fantasy.
Be one with the nature.. I was a sight to see even in winter. Wander around the Japanese garden and then rest your feet at the traditional tea house. Tones of gray takes nothing away from this place.

Even in Winter a very nice place to visit. We walked from our Hotel to the Garden about 20 minutes. The 200 yen ( about $1.75)admission fee was very reasonable. We at first thought how similar this Garden was to Central Park in NYC. Here is a great quiet oasis in the heart of a bustling city. There are three different type landscapes within this one location. As we started walking around the ponds it almost seemed "American" but then we were suddenly in an Asian type scenery. I would love to see it in spring when all the cherry trees are in blossom. Although we did not stop there were tea houses, snack and quick food places around the gardens. It was not crowded so we had a very nice leisurely walk. Close to train stations so when we left through the Shinjuku gate we were close to the subway for our next stop.
Very enjoyable couple of hours. We rated this garden above the Imperial gardens and really enjoyed strolling around it. The greenhouse is amazing and the Japanese Garden was a highlight.

Lovely gardens, definitely worth a visit. We visited the gardens in winter and they were beautiful but I would love to see them in spring or summer. Really nice traditional gardens right in the middle of Tokyo and very easy to get to. Recommend a visit.

A refreshing change of pace . A tranquil and beautiful garden in the midst of the bustling city district of shinjuku and its skyscrapers. Stepping into the gardens from the incredibly congested Jr shinjuku station felt like entering a totally different world. Went in the winter where the deciduous trees were bare/nearly bare but there were pockets of flowers still going strong around the gardens and the plants in the greenhouse were also in full bloom. There's also a decent small cafe and a souvenir/snack stand in the grounds.
Peace and serenity. Peaceful and beautiful gardens in the heart of Shinjuku, A great place to spend a couple of hours looking at the beautiful scenery in peace and quiet as a break from the madness

Impressive, even in mid-winter. This garden is well worth a visit, even in mid-winter. While the deciduous trees are all obviously without leaves, the garden is impeccably kept and great for letting kids stretch their legs in a very congested city. The topiary on the pine trees is admirable, and a great intro to Japanese landscaping.

A lovely way to spend a couple of hours. Admittedly there was never going to be any bloom in the heart of winter, but the austerity and barrenness of the denuded trees worked well with, especially with the layout of the Japanese Gardens. There were two lovely tea houses where one can pay for a serving of green tea and a little dessert (Y700 per person at the one we went to).The entrance fee is Y200, and we saw wheelchairs available there for people who might struggle to get around (cost unknown)

Deserves to be on the top spot!. It was the peak of autumn when we went here, and I was in awe of its beauty. It's a very serene place in Tokyo. I would say this is the best place to visit in Tokyo during fall and I heard also during cherry blossom season. This place deserves to be in the top spot.

I wanna go here again. Definitely need more time to visit this garden.
If you decide to go here, please come earlier and maybe the best timing is on weekday, not on a National holiday.

Lovely park and wonderful rose garden. We were there Sunday morning before the crowds of local people came to spend their day. It was a very pretty park and loved walking around the rose garden. We were lucky and were there while everything was still in bloom though we were at the end of the season. I am so glad we took the time to make a side trip to this park.
Lovely Garden. Amazing view. Lovely trees everywhere. I enjoyed walking here specially in the morning, the ambiance is very peaceful and relaxing. Worth to visit.
Scenic. Very scenic, especially with the Shinjuku skyline in the background. Great for a picnic on a sunny day.

Peaceful. It's is a great escape from bustling Tokyo, it's amazing to see so many locals hanging out on the weekend, picnics and games. Peaceful afternoon. Tip: if you can try to go during early April as all the cherry blossoms are in bloom.

Peaceful park for a walk. A lovely place for a relaxing walk to escape the busyness of Tokyo for a while. There is a vast amount of space to walk round and see the Japanese, English and French gardens that are here. You can also enjoy the traditional Japanese tea houses. There is a very small entrance fee but it's worth paying.
Beautiful and Big. There is a lot of different things to see here. It is the perfect place for a picnic. The GreenHouse is my favorite part of the garden.
An amazing garden. We spent 2 hours wandering around, incredible place in the heart of Tokyo. The tree colours were amazing in December and weather perfect.

Peace and Tranquility. I loved this Garden! I wish I would of come earlier so I had time to just sit and relax for much longer and perhaps head in to one of the traditional tea rooms. The manicured trees and tranquil seating around each corner was very nice. The way everything was laid out was like they want every chair or hill to have its own separate view of the natural beauty. Every corner I turned had a way of pulling you into a tunnel before opening up to another serene scene.

Beautiful gardens. Being from Australia where you can find green parks everywhere I wasn't totally impressed, but I must admit that the Japanese Garden where beautiful and had this atmosphere around which makes you feel at peace. I went there at the end of Autumn, but I'm sure that during cherry blossom this park must be astounding.If you have visited all other main attractions in Tokyo and have room for one more this one is a good option.

Peace and beauty in middle of Tokyo. We arrived at 3.30pm and the park closes at 4.30pm (it was winter) so we felt a bit rushed and didn't get to see the whole park. Even in the middle of winter, the garden offered beauty and a break from the bustling city outside. We took snacks and soaked up some sun then wandered around. It costs ¥200 per person to enter and you are provided with a coloured map. We found it a bit hard to navigate using the map. There are posts around the park with reference points that relate directly to the map which made it much easier.

Green oasis with cushiest grass. When the weather is go, especially when it's quiet during low season, take a book to the center grass field of the National Garden, it's the cushiest grass I've ever walked or laid on. Bring a picinic blanket, some food or a good book. Or spend hours people watching.

No need to pay. There are many other places to visit for free that are better than here. That is the beauty of Tokyo, finding the oases amongst the chaos. Don't get me wrong, I love Japanese gardens, but save your dough.
Worth visiting!. For an admission of 200 yen, you get to see splendid sakura trees and people enjoying picnic with their family.
Beautiful . The park is very beautiful in the Autumn season. The trees are colorful with all shades of red and yellow. Beautiful ponds. Take a picnic and a camera.

Beautiful park, great place for a picnic or stroll. It costs 200 to enter, location is very close to Shinjuku station (in the Takashimaya direction / east). I went a little before the best part of autumn but it was still gorgeous. Many families having a chill day out at the landscape garden, and the entire park was dotted with photographers and painters. This was quite cool to me - don't see many people painting in the parks of Singapore.It should take no more than 2 hours for a really laidback stroll around the park and see everything.

Excellent Park seems you go out of this world and enter in other. This is a very big and wonderfull park, where you can escape from the big city, and find peace, not crowded place wonderful views, some wonderful lakes where if you like photography is excellent have also some wild ducks.The only thing is if you don't like to walk much then this park is may not be your choice (~ 4,5km)
Large park to walk around. The park is so beautiful park when the sakura flowers is blossom. Many beautiful pictures can be taken here, and the snack shop offers delicious Japanese snacks as well.

Lovely park. There was a lot of people there when I went but the park was large enough that it didn't feel crowded. I brought some food and had a nice little picnic there. It was quite cool to be sitting amidst the green, surrounded by tall buildings on the periphery.

"Worth a visit even if you have to pay for entrance fee". This is an oasis within the city. The park is big, spacious and so peaceful to spend an afternoon walking, running or just lazing.
We went in December and the colors are changing so you get a mixed of colors/falling leaves. A good place to go for an afternoon with the young or old.

Huge park, lots of flowers, enjoyable walk. Right in the city, easy to get via train/tube.Depending on the weather and season, consider bring a picnic which you can easily prepare just going to the shops and buying food.Lots to see, especially cherry blossom season. But it can get crowded during this time.If you want the place to yourself, go just before cherry blossom, season and you may still see some pink and white leaves/flower trees.

Stunning garden! Must visit during the cherry blossoms. Walking distance from train stations. Closed on Mondays. Entrance fee is 200 yen and it was worth the cost. Garden is beautiful, huge, well maintained and have different types. Trees are beautiful. You can consider bringing a picnic lunch here especially during the cherry blossoms. Alcoholic drinks is prohibited inside the garden. There are also some food stalls inside the garden. A perfect place to relax, walk around and clear your mind. :)

Just as beautiful in winter. I had my reservations about visiting this place during winter (Dec 26, 2015) as I was afraid it would be grey, brown, and desolate looking. Boy, was I wrong! After paying the nominal entrance fee (which is thoroughly worth it), we were greeted with the most beautiful garden ever. The further you walk, the nicer it gets. We especially enjoyed the Japanese garden. It was wow at every corner. So serene and calm. The lakes were so beautifully calm that it made for great photos. I can only imagine how beautiful this place would be during sakura season as well as autumn. If you're looking to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city for a while, this is a great choice. We surprised ourselves even by spending close to 4 hours here, just walking the perimeter of the park. Awesome!

Good way to walk off the jetlag. We arrived in Tokyo at about 5:30am. By the time we had had a light breakfast, travelled into the city and checked into our hotel (in Shinjuku) it was around 10:00. We did not want to do much but decided to take in the garden. A stroll around this neatly kept garden in the bright sunshine was a great antidote to a fairly sleepless redeye flight.

Closed Mondays. I was looking foward to this visit... Looked lovely from outside the gates.Gardens are open 9am to 4.30pm - closed Mondays and if Monday is a holiday then closed the Tuesday following. Looked like this is the maintenance day.Oh well, better luck next time I make it to Tokyo.

Peaceful and beautiful. Great relaxing park in the middle of busy Tokyo.Many gardens to choose from to visit of your own choice.Most important is the walk.I did this visit to the park alone and greatly benefited from the walk and calmness that the park brings.Lots of children running around during school trips and its a joy to see them.

Take Your Time And Enjoy What The Garden Have. I went during late December, and some trees were bare, fields turning dry. But this is one garden that I wish I could sit and spend half my day in. (In Tokyo) The charm of what this garden offered is beyond what i can write. If you love Japanese Culture, then Traditional Japanese Garden will one of the highlight. Stayed only for 2 hours and Garden closes. I wish i could spend more time there.
