Beautiful Garden. We went last Dec in the morning. Very beautiful scenery and we simply love the garden. Dispite winter, we can still see trees with red leaves and some greenery. We love the peaceful surrounding. Its really worth the visit, especially early morning when you hardly has anything to do in Tokyo!

Beautiful grounds in the middle of Busy Tokyo. Highly recommended. Walked through in early November and there was special Chrysanthemum display. Spacious and relaxing. Bring your camera, bring your paints. Each nook and corner is lovely sight.
A beautiful place. A very nice place for taking photo with family. There are also quite a number of nice restaurants inside the park.

Beautiful Gardens. A super tranquil place to walk and enjoy the quiet scenery, a must do in Tokyo. The park is large, has many gardens , a greenhouse, very Japanese style !!! Surrounded by skyscrapers its a great experience..

Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden has sprawling gardens, serene lakes, and a picturesque temple. It is well situated near both public transportation and other major attractions

Beat in spring . Just mark this on your calendar if you are visiting Tokyo in April.
This is simply beautiful in sakura season.

Nice walk!!. Walk around, sit down, enjoy the park! A small fee of ¥200 to enter makes this park much less crowded than others and makes it so there's no drunk picnickers! Beautiful grassy areas, pretty tea house, ducks... This park has lots of great things going for it.

Lovely break away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. A wonderful park right in the middle of Shinjuku. It takes about 10 -15 minutes to walk there and is a lovely respite from all the noise and bustle of Shinjuku and Tokyo in general. There are toilets available and a small shop selling drinks and of course the usual vending machines when you walk in. You could also bring a picnic with you if you so desired. There is a nominal entrance fee. The trees were covered in reds and oranges when we were there and it was beautiful. Be sure to check out the pavilion and little bridges. We easily spent a couple of hours here.

What's all the fuss about?. It might be that I was visiting the garden/ park in late December it is probably not at its peak beauty. In a major city like Tokyo if a park is rated as the # 1 thing to do on trip advisor it better mean something. I was left utterly disappointed - the park grounds were just ordinary. It is nice that in a concrete jungle like Tokyo there is so much green space.
Feed the fish. Landscaped gardens and ponds of fish (carp). Lovely, quiet (rare in Tokyo) spot to rest, refresh, even picnic.

You'll forget you're in the middle of a big city. We spent a few hours walking and relaxing in this lovely park in Tokyo recently. It's 144 acres in size so you can really get lost if you want to. Like many parks in Japan it has ponds, bridges, and a Japanese formal garden. Unusually it also has an English and a French formal garden. Don't expect a recreation of Versailles - this is just a few lines of deciduous trees and a small hedge with surrounding grey gravel but it's a nice contrast. Numerous tea houses are located in the park although most were closed when we visited in December. Large open lawns must be nice in summer but looked very brown and dry in winter. Mostly flat, easy grade walking and 5 minutes from several subway stations. Highlight for me was sitting in winter sunshine by the Middle Pond eating croissants and drinking a takeaway coffee and forgetting I'm in one of the busiest cities in the world.

One of my favorite places in Tokyo. I feel like this is Tokyo's version of NYC's Central Park. I loved it here and could have easily spent a whole day here. There's a lot to see and it's just a nice break from the busy and hectic crowds of Tokyo. If you come with kids, make sure to bring food to have a picnic in one of the many grassy areas. There are convenient stores nearby. It's a lovely place to spend an afternoon.

Nice park in winter - would be amazing in spring or autumn. Lovely peaceful haven to escape the crowds of Tokyo. A couple of nice bridges over the lakes, remnants of autumn leaves, camellias in bloom, and some magnolias about to come out. Would be amazing in spring or autumn.
Very nice treat for plant lovers. This garden has a wonderful "green house" which features well-designed botanical displays of tropical plants and a cactus garden. It was a very nice treat!
It's a walk in the park. Take a couple of hours and visit. Don't spend 100 clams on a tour (what??), but do take time out in one of the traditional tea houses.

Lovely garden in winter . A lovely garden to visit, even on the winter. The greenhouse is a warm haven. But whilst the garden isn't as colorful as it would be in spring, you still get a nice experience.
So beautiful. This is a traditional garden you don't want to miss. It's jaw dropping and great for pictures with a scenic background.

Wonderful escape from the city. Landscaped gardens with lakes and open spaces provided welcome contrast to the craziness that is Shinjuku. While I queried the need for a fee to enter, it was worth every yen.

What a beautiful place. My mistake was actually spending less time here and rushing for frozen yakiniku beef. It's such a beautiful garden in early winter with some red maples remaining. My son was here in April and I cannot imagine the beauty of the place with sakuras. Getting here is much easier with Tokyo subway connection than the JR, walking distance from exits of the Shinjuku-sanchome station.

Stunningly Beautiful and Peaceful Haven. I was in awe at the beauty of this park, a few blocks away from the metro. Costs 200 yen to enter the park. One can walk aimlessly for a few hours and come across ponds, groomed gardens, and colorful trees. Saw trees with leaves of green, yellow, red and orange - similar to the fall season in the states, along with cherry blossoms.

Great garden with exotic scenes. very nice garden with thousands of trees, and some pools which added depth to the great scenes. Went there while the autumn leafs turn red and is so beautiful ! Noticed that the garden got a sakura area, and no doubt it will be a very nice scene as well in sakura-period.

Peaceful stroll with beautiful scenery. My wife and I had a very relaxing walk through the gardens. While it was in winter the colours of the gardens were still vibrant with yellows, oranges and reds to be seen. We took some great photos! I would highly recommend it for anyone who loves the outdoors.

Lovely Garden in the City. We went to the garden to catch a glimpse of the late autumn leaves and indeed the colours of autumn in the garden is beautiful. My young children run around in the fields while hub and I stroll and enjoy the surrounding quiet atmosphere. The nearest subway station is Shinjuku and it takes 20mins to walk to the garden, if you know the right direction to walk. Just walk in the direction of Takashimaya Time Square and ask people along the way. The modern Japanese could speak some basic English and you won't be lost. There is a small admission to pay, children under 3 is free. It is definitely worth a visit if you are in Tokyo Shinjuku.
Good place to feel the scent of Japan. Good to walk around. So peaceful and calm. Located center of Shinjuku, so gdod place to take rest from the crowdy urban area.

Perhaps more beautiful in autumn or winter. We went at the end of Spring and the garden was all shades of green. Beautifully trained trees and manicured gardens with the occasional pavilions was a nice retreat from bustling Shinjuku. There were seasonal flower shows when we were there.

Best Place to see Cherry Blossoms!! . Enjoyed every minute spent in this garden!! A lot of Cherry Blossoms and when all the trees are in bloom... The garden looks so beautiful!! It doesn't feel crowded coz the garden is huge!!!

Beautiful Park in the center Tokyo. This place is one of the main attractions for visitors of the capital. I'm living very close to this place ( actually the fence is just less than 100 m from my home) which is about 400 m from/to the Okido gate) I do visit Shinjuku Gyoen several times in spring (beautiful cherry blossoms) and in autumn when the leaves turn red (Asian maple trees) or yellow (ginkgo trees). The Gyoen offers many sights, such as small lakes with turtles, thousands of trees, an English garden and many more attractions. I'm sure Shinjuku Gyoen will also attract many visitors during the 2020 Olympics. There is only one thing that I do not like.... The park is closed on Mondays and even the outer way -which is actually outside the park area - is closed. This is very 'provincial' in my eyes and unworthy of a modern tourist friendly city. Too often have I seen tourists standing frustrated and grumbling in front of the closed gate on Mondays. Something the bureaucrats of the Tokyo admin should think about especially in view of the Olympic games..
Nice autumn leaves. Beautiful autumn foliage and well worth a visit, but not really an escape from the crowds. There were heaps of people taking photos. ¥200 yen admission fee

Beautiful Gardens. A great place to enjoy nature, photography, isolate from the busy city just a few meters away from the traffic and noise. Extremely well maintained. Really enjoyed! Could have spent a full day there, but just an hour can be extremely refreshing.

Dense greenery in the midst of a busy Tokyo. This place has to be a compulsory listing among-st places to see in Tokyo. Right at the heart of the busy Tokyo, this is an oasis of green. Be prepared for a kilometer of a walk to the beautiful shrine. The walk is pleasant almost jungle like; with verdant greenery all around. Early mornings make for a great outing, as was in my case.

Easy to get to. I caught the train here early one morning and had no trouble finding the garden. When I say early I mean 10am. Tokyo wakes late!There is a small admission fee of a few dollars, but it's a lovely garden and well worth it.Unfortunately there were no maps in English, but as usual, I found a very helpful Japanese man who gave me an overview. He ran the cafe in the middle of the park. I wasn't even a customer, and he still gladly helped me.The garden isn't too big, and I walked around and saw everything in about an hour. The greenhouse wasn't very interesting at all, but the Japanese gardens with all the maple tree leaves in red were beautiful. All against a backdrop of the Tokyo city skyline.
Beautiful Gardeb. Visited this national garden on 15 Dec and spent 3 hours in the garden. Beautiful and tranquil. Great place to visit if you love nature.

Could easily spend the whole day here . Shinjuku gyoen national garden was so big that we could've easily spent the whole day here. Unfortunately, we didn't have the time so we only saw parts of it. I would've liked to explore this place more. It's just pretty and peaceful in the midst of a busy city. Definitely a recommended place to see!

Escape the madness. Perfect escape for Jetlagged family trip. We explored all of the gardens and did a traditional tea ceremony- our kids really enjoyed it. Really nice and cool compared to the heat of the city in July.

Nice walk all year round. In April you can enjoy the sakuras, come early though be cause it gets crowded fast - take a picnic and sit in the shade of the trees with friends, it's great! Alcohol is not permitted on the premises, though, so no beers or sake in the hamper!

I have never seen anything more beautiful. When I first decided to go the the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden, I felt apprehensive. I wasn't sure what to expect and I was afraid that their wouldn't be any cherry blossoms. This was not the case. I have never seen anything like this garden. It was beautiful, everything was planned perfectly. I am not normally a person that enjoys looking at a garden for multiple hours, but this was different. The garden was so peaceful and I left feeling like I was able to see one of the most attractive aspects of Japanese culture. I recommend this to anyone especially during cherry blossom season.

Great at the right times. Shinjuku park was given to the citizens of Tokyo by the emperor, probably Meiji but I am not certain. In a city jamb packed with buildings it is a very pleasant green space. Nothing outstanding except in certain seasons. The Cherry Blossoms in April are excellent, not the best in the city but very, very good. The chrysanthemum exhibit in October is stunning, Check the calendar for the dates it normally lasts about 2 weeks. The fall leaves come late in the year as Tokyo is a warm micro-climate due to all the buildings and people so you can see momiji there much later than in the outskirts of the city.Other than these three things there is little that I would go out of my way to see unless you are looking for green grass, trees, flowers, and a degree of quiet in a city that is sorely lacking in all four.

Out and about with the rest of Tokyo. This is a great park to get out and enjoy a peaceful moment in the heart of super busy Tokyo. Wide open fields, traditional Japanese gardens and even a French style garden will all be found here. Grab a bento box from a local food store and have a picnic on the grass or on a bench. Beverages are available from vending machines as well.You will see many Tokyo-ites out enjoying the park as well!

Amazing collection of orchids in the Greenhouse. It's not free! Admission fee is Yen200 per adult but worth the price though. Take note of the closing time.For orchid lovers, do visit the Greenhouse. There is a fantastic collection of orchids,.... many of which I have never seen before. Roses too.We were lucky to see 2 Sakura (I think) trees in full bloom..... beautiful. If you need space for your kids to run around.... this is it !

Beautiful Garden, Peacefull. We stumble into this garden on our last day in Tokyo. It was a great place to unwind our trip. It required 200 Yen for admission but well worth it. Once you are in, you feel like you are away from the busy city life which was just at other side of the gate. You will have a peaceful feeling while strolling around the park. There are many photographers in the park taking pictures, families having picnics or people just walking & enjoying the garden. It was a great feeling.
Beautiful in Autumn. We were here in December and this place was in full autumn colour, only a few dollars to enter, beautiful gardens
Beautiful & Relaxing. . If you stay in Shinjiku area. Must visit this garden. Middle of the busy city' escape for quite and relaxing atmosphere.

The garden. The name said Garden, more like a park, well organised with a green house and several themed sub-gardens. We're here for the Japanese Garden, it's beautiful.Entrance fee applied, do ask for an English guide. It close earlier at 4.30 pm, so plan well. Lovely place for picnic, so grab some food on way here, enjoy the breeze and the lovely blue sky instead of 'fighting' for seats or foods at the crowded cafe.

Absolutely beautiful. Our family enjoyed our morning stroll through the gardens. Even in the rain it was a beautiful place to visit. So many amazing plants, trees & colours, quite spectacular. Kids loved the greenhouse and seeing the fish in the ponds. Such an amazing space in the middle of a very busy city. Highly recommend. Would love to visit again in Spring.

Need to observe time of the year before visit. The national garden consists of Japanese garden , English garden and French garden .For the right time of the year - cherry blossom for spring , chrysanthemum for November , roses in the French formal garden in summer . Admission is only 200 yen for adult and it is Walking distance from Shinjuku- gyoenmae station .If you find this review helpful, please vote for me.

Beautiful autumn colours. We came here to see the autumn colours of the trees, as a late onset of autumn in Japan meant they were still at their peak in December. And a further bizarre twist to the climate meant that on 11th December 2015 it was a glorious afternoon with a cloud-free sky driving the temperature up to 22 C. So we had the colours and scents of autumn, but the feel of a summer's day.The Japanese love their autumn leaves, and they were all photographing them; initially to our bemusement, but we just had to join in and take snaps of the reds, oranges and yellows against the blue sky. To an Englishman, paying to enter a public park seems strange, but 200 yen was worth the experience.BTW the 'rest area' next to the Shinjuku Gate serves amazing vanilla soft ice cream cones

Great To Spent a full day in the Autumn in this Garden. Love the Autumn Golden Yellow trees around in this garden. It was such nice weather when we were there that I really do not want to get out of this park/garden after 3 hours. Though there is a small fees of 200Yen for each entry.I think it is worth. Remember to ask the Ranger at the Entrance for the English version mapNext we walk and saw the green house which at that time house a variety of specialty orchids and tropical plants ( which is common for me as Singaporean ) but special for the local and Japanese. There was a large banana plant in that green house with a special type of Banana with red skin. The local Japanese was amazed by this as I just walked by. So was the Hibiscus Plant and flower which is common in Singapore and Malaysia. The best park was the park. I love the yellow leaves and the trees. The families with children, the youngsters with their friend, an Indonesia family with the girl in Kimono ( dressed up for the Photo shoots ) were a few of the noticeable crowd around me. We found an empty place, like the locals, sat down and enjoy the sun ( warm and the cool late Autumn breeze). The Air as so fresh that I felt so refreshed and my mind cleared completely after a few very conscious breathing in and exhaling out exercises. Love the part that everyone mind their own business and speak softly- unlike the crude and loud audience shouting around the field. ( except for one occasion where a C national shouted across the field for her daughter and grandson) The pansy flowers which is common in Japan was my favorite. I took many pictures of these.Further round the other side of the garden is a pond where the ducks are swimming leisurely,waiting to be fed by the strangers. The tea place is so crowded that we decided to give this place a miss. I will definitely like to come again in late Spring or Autumn once more.

Nice Walk in the middle of the city. The park is not far from metro station Shinjuku.Admission fee 200 Yuen .The garden is not big , focus mainly on the Japanese garden , where they plant plants with different colors , fish inside the reservoir ( sorry it is a small lake create inside the garden and small , so I consider it as a reservoir ) People seems enjoy , lots of photographers and some artists throughout the garden .Lots of rest rooms throughout the garden and small variety store selling drinks .It is an attraction for 1- 1 1/2 hours .

Great Garden (Park). We enjoyed our visit here as it was a beautiful garden. We especially liked the Japanese Traditional Garden with its flowers, ponds, and traditional style shaped Japanese trees. It is a wonderful atmosphere and would definitely recommend a visit if you happen to be in Tokyo for a few days.
Beautiful Japanese Gardens. We went to see the Japanese gardens, but I'm sure the French and English gardens are lovely too. Beautiful spot for photos.

Beautiful even without Cherry Blossoms. I've been to this park during the early part of Cherry Blossoms last year and it was beautiful however it also gets crowded because of all the tourists. So I actually quite prefer enjoying a walk, a run or eating breakfast during early mornings on "non peak" seasons. It's easy to soak in the surroundings that way. If you're staying nearby, bring a rubber shoes because you never know when you feel like going for a run.

Peace in the middle of maddening Tokyo. We went here around 9am one morning. There were few people and it was very peaceful. We walked around the Japanese garden section and then stopped to have tea at the Traditional Japanese Tea house. The tea was served with a small sweet which complemented the tea very well. However, for 700yen we thought this was expensive. Go here if you want some time off from all the madness in Tokyo!
Oasis on a hot day. This garden is amazing and well worth a visit. The flowers and trees in Autumn are beautiful and so colorful. Ensure that you take your time and get lost in this garden's beauty.
lovely park!. This park is beautiful, a big pond with fish, a tea house, huge trees make a lovely afternoon walk. Entrance is cheap and the park is really clean.
Beautiful park in the middle of Shinjuku area. Great place to enjoy Japanese gardens with history. Perfect for family to enjoy peace, photography, Japanese style landscape, and time with family
Peaceful . Interesting peaceful garden with many different types of gardens. Many families here and a small entrance fee. Would recommend if you wanted to go for a relaxing stroll.

Beautiful place.. totally peaceful. This is a very peaceful place, vast grounds and beautifully manicured trees and plants. Even though the skies were cloudy, we had a great time there, exploring the grounds

Excellent!. We absolutely LOVED the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. We went on a day when it was drizzling with rain, but this added to the experience. It reminded me of Central Park in New York, it is like a little oasis in the middle of a big exciting city. The gardens are immaculate and gorgeous and you can spend a lot of time wandering around and exploring. A definite must for anyone traveling to Shinjuku!

A haven of peace and tranquility at the heart of one of the world's busiest cities.. We visited the park in late Autumn and the foliage colours were stunning. We were also fortunate enough to visit whilst the chrysanthemum exhibition was being staged and the flowers were beautiful. We even managed to have a snack lunch sitting outside on a cafe terrace in the warm sunshine overlooking the gardens and a lake.
Fantastic. Can be reached by metro, there are many gates, one of them is closed, very quite and nice , can be hot in August, vending machines available.

Wonderful gardens. November was not the best to visit but this was still a fine afternoon spent in the capital's best garden attraction. It was easy to access on the Metro and very cheap to enter. The indoor section was fascinating and outside it was a pleasure to walk so far among so many different plants and flowers.The only down side was the catering, the various little cafes were not up to standard for a national garden. There was very little on offer and what we did find was run in the amusing style of Julie Walters 1980s sitcom tea shop in Acorn Antiques! But to be fair that was our only food and drink disappointment in two weeks in Japan.

Ms. A must if you are in the vicinity. Tranquil serene and restful. Difficult to imagine such a place amidst the bustle and hustle of Tokyo. I dont think it matters which season you visit. I was here in Autumn and the colours were amazing. Plan to stay at least 2 hrs. Maybe take a packed lunch
Beautiful park in the city. Pack some food and drinks for a picnic in the park of weather permits. Beautiful autumn foliage in november and december. Entry fees apply.
Beautiful Gardens. We enjoyed exploring the gardens It was beautiful! Prepare to spend a couple of hours walking and exploring.

Relaxation points. The one thing I love about Gyoen National is not only the expansiveness of the garden, but the fact that as you walk around, you lose yourself in its serenity. Then, you'll get to certain points of the part where you'll look up, and realize, you are in the middle of Tokyo, one of the most populated Metropolitan areas in the world. Definitely worth a look
Simply stunning. Visited in October, and would love to go back in spring when the blossom is out.Really peaceful and beautiful. Worth the visit!

Lovely park. Beautiful park for a lazy days wonder. The shrine was quite spectacular as well. The autumn meant the trees leaves were changing which added to the beauty. Very peaceful condsidering the closeness to the city, easily accessible via public transport, nice way to spend s few hours.

Ambience awaits at the Sinjuku Gate. This 143 acre park was once the former estate of the & residence of the Naito family from the Edo period.There are 3 distinct features to the parks: the Japanese Garden, featuring its large ponds, quaint bridges and manicured shrubs; the French Garden, with its symmetrical lawns & delicate blooms; and the English garden, showcasing its landscaped grounds & colourful plants.During Hanami season (cherry blossom festival) this is the best place to view over 400 somei yoshino blossoming trees. The Cosplay adds to the thrill and excitement of a day escaping the city to leisurely stroll in the ambience of the gardens.
Beautiful . Amazing gardens. Well worth it. Take some lunch and relax on the grass.The autumn leaves were still on the trees at the very end of November.
Beautiful park!. Go early in the AM to beat the crowds and stroll the beautifully manicured trees. It's a small and manageable site worth seeing.

Beautiful open spaces dne up differently and well done greenhouse. took a walk around the garden in 2 hours going from one landscape to the next in the July heat. Recommended if you like nature and have time to experience it in Tokyo
Peace and Tranquility. Spent a morning wandering through these beautiful gardens; you wouldn't believe you were right in the middle of Tokyo! Small entrance fee was worth the cost.

Great getaway from the hustle and bustle of shinjuku city. Simply beautiful, cant belive that they have such a nice garden landscape in the middle of the busy city. We entered the garden via Sendagaya gate, walk one round and exit via Shinjuku gate. The view is just amazing. I could spend hours in there. A plus point when we visited is that there's a chrysanthemum exhibition.

Nice walk, a break from shopping. Tokyo is full of shopping so this can be a good break from shopping. Nice scenery and good for photography enthusiasts. It is in Shinjuku and walkable from Shinjuku hotels. Entry fee is 200 yen.

Such a relaxing place. We went on our last day in Tokyo and it was one of the best decisions because it was such a relaxing place.
Saw many locals picnicking there and washed we brought food for the same purpose.
Spend the day. Spend the day in the park. Nice refuge right in the middle of the city. We went in winter so colors were not great but I bet it would be beautiful in summer.
Peaceful, beautiful. Got there when it opens in the morning. I had a nice, peaceful walk through the gardens seeing the pretty tree colours.

Relaxing in the middle of chaos. Shinjuku is chaotic to say the least. The bright lights and constant foot traffic can be dizzying, luckily gyoen national park is near to save the day. This huge park offers sanctuary away from the madness. Even in late November there were still flowers. The green house is especially nice with a huge collection of flowers. You can also partake in traditional Japanese tea or just stroll along the many beautiful paths. Come here to relax if you're getting too overwhelmed by shinjuku.

Absolutely beautiful!. A really beautiful garden to visit - there are so many spots where you can sit and relax to enjoy the beautiful scenery! Bring a good book to read and make a day of it! I especially like the section with the Japanese Garden - it was definitely an interesting experience to be in the midst of beatiful gardens, surrounded by tall buildings on the outside! Beware of the fact that the gates close at 4:30, and also that it is not open on Mondays! :) Cost 200 Yen, you buy tickets from the machine out front! To get there, I took the Marunouchi Line (Red line), and got off at Shinjuku Gyeoemmae Station (M10). I exited using Exit 2 - when I came out the exit, I turned left and crossed over to the other side of the road! After walking left for about 5 minutes, it was on the right! You can't miss it, because suddenly a lot of trees pop up with a gate surrounding the premises! :) Enjoy!

Nice park, especially on weekends. It was the first sight I have visited in Tokyo and it gave me the feeling of being not in such a rushing metropolis as Tokyo actually is. On a Sunday there is plenty to do and see.

Fresh air, beautiful color!. I went here in Autumn, so the color of the trees are AMAZING!!I really love the bench under the trees, wish that I brought a book or bento. Absolutely will go here again when I'm in Tokyo.

Great garden, 2nd visit in a different season, autumn looks amazing. Definitely a must do while in Tokyo/Shinjuku. Hard to imagine a better oasis in the middle of Tokyo!Autumn colours were amazing, even better if not just as good as my last visit to see the plum tree blooming!For 200 yen, it is a steal, spend at least 1hr here and enjoy the peace!

The Gardens of Delight. A very pleasant way to spend a day in Tokyo when shopping and other activities have worn you down. Taking the time to walk these wonderful gardens not only restores your energy levels it also gives you a chance to reflect on a beautiful, busy city.

Beautiful gardens, practically next door to Tokyu Stay Shinjuku. I have titled it weirdly, to remind myself that when I am prepared to travel overseas again, I want to be staying in Tokyu Stay Shinjuku long-term so that I can take walks in this beautiful Shinjuku Gyoen gardens everyday. On this trip to Japan we visited many gardens; so much so that I can't remember what I saw in each garden. I just remember thinking, for future long-term stay, it won't be Hong Kong anymore, but Japan Tokyu Stay Shinjuku for daily walks in Shinjuku Gyoen, AND Lake Villa Kawaguchiko for walks around Lake Kawaguchiko.

What a lovely park it is...!!! Go on a sunny day!. This park is so lovely to stroll about.You can even see the red trees how they chance colors. There is even a little typical japanese house, where you can buy a ticket outside and visit it. The price in cludes a green tea or macha tea, and a mochi cake home made.The lady was very pleasant to talk to and friendly. The park is huge and you need at least a good couple of hours to see its main things, as ponds, little bridges, the ying yang, etc... Take one afternoon before dinner time, you will enjoy itThis park is in the centre of the city and one of the most well known parks in the area. It is surrounded by restaurants outside the park and caffee places. So no need to bring your own, unless you want it. Must visit it!I hope this helpedDanXX

Beautiful respite from city. This is a lovely place to go to if you want to have a bit of quiet from the loud hustle and bustle of the city. Pack a quick lunch and go enjoy the serenity that this beautiful garden offers.

Beautiful gardens. I loved our very brief visit to the gardens. We only got the chance to see a very small percentage of it as it is so huge, but the Japanese gardens are very beautiful and relaxing. A great place for a walk on a nice day. The juxtaposition of the peaceful greenery with the city skyscrapers as a backdrop is stunning. Definitely recommend.

Beautiful Japanese Garden. Very beautiful like every thing in Japan, walking distance from Shinjuku, unlike crazy Tokyo very calm and peaceful, I spent there 3 hours with my kid and we really loved that place, 3 hours is good for this place and can be a nice relax spot.Totally worth it.

Peaceful getaway!. I went to the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden on my first day in Shinjuku and loved it. The garden was picturesque and was amazing to spend time here and being one with nature. The leaves were browning and there are some beautiful lakes and bridges . If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle, look no further. There is an entry fee but it is very minimal!
Shinjuku- Lively and fun!. Lively area, good shopping, excellent transport links.Plenty of good restaurants. Easy for travel, and buses direct to airport.

Chrysanthemums and changing leaves in a peaceful oasis. . Well worth the minimal entry fee, this relatively large garden is gorgeous, with a range of garden types beautifully landscaped. We enjoyed the Taiwanese pavilion, the seasonal chrysanthemum displays and the western and eastern gardens. My 6 yr old son loved it here so much he asked to come back again. There are a number of eateries and tea places dotted around in mostly traditional style buildings. Nothing fancy but still pleasant for refreshments. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful!. A great place to go when you need a break from the city. Beautiful Japanese Garden & French Garden .
Large open green space. Beautiful park for family with small children. Lovely place for sakura blossom viewing in April and a great place to relax.
Gorgeous place to watch the leaves change colors. Sprawling park with many different types of gardens. Very relaxing and picturesque. An enjoyable way to spend the afternoon and escape the bustle.

Big gorgeous garden. Great for a wander around. Various different themed areas. The japanese pond was beautiful, and the English style lawns a lovely place to relax.
and all so close to the busy excitement of shinjuku

Great place to relax and spend the day. I traveled here frequently on weekends as I was staying nearby in Nishi-shinjuku. This is a huge park with multiple styles of gardens, and one of the best maintained Japanese gardens. Do travel here during the fall season to view the change of colors.
Nice place. A surprising quiet oasis in the middle of the bustling city...i remember it is quite cheap to go inside as well...i think 200JPY...a nice place to go and relax...recommend for sure
Beautiful . Oxygen area in the middle of the noisy modern Shinjuku. You are looking for silence, peace, then no hesitation go to this park. You will also enjoy the Tea Ceremony.

Breathtaking Park. I could have spent all day here! This park is beautiful and peaceful, which is especially amazing since it's located in the center of a super busy city. Definitely make time to just hang out here and walk around. It was my favorite part of Tokyo.
Cherry Blossom. Beautiful and peaceful park. The park has many different types of cherry blossom and walking though it you see so many colours. It is a must for cherry blossom watching!
Great stroll in the park. Visit the Japanese garden for a real treat. Great in the autumn at falling leaves times. Good greenhouse as well which includes plants from South Japan.

An Oasis of peace in the megalopolis. This was so nice to go to. There's some exquisitely crafted gardens, the layout is sublime, there's a really cute teahouse to visit that's not too expensive and its just a really lovely experience to wander round the gardens for the price of 200 Yen.

Exquisite . At any time of the year, during all four seasons, this park holds your attention. Having visited during Spring and Autumn I can say you'll enjoy strolling the pathways, running for exercise or just sitting to watch the people. Access is easy and worth the 200¥.

Beautiful Green Space in busy Tokyo. Only 200 yen entrance fee--a bargain for this wonderful space where one could spend hours wandering the various gardens. I spent most of my time in the Japanese gardens, which are stunning, with the backdrop of the city buildings as a reminder of how needed a respite like this is.I went right at 9am on a weekday, and waited with a few folks for the gates to open. Joggers, walkers, wanderers, photographers, tourists, city residents, groups of school children all seemed to enjoy this spot, but I never had trouble finding a tranquil quiet spot on my own.
A beautiful garden in the City. It was beautiful and quiet during the visit. Although not many people were there, its very peaceful and soothing.

A calm oasis in Busy Shinjuku. If you're looking for a great escape from the city, this park/garden is a great place to visit. There are several style of gardens (Japanese, French, English), along with a beautiful conservatory and tea house.

Multi-faceted gardens. A bit like Kew, with a large tropical green house and miniature forests. The street traffic is quite muted and you can hear birds tweeting, more than in the countryside I thought

Quiet Respite in busy city. This is a nice, gated park right in the city, so you can only get into when it is open. There are British,French and Japanese gardens here. When I was there, the chrysanthemums were on display. It is very relaxing place to be.
Nice park. Very nice park to walk around in. Nice varm weather in the middle of November and also a chrysantemum display.

Ohh!!! Simply LOVELY!!!. Paid 200 YEN per person and get away from the most busy city in the world. Take your time to walk around the garden. Don't missed out on the Japanese garden section.All in all, just go! Rest your mind for a couple of hours. Its worth it. :)

best park i ever visited during cherry blossom. went there during cherry blossom season(early april). this my favorite park to visit during the day. this place having lots n lots cherry trees. Best time is when the wind blow the petal... feels magical. if you only have one chance to visit park during your stay, consider this place as must visit.they have stall selling snack as well so dont bother to carry yourself if it is a hassle. love the Miso soup there

A haven of quiet in a mad mad city.. Enjoyed several hours walking through the gardens, a welcome respite from the madness of the city streets, throngs of people, cars and all the associated noise that goes with. Such a contrast and really quite peaceful to stroll through or sit and just enjoy the views. Several spots to grab a bite or a drink, plus a large greenhouse area to walk through. Entry fee is minimal at around 200 yen (approx.). Worth a visit to relax and regain a little calm in your day.

A Beautiful Afternoon. This is a beautiful garden with many places to sit and take in the quiet surroundings. Walk as much or as little as you wish. There will always be beautiful things to see. Be sure to check beforehand to see if it's open on the day you wish to visit.
Beautiful. What a beautiful garden. The chrysanthemum flower displays were gorgeous. I had no idea flowers could be trained to grow a certain way. It is quite impressive!

想像以上に自然豊かな公園でした : it has so rich nature in tokyo. 最寄りの鉄道の駅が５個以上有る便利な場所にあります。以前友人の子供の誕生日会をやった場所なのですが、思いの外自然豊かな場所でした。広い庭で、探せば木陰も有り、レジャーシートを広げてゆっくりみんなで楽しむのにいい場所でしたThe park has many train stations around it. So, it is easy to go the park. We made birthday party for our friends' daughter with out alcohol. It is good spot to make such party with out alcohol. And, you can easy to find shade of trees in a park. So, you can enjoy a day, if you bring small leisure seats.
Best view. Best view in gyoen shinjuku park... you can relaxing here or have a lunch at the grass... the air so fresh and also you will see a beautiful flower n view in here.. nice n recommended

Wonderful place -- gardens, ponds, greenhouse.. We visited these gardens twice. They are a very large peaceful area in a busy city. The greenhouse offers a wide variety of plants. We were fortunate enough to visit during the chrysanthemum festival -- varieties I had never seen before, and some were pruned to cascade from a single stem. The restaurant is a welcome and friendly stop, serving simple meals.
Lovely gardens. it was a surprise to see such a large garden area in the middle of the city. Within walking distance from central Shinjuku.

Absolutely stunning. A tranquil getaway in the middle of Tokyo, Shinjuku Gyoen is a must-see. We went on the weekend, but it certainly didn't feel crowded. The Japanese gardens are lovely and the tea house was a highlight. It costs 200y to enter and there are automated ticket machines with English options at the gates. Easy to wander through the garden to get from Shinjuku to Harajuku/Shibuya.

Nice experience. This garden located at very busy area, however once you get in, all you can feel is relax and comfortable.If you have time,go to the tea house and with small price, you can enjoy the sweet and green tea

Peaceful garden away from the crowds. One of my favorite place in Tokyo! Definitely you should visit if you need a calm peaceful place away from the crowds in Shinjuku. There's a beautiful Japanese garden and cherry trees as well. Good place for picnic and chilling out but the garden doesn't allow to drink alcohol for Hanami and close at 4pm.

Beautiful. We visited the gardens on two days as we were staying nearby. The Japanese garden in particular is exceptionally lovely. There are many local people having picnics and family gatherings and there was a large yoga group practising when we were there. In autumn there were some nice colours of the season but it must be beautiful in blossom season also.
Quiet oasis in Tokyo. Beautiful gardens in the crazy area of shinjuku. Despite it being a Sunday it was quiet and just a lovely Japanese garden. Only around 200yen to enter and well worth it.

Worth the entrance fee. There was an exhibition of chrysanthemums all over the park.
The park is also divided in the three different schools of garden designing (French, english, and Japanese).

Oasis amidts the concrete jungle. As an avid runner- Shinjuku streets are a tough place to navigate in the morning- Between drunken patrons still wobbling or lying in th sidewalks to delivery guys with their hand trucks- This place is an oasis- nice green pathways- tranquil gardens- nice and quiet in the middle of bustling Shinjuku- One drawback is it opens late at 9am and has a 200 yen entrance fee..
Chill out in the heart of Tokyo. This garden is a short walk from Shinjuku station. It has restaurant and Kiosk facilities. It is a pleasant place to spend a few hours.
Solitude in the city centre. An amazingly quiet and peaceful garden in the centre of Tokyo. Beautifully presented and a wonderful photo opportunity.
Pretty and Interesting. Lovely gardens with traditional Japanese garden, ponds, teahouse, and English and French gardens as well.

Sunday in the gardens. The Shinjuku Gyoen Gardens are beautiful. We only walked the Japanese garden as time did not allow us to see the whole gardens. However the Japanese gardens were beautiful. Being a Sunday it was full of picnickers which added to the atmospher. It was easy to get to on the We bus circuit.

An Oasis in the midst of the hustle and bustle. It was fascinating to see this park located in the midst of all the hustle and bustle around. It was even better to see people using it i.e taking in the sights, just relaxing or having a picnic. There were lots of people around but you don't feel crowded. I would say pass on any organized tours - you can do this one on your own without any hassles.

Beautiful and peaceful. If you fancy a break from the crazyness of Shinjuku, I recommend this park. It is so peaceful and absolutely gorgeous. There was a small fee to go in (I think maybe 500yen) but it is completely worth it.

Beautiful and lovely. This park is located in city center, so green and beautiful. So many people, families are having rest on the lawns. We lied down on the lawn and had great time having rest, it was our last afternoon time of our 8 days Tokyo trip this time. It's better come here on sunny day and on holiday. They prepared wheel chair, anybody can use it free inside park. There is a votanical garden for tropical plants, Japanese garden, European garden, and big beautiful lake. Walk along the path, sit, lie down - enjoyed like in heaven.

Beautiful and varied. This splendid park contains a small formal French garden with plane-tree baby avenues à la Versailles, a large Japanese garden and an enchanting mini-forest. A lovely place to unwind.

Time well spent. For foreign visitors it is advisable to be protected by an insect repellent as on arrival at the main gates you are informed of the threat from mosquitos.You can also be prepared to spend many happy and interesting hours just walking around the grounds which feature a Traditional Japanese Garden( which we had found difficult to locate in Tokyo),a landscaped English Garden and a French Formal Garden.We visited on a Sunday and found that it was very popular with the locals although despite the numbers they are not intrusive and there is still lots of space and quiet areas.There are many public conveniences and a central Restaraunt which seemed to specialise in a Japanese Curry Special Offer Dinner.

Pleasant and relaxing park, not a tourist trap. Pleasant break from the street noise. Very relaxing park to wander around in. There are tourist here but most visitors are Japanese. Make sure you visit the various structures in the park and that you are not in the mindset of just ticking it of your list.
Beautiful Garden!. A great place to have a walk in the park and escape from the city area.Fantastic traditional garden and the pond is awesome with alot of koi fishes.Worth visiting.

Relaxing area within the busy city!. A very nice garden with some old style tea houses and good walking space.Its surprising to know that this area is within a large city like Tokyo. There are a few ponds around and local painters passing the day in the garden.It closes quite early (4:30) and has an entry fee of 200 yen (£1 approx)
Lovely garden . Worth spending a few hours walking around this garden. It is away from the crowds and has a stunning tea house and greenhouse. Located close to shinjuku.

Good visit for half day. It was a good trip to the park. There were displays of plants and description was mentioned for most of the displays. 5-6 hours is good for this place and can be a nice picnic spot.

Large, relaxing and nice garden in a busy suburb. This garden is large, quiet and relaxing to walk around, sitting by a pond or having a picnic. There are themed gardens like Japanese traditional garden, French garden and also a green house with nice collection of plants.The garden is accessible by walking from JR Shinjuku station.

Nice, calm gardens, interesting features. we spent a morning post flight in the park, it was tranquil in a fast pace city. It was a little under whelming though but perhaps I have been spoilt by parks in London. The carp were impressive
Just ok. Move well kept and well maintained gardens basically a mini Central Park in the centre of the city surrounded by high rise buildings peacefull and well laid out but didn't get excited

Beautiful beautiful and peaceful garden. Beautiful beautiful and peaceful garden next to one of the most busy centers of Tokyo few hundred meters from Shunjuku station, you have to pay a small entrance fee (so there fore you have closing times), spotless clean, bring a blanket and just relax in the sun. With or without Sakura a beautiful place in Tokyo

Simply beautiful!. Shinjuku Gyoen is a fantastic place to have a quiet walk. The scenery is beautiful and very well-maintained. The backdrop consisting of Shinjuku high-rises makes that this beats NYC's Central Park for me.

Beautifull Sakura Garden. This garden look a paradise when Sakura growing.. Make me so relax with beautiful scenery.. An every corner take a shoot, always get perfect photo.. One of the places that should be visited if we go to Tokyo..
Very relaxing. This is a great place to rest for lunch if the hustle and bustle of the city gets too much for you. Beautiful place.

Check the closing time. I didn't check the closing time and ended up having only an hour to enjoy the park. I didn't get to see the greenhouse. Apart from quaint tea houses, this park doesn't seem to offer much. For me, the 200 yen entrance seemed a waste of money.

Best during Sakura. Very close to our hotel, we visited in autum and it's really nice with all the red and brown colors, but this park is really at it's best during the cherry blossom season, aka Sakura. Besides, on that time, on top of everything you can enjoy at the park, you will stroll by the famous Hanani "blue-sheet" celebratiions.

Peaceful Place to Enjoy Nature. To get in, you have to pay a small price but it is definitely worth it. The place is really peaceful, there are not much people and it's a great place to walk around in and take pictures. If you do not feel like walking, you can always just sit down wherever; there are benches if you don't like sitting on the grass and if there are a few vending machines and a store in case you get thirsty or hungry.I would recommend visiting during the spring because there are a lot of cherry blossoms at around this time. Definitely bring a camera, especially if you like to take a lot of pictures. If you wish, you can also picnic inside although I've never tried it. If you are coming from Shibuya, you can easily walk to this area. We didn't take up much time in the area though, just an hour probably but it was nonetheless a worth-it visit.
a garden for the gods. it must have been designed by a mathematician, so many circles and finement, the small fern trees typical of Asian flora, beautiful cared for.a very typically tea-house.
Great place to chill. I stayed in a hotel close to Shinjuku Gyoen and it was a great place to chill out.I have been to Shinjuku Gyoen before and always enjoy going back there.
Peaceful. Ticket only 200 yen. Really nice place for family with kids. This is a beautiful large garden. If you like natural beauty come here. Totally worth it.

Great Japanese Gardens. If you spent so much time walking around Tokyo, taking time to experience this place is a great way to cap your visit of the city. There are different kinds of gardens, but to me, the Japanese garden is the best. The kids felt so free here, running around and enjoying nature. It was a great way to escape the urban jungles that they're used to when travelling. If you want peace and quiet, visit this wonderful garden.
Serene. Beautiful park. Well worth your time. The Japanese style area was lovely but the French and English areas weren't terribly impressive.
Must see in Shinjuku. Great park with a variety of gardens in close proximity to Shinjuku Station and the associated shopping centres

Nice Walk in the Park. Great park to come with a family to play or for a picnic as there is lots of open space. Its a nice walk but other then that there isnt much to see, unless you are there when the cherry blossoms are blooming. But again not much to do...

Nice place to spend an afternoon. We went there like if we were another japanese family on a sunday afternoon. Very familiar place, to stroll, take a break from the busy city, to relax by the lake or lay down on the grass. You pay an entrance but it is like 2€ or less and they give you a map as well,so it is no expensive.Ideal as well for a picnic on the grass.The greenhouse had some amazing flowers.I really enjoyed the break,the familiar atmosphere, that everything was so green and clean.
A great walk in the park. A great walk in the park. If you are staying in the Shinjuku area then spend a morning walking through this park. There is a small entry fee but worth it.

Best park for me in Tokyo. If there is one park in Tokyo you must not miss it's this one. There are different gardens here they have Europeans etc. When you walk here it's like you are in a painting full of colors and amazing water ponds.
Beautiful park. One of Tokyo beautiful traditional parks inside the city. It is not located far from the train station. It will take around 2 hours to walk around it.

Oasis in the city. This garden is like an oasis in the middle of the city. There are many paths to explore, with beautiful scenery of lakes, trees and gardens. There is also a greenhouse to explore too. Admission will cost you Y200 per person

Oasis in the bustling shinjuko area. For 200 yen you can escape the city bustle and forget that you're in the middle of it unless you looked up and see the skyscrapers. Traditional Japanese garden is the best to wonder peacefully.
Peaceful. What a beautiful way to spend the afternoon strolling through the peaceful gardens. It is a haven away from the pace of the streets.
Just Beautiful. I visited this park on the last day of the Cherry Blossom season. It was amazing and a great experience. It's one of the better parks I've seen for Cherry Blossoms.

A nice, large garden, watch out for spiders off the beaten path. I think I'd be more appreciative of this place as a local, needing to escape concrete Tokyo for some greenery but as a tourist it was just an average green space. HOWEVER, if you glance off the path into the trees, there are decent sized spiders everywhere. I mean, everywhere! Stick to the path!
Nice Garden. Nice garden but definitely not the no 1 to do in Tokyo that it is while I'm typing this. The view on one of the skyscrapers is amazon though.

Appreciate The Garden's Distinctive Japanese Beauty!. The park is closed on Mondays.I visited the park in mid September 2015.It was the most beautiful park I had visited. Do visit the park if you are around the Shinjuku-Sanchome Station, take Exit C5 or C1. This will take you to the Shinjuku Gate entrance of the park.There is a visitor information centre near the entrance and the admission fee to the park is 200 Yen.I visited the park in the morning and had an enjoyable breakfast of coffee & curry croquette.This extensive garden is composed of 3 distinctive-styled gardens: English Landscape Garden, French Formal Garden & Japanese Traditional Garden.There are tulip, sycamores, ginkgo & maple trees. As I visited the park in early autumn, the entire garden was transformed from a sea of green to a riot of autumn colours! Unique autumn foliage can be seen everywhere!People can also open picnic or small party on lawn. I can say that there are many good things to enjoy there.In short, there were many things to enjoy at that park.I really loved the freshness and the coolness which were always eased my mind, shared both sadness and gladness with me.

Wonderful urban garden not to be missed. A short walk from the Shinjuku train station, this is a beautiful and quite large national garden. Like most it changes by the season but is always beautiful. Sunday's brings out families but it still has many peaceful places. Head for the green house first and its best to be there around 1000 when the green house opens. Takes about ten minutes to walk to from the main gate. Orchids inside are varied and gorgeous. For the rest of your visit there are 4-5 separate areas spread around the park and 2-3 places to get something to eat or drink. Plenty of bathrooms, helpful signage and park benches to relax and drink in the surroundings.

Worth a visit!. My family walked these beautiful gardens over a couple of hours. So peaceful and relaxing. The kids had a great time and loved seeing the temple and the fish swimming in the many little lakes. It was a great day and well worth the visit while in Tokyo!

One of Tokyo's best place for viewing Cherry Blossom season. We went there on first week of april and the cherry was already at full blossom. There were so many of them and the view was just spectacular. The park was clean, tidy an well organized.We go round the park in slow pace, absorbing all the wonderful view around us. We were just planning to spend an hour there since we want to visit other places but in the wend we spend more than 3 hours.

Worth taking the time to enjoy.. There was so much to take in it needed to be a leisurely stroll. The beautiful shaped plants the manicured lawns, the fish,turtles and birds all contributed too a pleasant time at these gardens. Dont forget to also take in the conservatory which has a great layout and for us was a grand finale.
Beautiful garden to take a break in. We spent a couple of hours wondering through this beautiful garden and only just scratched the surface. Lovely place to take a break from the hustle and bustle.
Nice walk. Had a nice walk around. People everywhere in Japan so when you get a chance visit the gardens and just enjoy. The crows are huge in Japan.
Relaxing walk.. Pretty gardens, nice walk on a hot day. Magnificent surroundings. Lacks eating places though. Nice to look at from a high floor too.
Garden in the middle of the city. Beautifully maintained old garden, has several styles-- English and Japanese gardens, great place for rest, picnic and meditation.

You pay to get in but the view is priceless....... The park is about a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station. There's a nominal admission fee but it's worth it. One view in particular (looking back towards Shinjuku at the building that looks like the Empire State building) is absolutely fantastic and will stick with me for a long time. There are some nice open spaces and plenty of sheltered spots too for those that don't like the sun. It is a popular park so secluded spots are rare but if you are staying around Shinjuku then I recommend a visit. If you are not staying around Shinjuku then it is worth checking whether there is a similar park nearer to you as Tokyo has plenty of great green space!

Green haven in a concrete jungle. Large and beautiful park, particulalry during sakura (blossom) season when it is less crowded than Yoyogi.The park is encircled by skyscrapers which enhances the "natural escape" feel of tranquillity amongst the urban sprawl.Good place for a picnic.

Beautiful Gardens for a Couple Hour Walk. Wonderful walking park that has clean facilities and easily accessible. Make sure to bring 700 yen per person to enjoy tea in a traditional tea house. I walked through the park with light rain and it was still very enjoyable.

Lovely peaceful and cool. It was a very hot day so it was lovely to walk I into the cool gardens. There was a little market on the day we went (Sunday) selling food which was a lucky find. Signage not in English and I can't read Japanese which is a shame as there were a few sculputures with placards.

Peaceful haven in the middle of bustling Shinjuku. Shinjuku Gyoen is a wonderful place to take a break from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, and just spend a relaxing part of the day strolling around the gardens. There are several landscaping styles on offer, a couple of tea houses and even a greenhouse displaying more tropical plants. There are numerous rest spots on offer where one can buy a drink or snack and sit to enjoy all the greenery with the view of the city skyscrapers in the background. Great picnic spot for the family, couples, or solo traveller alike to enjoy.

Nice break from the somewhat hectic Shinjuku. After a busy day in Shinjuku we needed a place to relax. Upon entering the park, the traffic noise seems to diminish almsot immediately, and everything is green and serene. The park is beautiful and well kept. It is easy to navigate and get around and there are several nice spots to rest.

Tranquility place and big space for picnic with friends or family. As per title, tranquility place and a lot of room or space for picnics with friends or family. We went there for picnic in the end of summer. Good weather. It is not for free to enter. Need to buy ticket at the gate. Per adult person is 200 Yen. It is worth more than you pay.

Loving Japan. A very good place to take a very good rest. Very peaceful place that is why I recommend it when you want to escape the hustle of the tokyo for a while. I love the culture of asia and japan is one of the country in asia that I love to visit. This place is ideal for those who loves nature.
Peaceful park in Tokyo . This park is so big and beautiful so allow yourself a couple of hours. There is a traditional Japanese garden but also lots of space for a picnic. It's closed on Monday.

Garden in the City. We were there in the late morning of a hot August day. Very peaceful and quiet and not many visitors at that time. We spent most of our time in the Japanese Garden area which was very pretty. Next time we should check out the French and English gardens.
Central park Tokyo. This is a lovely, very peaceful garden in the heart of the city. We spent a damp afternoon there, wandering around the paths and enjoying the very lovely planting and trees

Peaceful oasis on the edge of Shinjuku. The park is great for a break from Tokyo's hustle and bustle. There are Japanese-, French- and English-themed gardens to wander through. We also dived into a tea-room to escape a sudden downpour.

Beautiful park in the city. This is a very nice park, convenient to walk if you're staying in the area. It's a very large park with multiple ponds and traditional tea houses, with backdrops of city buildings. Many koi and carp inhabit the ponds. The park has extensive "free" area where groups of school children meet during the day for field day activities. This was one of my favorite parts -- watching the children in their coordinating hats participate in games. There are refreshment areas and sufficient bathrooms. It's a very nice way to spend the day, and I didn't even get to cover the majority of it!

Nice leisurely stroll, variety of trees. Amazing to think there is a place like this in the middle of Tokyo! 200 Yen entry. I have never seen so many different species of trees. Awesome. Very pretty. Easily accessible by many stations. Peaceful and tranquil. Not a lot of flowers, mainly trees and plants, but well maintained and worth a visit. Can walk the whole park/garden in 90 minutes.

Gem for Garden Lover. The entry fee is 200 yen. It's a popular destination for Cherry Blossom. We went there in May 15. Most of the trees are green. I believe it is very beautiful in Spring and Autumn. Regardless, I think with 200 yen entry fee, don't miss out on one of the biggest garden in Japan. If you like it good, if you don't like it, its 200 yen :)
just beautiful. Beautiful garden I've been there in autumn fall and in the cherry blossom .the view in both are magnificent. The most beautiful garden in Tokyo

The Park was like a big Garden with beautiful Lotus and the pretty ponds I enjoyed my day enjoying nature at its awesome. I highly recommend you go there especially if you are a nature lover like me, you will not be disappointed.

Nice sakuras. Lovely park, I managed to see the lovely sakuras almost towards the end of the season. Family and I walked around the park and stopped by the food stand inside the park for a short morning picnic.

Lovely ponds, great for photos or painting. We enjoyed a great day at the park on a Saturday. Not too busy. Lovely young families picnicking in wide open spaces. Beautiful ponds, wooden bridges in expansive Japanese garden. Venison spaghetti bolognaise in restaurant was superb and cheap.

If in Shinjuku: GO THERE!. Huge park to wander around. Plan to stay 2-4 hrs depending on how interest you are in different type of flowers, architecture and gardens. Must visit: Traditional Japanese Garden.
Closed on Monday's

Open space in the midst of Tokyo. I went there on a very rainy day where I was almost alone in the park. It's a tranquil setting worth some time to visit for at least an hour. Wide open spaces await you with some history and naming of species. If you want to get away from the pachinko machines and the people here is the place for you

Great nature get away smack down in the center of Tokyo.. This place is perfect for a quiet and calm walk within the monster of concrete that is Tokyo! If you like jogging or gardens, this is the place for you. Very big, cozy, and beautiful. I would bring a blanket and a picnic basket and make a day out of it.

Beautiful park to escape from the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku and Tokyo. Huge Lovely Garden in Shinjuku with wide open spaces and beautifully manicured gardens. Especially colourful during sakura season and autumn. You can bring a mat and sit on the lawns with you picnic and drinks - but no alcohol allowed! From the metro station pop by Isetan Food basement grab the yummy beef rice or salad and a dessert and a drink from the supermarket then a short stroll over to the park. There are many trash bins at the park so don't leave your disposables on the lawn.

Sakura was beautiful. Went there in April, Sakura was in full bloom. It was simply mesmerizing, I can sit there for hours. I went on a Friday, but it was still crowded with people (japanese and tourist) having hanami there

Beautiful garden, don't skip it!!. A beautiful garden in the midst of Tokyo! Almost unbelievable that this kind of place exists in the middle of a city like this. You can walk around here definitely for 1-2 hours and admire the Japanese gardening quality!

Lovely Park in the middle of the city. Easy walking and good array of plants and trees. If you are in the neighborhood, stop by. Don't expect much. It is a gorgeous garden and specially in the spring when the whole area is surrounded by cherry trees and beautiful "Sakura flowers " Great place to relax the body and mind. Clean and well maintained.

So Serene. You can take a quick wander or linger in the tea house, the choice is yours. The grounds are simply stunning, such a relaxing setting that you are almost in a meditative state upon entry. Bring repellent in the hot seasons.

Greenhouse and gardens serene . Easy walking and good array of plants and trees. Visited on a rainy afternoon and both my wife and I loved the gradens. Pick some of the trees we would like to have in our garden when we have the chance.
Worth an easy afternoon stroll.

A must visit during sakura season!. The visit to this park was the entire defenition of my trip from end of march to start of april. This was the best park I have ever visited! The grass was clean cut, and the sakura trees were huge. Going back during the autumn to see the koyo.
A lovely, tranquil "walk in the park".. A must see in Tokyo lovely gardens and greenhouse. I went early and it was deserted - perfect for taking pictures.
Serene. Beautiful place.... Vast area amidst hi-tech city. Well maintained and lovely place to visit. Best time to visit should be spring.
Check this place, please. Beautiful landscapes and a great greenhouse with small ponds and nice walkways. A MUST see for all travelers.
A total surprise. An oasis in the middle of Tokyo. Lovely. Lots of grass and beatifully sculped pines. Bring some lunch and have a picnic.

Not up to japanesse standards. Visited this garden expecting to see a great example of japanese gardening. Unfortunately the gardens are not maintained with weeds and overgrown plants. It was nice to see grass and plants but the entrance money needs to be spent on gardeners.
Great place for jogging. Amazing park. Beautiful gardens. Nice to walk around or go out jogging. Important: opens at 9:00am and is closed on Mondays

Lovely space in the middle of the city. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit this garden (like I did). My review may be influenced by the fact that I was tired, it was raining and I was short on time. It's a lovely serene space. If you have time, want a respite from visiting temples and the like, and have time to have tea at the tea house, this might be worth it.

Pack a picnic and a tarp to sit on. So beautiful. The softest grass and the most beautiful vistas. Stop into the Isetan food hall on your way and grab some delicacies for a picnic in the Japanese section of the garden.
Lovely gardens but watch the mosquitoes. This park is amazing but it is a mosquito haven so take some insect repellent with you. We got some great photos here in the picturesque setting

Lovely garden and greenhouse. A large garden near Shinjuku, with various sections: British, French and Japanese. Many lovely walking paths and views and seat, all no doubt changing with the seasons. We went in summer, when everything was green, but there were less flowers than you will find in Spring. It's a nice garden, but not in the same league as the gardens in Kyoto, so if you've been to Kyoto, maybe think twice about this one. This is often described as one of Tokyo's best gardens.The Garden has a very good new greenhouse that is certainly worth including in your visit.The best way to get there is on the Marounuchi Subway line, even though it's a couple of stops from Shinjuku station and is walkable if you wish. There are some small snack bars and some traditional tea houses in the garden. We partook of a traditional tea and sweet, which was quite expensive, but nice nonetheless. Not a tea ceremony, just fresh tea and a jelly sweet, nicely served in the tea house. (see the photo)There's a small entry fee.Worth a visit if you're in the area.
Nice garden with many flowers and a lake. nice relaxing garden with many flowers but also with unfortunately to many people, but hey, it is tokyo

Japanese garden mastery. Peaceful and beautiful place. Must visit in order to enjoy the mastering of plants growing. BE AWARE: Long trousers and sleeves are needed to avoid mosquito bites. Better safe than sorry. Do not miss the greenhouse.

Maybe too hot to walk in summer, but very nice!. Strolling in a nice park in the middle of Tokyo is very refreshing. We were there in the end of May and it was too late for cherry blossoms, but saw some flowers such as azaleas and roses. Must be pretty in spring and autumn. I believe it’s too hot and humid to walk in summer months. Lots of trees, gardens, and ponds. A little green house was interesting too. Wear comfortable shoes. You will walk a lot. From JR Shinjuku station south or east exit, walk along the big street (Kosyu kaido) to east. In ten minutes or so, you see the park entrance on your right. Or you can take Tokyo metro Marunouchi line, and get off at Shinjuku gyoen station which is in front of the park. Admission was 200 yen. Soft serve ice cream at the little shop in the park was good!

Spectacular Garden. This garden was beautiful and it represented both modern western styles and traditional Japanese designs. It boasted with a variety of flowers and trees. You could spend hours walking without being bored or tired. It is a must see.
The house. Amazing garden, I suggest you to got there and try the traditional tè ceremony in a tipically Japanese house.

A perfect escape from the big city. In this park, there's a Japanese, an English and a French garden. Although the English and the French gardens are not worth mentioning, the Japanese gardens are to die for. Make sure to take your camera with you as you are definitely going to take loads of photos.

Sanctuary even on a rainy day. I visited here mid-afternoon on a humid day that had seen some rain. Despite that the park is very nice, not outstanding in summer I would say as there were little in the way of flowers but it is still pretty and a tranquil place for a break from the hustle and bustle of the city. It costs just over £1 to get in which is pretty reasonable.
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens in the middle of a very busy Shinjuku! Only 200Yen entry which includes entry into the greenhouse. Reccommended.

Great break from the streets of Tokyo.. Shinjuku Gyoen is a vast and magnificent garden, and a great break from urban Tokyo. Plan to spend at least two to three hours because of the many different landscapes to visit.

Simply splendid!. I had a weekend free in Tokyo during a business trip. Having done quite a few of the sights on previous occasions, I resorted to good old TripAdvisor to see what they recommended in their top ten list of things to see and do. Number one was the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden, and as I planned to have lunch in Shinjuku I decided to make a trip to these gardens.And am I glad I did. The Gyoen National Garden is simply magnificent, and huge (although it is quite feasible to explore the whole park if you have time). I entered at the north-east corner of the park, about ten minutes walk from Shinjuku Station. The entrance fee is 200 Yen, a little under US$2. My circuit on this particular day took me first to the western part of the park, and the expansive Japanese gardens. Then I skirted the southern edge all the way to the French gardens on the east side, then walked through the English gardens to exit from the same place.I spent about two hours in Gyoen, but you could easily take half a day or more to explore. What I liked most about these gardens, and this was quite a busy Saturday afternoon, was how easy it was to find solitude. I also loved the Japanese gardens and their picturesque lakes, islands and bridges.So, if you are anywhere close to Shinjuku, don't miss out on this horticultural wonderland. And if you're a bit concerned about finding the place, get a taxi. Everyone in Tokyo knows the Gyoen National Garden!

Great quick wander. Amazing little haven in the city. We walked around it 30 minutes before closing and had the whole place to ourselves. Kanazawa is obviously very proud of it and they keep it maintained to those standards. Great for a 10 minute wander, not more.
A tranquil afternoon.... A nice place to wander around and relax for an hour or two in an afternoon. There is a 200 yen entrance fee. Not too big.

Certainly worth a walk around but take some mosquito spray. Exceptional park and a nice respite away from the bustling streets of Tokyo, just make sure you take some MOSQUITO SPRAY. The park is well maintained and the Japanese Garden is my favourite part. You only need a few hours here and is great stop off if you need somewhere to relax for a bit or have a bit of time to kill during the day. There is also a greenhouse to walk around but given it was such a hot day we gave that part a miss.
Amazing. We only had one hour to see it, we managed to have a walk and see most of it before leaving Japan. Probably better to visit during spring.
Quiet retreat. Beautiful gardens - well worth visiting. I went one time in Cherry .Blossom season and it was spectacular - an oasis in Tokyo

As in much of Japan, be patient. This is a beautiful and calming place. I came here in the fall and the weather was amazing. If you are the kind of person who relishes running from one visceral activity to the next then perhaps this park isn't for you. It's true there isn't a lot 'to do' here, but the joy is experiencing the patient serenity in the heart of a world class city. Bring a picnic, and tease yourself with a genteel pace.
Beautiful Walk. Absolutely breathtaking garden. We spent a couple of hours walking this beautiful area. It's rather large so you should bring comfortable shoes.

Tranquil gardens.. A beautiful, peaceful oasis in the heart of Shinjuku, covering a vast area. You need to allow several hours to really get a feel of the the different areas. It is a wonderful spot for photography, and on a hot day, which it was when I was there, there are many areas with seats conveniently located to get respite from the heat and allow a vista of a section of the gardens.

Peaceful gardens. My 2 daughters and I spent the day here after we arrived in Tokyo. It was a beautiful place to relax on our first day. We brought a picnic lunch and our books and found several shady places to enjoy the garden. We were surprised by the thousands of dragonflies and also the sunbathing men! There are several places to purchase snacks and soft drinks.

Do not visit in summer. Well its a park with nothing else to expect. I come in August which is summer, and found nothing but park. Some nice spot here and there, best for relaxing afternoon stroll. Just don't expect anything fancy, at least not in August.
Pleasant park in city center. It was raining when we visited so it was a little less pleasant. Indeed, it is a wonderful park but it is not very different from many others.

Relaxing stroll away from the busy Tokyo. I stayed nearby so I took some food with me and took a 1 hour stroll through the park looking at all the fascinating trees and flowers. There is a Japanese, English and French garden within the park that all three are interesting to look at, and compare. There is a very small fee for entering.Very relaxing :)
Great garden. Nice garden peaceful in the middle of the city - highly recommended - we visit only this garden and Shinjuku garden which was near to our hotel and was also very nice

Amazing visit!. Entrance fee is 200 yen per adult. The park is much larger than i thought. It was extremely well maintained and pretty. The map and the instructions inside the park are easy to read so even tourists wont get lost in the park. Worth visiting.

Beautiful! . Didn't know the garden is that huge! It has parks with different themes showing Japanese styles and western styles. Very well maintained. The instruction in the park is pretty clear even for tourists so you won't get lost. Worth visiting!
Great Escape. A very calm and relaxing break from fast-paced city sight-seeing. Beautiful lush greenery with well-maintained trails and toilets.

Huge Garden in the middle of Tokyo. This Garden is open for public, but they have operational hours for entering the park. When we came here it was 5pm and the garden is already closed 30 minutes before we arrived. (last admission is 4:30pm So for you who want to visit this place, please come earlier.

Relaing Parc. A very calm and relaxing Parc in Shinjuku. You can easily walk for hours. You have Japanese, French and English garden. Same "minilacs" and the famous Green house with a lot of fantastics flowers. Don't forget to bring water to drink with you while walking around.

Pretty, pack a lunch. . There is so much to see here and it's easy to spend an entire day here. Be sure to bring plenty of water if you are visiting during the summer months. This is also a beautiful place for a picnic if you don't have plans for lunch.

Lovely park. This park is wonderful. It's large and compromises of a number of different areas including an 'english landscape garden' and 'japanese traditional garden', both of which we particularly enjoyed strolling through. We also enjoyed having having a drink at the tea house which was very relaxing. There are a number of places to get snacks and drinks (including a restaurant by the entrance where we actually had breakfast) and a very adequate number of toilets throughout the park, too. At only a couple of hundred yen this park we thought was extremely good value and I can't imagine that anyone would not enjoy their visit! It's a very refreshing contrast to the busy hubbub of central Tokyo and a very beautiful park in its own right, so I would definitely recommend it.

The green heart of the city !. A huge and magnificent park (particularly the Japanese traditional garden), a "parenthesis" of peace and freshness in this crazy city ! In autumn, the colors of the red maples trees are magnificent and in spring all lovers come for a cherry blossom photo. the show is on trees and on ground with petals covering acres of grass. In summer, the cicada song is so impressive that it's deafening and recovering even from the park's entrance the noise of the city. Two small advices : 1) To enjoy even more this beautiful park, you can come with a picnic. Small shops are selling tea, coffee and few sweets. For main course, don't forget to stop before at level -1 of ISETAN (in Shinjuku- 5 min from the park), where the best take-away food is sold. 2) Going out by the sendagaya door will allow you to easily reach by foot the Meiji Temple, then move on for a walk in Harajuku and Omotesando.

A must during Sakura timr. We went on the 9th of april...,when the peak of cherry blossom was kind of over around most of tokyo...but because this garden has such a large variety of cherry trees...many were still in full bloom in large open spaces in the park n it was a sight to behold!
