It was breathtaking to see line upon line of pink trees with lots of happy families picnicking under them! The Japanese sure do love their gardens! I can't comment what the park is like out of sakura season, but it's definately a must during sakura time!
Peaceful. This is a nice, peaceful place in the middle of an extremely busy part of Tokyo. The tea house I visited was really lovely!

Peaceful. Spent 2 hours here on a hot August day. Not crowded at all. 200 yen entrance fee, a bargain. The park is large, with many different kinds and sections of gardens. Very nice way to get away from the crowds in hectic Tokyo.
Nice park. A real nice park to visit all year round really. In Summer it is a good place to get away from the busy city. In Winter it is just a nice place to walk around in.

Nice park. A big park in the Shjinjuku. The park have a Japanese, a french and an english section. Nice place to just take a stroll or sit down and relax. During Sakura season its also a good option to Uena park since its less crowded but still got plenty of cherry trees. Note the park have an entry fee.

Beautiful peaceful garden. Of all the gardens in Tokyo, this is definitely my favorite. More like a botanical garden, it's lovely to walk under well established shady trees, on green grass & through fragrant rose gardens. With thoughtfully placed seating, it's a great place to take a book on a hot summer's day, with adequate refreshments sources.
Amazing!!!!!. This is by far the best, most beautiful and well maintained public park I've ever been.. If you're in Tokyo this Is a must go .. It can't be missed!!!
Impressive . Impressive garden!! But if you go in the summer use a lot of sunscreen and with a hat!!! It opens at 9 a.m.

Need upkeep. Enjoy strolling in the gardens but due to heavy rain the paths were full of puddles which meant walking on the grass at times. Perhaps top up the gravel before the wet season!The woodwork on many structures rotting and the garden areas riddled with weeds. I love gardens and felt very underwhelmed. The glass atrium hot house was lovely.Lunch was lovely but was ordered via a vending machine and then brought to the table. Don't know why we couldn't pay the waitress and she take our order.Interesting, but hey go with the flow.
A pleasant braek from the crowds. Nice park located close to the Hyatt Regency. On some evenings in summer, they have open air dining/bar.
Beautiful park. Very enjoyable stroll through meticulously maintained gardens. We went on a Tuesday and unfortunately the tea rooms were closed. Well worth the 200 yen and time.

Beautiful Shinjuku Gyoen. A wonderful escape from the city surrounding Shinjuku Gyoen. Very well maintained throughout the year, most notebly popular in the Spring during Cherry Blossom season when the Sakura flowers come out. Spend two to three hours slowly circling the garden, feeling lost in its tranquilaty.

If you are in the neighborhood, stop by. Don't expect much.. Honestly, you can pass. I mean, if you are already at the area, like staying nearby or something, then it's okay, but I've seen better, more impressive, gardens. If you just want to escape from the urban view, you can go there, but there's really not much to do there. You can circle the entire place in about 54 minutes. I thoulg the GreenHouse would be worth visiting, but it was quite dull. Nothing too special there, too. The entrance fee to the garden is very low, like a few dollars, but again - not very attractive in my opinion. To be fair, I was there in one of the hottest days of the year, so maybe in a cooler time it's nicer.
Pretty and relaxing. This is a lovely park to visit. It is cheap to enter and is an escape from the city buzz if you are needing some quiet time. there are Teahouses if you fancy a cup of green tea.

Best garden in Tokyo. The best and most beautiful garden we visited in Japan. Right in the heart of Shinjuku and an absolute bargain at only 200 yen entry fee. This is a must visit for any trip to Tokyo.
Best Garden in Tokyo. It is a gorgeous garden and specially in the spring when the whole area is surrounded by cherry trees and beautiful "Sakura flowers ".Every season is beautiful.

Japanese style garden, perhaps prettiest in autumn. It's huge, and requires at least 2 hours to cover the whole park. But having just come from Hokkaido where even on the streets you can see flowering plants in abundance, in contrast there were more trees and greens than flowers in this park.The Japanese touch is evident - nicely pruned trees everywhere (makes some parts of it look like a huge bonsai-inspired garden).Perhaps better to visit in autumn, when the leaves are changing.Take note of the closing time, it closes at 16:30, and there is a ¥200 entry fee per person.
Nice escape. Beautiful park in the heart of the city. Great place to relax the body and mind. Clean and well maintained
Loving it.. A must if you want a calm and quiet place after shopping and sight seeing. Make sure you bring a picnic. Great park. Toilet are conveniently placed.

Quiet Park in the Middle of the City. - well preserved park
- pretty good size to walk for an hour
- it has not been invaded by the tourists coming off from tour buses
- good location for someone in Shinjuku who is looking for a change of pace from busy business or vacation schedule

Beautiful Garden and worth to visit!. We visited the garden in Sakura festival, very crowded and long queue at the entrance, but very well controlled by the staffs. Paid a admission fee 200yen per person, but really worth the time and money. We spent more than 3 hours there and really enjoyed a wonderful morning, very nice weather and beautiful garden, planning to visit there again next year.

Very serene, take the Shinkansen to Kyoto tho.... It was gorgeous and incredibly serene. I truly enjoyed the visit. It is a wonderful retreat from the chaos around Tokyo. However, compared with smaller gardens off the beaten path I would say that the National Garden was bombastic, but not necessarily the prettiest. Take, for example, Chisakuin garden in Kyoto. Much smaller, hard to beat. If you are only visiting Tokyo, don't miss it. If you are heading to Kyoto, too, skip it.

Peaceful. We stopped by here on our first day of arriving in Japan. Cost about ¥1000, roughly £5 for 2 people.The gardens are very tranquil and you feel at peace almost instantly on arrival. The birds and wildlife make it very noisy but I enjoyed that. Lots of nice walks and in spring when the cherry blossom is it'd be spectacular no doubt. Great if you want a break from all the people in shinjuku......
Beautiful garden in Shinjuku. A beautiful garden, with different styles within different pavilions. For a small entrance fee you can find a place to have a picnic in a park in Tokyo.
Quiet green retreat. Visited these in a misty, wet grey day but they still provided that little piece of peace in the midst of bustling Shinjuku

Perfect place for a picnic. We arrived a little too soon for the Sakura festival, but decided to enjoy the beautiful gardens since we still had nice weather. We went to the store, picked up some food and items to have a picnic, and enjoyed a wonderful afternoon people watching and enjoying the beauty of the gardens.

Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. Went on a morning and paid Y200 for entry. There is a glass house and this park is huge. However, as it was drizzling, it makes moving around kind of uncomfortable. There is a traditional tea house that serves a sweet and green tea for Y700 - worth a try especially when it is raining or very hot as this place is well air con. And, very peaceful within here.Variety of flowers in the glass garden was aplenty though one need to be meticulous to spot some. In other areas of the park, it was peaceful to just wander around.
Nice garden near Shinjuku center. From walking distance from Shinjuku center is this beautiful garden. Water, old walking bridges... Nice place to relax without rushing people everywhere.

Beautiful and calm. This is such a nice garden - the japanese garden was outstanding. Even though the rain was pouring down like crazy, my friend and I still had a nice walk with lots of nice photos taken. I strongly recommend bringing a long sleeved shirt and trousers to avoid mosquitos.There is a traditional tea house in the middle of the japanese garden which for us got a little awkward since it's a very open space and we were alone at the beginning. It is probably not as awkward around noon when the weather is nicer, though. Anyway, the tea was tasty and the japanese sweets were really pretty. We were unfortunately too late to visit the green house.
Tranquil. Gorgeous serene getaway in the middle of Shinjuku. The park is HUGE and you could easily get lost. Entry fee was cheap 200 yen

Beautiful landscape, but very early closing hours.. This garden (which charges a small entry fee) is very beautiful to visit and has French formal gardens, and Japanese gardens. There is also a greenhouse on the grounds. The trees are labeled, so if you are interested in botany, it will help you out in identification. The downside is that the garden's last entry is 1600, with everyone kicked out at 1630. The early closing hours are a real bummer, since if you work in Tokyo it is impossible to visit after the workday. Finally, the gates all close before 1630, except the main gate. So if you are leaving at 1630, you may not be able to exit the gate you came into.
Beautiful!. If your in the Shinjuku area, this garden is a must see. A break from the busy city. Its peaceful, quiet and tranquil. Koi and turtles are in the lakes.

Good stroll in a sunny day. Good stroll in the morning before browsing the shinjuku area. If you start from the shinjuku gate, you will start by japanese garden and end at the french garden. A beautiful and very well maintained garden, perfect for picnic, jogging, etc.

It was ok.... The garden is quite beautiful if you have never seen a Japanese garden before. It's not very special/unique to some of the other gardens located in Kyoto. The observatory had some pretty plants but not anything to go wow over. If you live in Malaysia, it seems like some of the plants back home.

Go if you're in Tokyo!. Ahhh this botanical garden/park is really lovely. It's about $1.50 to enter and well worth the price. There are sprawling grounds of green, a lovely pond and the fantastic botanical garden which is worth the $1.50 on it's own. Surprisingly, my boyfriend and I were able to find some empty paths where all we could hear were the birds chirping and enjoy the shade of the huge trees. Bring a blanket and a book for a break from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Nice, but not too special. Beautiful Japanese garden, a nice break from the crowded city life, but honestly not so different from so many others in Japan.

Urban Oasis. The National Garden is a relaxing addition to your Tokyo visit. I came here on an overcast afternoon and spent about two hours walking and blogging from a quiet bench by the ike. The visit was peaceful and refreshing. There are several themed gardens, a greenhouse, an educational center, two tea houses, and a cafe. Admission is 200 yen. I especially enjoyed the view of the traditional Japanese garden bridge with a towering skyscraper behind it. It was quintessential Japan - the old and the new coexisting in a beautiful way.
Beautiful. The garden is well managed. I appreciate all the nature. You should visit here and feel the tidy Japaneses botanic architecture.

Lovely Gardens. Spent a wonderful hour strolling the park. It was a misty day, a welcome respite from the hot sun. Park is well groomed, two tea houses and an informative modern greenhouse. Well worth the 200 yen.

Beautiful garden. We visited this beautiful garden on a rainy day but it was worth the time. Well -kept and clean with beautiful garden designs. It is close to Shinjuku station and is within walking distance from Sunroute Plaza hotel.
Great representation of a Japanese garden!
Beautiful Garden. I have been visited in the winter and I and my family love it!!!! Amazing place with animals to see and great to walk and enjoy the nature in the middle of Tokyo

Awesome!!!. A very nice place to relax and unwind. Lot's of Cherry Blossoms tree with different colors & species and they have a restaurant in the area. My family enjoyed here and took so many pictures here. The place is huge and definitely would love to visit the place again.

Cherry blossom highlight. This was a lovely park filled with cherry blossoms when we visited. We met a friend and her kids there and everyone had a wonderful time. The kids were entertained by the trees and enjoyed an ice cream snack in the restaurant. We had a limited time in Tokyo but this was a highlight of the trip.
Worth to Visit but Except Summer Time. Very well settled and protected park where you might have a nice long walk and enjoy great nature but keep it in mind its too hot in summer time.
Beautiful BUT its mosquito city!. Beautiful place worth a visit. Note that there are lots of mosquitos here so spray before walking round or you will be munched! Seriously munched!
Beautiful garden. A beatiful refuge from the noise and stress of Tokyo. It's truly relaxing to just walk around for a couple of hours.

Beautiful gardens. We visited the gardens one morning since it was a close walk from our hotel. The admission was 200 JPY for adults and 50 JPY for our teen kids. English maps were available at the entrance. We were surprised at how large the entire park was. We visited the Japanese traditional gardens and many beautiful ponds throughout the gardens. We enjoyed leisurely strolling the gardens and many large lawn areas surrounded by lush green trees. There were a few tea houses and a restaurant, but we didn't go inside these. We, also, visited a greenhouse with many tropical plants and a small waterfall and formal French style gardens with rose bushes and sycamores.We probably spent a couple hours exploring the gardens. There weren't many people there when we visited, so we enjoyed a peaceful morning walk. It was a wonderful respite from the busy city. I loved seeing all the beautiful greenery in the middle of crowded Shinjuku!

Not great in summer. Went to the gardens expecting something amazing. It was 200 or 500 yen and honestly it wasn't any better than the imperial palace gardens or any of the other 15 free gardens in Tokyo. I can see how it would be really pretty in the spring but it was just green and leafy in July. Fun to see but not a must.

Universe of calm in skyscraper central of Tokyo. Do drop by Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden if you've got time to spare when visiting Shinjuku. I know I did and I'm very glad. I was amazed and surprised that they charge an entrance fee but quickly understood why and I feel it's definitely worth the entrance fee. Wish I had spent more time there and it hadn't rained so much during the day I visited Shinjuku.

Going green in Tokyo. It was really green in summer. There is Central Park in NYC, there is Hyde Park in London, there is one in Tokyo – Goyen Park. Peace and tranquil in the city, accesible easily from the nearest train station. About 5 to 10-minute walk. It’s a good place for families with children where kids can run freely. I went on a Friday morning, hardly anyone there. There were groups of children (from some kindergartens probably) with their families enjoying the space. You may watch some old Japanese men trying out their hands at painting the scenery. There are cafes in the park and a small cottage to experience the Japanese way of tea-drinking – for a price,700 Yen. Be prepared to walk if you are going for the greens. A pair of comfortable shoes is a must.

Very lovely and relaxing place. Entrance can be through three access points but the main gate is currently closed. Fee is 200 yen for adults and 50 yen for kids.Quite a big garden and plenty of places to relax in the sun or shade.French garden found at site, was blooming with roses and looked very pretty. Many benches. In certain areas the mosquitoes were unbearable so if you are a person susceptible to being bitten take insect repellant.The pond with Koi carp and terrapins was very scenic and looked traditionally Japanese.There is also an Old Imperial Rest house that is open to the public and one can walk through it to see around four rooms that used to be used by the imperial family in 1896. Couple of tea houses, rest houses where one can buy snacks and a restaurant are in the garden.Many restrooms interspersed all round the place. Coin lockers available. Wheelchairs are available free of charge for any visitors who need them.

Beautiful in Spring. A nice pit-stop whilst walking around such a busy city. Great for photos with the skyscrapers behind the trees. Closes quite early so be careful to check ahead - we went in the Spring and had to leave at 16:30 even though still very light. Especially beautiful in the spring with the cherry blossom and lots of families enjoying the park

lovely spot - even though no cherry blossoms!. We went in June so knew there'd be no cherry blossoms but this garden was still amazing. There are so many lakes and it's a very typical Japanese garden but very well maintained. Being able to see skyscrapers towering over the garden is also a very interesting sight!

Introduction into Japanese Gardens. This is my first time visiting a japanese garden, and it really is a relaxing place to unwind after a day's work. I wish we had a garden like this back at home.Very inspiring and beautiful. <3

A Place to Escape from the Busy City. I went there in the cherry-blossom seasons. There are lots of tourists but as soon as the park is big you would not feel as crowded as in the street. We need to queue for entrance, but it is not long and is in great order. The cherry trees in the park is in huge quantity, so many colors and species. It is also a nice place for picnic.

Beautiful, clean park in the middle of the city. If you're looking for a picnic destination with a relaxing atmosphere, beautiful surroundings, and in a central location - Shinjuku Park is the place for you. Although there are opening times and a small entry fee, the park is immaculately kept, and offers plenty of opportunities to explore the gardens or enjoy a picnic lunch in one of the green spaces. I do believe there are a few cafes and tea houses; however I didn't have the opportunity to visit due to buying a bento from the conbini beforehand. Although it was very crowded when I visited (late March-April during cherry blossom season), it does not distract from the natural beauty the park has to offer.

Green Oasis in Hectic Shinjuku. Open from 09h00 to 16h00, this park has a 200Yen entrance fee. It has both lawns where you can picnic, manicured gardens when grass is off-limit, pond and tea house, as well as a greenhouse. Not as crowded and quieter than Yoyogi park, it is a great green oasis within hectic Shinjuku.

A great break from the busy city. I have been to Shinjuku Gyoen many times. It is one spot in the Shinjuku area that you can count on for being clean, fairly quiet (except maybe during cherry blossom season), and full of greenery. If you're looking for a park to play, run, and drink in, this is not the park for you. For that, you're more likely to be happy with Yoyogi Park. Shinjuku Gyoen is a great place for a quiet picnic, a pleasant stroll, or a place to take a rest. If you are there during a busy time, you're best not to use the main gate if possible. It is the Shinjuku Gate that can get backed up as people are buying their entrance tickets.

Great park with a lovely and relaxing atmosphere.. I was staying at a hotel not far away from this lovely park. It costs 200yen to get in and worth every yen! The park itself is well kept, has large areas and is stunning. It is a good place to take photos and great to stroll through in the morning. I would say it is one of the best "city parks" I have ever been to !

Best Park in Tokyo. My favorite park in Tokyo. The 200 yen fee is well worth it. The money the park makes each day pays for the cleanliness and beauty. The park is split into sections, each one with its own style. There is, of course, a traditional Japanese garden, but also a Chinese garden, an English rose garden, and a few others. It's a great place for a picnic, but know that alcohol is not allowed and the park closes at 4:30 each day for landscaping and maintenance. The view of the Shinjuku skyline are nice, too.

Large, relaxing and varied gardens in the middle of Tokyo. As we were staying less than 500m away from this large expanse of green it seemed a shame not to go an have a look and to contrast with something like the Palace gardens. The Y200 entrance fee was a little unexpected (I hadn't done any research), but it is pretty nominal. There are some interesting restrictions/warning signs - no kites, no sports, but these are appropriate as it is a relaxing and peaceful place - not a sports field.The gardens have a good variety of trees, plants and areas. The greenhouse is quite a modern design, but very attractively laid out with interesting specimens (I was interested to see the pitcher plants and the banana palms had a lot of bananas).Elsewhere, examples of shaped bushes, ponds, a Japanese garden and expanses of grass let me explore different sections and appreciate the overall feeling of space that is present. However, the fact that you are in the middle of a city of 12 million people provides reminders including the sound of trains and the skyscrapers that appear in the pond reflections.On the cloudy day I went, it was nice, relaxing and enjoyable. On a sunny day, other than being hot, I expect the blue sky and bright greens would make it even better.

Zen out bruh. This garden is gorgeous. I'm not one to throw that word around either. The city is wonderful, but at some point you need to just relax and this was my favorite place in Tokyo to do so. The gardens are split into three sections, Japanese, French and English. Japanese was obviously the best. If you wanted a more visual look at the gardens check out my video on it here:Starts at 5:49 - https://youtu.be/LdDCscCVs80?t=5m49sThis video also gives more suggestions of places to visit in Harajuku, Shinjuku and Shibuya. This is also just an episode of a series so check the rest out if you want some cool destinations in and around Japan if you are inclined. Have a great visit!
Great escape from crazy busy Tokyo streets.. Beautiful tranquil gardens in the heart of Tokyo, peaceful and quiet. Don't miss seeing the French garden. Entry is 200 yen,closed on Monday

Urban oasis. A large park containing a wide variety of gardens, ponds and lawn spaces plus a fascinating modern glasshouse. A welcome oasis right next to the busy Shinjuku area and easily accessible by foot or the metro. We were there during the chrysanthemum festival and the many displays of this plant were all stunning; quite extraordinary the skill and artistry involved.
Lovely Garden. Very pleasant place to spend a moment! Fine places to walk around. What a lovely sight! Really worth visit.

Very relaxing. Strolled around for a couple of hours and didn't even reach the French garden before we had to go.The Japanese and English style gardens are beautifu, well kept and very pleasant to walk around in.I would suggest bringin a picnic.

Shinjuku Gyoen Park. This is a beautiful garden Entrance is under $5.00. During late March and early April, Cherry trees are in full bloom. Atound mid April when I visited, some trees were still in blooms. The park is surrounded by ponds and fountain. Some of the old trees are spectular. There ard places to have picknic with family and friends. It would be better to pack your lunch since not much is available inside. Ine can easily spend half day there, dependingbon weather. Summer could be hot to walk around.

Pretty buts needs some love. The gardens are an oasis in the city but the facilities need some refurbishment. After all the noise of the city, listening to the bird calls and strolling around the cherry trees was very refreshing.
Excellent garden. Nice to walk around in different gardens. The Japanese are good to this! Peaceful even with many people. Well worth a visit!

Not sure what the big draw is. We were very excited to visit the Garden after reading all the reviews. But overall, it was not very impressive. Yes it is a big open space in a metropolitan city but nothing special.

Huge Park in middle of a busy city. This park is huge and is located in middle of Tokyo. It is surprising to see such a calm and quite place in middle of a busy city. Definitely worth a visit. They have divide the Park in different gardens. Wonderful place to see the traditional garden styles, and also has lot of cherry trees. They also have a glass house which has different varieties of flowers from all over.

Shinjuku Serene Side. This is such a serene place, in the middle of the very busy Shinjuku district. Pensioners practicing yoga and tai-chi in the park, undisturbed by the vast metropolis around them.
Japaneese traditional garden. Very lovely place in Shinjuku. Not easy to find entrance gate when first time. Quiet and good for relax in serene surrounding Recommended

The Large park. This is a large open park in the city center of Tokyo which is as a favorite place. The park is very beautiful, well maintained, clean. At the time of spring, you'll find the beautiful cherry blossom decorate the scenery. The location is very close to Shinjuku station. Admission 200 yen per person.

Beatiful. It's very beautiful and serene here. Not a lot of foot traffic inside the garden and we couldn't hear much outside noise while checking out the trees and plants. Be sure to take a map at the entrance. Check the hours before you go, we got there figuring it would be open and had to wait an hour (even though wandering around in Japan is the best kind of waiting). Happy travels!

Nice shrine within. A minute's walk from the Hilton. Good place to people watch at lunch time with the City Govt Office right across the street. Peace and quiet in the middle of the city and a small shrine to visit in case you don't get to see any in Kyoto.

Nature. If you have time give this place at least half a day, it's worth it! It's a rest from the crazy streets of the city, gives you an opportunity to breath and a demonstration of Japanese gardening. Lovely place for a breath of air and a rest from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.Do not forget mosquito repellent!

Nice. Nice park for an hour stroll. Not the best botanical garden I've ever been to so only giving it 4 stars because it didn't live up to the hype for me. I guess I expected the best garden in the world given the reputation of Japanese gardens and design. The Tea House is worth a quick stop. Overall it was a nice stop and peaceful walk.

Lovely place to visit when in shinjuku area. Take some time off from the concrete jungle of the shops and buildings in shinjuku and head over to this lovely park. I was there during summer and was glad it didn't rain. With the cool breeze and sunny skies, was a nice day to just lie down on the grass and appreciate what nature had to offer.For those who are not sure how to get there from the shinjuku station, look for the shinjuku WE (west East) bus and for only 100 Yen, you can take the bus for a tour of East and west shinjuku and eventually will stop by the park.
Quiet time amongst the busy streets. Beautiful escape from the busy streets. Enjoy the bridges/ponds and people watching. Take a bento box!

Great escape in a busy city . Even though Tokyo is one of the least polluted large city I visited, it is still very nice to visit this park and leave the buildings behind. This park has a large selection of landscapes, from Japanese gardens to open air green field through a botanical garden. Definitely worth a visit.

okay place to visit in the midst of a busy city. Came here on a Monday and it was closed. Came back the following day when the weather was overcast. Not too many people were here. I liked the pretty Japanese garden, the Taiwan Pavilion and the French garden. The English garden didn't have much to look at and I'm not sure why there was a mother and child's forest.

Unexpected beauty. I had one last day of solo travel before heading back home. I looked around on trip advisor to see what I hadn't yet done and stumbled across this national garden. It's gorgeous. It's low key, it has some beautiful flora. The greenhouse has beautiful plants that I've never seen. The flower garden is surprisingly meticulous. The tea houses are nice to visit. Buy a popsicle and then pop a squat under a tree to take in the beauty around you. Make sure you go at a reasonable hour as it closes around 4:30pm. Wear sunscreen and/or a hat.. it can get toasty during the summer. Lots of families and friends can be seen hanging out in the various patches of grass around the park.

Beautiful garden. Beautiful garden and well-maintained. Came here just after arriving to Japan and actually fell asleep in the sun. Lots of schoolchildren visiting, but the noiselevel was still low. Very nice place to go just to "get out of the city" for a few little while.
Gorgeous. Beautiful gardens that offer a variety of types of gardens. You can see Japanese, french, english etc. don't make the same mistake i made though, they are closed on Mondays!

Traditional Japanese Garden. This garden is in Shinjuku and is a modest size garden that you can see in about an hour. There is a Iris garden, which is in bloom in June and this is clearly one of the highlights. Garden is well manicured and has plenty of resting areas and lots of beautiful and serene spots to relax. Enjoyed a lovely afternoon here.
Beautiful during sakura. Nice place to come and relax after a hectic schedule in the city. Place is a bit big so need about 2-3 hours to explore the park.Beautiful selection of trees and flowers.

One of the best places for Sakura (Cherry blossoms). Here's something to remember about this garden. When all of the cherry blossoms have bloomed and past their peak go here. This garden/park has many varieties of Cherry Trees that bloom at different times so even if there are none left in Ueno Park or the Imperial Garden come here.The trails weave in and out between ponds and water features as well as by tea houses and pagodas. there is a lovely Greenhouse with orchids and more. It's a lovely place for a picnic and to spend an afternoon. It's my favorite park in Tokyo

Vast, but beauty awaits in every corner. The Shinjuku garden is absolutely superb. Its free entry makes it an attractive place for anyone wishing for time away from the bustle of Tokyo. It is insanely lush and the fresh flowers offer some of the most vibrant colors seen in nature. Great place to find some peace.

Lovely Classic Gardens. We visited during hanami (cherry blossom viewing). The cherry blossoms in this park are gorgeous and the large and beautifully designed grounds handle crowds well. Alcohol is banned, at least during this time, and there were searches at the entrances. The no alcohol rule gives this place a completely different feel from, for example,Ueno Park's hanami. Be sure to either bring something to eat or eat beforehand, because the food choices in this park are limited and not nearly as good as at Ueno Park.

Beautiful, Peaceful place. For a beautiful place to spend some peaceful time, this is the place to go. The gardens are filled with colors and designs of all kinds. The large fields were great for playing or taking a restful nap.

Beautiful!. This was a great way to spend a warm afternoon. The beautifully manicured gardens transport you to a place of tranquility in the heart of Tokyo. You can spend an hour or two easily wandering the grounds and looking at the different styles of gardens And nature. Will definitely visit again next time I come to Tokyo.

Peaceful, natural, calming & above all, authentic. I visited and walked the whole National Park in a couple of hours. No cherry blossom whilst I was there but it was lush, green and beautifully maintained. Some of the Tokyo skyline can still be seen from the National Park....

Very Nice. Beautiful garden, but not in November. Should visit in April for cherry blossom. It is a very famous place to see cherry blossom. Walking distance from Shinjuku station and hotel where I stayed, Shinjuku Washington.
Very busy at the weekends. The park was very busy the last weekend of March with lots of people out, locals and tourists enjoying the Cherry Blossom. But still very pleasant despite it being busy.

BEAUTIFUL!. We were here with my 17-month-old son on a public holiday so got free entry into the park! My son had a great time running around the garden.. There were lots of people relaxing there, blowing bubbles for nearby kids, singing songs and having a good time. My personal favourite was the Japanese garden with its neatly manicured shrubs and bonsais. Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful place to spend the morning. My husband and I spent the morning here and spent a good 2 hours just strolling around the gardens. Its very quite in there despite the amount of people that walk around. There is always a space you can find if you just want to be alone and enjoy the view. There is a small fee, from memory its $3 aud. There a vending machine to grab a drink and a cafe to get some food such as sushi and typical Japanese snacks. Great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.

Hidden oasis. Stumbled across this gem walking around shinjuku. In a city full with 16 million people it is nice to find a place with open areas and serenity. Garden is 200 yen to enter but absolutely worth it

An oasis in a hugh city. This is a nice place to spend a day with good weather just to stroll around and enjoy the quiet and calm that you never could imagen exist in this fantastic town..easy to reach and fund by subway and strongly recomended

Beautiful Garden. We only had a couple of hours to enjoy this beautiful garden, wish we had more time to walk around here. We only got to explore the Japanese Garden area. This place is right off of the JR Shinjuku stop. There is a cafe and plenty of sitting area to picnic. They also have a few vending machines there for drinks. I would highly suggest coming here during Sakura season.
Very beautiful gardens. A wonderful garden with so much to see. Very tranquil space to walk around and take in the ambience. And a magnificent greenhouse as well.

pleasant for strolling and enjoying one's self. There's a fee to enter but you can feel the values just in the maintenance of things, let alone the lovely landscaping and the very interesting greenhouse within. It was a really nice place to visit, there were people all over just enjoying the nice day with friends and families. I was alone and took my time to enjoy the nice scenery and take some photos.
Shinjuku gyoen. Peaceful place in the heart of Shinjuku. Beautiful in all seasons, especially during autumn and spring. Probably my favorite garden in Tokyo !

Best park in Tokyo.. Such a great day out. Relax, walk and contemplate this oasis. Lots of rules to follow, no ball games, frisbee, dogs, alcohol, and closes around 4.30pm (yes it's gated).Admission charged, about $3, closed on Mondays.The focus is on the botanical aspect. Great green house to explore.
A must if you like Japanese gardens.. This garden was a wonderful surprise. It's really beautiful. Depending on the season, you can see all kinds of flowers.

Great park in Spring time. Our hotel was about a 5 min walk to this garden. What a great place to admire the beautiful flora. There is a traditional Japanese garden, rose garden, english garden & a Glasshouse. We spent hours taking photos and exploring. Closed on Mondays. Great place to relax.

Chill and relax. A great place to just walk around and enjoy beautifull japanese garden i Would recomend it for all the couples out there looking for a nice relaxing time bring a picnic basket pack some fruits sandwichs and just chill for a bit btw be carefull of any karasu they will still your snacks and fly away

Beautiful Park. Beautifully landscaped park just a short walk from Shinjuku Station south exit. Approximately 3.5km to walk around the whole thing. Very well used with a lot of people in the park but there is plenty of room for everyone to enjoy. Entry fee was 200 JYN. Glasshouse inside the park is fascinating. You could spend half a day here easily if you like to sit and read a book. Or just 1-2 hours if you are out for a walk.

You should pay a visit for Sakura!. A worthwhile hanami spot! Easily reach by subway, just get yourself to Shinjuku gyeonmae (M10). Admission fees is 200yen. A huge park in the middle of city! I was there during last week of March and the view is just awesome! Many types of sakura and other flowers as well. To be expected that the park is very crowded, thus, please go earlier. If not, you will need to share your photos with strangers XD. Please put it in your itinerary for your coming sakura trip in Tokyo!

A walk among the cherry blossoms. The park is huge and has thousands of cherry trees. When they're in bloom, it's wonderful to stroll around and have a picnic there. Beware, however, you won't be alone - throngs of Japanese people will be doing the same, probably in an effort to escape the confines of their puny apartments! Well worth a half day in April :)

You must find the bamboo waterfall and stoop to gear it fall, hidden from view but like music!. Exquisitely manicured garden with that wonderful Japanese feeling of calm and order. Wandering round the pathways and seeing a different view at every turn is wonderful. Not a leaf or a stone is out of place. The acers are beautiful and grown to frame pictures of pools of calm. Japanese rock garden are perfectly combed , combining colour and texture in a way never seen anywhere else. On one pathway you will see a bamboo water feature. It is quite small and you could easily pass it by mistake. Lean down and gather a small container of water from the flow. When you pour it down the hole and bend to listen, a musical waterfall can be heard as it trickles down into the earth. So lovely!

Get lost for days. This is a really impressive park with beautiful gardens and is big enough to be able to get away from the crowds. I was certainly more impressed than I had been with the Imperial Gardens but that's purely a personal preference. Entrance fee is 200 yen and there is a shop to buy snacks and several vending machines for cold drinks.

A beautiful variety of Cherry Blossoms trees. I was lucky to be in Japan during the brief cherry blossom season. (Even though the country's range of flowers through the year is quite breathtaking.) We picnicked at the Shinjuku garden with (what seemed like) the entire population of Tokyo. But the park is so large & the Japanese folk so disciplined & discreet, that it really didn't matter. The park has various gardens in different styles. I loved the hothouse & the beautiful Japanese garden complete with its pond & bridge. Highly recommended at any time of the year because of the variety of flora.

Lovely Garden. We were in Tokyo around two weeks after the cherry blossoms peak season but we were still able to see lots of cherry blossoms in full bloom in this garden! What a lovely sight! So serene and welcome respite from the bustling city!

Great Park/Garden in Downtown Tokyo. I've been here multiple times over the years. It is an excellent visit if you going to be in Tokyo for an hour or 2. There is an admission fee of Y200 yen, and the park is about a 15 min walk from the station. There is wide expanses and a nice array of foliages and trees. The Japanese Garden inside as well as a rose garden inside are 2 of the highlights. Worth a look, but can be quite hot during summer outside.

Amazing during cherry blossom season. We visited this park mid April and there were still a lot of cherry blossoms out. It was beautiful, magical, like being in a film. The cherry blossom was falling from the trees, making you feel like you were being showered in confetti. It created a carpet of pink. So very special. The park would be beautiful outside of cherry blossom season too with the many trees, bridges and grassy areas. We visited on a Sunday afternoon so it was busy with families having picnics under the trees. Such a great atmosphere. There is a small fee of 200 yen to enter the park and this includes access to the amazing conservatory with the many varieties of plants and flowers.

refreshing in the middle of Shinjuku!. this is a present Emperor's garden which is open to public unless there is any event or on Monday. you can browse the English garden or Japanese garden, nap or walk around or see the green house. entrance fee is only 200 yen for adults. opening hours limited. no alcohol drinks allowed.

Park well worth the visit. One of the certain highlights of our visit to Tokyo, especially during the cherry blossom season. The Sakura trees were wonderful, and the park was busy - but without it being an annoyance. As there's a small fee to enter the park, the crowds are far smaller than in the public parks during the season. Well worth the trip, and it's just a short walk from the JR station!

Amazing gardens. There are 3-4 amazing gardens within the complex of National Garden: French, Japanese, English etc. They are very well maintained and the entrance fee is very reasonable. I was surprised to see so much open and green space right in the middle of the one of the most expensive city. The Taiwanese pavilion was very beautifully located around trees and small pond. The french garden had huge variety of roses.Overall this is a must attraction of Tokyo.

Beautiful Park. This park has a small fee of 200 yen to enter. It's quite large and well-maintained. Unfortunately, it closes quite early at 4:30pm. We arrived at 3pm and only had enough time to walk around and see the main things. I would allow at least 2 hours to visit the park or more if you're wanting to have a picnic and relax. There is also a green house with tropical and endangered plants, but it was closed when we tried to go. The English part of the garden wasn't much, but the Japanese and French portions were quite nice.

These gardens are stunning. I really loved this park, I was lucky enough to get there while the blossom was still there when it had disappeared from most other places. The gardens are stunning and it is well worth a relaxing walk around. Possibly my favorite park that I went to in Japan.

Highlight was lunch!. Gardens were nice but severely overgrown in areas and not the immaculate image we expected considering how pristine Japan is. Still worth a visit to escape the crowds and hustle and bustle of the city. Had lunch at the Eco restaurant inside the gardens... The food was cheap and tasty and the service was impeccable! Definitely stop there for lunch!!!
Peaceful and tranquil oasis. Could easily spend a day getting lost in this park. Lovely and peaceful break from the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku.

So tranquil. I loved it here. Whether you pack a pucnic with friends pr put on your joggers, its the perfect place. Come here to capture beautiful photos or sit and paint. There is a tea house which wasn't open. Perfect place for couples to come and fall even more in love!!
Lovely and peaceful. The park was very quiet when we went, and was absolutely beautiful to walk around. The park is well signed, in English, and there are many beautiful places to just sit and relax.
Beautiful. Had a great picnic lunch by the Japanese Gardens- really nice place to escape the bedlam that is Shinjuku!!

A haven from the hustle and bustle. We love Tokyo with all it's energy and the many things going on but it can be rather draining for travellers - Shinjuku Gyoen is a great place to revive those batteries and just chill for half a day before jumping back in. We loved the huge green house with it's waterfall and exotic plants and also enjoyed the set French, English and Japanese gardens. Good places to buy a snack or even sit down to a full lunch. Great experience all round.

A great escape from the busy city. After a short walk from the Shinjuku-goyemmae subway station, you come to this huge park. It's 200 yen per person to enter and it closes at 4:30pm, which had tripped us up the day before. We were happy enough just visiting the picturesque Japanese garden but there are also the French and English gardens. The area is vast and incredibly peaceful. You can glimpse the tops of the tall buildings beyond the park but the only sounds you will hear are the birds in the trees and the other people in the lark. This is a must-see if you want some time to relax in between walking and taking the subway.
Green in a jungle of grey. Magnificent oasis where one can walk and breathe and not be hassled by traffic.Take in the views, the air and the waters. Surprising place in the heart of the city.
Chill mood. Beautiful garden, Beautiful mood, Beautiful weather! I only got to see half of the garden, and regret that I didn't arrive earlier.
Beautiful! . A beautiful and serene escape from the city! Wonderful place to bring a book, relax under a tree and eat lunch, or just walk and explore nature in this big city!

Wonderful Japanese Garden. My wife and I caught the Metro from Ginza to Shinjuku-gyoemmae station and from there it was a very short walk to the gardens. We mainly walked around the beautiful Japanese gardens which were very peaceful. Saw lots of locals studying plants and even some painting the ponds and beautiful trees. Plenty of places to buy a snack or a drink on a hot day.

Huge garden. It is a huge park. Visit only if you have plenty of time on your hand. This is huge garden and cannot be seen in a rush. It is pretty amazing that such a quiet and serene garden is right in the middle of the city amidst all the high raises. Plenty of walking to do.I didn't have much time and just wanted to go see the Japanese garden, I was hoping to see Bonsais and such, but was a little disappointed to not see those or may be I didn't go to the right end of the garden.

Wonderful!. Do you need a place to relax? Go to Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden! We went there after we'd just arrived in Tokyo. This park was the perfect place to relax after our 12 hours flight!TIP: Take a towel or some kind of mat with you because the grass might be prickly. Locals often bring a (plastic) picnic mat.

Lovely park in the center of the city. We went there on a Sunday and enjoyed seeing Japanese families walking and picnicking in this lovely city park. The park includes a very nice and extensive Japanese garden, an okay English garden and an attractive French garden. On a warm day, it's a great respite from the heat and activity in Tokyo.

Amazing Site to See. The National Garden is a place you simply can't miss. I visited twice, once in November 2014 and once in February 2015. Even in the cool winter weather it is a great place to visit. Walk around and enjoy the scenery, people watch, take in one of the best garden's in Tokyo. We made a list of sights to see on these trips and this one was at the top of the list. The list of reasons for this could go on and on but please make sure you include this on your list of activities in Tokyo. You cannot pass this up.
Sweet little park. Very peaceful park, a very pleasant place to spend a moment away from the hustle of the city. Its on the way to the sumo museum.

A nice garden to visit if in Tokyo. Not a Central Park or Kew Gardens which would merit 5 stars, but still a lovley little park with nice flower area, some interesting trees, and lots of paths to follow. We were sad to reach the what-looked-interesting hot house at 3 pm and find it closing. Much too early!
Nice Place to Relax and Unwind. Huge park that could take up to 2 hours for you to enjoy and take photos. Come on Spring when the Sakura trees are in full bloom!

Gorgeous park in the heart of Tokyo. Amazing park with sections dedicated to different countries. Traditional Japanese, French colonial, Taiwanese style etc. A pittance for entry and well priced food available at the kiosk. Try the chilli hot cocoa! Smokers can only smoke in designated areas so check your English map for that. Enjoy!

Sheer Size Makes It a Winner. With only time to see a couple of things in Tokyo before we left we chose to stop by the Shinjuku Gyoen Nation Garden for an hour in the evening. As others have mentioned, this garden is huge. That is both a blessing and a curse! Due to the size it is relatively easy to get away from the crowds though some of the more desirable areas will always be busy. The down side is the fact that it takes a lot of time to really see the entirety of the park! In the hour we were there we really only saw a third or so. Admittedly, we were taking our time.There are plenty of things to do in Tokyo; the National Garden is definitely one of the better stops you could make. Plan to make your visit at least a couple hours if you want to see everything.

What an amazing City with polite & systematic public. I was amazed at the courtesy & consideration of the Japenese people towards each other even in the overly crowded places be it the streets or markets.Not a single time I saw anyone being pushed or shoved around.If you were in their way, they would actually move away & let you pass happily. unlike other crowded cities where people won't budge from your path. A truely Polite Culture & Great Nation

Hot day in the park. Beautiful tranquil setting, very peaceful and with beautiful trees and bushes. My only criticism was that although there are plenty of spaces to sit, there are not so many grassy areas to chill out. I went on one day that was particularly hot and humid. The local people were enjoying their lunch upright and in the shade. I wanted a space to lie down, in the sun, and sunbathe. Still I would go back and enjoy.

Refreshing. The sprawling 58 hectare...almost 4km circumference garden has around 20,000 trees. An awesome place to visit and experience Sakura or Cherry Blossom at its full bloom! Perfect for a quiet family outing especially in the early mornings.

Relaxing stroll!. The garden was a bit hard to find; kind of hidden in some deeper streets off the main Shinjuku area. We would suggest going a bit later than mid-March as the cherry blossoms were not fully blossomed yet- only saw a dozen of them blossomed. Overall quite a nice stroll, they have cherry blossom featured food items (mostly sweet) that you can buy. Super nice and good cleaniness. Check out our vlog documentation about it!https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CdkT1N4sWP0

Visit to Shinjuku Garden on a Sunday morning. I went there on a nice & sunny Sunday morning with a friend & enjoyed the visit to a very nicely kept traditional Japanese garden. It is pretty big so takes a bit of time to walk through & see all the different mini gardens inside but it is worth it. I was also pleasantly surprised with the no of people having a picnic/get together there as well as no of artists making paintings of flowers.
Pleasant Park. If you're staying in Shinjuku, this is a nice park to have a walk around. Probably not worth making a trip for though.

The search for balance . Call it serendipity.The decision to stay at Shinjuku resulted in morning walks through the gardens.The garden is deep and as the sun shines through the thick foliage, near magical.As luck would have it, a girl played the violin in the gardens that morning and as the tunes wafted through the greenery, oh all my troubles seemed faraway. The museum is a picture perfect example of the old existing with the skyscrapers which seem to peer over. Keep walking, your mind gets refreshed with every step.

An oasis in Shinjuku!. It's a gorgeous park with Japanese, English and French gardens. When we went, the rose bushes in the French garden were at their peak and it was just fantastic! It's also got a greenhouse, which houses the tropical plants.You can probably walk the whole thing in 3-4 hours.You pay 200 yen to get in. Definitely worth it!

Beautiful park with cherry blossoms. We spent the afternoon walking around this beautiful park and were lucky enough to be there in cherry blossom season with the sun shining. Highly recommend visiting if the weather is good.Be aware that it closes quite early (approximately 4.30pm).

Peaceful Place from the City. The park is basically split to two parts: western and eastern. The western part consists of a green house and a French garden, and the eastern has some nice pavilions and a Japanese garden. The place isn't too big, but it was a nice place to retreat from the bustling city. It is very inexpensive to enter, and when we went, there were a lot of elementary kids in school trips. The French garden consisted of a lot of mixed roses. Overall, it was nice.

serenity garden. as with all the exquisitely kept gardens in Japan the Shinjuku Gyoen is no exception.harmony and serenity are both offered in the heart of a bustling city precinct.a calming escape for a time to suit your own day.accessible by public transport.we visited during sakura season which of course is the ultimate time.high recommended.
Nice. It is recommend to visit during the stay in Tokyo. Nice garden, you can also have picnic in here. It would be great in Sakura Season!

Beautiful!. We visited on an extremely wet day toward the end of the cherry blossoms.Despite the weather we found this park a gorgeous oasis in the middle of Tokyo.We spent a couple of hours rambling around the various sections of the park and also enjoyed time in one of the tea houses.
Calm. This place is at Shinjyuju(so crowed city).but I entered the garden,feel calm.I can be relax in there.nice place!新宿という土地ながらとても落ち着く空間です。お花見の時期は混んでいますが普段は静かです。本を読んだりしてゆっくりと過ごせます。
Beautiful. Very convenient place to visit and very cheap only 200yen ($2 AUD). This was very nearby other attractions we were keen to see and the Japanese garden was beautiful.
Nice greenery from the concrete jungle.. A nice escape from the concrete jungle around the hotel. Was there in the early morning was was quiet and serene.

turist. very beauteful park. You have to pay to get in. The japanese garden in the park was very beauteful, as the Cherry Trees were bloming. There should be 1000 cherry trees. The french part of the park was to early to visit, because is was most roses. And the English part was not so interesting, but the japanese .... wonderful.
Large public park in the middle of the city. Beautiful gardens and paths to walk around all day. Food and beverage outlets too if you get hungry or thirsty. Only 200¥ entry fee. Well worth the money

Nice park in Shinjuku. This is a nice park in Shinjuku. It´s not free of charges it will cost 400 Yen. You can have a nice lunch in one of its tea houses great value. Nice area in a very busy area of Tokyo!

Great people watching and relaxation. Fantastic place for everyone...families, couples, and yeah, even a solo journeyman like myself (insert violins playing here). Good for a walk, good for cuddling on a secluded bench amongst the trees, good for frolicking, and good to sit and watch the masses do the previous 3 things. Must be amazing when the Cherry Blossoms are blooming, or the azaleas are in full swing. Carve out some time for this place.
Stunning!. My first day in Tokyo and I went to Gyoen Gardens to see the cherry blossoms - it was breathtaking. Everything I had hoped for and so much more.

Fantastic place for cherry blossom. We had clear blue sky on our day here with so much cherry blossom you did not know where to look. Highly recommend this during cherry blossom season, but it would be pretty any time of the year.

Stunning Gardens. These botanic gardens are divided into a number of sections, of which one is Japanese. While the gardens cover a large area, we only spent time in the Japanese gardens and were completely satisfied. As we were there in the first week of April, the gardens were teeming with cherry blossoms, as well as budding maple trees and a wide variety of other beautifully manicured shrubs and trees. There are a couple of ponds to wander around, with bridges crossing the water. There is also a temple in the grounds that make a wonderful photo opp. It was lovely to see so many families out enjoying the gardens and having a picnic under the trees. There were plenty of places to buy food or drinks to enjoy while you roam the grounds. We spent a couple of hours just in the Japanese part of the garden and I'm sure the other areas are equally as beautiful. If you have the time to spare, I would recommend you take the time to enjoy a stroll around the whole garden. It would probably take most of the morning or afternoon at least if you want to take in the whole garden.

A beautiful garden/park - expect to be here a long time!. Expected to pop in and out again but this is the most beautiful (and large) garden, with Japanese, English and French themed areas. We were lucky to see the stunning cherry blossom, ranging from white, through various shades of pink, and the wonderfully coloured acers and maples, reflected in the many ponds. We arrived early and slowly saw the garden fill with picnicking families and amateur photographers keen to catch the varied foliage. We marvelled at the enormous Koi carp and at a bride and groom posing in traditional wedding costumes. We saw some interesting bird life and enjoyed the large greenhouse. Refreshments available within the park. We loved the pleasant hours we spent here.

Beautiful gardens. A nice walk takes an hour or all day, was very colourful, was a little disappointed in the Japanese garden section though, French and Greenhouse nice. Can walk from Shinjuku station past main shopping area
Sakura!. Lovely place to visit during Spring. Visited just in time for the bloom of the amazing sakura in the garden. Beautiful park!

Beautiful Cherry Blossom. We were fortunate enough to go during cherry blossom season and experienced this beautiful time of year.
The park was full of people having picnics and enjoying the amazing blossom. It was truly an amazing experience as everyone seemed so happy. Definitely worth the visit.

superb. beautiful park well worth a visit.very well designed.very photogenic place for pictures. entry fee is charged but its worth it.a park well designed for all age groups.it wasn't much crowded on our visit.the cherry blossoms make the park look even more beautiful.very beautiful serene place.would surely visit this place again when in tokyo.

Cherry Blossoms!. Very nice place to visit in shinjuku! Amazing view of the cherry blossoms! Its a really huge place so takes about and hour or 2 to walk around here as there are so many views great for photography!

Good for Family visit. I love this garden park, the addmission is only 200 Yen but you can stay whole day enjoying a picnic lunch, beautiful Japanese garden, peaceful nap under the tree......one of the best place to spend yourrelaxing family time in Tokyo.
A lovely peaceful park with some beautifully designed areas.. A lovely peaceful park with some beautifully designed areas. Can be a great escape from the madness of the city.

Fabulous park and perfect when you have small children. Interesting, beautiful, safe with wide open spaces and lots of Japanese families, mothers' groups and other children for my kids to make friends with.
Beautiful garden. I and my husband visited this place during cherry blossoms. It was quite crowded but we still enjoyed the view.

The "Central Park" of Japan. To visit this park you have to pay a fee, but it is worth it as it is very well maintained. Visiting hours are limited so do plan ahead. There is also a Summer House inside. If there are no trees bloomed things still look good. The skyscrapers around the park gives you the sense that this is a metropolis, but the Japanese type areas of the park gives you a sense of authenticity.

Heaven on earth. If you go to Tokyo and don't visit this one consider your visit lame. It's one of the most stunning gardens I have ever seen, and I've seen loads. I was lucky to be there during the cherry blossom season, but cherry blossom or not, this garden merits a visit anyway. Just go and enjoy. I don't believe heaven exists, but if it does, it must look like Shinjuku Gyoen.

Good example of the Japanese garden. You should visit it the beginning of April when the cherry tree blossom. We almost missed it, we were there in end of April. You can have a nap good place to rest in the city.

Best Hanami Experience. It was cherry blossom season and flowers were blooming everywhere..
great picnic spot, fantastic view and do nothing!
just to sit there and feel the serenity of that place was enough to convince me to visit again soon.

Walk up an appetite and eat at Yurinoki Restaurant. We were here for cherry blossom season so a real cultural and aesthetic wonder. We went back a second time just to revisit Yurinoki Resaurant, inexpensive and wholesome but the main attraction is the small army of 'older' waitresses who are just lovely.

Peaceful Garden. Shinjuku Gyoen has three gates. I chose to use Sendagaya Gate, as it would be the easiest way to go from Ikebukuro where I was staying. I went to Shinjuku by JR Yanamote Line and changed to Chuo-Sobu Line on the other side of the same platform to Sendagaya. Sendagaya station has only one exit. When you exit, turn right immediately and then turn right again to go under the railway bridge. Keep going along the iron fence of Shinjuku Gyoen. Soon you will come to Sendagaya Gate. I arrived there at 9:30am and there was no queue at the ticketing counter, although cherry blossoms were still in full bloom. Admission fee was 200yen per adult. There was a security check counter. Free maps in Japanese were available inside the garden and maps in English were available from the ticketing office. The English one has more precise information for visitors including the historical background of the garden. I found this garden very friendly and enjoyable, because we could go right close to the cherry blossom trees to take photos. I walked along the pond and took many photos. I was able to sit down on a bench to enjoy the serenity and beauty of the garden without being bothered by a crowd of people. There were many professional photographers setting up their cameras on tripods. I thoroughly enjoyed Japanese garden around the pond. By 11:30am I noticed that more visitors began to arrive. So I decided to leave without going to see French and English gardens. I saw several people lined up at the ticketing counter. As I walked back to Sendagaya station, a stream of people going to the garden carrying their lunch. I remembered about the Japanese tradition of eating and drinking under the cherry blossoms. It was the best place of all I visited during my 6-day stay to Tokyo during the cherry blossom season.

Relaxed time spent in the park ... Visited this park in the fourth week of April 2015 when cheery blossoms are still watchable. The authorities charge a nominal fee to enter the park. The park is divided into different landscapes for e.g Japanese, English etc. You can pick up a spot in one of these landscapes and relax for few hours or you take a long stroll crossing these different landscapes one after another. The park is visited by a lot of tourists and is generally full. You would see groups, couples sitting and little kids playing all over the park and it gives the park a great energy. There are few places where you can get a decent refreshment. There are few water bodies as well where you would get to see bridges and fishes, We also stayed close to one of these ponds and spent some relaxed & beautiful times. Definitely I would like to visit it again whenever I get a chance next.

Very Pretty. It was a nice stroll to the park. Got to see one single cherry blossom tree in late May. Though, we locked our bikes inside the gate and got out on a different side. When we returned, they had closed the gates and there was no way of getting the bikes back until next day. So if you are riding on bikes, remember the gates close by 5.
Cherry blossom season. Great park, especially if you go like we did during the cherry blossom season. There is a small admission fee for the park but it's nominal. definitely recommended.
Spring Blossom. We visited second week of April so best possible time for the cherry and other blossoms. Of course also the busiest possible time to visit but great place to spend a few hours walking

Beauty beyond description. This is the most beautiful garden I've ever visited. We were lucky to be there during the peak Sakura period which makes all the differences. The colors and vibrance of nature is beyond description. Must visit when in Tokyo!

Lovely lovely lovely. I just caught the end of the cherry blossoms. Stunning park in the Japanese gardening tradition. There was a traditional archery contest going on when I was there...there were kimonos on Sunday as well

Beautiful Contrasting Gardening layouts. Set underneath the mini version of the Empire State Building is a great break from the crowded city streets of Tokyo. Slow down with a relaxing stroll thru well maintained and manicured gardens
Beautiful !!. Highly recommended especially during spring!! The many types of cherry blossoms r breathtaking and the Japanesw garden is beautiful too.

A beautiful park. We visited this garden in mid April. It is a very cheap to enter this garden, at 300 yen. Lots of families sitting under trees having picnic lunches. So we joined them and had our lunch on the grass as well. It being the end of the Cherry Blossom season there were no single blossom "Sakura" trees in bloom but there were still several large trees covered in double blossoms in both white and pink. There was just a hint of the azaleas coming into bloom which would have been better seen at the end of April.

A boring park with little going for it out of season. It was well rated so I had high hopes and I went early (jet lag) to see it in the quiet of the morning. It was empty, probably because it didn't have much to do /see and without Cherry Blossoms it's a boring park with little to do or see. Very disappointed.

Quite inexpensive, much fun. Beautiful park! You can feel relaxed sitting on the grass, seeing flowers, looking into the greenhouse, having lunch, etc.Only one attention: you cannot bring any alcohol drink. And maybe barbecue is not allowed..?Very good place though.

Historic garden oasis in the middle of Shinjuku. We managed to grab a couple of hours in the gardens on a Sunday towards the end of cherry blossom season. Because it was a beautiful day, and a Sunday - it was filled with families and groups of friends having bento and looking at the last of the cherry blossoms. But even though there were so many people, it was still relaxing, and the garden has so many paths that it was easy to avoid the crowds.The garden dates back to the beginning of the Edo period, when it was a residence of Naito Kiyonari, then it became the Naito Shinjuku Experimental Farm, cultivating western fruits and vegetables. It then became an Imperial garden but by 1949 it was opened to the public. Although it was the end of the Sakura season, there were still blossoms - the garden has 1,100 cherry blossom trees (65 varieties) there is even a magnolia tree said to date from the Edo period, but that had bloomed before we got there. We saw koi and even some turtles in the ponds. Grab an English map when you buy your ticket, so you don't miss any part of the garden - we ran out of time to see the French Formal Garden, but was glad to see most of the Japanese traditional.Admission fee was ¥200 ($2.10 AUD), it's a 5 min walk from each of the 3 stations you can enter by - Shinjuku-Gyoenmae, Shinjuku-Sanchome or Kokuritsu-Kyogijo The JR line station is JR Sendagaya or JR Shinjuku Closed Mondays unless it is a public holiday. (Although open everyday during Spring and Autumn) hours are 9an - 4pm.

Great for cherry blossom. Visited during the tail end of the cherry blossom season. The garden is huge, having a Japanese and French gardens within. However, giving it size, there is really very little to see.

Beautiful Gardens. We were lucky that the Cherry Blossom season was late this year, because the garden was filled with them! A serene traditional Japanese garden that is a nice break from the craziness of Tokyo.

Stunning garden. Stunning garden close to Shinjuku station. We were lucky enough to visit on a beautiful sunny spring day in the cherry blossom season. Each corner you turned afforded a even better view with stunning landscaping and beautiful trees. There was a small tea house where for 750 yen you received a small bowl of green tea and a sweet served by a lovely Japanese lady in a kimono. Must see garden in Tokyo. Plenty of public toilets and vending machines selling iced drinks. There was also a small stall selling delicious sushi bento boxes which we ate in one of the rest area pavilions. Beautiful place!!!

Most exquisite during cherry blossom season. Now this is the number one spot in Tokyo when you just seat down, chat with friends, drink and be merry underneath all those beautiful cherry blossoms. I went here around hanami and what a sight it was! Several different kinds of cherry trees were blooming and thousands were line up in this enormous park. It was literally sublime! The Japanese garden was probably the best. Already went here twice, last time it was during autumn. The trees were crimson red and were quite beautiful as well. But nothing beats being in Japan than just staring into those beautiful, pink cherry blossoms. A must see!

enjoy nature in the middle of the city, Shinjuku.. this is a garden of the Emperor open to public for minimum fee. quite big area with Japanese garden, English garden, and more. open hours limited up to 16:30 or 17:00 depending on the season.
Great escape from seedy Shinjuku. This is a beautiful garden where you can relax and escape the city. It's quite large but can be a short or large trip if required. Nice for photographers..
Beautiful in cherry blossom time. A real treat in Tokyo this magnificent garden with lots of cherry trees. A must to visit not only in the cherry blossom season but at other times as well
Good place for cherry blossom viewing. As there are different variety of cherry blossom trees in this area, no worries of not Able to see cherry blossom even if u come during mid - end April (:

Great Japanese garden. This was our first garden we visited while in Japan and really liked it. The entrance fee of 200 Yen P.P. can be paid using the machines before the entrance. We were lucky enough to experience the end of the cherry blossem, a very nice relaxing park/garden. Definately worh the visit

Beautiful gardens in different styles. Japanese, French and English style gardens with typical Japanese building and bridges. Lovely views and an oasis of tranquility in the heart of Tokyo. Drink green tea served by a gheisha or just hang around.

Nice place for cherry blossom and maple leaves!. Walking from JR shinjuku for about 15 minutes and you would arrive this gorgeous garden. The garden had plenty of different species of cherry blossom and other flowers which made your spring trip quite romantic! If you visited in autumn, there was also a great place for maple leaves, too.

GORGEOYS CHERRY BLOSSOMS!. Visited April Friday 17 April -gorgeous Spring day. Plenty of Sakura blooming still (loved the weeping Cherry Blossom trees) had a great time strolling this park. Will definitely return on our next visit April 2017!

Tokyo Tranquility. We were fortunate to be there the week the cherry blossoms came out, and though they were just beginning to bloom, it was an amazing sight to see. Aside from the cherry blossoms though, the garden offers a perfect counterpoint to the business of the city. Lots of open space and greenery and a huge greenhouse as well. If you are there when the weather is nice, you can bring picnic materials and spend your lunch there on the grass, great way to relax!

A must see. Although we are not generally park goers this was our second visit to Shinjuku Gyoen National Park. Missed the Cherry Blossoms but everthing else was stunning.A must see, Remember it is closed on Mondays

Beautiful park.. beautiful cherry blossoms!. We visited Shinjuku Gyoen on a rainy morning early this month. The rain brings out the beauty of the park and the cherry blossoms even more! We truly enjoyed our walk around the park.. enjoying the many types of cherry blossoms which r blooming so beautifully. This park is a gem and is truly worth visiting.

Beautiful and Tranquil. The Shinjuku Gyoen was absolutely beautiful and a very well maintained garden. You will especially appreciate all the greenery, if like me, you are from a country like Qatar that is somewhat deprived of any lucious nature.
Despite the amount of people there it was still very calm and peaceful, well worth the nominal charge to get in.

A wonderful morning . Went to the gardens on a beautiful Sunday morning and could not have been more pleased with the decision. Many families and couples enjoying the park and the scenes is splendid. Must see landmark in Shinjuku!
Sakura. Lots of cherry blossom to view in the first part of April and some classical landscape designs. Space to sit and have a picnic or let kids have a run around

首都圏のオアシス Oasis for a metropolitan area. 東京は、安全で快適、かつ刺激的な都市ですが、緑が少ないのが欠点です。しかし、この新宿御苑は、例外的に豊かな自然環境が維持されている公園です。あなたが自然な環境で一休みしたいと思った時には、ぜひこの公園にお立ち寄りください。春と秋は、気候も良く、さまざまな花々が咲いていますので、特にお勧めです。ただし、４月上旬頃は花見客で大混雑しますので、この時期は、午前中の訪問が良いと思います。また、酒の持ち込みは禁止されていますので、ご注意を！Tokyo is safe, comfortable and exciting city, but has little natural environment. However, Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden exceptionally maintains beautiful natural scenery. In case you want to rest in the bosom of nature, why don't you stop by it? In particular, it's good season to visit here in spring and autumn because various flowers bloom one after another. Only the biginnings of April, it's congested due to the cherry-blossom season, I recommend you go there in the morning. Finally, please make sure drinking alcohol is prohibited in this park.

Beautiful cherry blossom. I went here with my wife, she insisted that we have to go here. Finally I agreed with her suggestion, it was a beautiful garden with the cherry blossom still blooming in some of the trees... Nice place for couple, family and for people who likes photography...Just a suggestion if you want to come here, you'd better come in March so you'll see the full cherry blossom season.

One of the best. A very interesting and beautiful garden with a Japanese, English and French section. I visited when the cherries blossomed but it is so well designed I am sure it is a delight all year round.Very well maintained and plants are marked in Japanese, but botanical names are also given in roman letters. With so many languages in the world you can hardly do better than giving the botanical name.An absolute delight.

Good Sakura,,,. Beautiful park with a lot of Cherry blossom, the Japanese Garden and the Tea house where also worth to see.A little rain but still good family time, close to Sendagaya subway station and close to a very famous Takeshita street.I ate a really good crepes in Takeshita street.
A Treasure of a Park. It is rated as one of Japan's best and is worth the rating. The three gardens, especially the Japanese are worth the tiMe.

Three Hours Well Spent. If you're into gardens and you're ion Tokyo at cherry blossom time this was one to see. So many different varieties-some in mass plantings, some on the edge of the lovely lawn area. I wasn't so impressed with the Japanese garden but the bare Sycamore trees were stunning and I'm sure the formal French garden would be beautiful in summer.
Great nature trip in Tokyo. Vegetation was beautiful. Park benches ideal for reading and big grounds for picnics. Being tourists, we wish there were English description of trees/flowers.
Sakura season. Went here few weeks ago for "hanami" which is a japanese tradition for viewing flowers and picnic under the sakura trees.. I love this place as it is very peaceful and so beautiful <3

great park. We visited here twice during cherry blossom peak. Wonderful park with wide open grassy areas, ponds, and hundreds of cherry trees. The park is so big that even with thousands of visitors, it doesn't seem crowded

Let it be. Come here during spring. Place to be alone or to have picnic during spring under the sakura tree. Beautiful place to be. Even the local love this place. Romantic place for couples. Photographers find this place really lovely. Stretch your legs.

This place is huge!. This place is huge and we did not managed to venture the whole area. We were there during the Sakura season thus the flowers are all blooming and very nice colours. There plenty of space to lay down your picnic mat and basket and enjoy the moment.

Beautiful Sakura. This garden was our 1st stop in our itinerary list for Tokyo. Sakura was on full bloom & weather was sunny when we arrived. The well kept garden is so charming and breathtaking. I bet it is lovely at any season. People can have picnics there but no alcohol allowed so it is good to bring your kids.The garden is close at 4.30pm sharp so make sure you come at the right time. Please refer to their website for more details http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3034_001.html

must see in tokyo!. For me, this was the highlight of my Tokyo stay. Very calming and peaceful to be among the cherry blossoms. Very very lucky indeed to have chanced on the blooming period. Now i understand why the japanese just sit down and relax under the trees. Bring a book and some snacks and enjoy the day. Kids can run around and play games. However, the comfort rooms are quite smelly. We went to the one near a dining area and we could not even walk near it since the stench is really dreadful. Fortunately, found a cleaner one on an offbeat track, but it its the squat type.

Tranquility just minutes from the hustle of Shinjuku Station. We were fortunate enough to visit Tokyo in April when the cherry blossom was out. This garden was very pleasant for taking a stroll to get away from the hectic urban sprawl that is Tokyo.

Perfect for Cherry Blossom viewing. My friends and I went to visit this place for Cherry Blossom viewing. We visited at the end of March and most of the Cherry Blossoms have bloomed.The park charges Y200 as entrance fee. You can bring your mat and choose your spot to have picnic. There are also food stalls inside where you can buy food if you haven't brought in some.If you want to see this the Cherry Blossoms this is a good place. It's in Shinjuku and closest to Shinjuku Gyoenmae Station. Here you can see different types of Cherry Blossoms and of different shades. There are also different types of garden within the park. But the park can get really crowded during the Cherry Blossom season. When we left at around 1pm the park was so full of people already. This is a good place to see Sakura.
Beautiful sakura. Our timing was great, we visited this park in last week of March 2015 and it was 70% bloom. Well, ok, it's not 100% full bloom but its still soo beautiful. What else can I say...
