Gorgeous. There is an entrance fee so you can't just go there to jog at any hour of the morning or evening. It is a beautiful park and was crowded with picnickers on the day we went (Sunday afternoon during sakura season)
Pretty but nothing too special. If you're in Tokyo for a while, make a visit. But it's nothing too amazing. Better off going to Meiji Jingu so you can see gardens and the temple

Beautiful Garden. Huge botanical garden with lots to see and many environments to admire. The garden is laid out into many different sections, both western and eastern. The eastern gardens have a beautiful sense of space and colour and you can see them from many angles. If you can catch it on a nice day take a picnic as the options there are a bit slim. There is loads to see so definitely set aside a few hours.

Beautiful late "hanami" (cherry blossom viewing). We visited middle of April and most of the cherry blossoms were gone. However this park still has the white variant of the cherry blossoms and a few pink ones scattered in the park. It is a truly beautiful sight and a must see when visiting Japan. The park was still filled with "hana" plus there was a lake in the middle that boasted of amazing Japanese landscaping.

Best park in Tokyo. This is my third time visiting this park and it still captivates me. I managed to catch it at the end of the Cherry Blossom Flowering and grab some great photos. It takes about 2 hours to walk around and taking the time to have Green Tea at one of the tea houses is a must.

Beautiful Park. We went during Cherry Blossom time so it was crowded but beautiful. There is a small entrance fee and bags are checked for alcohol. There is an indoor Greenhouse, which is worth a visit. The park also has a Japanese Garden, a French Garden and an English Garden. All are beautiful. People picnic under the many trees. It closes around 4PM/5PM so make sure you get there early enough to explore this large park.

Spectacular!. This is simply a must in Tokyo during this time of year. The cherry blossoms transfix you.This is not a long excursion either. You can complete the whole park within 2 hours and continue to check out the rest of what Shinjuku has to offer.

Lovely National Garden. The entrance to Shinjuku Gyoen was crowded earlier this month, but this former imperial garden is so vast that our group was able to enjoy the park and the beautiful cherry blossoms. Some of the trees offered dramatic backdrops for photos since the branches came down to the ground. The teahouses had cherry blossom-themed snacks for sale. We were surprised to see people on the lawns, and were not sure if this was permitted outside of the cherry blossom season. One person in our group purchased plastic mats at the refreshment stand and we happily joined the others in relaxing on the lawns. It's hard to believe that a busy city surrounds the park.

Great for relaxing cherry blossoms. Not as happening as other parks.. Gorgeous area for being completely enveloped in the cherry blossoms. If you have an afternoon it is worth a stroll or a picnic. Lots of school children were playing and business people took their afternoon lunches in the park. However, if you are looking for the party park, it is Ueno. I've included some of the pretty photos of cherry blossoms here.
Beautiful garden . This garden is amazing and peaceful. It's not expensive to get into. It's big! With beautiful small ponds. You can have a picnic there which is lovely.

Beautiful scenery and parks, close to train station.. We were a little early for Cherry Blossom season, arriving here at the end of March - some of the trees were blooming, but many others still had buds on them.The park is quiet beautiful and within walking distance to the station. Well worth viewing.Bento boxes were being sold at the park and they were fantastic.

My favourite park in Tokyo. This was the first park I visited in Tokyo. It was cherry blossom season and beautiful. It was raining heavy but this did not disturb how lovely this park was. There is a green how with a waterful and a amazing traditional Japanese garden. The park is split is sections of didn't views and feels, this helps makes the park feel less busy.

Fantastic!. We visited the garden to see the cherry blossom trees and whilst we were late in the season we were not disappointed. Beautiful large gardens! Close to train stations! We visited the Japanese and English gardens and it was a treat! Simple ¥200 entry fee which was fine, some people I read complained about this, but what's ¥200? I assume it's for the upkeep and the garden is well kept! Some beautiful treasures throughout including a traditional tea house etc.A must do even when cherry blossom season isn't on!

Beautiful Place for Hanami. We went there during the cherry blossom season and even though it was near the end of the season in Tokyo, there are still cherry blossom tress in full bloom as they are many different variety of cherry blossom trees there. On a sunny day, the whole park is a beautiful pink, white and green and many people are seen picnic while hanami.There's an entrance fee of 200 yen per person but it is definitely worth it. Alcohol are also not allow and they do check your bags and smell your drinks for it so don't even think of trying to secretly bring alcohol in.

Beautiful. Strolled around the park with the cherry blossoms blooming. Absolutely beautiful. The park us a rather large one for an Asian city. It is very peaceful. The glasshouse in the park is worth a visit for the collection of orchids.

Wow - beautiful cherry blossoms. Thought we were going to miss the cherry blossoms this year. What a beautiful sight - the reds, pink and white blossoms in every corner of your vision. A once in a life time sight in this beautiful park.
Great view. I went to Japan in the middle of April and i still able to see the sakura in garden. I love it and the weather is really sunny at that time

Sakura. On a very wet day, we went to visit this iconic garden. We were welcomed by the most amazing number of cherry blossoms in full bloom, where the season is nearly over. We were so impressed by the amazing display without anyone else.What a very fortunate outcome and wonderful afternoon.A man in the street told us not to waste our time going there, but luckily we persisted.Thank you

Just so beautiful. I came to know this place while I was doing my plans in Tokyo. I came here first week of April to see sakura, cherry blossom in bloom and I was not disappointed. The park is breathtaking with all cherry blossoms in full bloom. I was in awe just looking at them. Do not miss this place during sakura, lovely indeed.
Lovely park. We visited just at the start of the cherry blossom on a sunny day. Spacious and pretty park, worth visiting if you have the time and like that sort of thing.
Best place to view sakura. The garden is so big, you need a whole day to spend there. The alchohol drink is not permitted in the garden,don't bring one,they'd check yor belnongings before you got in.

Great Park. Always nice to return to this beautiful garden right near walking distance from Shinjuku. Nice retreat from all the concrete and traffic.
Even better when its blossom season. Lots of path in and out of trees to explore. Very beautiful.
So nice I went there both Sunny days in an otherwise cruddy weather week in Tokyo.
Don't miss it.

Stunning place. Went here during the hanami season in the beginning of April and it was simply beautiful. It is not so far away from the shinjuku station, therefore you should definitely go visit. It only cost a small fee around 200 yen. I recommend bringing some food and spending a relaxing afternoon here.
Worth a visit. Small charge to go in but worth visiting, particularly during cherry blossom season, as it is well kept and large enough to have a good walk around or find a picnic spot

Beautiful garden!!. One of the most beautiful garden I've ever visited, it's a big garden, lots of beautiful Sakura trees. Very nice and tranquil, it was not too crowded when I went there. After the entrance, there is a stall that sell sakura flavor soft ice cream, and after tasting a few of sakura ice cream during my trip to Japan, the one I ate at Shinjuku Gyoen's stalll is the best sakura ice cream!!
Simply Beautiful !. Large gardens; lots to explore, I got lucky to visit during Cherry blossom. It was simply beautiful . Must visit the traditional Japanese garden

Destination garden during sakura season. Morning and afternoon light is wonderful for this garden and taking photos. A short walk from Shinjuku station and you are right in the heart of cherry blossoms in the middle of the city. The crowds will be there but there is enough room to walk around and find a spot to enjoy a hamani.They are checking that you don't bring in alcohol so be respectful and don't try. Grab a box lunch from the station or a food store nearby. Make sure to have plenty of memory on your camera! A walk around the park to get your bearings is useful then go back for photos or wait for crowds to pass by to get less crowded shots. With all the people sports such as frisbee or throwing/kicking a ball will be met with rude stares. Be nice and leave the sports at home for this one in sakura season.There are plenty of toilets and food to be had once in the park. It does close around 4PM even in peak season so don't plan to go late or you will be hurried out along with all the other onlookers.

One of the most beautiful parks I have sene. This is a very beautiful park to stroll around in. We were lucky to be there when the cherries blossomed and it was amazing.Don't miss having a cup of green tea in the traditional tea houses.

Huge and great park. Tokyo has many beautiful gardens. This may be the most beautiful one. you pay 200 yens at the entrance, but this is really nothing. Have some food with you and some drink. If you have your jeans on, you don't need a mat. Just sit on the special grass and enjoy the beautiful trees and flowers. You can find food and drink inside but not that much option.Don't forget, going in and out is from the same gate and the park is really big.

Beautiful oasis in Shinjuku.. We went to Japan to see cherry blossom and gardens. We weren't disappointed here and spent several hours on a Saturday afternoon wandering through the gardens. There is a large Greenhouse, a French Garden, an English Garden and a Traditional Japanese Garden all set amongst lakes and parkland. Woudbe lovely in autumn as well as spring.

Beautiful garden. This is my second time visiting this garden. It is easy to locate and within walking distance from the busy Shinjuku station. Last time I was there to experience the beautiful autumn scenery and this time to experience the sakura and cherry blossoms. It is such a beautiful sight but was a bit crowded due to the short blossom seasons. Love to see the families enjoying the sunshine and beautiful blooms. This place is definitely a must visit place if you love nature.

One of the popular sakura viewing spot. Come sakura season, this huge garden is packed with visitors. Many locals will come prepared with mats, food and drinks. Sitting under the sakura tree with family and friends, enjoying the view, company and good food. There is an entrance fee of 200yen though. It's worth a visit.

Breathtaking Cherry Blosdom. About a 7 min walk from Shinjuku station. On a sunny day grab some sandwiches and a drink and have a picnic lunch. There was a great kebab truck outside the park when I went but not sure if it's always there. The cherry blossom is outstanding. Hundreds of trees and lots of different varieties so a lot of color variation. From Snow White to deep cerise. Planted throughout the park they can be found in large avenues, clusters or weeping like giant wedding veils into the water features.
Beautiful. Worth the trip just by looking at the Sakura. Once in s lifetime exprrience. Walking dustance from Shinjuku Station Southern exit, turn right and 7 mins walk.
Pretty Sakura Trees!. Went for a picnic there and loved the view of the sakura trees in the park. There is a 200yen entrance fee thou! Worth a visit!
So many cherry blossom. Perfect spot for hanami! Packed with people when cherry blossom season. You must buy ticket for 200 yen / person.Walk about 2 minutes from Shinjukugyoen-mae Station.
Cherry blossoms galore. Blissful and serene. This wonderful park is located at the heart of shinjuku area. Cherry blossoms were at its finest. An oasis in the hustle And bustle of this busy Tokyo.
Very Pretty and Crowded for Cherry Blossoms. 200 Yen entrance fee and they search your backpack (no alcohol allowed). Lots of beautiful trees make it worth the crowds.

Visit to Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. We walked to the Shinjuku Gyoen National Park from Shinjuku Station on March 29th to view the cherry blossoms. It was about an 8 minute walk. We arrived early and had to wait in line. Paid 200 yen per person to get in. Cherry blossoms were in full bloom and so beautiful. The park has several sections to it.. The best portions were the Japanese and Chinese gardens. The other European style gardens were more expansive. Since we got there early, it wasn't as crowded as Ueno Park in the Asakusa area of Tokyo which was wall to wall people sitting on their red blankets for their traditional picnics/drinking parties. Even without the cherry blossoms, this is a very beautiful park almost as nice as the Imperial Palace East Garden in downtown Tokyo.

Fantastic park with all the amenities, check the blossom calandar. So, if you nail this one right like we did, the blossom calendar says it's good here for a week, but if it's not blossom season, it's still worth 200 yen and an English map comes free. Toilets, little cafes, lots of people, open areas to picnic, excellent park.

2nd visit during cherry blossom time. 1st visit was 2 yrs ago in November when it was late autumn still and absolutely beautiful. 2nd visit (3 april) to see cherry blossoms and we were delighted with gorgeous blooms of sakura. Luckily we visited way before noon. When we came out of the garden, there were long lines of people waiting to go in! It wouldn't have been so fun jostling with crowds snapping away.
A haven in a busy city. Just a nice place to relax and experience a more natural Japan. There aren't many places to sit but it is a wonderful place to see the blossum

Cherry Blossum Time. Open park with blossums in full flower everywhere we looked, plus traditional japanese garden. lots of families picnicing and having fun.mostly easy walking and close to Shinjuku Station and hotels plus shopping.
Cherry Blossoms!. One of the place where the locals gather for a picnic under the cherry blossom trees during the sakura season! It can get pretty crowded during this season.

Gorgeous and Peaceful!. We traveled to Tokyo at the end of March. I read that Shinjuku Gyoen was one of the best places in the city to see cherry blossoms -- and that certainly ended up being true! This garden was one of the highlights of my trip to Japan. It offers a peaceful retreat in the midst of a huge city. The experience of looking up to see a canopy of blossoms above my head was truly unforgettable. We also took some great "selfies" with the blossom trees. Shinjuku was a relief after experiencing the crowds elsewhere, especially at Ueno Park and Yoyogi Park. There were lots of photographers at Shinjuku Gyoen, but everyone seemed calm and very appreciative of the beautiful surroundings.Given that there is not a party atmosphere at this park, they do not allow alcohol -- they even sniffed my water bottle when I entered. Expect to see lots of families setting up picnics beneath the trees.

Breathtaking!. My family and I went there last March 31, 2015 and caught the Sakura just at the right time. The entrance fee of Y200 was more than reasonable. Canopies of Sakura trees surround the area and even other beautiful flower trees like Magnolias pepper the area. We spent the morning there and saw there was an area dedicated to rose bushes. I'm sure this will be very beautiful as well when they bloom. Best time to go is early morning because by the time we left at lunch, the lines to the entrance were very long. We stayed in the Shinjuku area but took the train to Senagaya station where there is another entrance to the park. There was hardly anyone at that entrance. We walked around until we exited the Shinjuku gate.

Amazing Cherry Blossom. If you wants to know the Best `HANAMI` ( Cherry Blossom )spots in Tokyo Shinjuku Gyoen is one of the Best. You have to Pay 200 yen as entrance fee. This is a non- Alcohol　park :((( Security check is bit strict. This park has huge varieties of Sakura Trees. so much spacious and you can leisurely walk. There is nice Jpanese Garden, model of a Japanese architecture and some green houses. You can walk through out the day! This is an amazing place that lovers, friends,family can enjoy. You can take so many pics in different angle. park view, Time square view, Lake view, Japanese garden view..so on. This is not crowded like Ueno , Sumida or Yoyogi park. So if u happened to be in Tokyo please pay a visit. It will absolutely be worthy.
SAKURA. Beautiful peaceful break from Busy Shinjuku area. During the Cherry Blossom season people walk around admiring the beauty of Cherry flowers and having picnics under the trees.
Glorious. lovely weather lots of people lovely ambience well worth the Y200 and gorgeous gorgeous blossom an absolute must.

Amazing cherry blossoms!. The park was a great place to see the cherry blossoms. The Japanese tradition garden was stunning.It was busy but not overcrowded. He queue to go into the park seemed really long but moved quickly.The only downside is the food in the restaurant. It wasn't awful but there are better places to eat in Tokyo.

Even our teens were impressed by the blossoms. If you are in Tokyo this is the one place you simply have to visit. Take some time to enjoy the beautiful views and the different kind of blossoms. We were lucky to have a sunny day and that does make a big difference. Next time we will take a picnic and spent some more time sitting under a blossom tree.
Cherry blossom awe. Wonderful experience, on weekdays that is. Beautiful blossom everwhere in a nice big park. You cannot bring alcohol inside.
Wonderful Park. At Cherry Blossom time it is very busy, trees are lovely. Small entrance fee but worth it, away from the bustle of Tokyo for a few h.ours

Incredibly Beautiful Garden. Shinjuku gyoen is an oasis in the middle of the city - it's sprawling, green, lush, and beautiful. Apart from the cherry blossom avenues, there are Japanese, French, & English gardens, and a couple of traditional tea houses. You can spend hours and hours oohing and aahing about the beauty here!
Cherry blossoms!. Beautiful garden in Shinjuku. Perhaps best in Tokyo. Great for a stroll. We arrived just before last entry at 4:30 and made quick work to see it in 45 minutes.
Great place for a picnic. We grabbed a mystery bento at Isetan and sat under a tree. Perfect for a snooze under the amazing cherry blossom. The Gardens here are beautiful.

Absolutely Stunning. At first entrance, this park seems overcrowded and chaotic, but as you diffuse into the gardens, the crowds fade away and you are left to gaze at the beauty of this work of art. Truly stunning and definitely worth a visit in Tokyo.
Green Oasis. Was a great place to go and enjoy the sun and green in the midst of all the city's clamor. I especially enjoyed the greenhouse, it was spectacularly well done.

Cherry blossoms. I guess the garden looks stunning all year round, but probably more so during the cherry blossom seasons, they were so pretty. We picnicked under the trees, like many other locals do, and strolled around the gardens. Nice ponds, also enjoyed the green house.
Tips: try coming in the morning. It gets crowded in the afternoon

Tokyo in bloom. We visited during sakura, which turns this parc into a wonderland of cherry blossom. The Japanese garden is stunning with so many wonderfull viewpoints. The variety of blossoming trees makes for great mixtures of colors. Parc should be nice in summer as well with varying landscapes, greenhouse and the French rose garden. Next time, we will try to visit in autumn.

Pretty garden in the city. In the midst of all the crazy traffic ams heavily populated city, I found it quite pleasant to know that this pretty garden area is a place where you can go to escape and relax. Beautiful colors of trees in October/November. Breathtakingly pretty all around. Romantic and a must visit place in this city.

First taste of cherry blossoms in Japan. The garden is large and includes many different types of cherry blossoms together with traditional Japanese style garden. Get there first thing as it gets very crowded as many take part in Hanami (bags checked for alcohol).

Visually stunning! . Wow! What a great little haven in the middle of a hugely expansive city. We had great luck with our visit and saw the Sakura in full bloom. We also had a strong wind blowing the petals around like snow, it was a great vista! Call me a grump, but places like this are always crowded at the best times, and it was hard to move for the other tourists and locals jamming up the pathways and bridge. It was almost impossible to take a photo without other people in it, it got frustrating quickly for me, but wasn't really the parks fault. Overall a great place to see the cherry blossoms!

Beautiful park . Great park to walk around and enjoy the scenery.Very well maintained throughout the whole park and very peaceful to just stroll around and let the day pass you by.Easy to get to from most parts of Tokyo.

Beautiful full bloom sakura. I was lucky to be able to catch the sight of full bloom sakura when I visited Tokyo. The park has numerous early and late blooming cherry trees which provide an extended cherry blossom viewing season. This is good for those who miss the main season. Shinjuku Gyoen Garden is the best place in Tokyo to view the cherry blossom during spring season. From the garden, the best landmark sight is the NTT Docomo building which is featured in some of the movies such as Ultraman, Superman and Godzilla. Located just a short walk from Shinjuku StationFor more info and pictures, kindly visit my blog:http://tummyfull.blogspot.com/2014/04/sakura-season-at-shinjuku-gyoen.html

Excellent day for cherry blossom viewing. Today was clear and sunny day, perfect weather for cherry blossom viewing. The park was easily accessible by train and within walking distance of all stations nearby. You can check out the official website for the stations that have access to the park. Admission fee is only 200 yen and is well worth it. We arrived early to have a head start before all the Chinese tourists arrived. We were able to take some great pictures before the park got really crowded due to the very very many Chinese tourists. The park opens at 9am and it's best to arrive early so your pictures won't have a lot of people in the background. The Chinese tourists were very aggressive when taking pictures, they are very load and all over the place. But overall, we enjoyed our visit to the park.

Must see in cherry blossom season. I went there April 1st and the park was shock full of people enjoying a sunny day in a park full of stunning flowering trees. High chance you'll take some great photos here.

Incredible variety. An amazing park with not only Japanese gardens but also English & French as well. I got in lesson in Botany as I wondered through the Greenhouse and ate my lunch beside a lovely pink blossoming tree. This park was closed on Mondays when I visited and there is a small entry fee you have to pay. Also make sure you obtain an English Map and take some pack a small bento, lovely place to picnic

Peaceful beauty. $2 entrance fee, beautiful large park for cherry blossoms. Go early if you want to beat the line. We got there at 10 when you didn't not really have to wait. Leaving at 12.30 the line look endless! Don't be scared by the insane amount of people taking photos everywhere when you walk in, walk in abit further and it becomes less busy and more chances for you get better pictures. Lots of people go in there for picnics as well , which I think it's a good idea.
Beautiful park. Beautiful park, peaceful. 200yen for admission, it's nothing to enjoy this place.This piece of nature in the middle of the city is really worth to visit.

A Centre of Peace in the Middle of the City. Shinjuku garden was easily accessible from the Shinjukugyoemae metro station. The park was spacious, the counter had an English language brochure that helped us a lot. We spent most of the time in the Japanse garden section which was really beuatiful. The cherry trees had started to bloom and we saw a large number of presumably local residents with their families. From far,the French section also looked very nice; we did not have enough time to visit every part of the garden. Overall a very refreshing experience.

Lovely garden. I was here late in march which spring is coming. Sakura is blooming, the garden providing one cup of green tea for me to drink and sit down to admire the beauty of garden.
Very lovely garden.

Bursting with Blossoms. Wow. $2 entry fee and the most spectacular urban garden we saw in Japan. The blossoms of course helped that cause. Busy on the weekends but everybody is super quiet and polite. Go here.

Beautiful Park and a Lot of Great Sakura Trees. So far, this is the best park I've visited in Tokyo. It's not free, you need to pay for the entrance but it's worth it.
The park is very large and visitors must not bring alcoholic beverage inside. There is a lot of great sakura trees here, they are magnificent.

Enjoyable way to spend an hour or so. This is really a pretty park with nice walking paths and beautiful trees. Especially crowded around cherry blossom season, but manageable. Make sure you have Japanese yen. They don't accept credit cards.

Beautiful Park to get away from the busy city life. The cherry blossoms were starting to bloom and the trees started to get their leaves back. The scenery is breathtaking - so much so that my partner proposed to me on the bridge overlooking the ponds! I do think that if we had have gone in a bit later in the month or in April the blossoms would have been in full bloom and that would have been even more breathtaking.The park was well worth the small entry free and a must do if you want to get away from all the people in Tokyo!.

If you are staying in Shinjuku go, if not, don't bother. This place is a large, beautiful park/garden area in Shinjuku. It is only a few minutes walk from the Shinjuku station. I don't remember what we paid to get it but I remember that it was fairly cheap. My girlfriend and I were staying close-by and decided to walk over and take a look. I had heard about the cherry blossoms "thing" before but I saw it up-close and personal on this visit to the Garden. Wow! The Japanese take the cherry tres blossoming very seriously. People had their impressive-looking cameras fixed on the tree blossoms, both mid-range and close-up. It was interesting to see this alone.The walk through the grounds is nice. I recommend going in the morning and being done with it. It helps to be with your significant other. As my title suggests, if I was staying in a different area of Tokyo or Japan I would not bother wasting time on this place.

Lovely garden. Great garden to visit, even in the rain. Cheap entry fee and lots to see, including a greenhouse/botanics. Well worth a visit and no doubt very pretty during autumn or cherry blossom season, sadly we seemed to be just a tiny bit early for that.

Lovely and relaxing. The blossom had just started blooming so it wasn't too busy here. Lovely gardens with themed areas. Tea houses within the grounds where for 700 yen you can be served traditional green tea and a sweet from a kimono clad lady. There is a 200 yen charge to enter. There is no alcohol allowed. It's very family friendly. Perfect for a morning stroll or a lunch time picnic.
Pretty . It was a nice walk around and the blossoms were pretty. Teenagers got bored real quick and I was a super mum for having pocket wifi to save their sanity.

Exquisite. The park that we can never get enough. It's our 3rd time out of 5 visits to shinjuku. It changes by the season and we are always finding new spots and nooks at every visit. The last visit, we spent half a day just enjoying the big lawn. Perfect picnic place, especially for families with children, or if your kids love the outdoors this is it. Remember to bring some food and and trash bag. And somehow, no alcohol is allowed, but we see a couple of beer cans here and there sometimes. Id i have more time in Shinjuku, will definitely visit again.

Go for the beautiful cherry blossoms!. This extensive garden has more than a thousand cherry trees and most of them are in bloom now! There is a security check (for alcohol) going into the park, but the line moved fairly quickly. The paths are well marked and there are several small ponds throughout as well as a field of daffodils. We saw many Japanese picknicking and some hotels will pack you a lunch to go.

Nice for a wander. So, things got a little out of hand on a night out and I woke up in a bath with an urge for rice triangles - or onigiri, if you prefer - and a splitting headache so trust me when I say this.Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is not only very pretty, but the ideal place for a pensive wander in the sun while you reflect on what you've done, whether you're going to do it again (you will, obviously) and where you're going next. I had an ice cream at the little café, fed the koi, stared for a long time at the leaves on the trees and generally ruminated on how it was exactly what I needed.When you consider that this is the middle of Tokyo, it's pretty amazing really. It's probably just a nice without a hangover.

Cherry Blossoms Are In Bloom. Showed up at Shinjuku Gyoen National Park this morning looking forward to seeing the English and French gardens and to our surprise the Cherry Trees were in full bloom. No crowds just lots and lots of Pink and White blossoms. I am so glad because the English gardens are almost non existent. The Japanese gardens are beautiful and the cherry trees are the cherry on top.

Early Spring in Japan. Spent the afternoon at this expansive, beautifully maintained national garden. The cherry blossoms some have bloomed while others are still at the budding stage. The Japanese Garden is absolutely amazing with water features, sycamore trees and there is a stream flowing through the garden. Perfect place for hanami picnic with friends and family and a huge expanse of greens where children can run and play safely.The Garden is easily accessible by train from the Shinjuku station and a 10 minutes walk to reach it.

Sight of the Real Flower. Was here early March and it is technically winter. Nevertheless, there were already blooming flowers. Some trees were still without leaves and flowerd and the grass were not yet green. Even though, the place was serene and perfect for strolling. The place was still "photo perfect". Also tried the 700yen tea break and we loved the taste and the hospitality. The mochi that was offered in one of the tea houses was memorable and taste like no other. The entance fee we paid is less of what we got from enjoying the real sakura and the photo memories we will cherish for life.

Very Nice!. I'm so glad we were able to fit this into our trip. Such a beautiful garden! Definitely great if you have children as well. Tons of green space, fish and turtles in all of the ponds, and plenty of space to run around and get away from the big city for a while. I would absolutely return here!

Something new every time. I have been to this park several times over the last few years and each time I find something new. We walk a different path each time and find things we had not seen before. We love Cherry Blossom Season here but any time is a good time for a walk in the park.There is a small fee to enter. Have coins ready to use the ticket machine.

Beautiful oasis.. I loved Shinjuku anyway, and even though it's very commercial, it doesn't feel built up or oppressive but it is high-rise and so the park is a lovely contrast. We were there in April, when the cherry blossoms were out and we had to queue and pay to get into the park. I'm not sure if this is the case all year round. They were searching bags as no alcohol was allowed in the park. The Japanese were there with their big blue sheets, picknicking under the cherry blossom, just enjoying themselves in their usual polite, considerate way. It's a big expanse, with some great views of the tall buildings of central Shinjuku in one direction. Koi in the lakes, beautiful trees and shrubs and cafes. A nice break from the sightseeing.
Absolutely Beautiful. just peace and quite in the middle of a city and lights. its a great way to get a break and relax from all the running around. highly recommend spending some time here

Beautiful breathing space in middle of town. Got there just week ahead of full spring blossom. The garden still had some great views to offer. It is an easy stroll with signs in Japanese and English. Approximately 10 minute walk from the Shinjuku station.
Beautiful. A short walk from Shinjuku station and well worth it! Beautiful, peaceful place. Would be amazing to see it when the cherry blossoms are in bloom!
Beautiful gardens. We were lucky to be here when the cherry blossoms were blooming. The park deserves at least an hour or 2 to enjoy. Must do!

Amazed by the sakura blooming. We have chosen this garden as our last day's destination before our departure from Japan so that the date, 22nd March is closer to the blooming of sakura. Indeed, we are amazed and satisfied with the blooming of different species of sakura and other flowers even though not all trees are blooming. Entry fee is reasonably low, just 200 yen per person. Beautiful park.
a lovely garden. The cherry blossoms is just emerging, and the magnolia blossom is in full bloom. The Japanese gardens are beautiful and very well maintained. Well worth a visit

A gentle relaxing afternoon. This beautiful garden has many entrance gates, there Is a charge of 200 yen to enter enter but worth it. once inside There are a number of pathways to follow. You only need a few hours to walk them all. There are paths around to the koi lakes which also have turtles swimming in them. carry on past the Japanese garden and on to one of two traditional tea house buildings. There are beautiful open areas where you can sit and relax, and the backdrop Of the trees and their blossoms so tie your visit to when blossom is there if possible. If you look above the trees you can see the tokyo skyline. Definitely worth a visit or better still taken picnic.

Great Retreat from the busy Tokyo Streets. Park is kept in great condition. Nice to stroll around and also sit and relax on the grass on a sunny day. It is a lovely retreat from the busy Tokyo streets.

A wonderful time for the senses. During early Spring I was fortunate to visit this park. I had wanted to see it since watching the anime "Garden of words" (well worth watching if you like a tear jerker). Entry to the park is 200¥, and it's easy to find from several directions as it covers such a large expanse of the district. I was awe struck by the beauty of this park and it's amazing array of fauna. As an amateur photographer, at best, this park makes even the worst of us look good in our picture selection. One thing I enjoyed most was taking the time to use all my senses, to listen, touch and smell. This was my first experience of Cherry Blossoms, but there is so much more to see.On a practical side disability access is well catered for and public toilets abound. You'll also be able to find food and souvenirs to purchase. If you're a runner, and who isn't, then spend the money, you won't regret it. Access times vary throughout the year, so confirm before you arrive.

Peaceful garden escape.. Shinjuku Gyoen is such a beautiful place. Gardens, blooming flowers, park benches. No place nicer in all of Tokyo to have a stroll and enjoy the outdoors. I came in March just as the Cherry Blossoms started blooming and they made the experience even nicer. Only 200 yen entry, can't go wrong. Chill out, take photos, whatever you want. You'll be glad you came, just as I was.

Lovely breathing space in the heart of the city. We walk to this place from our hotel and found the place of peace and freshness. There were already Sakura (cheery blossoms) in bloom which was a surprise since it is not season yet (first week of March). We liked the traditional Japanese garden and the green house. The spacious lawn was a beautiful place just to sit and spend the time. The tropical greenhouse also housed well maintained and flowering plants and orchids. We liked the place so much we spend a lot of time, twice. There was also a showcase of Japanese bird sculpture. Such a lovely place, highly recommended.
Best place in Sakura season. Lovely big park / garden. Good place for Haname in Cherry Blossum season! They have internationally styled gardens there too

Just like a dream.. So excellent for those who seek peace in the middle of crowd of Tokyo. This is the first place i planned to visit when i hit Tokyo. I knew this place from the movie "Garden of Words" and it is so illustrated beautifully that i want to see it for real, and not disappointed at all, the reality is so beautifully the same like in the movie. The ponds, the trees, the hills, the grass, it all so perfect that only staring at them is makes your heart drenched in peace. I spent time in here for like 2-3 hours just only for sitting and napping and gazing to the sakura tree that the only one has bloomed (i visited this in the beginning of March). It will be awesome to visit in the full bloom season which near end of March to April.

An oasis in the city. How does one relax in a huge metropolis? Come to this garden and you will learn how you can have peace, right in the middle of Tokyo. Wonderful garden and a great getaway when you are tired of seeing buildings/sights in Tokyo. Got here during the plum blossom, stunning to walk around and enjoy yourself.Plenty of clean toilets/water fountains. It's really a bargain for 200 Yen and relax for 45 mins in here.
Great retreat in Shinjukiu. Larger garden with exercise area (with metal workout equipment), play area and plenty of space to walk with sun and shade.
Central Park of Shinjuku. Beautiful gardens ! A must if you're in Tokyo, it's very close to Shinjuku and a not too bad walk from Shibuya :) Nothing better then a little stroll in the park, no?
Simply calm. It's amazing how a garden in the middle of the city can be so quiet. It's a must to anyone that likes nature.

Calm among busy Shinjuku. Beautiful in any season.....central location....best during sakura season......take a break from the hustle and bustle of shinjuku......if you have time for just one park in Tokyo.....this is the place!

Loved this place!. This was actually one of the highlights of my time in Tokyo! I spent at least three hours just wandering through its Japanese, French, and English gardens, as well as its green house. I enjoyed the peace and quiet amidst Tokyo's - and Shinjuku's - hecticness. If you crave a little green space, you must check this place out! Pack a picnic and just soak up the calmness of it all.

It's a park nothing special. I went there because it was closed to my hotel, I went late February and a lots of the flower and trees where stil without flowers, so it was a little disappointed. But it's a nice place consider it's in the middle of Shinjuku.

Would have like to visit. Unfortunately the park was closed due to a mosquito related disease outbreak. It looks beautiful in the pictures though. Lots of homeless people hanging around out the front.

Worth the visit!. A quick visit has been made to have a glimpse of the cherry blossoms that are just minutes away from the nearest eki. We do not have the luxury of time to be able to visit larger parks out of Tokyo and having this gyoen nearby has been a day saver for us :)

BEAUTIFUL, WORTH THE PRICE OF ADMISSION. Loved this park even though we were there in winter time. The bridges and trees were gorgeous. I can only imagine what the park looks like in spring. It is definitely worth the 200 yen price of admission. Inside the park there a place where you can experience a traditional green tea ceremony. I would highly recommend this as well.
japanese gardes - pristine. cool japanese gardens - tradiitonal gardens and chinese architecture. well worth a walk around, fffff
AMAZING!!!. The beauty of this garden brought me to tears. You can easily spend half a day here. There are tea houses, koi ponds, and just acres and acres of loveliness!

Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. This is a beautiful park with lots of open grassed spaces for children to play in.
Lovely to take a picnic lunch - you can buy from the food hall at nearby Takashimaya and just spread out on a rug!
Highly recommended!

Great open space in Shinjuku. The Shinjuku park is one of the biggest in Tokyo, and probably the one in which one has the biggest feeling of being outside of the crowded metropolis that is Tokyo. The entrance of the park is underwhelming, but the more you walk towards the japanese garden the better it gets. And when you head back to the Shinjuku gate you get a central park-ish experience with the row of modern buildings you can see on the horizon.I went to the park in January, and I'm looking forward to going back in spring to experience the park in its blossoming state.This park is a great for families or couples. It looks great for picnics although it's not really a japanese thing and I haven't tried it on my own. The entrance fee is cheap (200 yens/adult I believe).
Cold gardens out of season but still very nice. Great greenhouse especially when the outside is 4 degrees. Very well maintained and would be fantastic in spring.

Beautiful park. It was a surprise as we didnt expect to see the park decorated with all the colour trees. The yellow, orange, red leaves trees with Japanese style garden was beyond words can describe. We had a wonderful half day wondering in the park. We laid down on the grass and enjoy the colourful surroundings.
Not a winter attraction. Visited in the middle of winter so, I am sure it was not at it's best. Need to go again in spring or summer.

Nice park away from hustle and bustle. This is the quiet part of Shinjuku like Central Park in New York. Park is very good as a hiding spot to be away from the city noise and have a quiet lunch. There is a tea house and garden as well as grass area you can sit and relax.

Beautiful Day Outing on a Sunny Day!. This is a great park close to Shinjuku. The colors are especially beautiful during autumn. Entry fee is 200 yen and it tends to be slightly crowded over the weekends
A Must Visit. We really enjoyed our stroll through the garden. It was so beautiful...even in January! It was also very inexpensive to get in. We only wish we had more time to see the whole garden!

Lovely Oasis in the Middle of Tokyo. This large park is a quiet retreat surrounded by a busy city of 4 million people. A small admission charge allows one to wander through several different garden themes, over bridges, and around a small lake. Some areas are more wild. Others are very manicured. There is a large grassy area where families can stretch out on blankets and enjoy the peaceful setting. A lovely place to recharge.

The real National Garden - When east meets west. Although located in central, Shinjuku, this lovely garden is one the best place to visit for tourist. This is the place where your kids could running in the filed without worrying of other peoples. A highly recommend place once you should visit when travelling in Tokyo. A place that you can take photo of Japanese traditional garden with background of skyscrapers buildings of Shinjuku - east meets west....

Boring in winter. Before decided to the park, we actually did struggle, should we visit the park in winter? There should be nothing interested can be see at this time.so we read the review in trip advisor first. The latest review in January 13 say that is still worth to see even it is winter.In my opinion, absolutely NO. you can skip this during winter. But if you think that tree without leaf, large area of yellowish grass is interesting for you, please go ahead =)
Awesome Visit. Highly recommend anyone visiting Tokyo to come over to Shinjuku to see the garden! it's located right in the heart of the city and is well designed!

Beautiful grounds - great walking space. Just beautiful gardens. We were there for a chrysanthemum exhibit and they were gorgeous displays, some taking a year to create. We go there late so didn't get to spend as much time as we would have liked. Easy to get to with the train.

Plan for a long morning or afternoon visit. We came here looking for koyo. What we found, in addition to koyo, was one beautiful fuyuzakura which we had so wanted to see somewhere. Nothing like the sakura in spring, but quite a sight to behold in December. We can only imagine what the garden must be like full of hanami parties as we are used to seeing in Ueno Koen.The autumn colors were a bit past prime the first week in December, but were still beautiful. The pond offered some excellent photo ops as did Momijiyama. The Japanese garden was our favourite section and the (Taiwan) pavilion provided some great viewing points in addition to being a focal point for photos. We found the formality of the rose gardens boring by comparison.Look for pods of photographers on hills, around the ponds, near the bridges. Someone in every crowd has already found the best spot for the best photo angles. Entry fee was ¥200. We spent about 4 hours here and got snacks for lunch at the rest house. A great way to spend a good part of a sunny day.

Beautiful and peaceful place. The park is green and very peaceful, a great place to have a break from business of city. It is only a short walk from busy shopping/entertainment districts, so placed very appropriately.The Japanese part is amazingly beautiful and well designed. Every view is like a picture from some tourist brochure, very cute. Other parts of the garden are not that well designed, and frankly seem a bit out of place and hectic. Nevertheless, totally worth a slow walk around. A little greenhouse is worth a visit as well.

great gardens. Go during cherry blossom season which is 1st two weeks in April. It will be a mob scene, but one of the best cherry blossom viewings in Tokyo. Other times of the year it is still beautiful

Gorgeous scenery. These gardens were on my list to visit as part of my 2 week trip to Japan and I wasn't disappointed.It is 500yen to get in but you can stay as long as you like.There are many paths to take wandering around lakes and Japanese buildings where you can take the most stunning pictures.We came in January so no cherry blossom on the trees but could imagine how beautiful the place would be. Lots of open space and fabulous horticultural area.There were tea rooms but we didn't go in because it was too expensive (700 yen).There is also a greenhouse to visit but we went later in the day and it was closed.Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful park. This park is absolutely stunning, even when it's packed during the busy cherry blossom season. It's just a short walk from the station and definitely worth the trip.

Great Park.. Well worth the effort to get here and look around. Park entry fee was a surprise, but it was a negligible cost and worth the price of entry. Had a good look around, the lakes had large slabs of ice on top which was pretty cool and made a great noise when hit. Lovely gardens, and great change of pace from bustle of Tokyo.
Good for a Stroll. We only stayed there for a little bit but we we enjoyed the scenery very much. Even in winter the trees were beautiful. It is also a good place to just sit, relax and people watch.
Sakura. Time your visit in the Spring for the cherry blossoms. There is alot to see, alot of walking. Worth the visit, nominal fee to enter. You can spend an entire day here to do it justice.

Gorgeous late blooming cherry blossoms!. We brought a picnic here for the late blooming cherry blossoms and had a lovely afternoon! The rest of the foliage was spare because of the season but the people watching was wonderful.

Garden of Serenity. Loved how calm this place is! Very relaxing, and well worth the visit if you want to get away from the busy city streets of Shinjuku. It cost a small fee to enter (200 yen). It's a very big area, so you can wander around quite a bit. Also, never before have I seen so many koi fish in my life!

Well laid out green space in the city. The park is a beautiful break from urban sprawl! We did find it hard to enter from the south and had along walk around to the enter and, but inside the different area gardens were a nice way to pass a few hours
"Our" garden. A beautiful park with stunning tranquility contrasted with thousands of locals on a public holiday picnicking!

Great place for morning walk. An oasis in the middle of a concrete jungle great place for a morning walk but when I first visited it was close due to new year eve celebrations and didn't reopen till 4th January
Peace. The gardens are a peaceful sanctuary in a very busy city. Even though we visited in winter, it was still a great place to spend a morning!

Beautiful park at the heart of town... You should visit the park when the leaves change its color to yellow and to red. Plan your holidays at end of November and early of December. This is one source you can check with: http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e2014_when.htmlOverall, the park is very beautiful with yellow and red leaves. Some are momiji (red), some are ginkgo (yellow), and some others are still green. The place is maintained properly and it is so big and so cold during that time (early Dec) that we cannot visit the entire garden...
Beautiful Garden. I visited this place in december which is not common time to visit but I was excited by beautifully maintained garden near shinjuku eki.
Magnificent garden!. A very beautiful place to view cherry blossoms. Ample space for picnic. The park is really big. 200 yen per entry for adults.

Well kept and beautiful even in December. Caught the train to Shinjuku and had lunch in one of the small restaurants under the department stores before walking into the park. There are 3 areas of the garden each with a different feel, traditional Japanese, English with wide open spaces and a formal French garden. The excellent greenhouse is accessible from the English garden. Very pretty even on a cold December day, and like most places we visited in Tokyo, very clean. Lots of photo opportunities. Allow a couple of hours, and on a warm day could easily spend longer.

Nice Garden to Visit. I had the opportunity to visit the gardens on our trip to the Tokyo area this summer and take a walk through them. It was early July when we were there and while there were not many plants blooming it was a nice walk. Overall It was nice but we felt like the garden was a little rough in places like it needed maintenance. Nicest areas were the traditional Japanese garden and the arboretum. The rose garden did have quite a few blooms but felt a bit run down. We did eat lunch in the restaurant located in the park and it was very nice with a high level of service from the staff. If you enjoy botanic gardens and don't mind a walk it is worth going and it was not very expensive to visit.
Too good. Lot of colorful trees and mild cool wind. Nice place to visit in busy Tokyo. This place is not looks like a 'business Tokyo' town

Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. My favorite was the Sake Barrels and the Wine history from France. Overall, walking tour was pleasurable, give yourself about 3 hours. Korean restaurant nearby was very good and the tourist area was for shopping was okay.

While away a couple of hours. This Garden is enormous! I went due to an unexpected change in plans. It cost 200 yen to get in but it was worth it to wander around for a couple of hours. I did go in winter so the garden wasn't at it's best, but the Green House was lovely and a great escape from the cold and rain.There was a bit of work going on, so some areas were off limits but I'd say this wouldn't be the case during the warmer months.

It's really big? . This was a stop on my Tokyo list from day one and I wanted to love - I really did - but I just...didn't?First off, let me say the gardens are of course quite nice, they're pretty and well maintained. I just didn't really see anything particularly special about them besides their size and the fact that yes, they're in the middle of a concrete jungle. It would be a lovely escape if you were in Tokyo for an extended period of time or if you were from somewhere where this sort of greenery is unusual but for us, there wasn't anything particularly standout about the gardens themselves. I guess maybe it's because we're from Australia and we're a little spoiled for flora over here - there's lots of gardens like this one at home. If you're a flora buff however or a photography nut you'll probably enjoy it. It's a paid garden but it's a really cheap entry fee. Also, if you have any with you make sure you spray on some mosquito repellent on before you go! :)

Must visit. Entry is only 200yen and you get to enjoy a few hrs of this beautiful park with the best colors for photo taking. Highly recommended if in Shinjuku. Take the subway to Shinjuku gyoemmae and it's only few minutes walk from there.

Oasis in a concrete jungle!. The park is adjacent to the Skyscraper district of Tokyo in Shinjuku. Naturally the area has tall buildings. This garden appears an oasis in their midst. We visited in late November when the autumn colors were nearing their peak. It was awesome - seen to be believed.
If you are staying around Shinjuku, this is a must visit.
Beautiful Paid Garden!. Undoubtedly it is so much beautiful that can't be describe in words only, you have to visit it but the only drawback is that you have to spend some money to get into it!

Beautiful garden to relax in Shinjuku. This is a beautiful garden in the middle of busy Shinjuku. It's worthwhile spending a couple of hours to just walk around & enjoy the peaceful surroundings - lovely break.The French garden was very pleasant with rows of plane trees and park benches. The English garden was nice but nothing particularly special.The traditional Japanese section was our favourite, very beautiful & traditional. When we visited during October, a special chrysanthemum exhibition was being held. It was an amazing display of different varieties as well as techniques of growing/training chrysanthemum plants.

Paradise. This place is a "oasis" in the middle of Shinjuku.Is really cheap (200 Japanese Yen). I recommend that you spend a couple hours to visit this fantastic garden.NOTE: My favorite space was the orchidarium, with beautiful species.

Picture of serenity. We went week 1 December and the first sight that greeted us were flaming red leaves, golden leaves and falling gently. How romantic- like a scene from a love movie . People having picnics and such a huge and beautiful park. Love it.
autumn leaves. for picture taking and a bit far when you walk from shinjuku station.the leaves during fall are great in photos. you will see crow all over the park

Beautiful autumn colour. Even without entering the Gyoen, the entrance itself was a big WOW with amazing colours of autumn. The entry fee is only 200 yen so why not pop in? I felt I was in an English park and it had such a calming effect by walking around although I only had to have brisk 30 minutes quick walk around due to work commitment. Many people brought their picnic.

Great stroll through lovely gardens.. We really enjoyed walking through the gardens. We were fortunate enough to be stopped by some Japanese college students who wanted to work on their English and were giving tours through the gardens to English speaking tourists. This wasn't a scam, something you sometimes encounter in China, and they weren't aggressive in the slightest. We welcomed the offer and the students were pleasant and fun to speak with. The gardens were beautiful and green. It's incredible how huge they are. It reminded me of Central Park in Manhattan, but with a different vibe. Altogether, we enjoyed our visit.

Even in winter worth a visit. By metro just get off at the station before shinjuku and the gates are a two minute walk from the exit. Entrance fee is 200 yen and park closes at 1630. There is a big area to walk and a lot of benches to sit on or grassed areas if you prefer. Small snack area and a restaurant which we didn't try, toilets as well and changing area for kids. There's a real relaxed atmosphere as you would expect and would love to go back in a different season.

Nice for Cherry Blossom season !. Great place to enjoy the Hanami (cherry blossom) and much nicer than going to Yoyogi Park unless you want to see more people. The only drawback is you have to pay to get into the park.
A little sanctuary in Shinjuku. Great park for a quiet moment, away from the hustle and bustle of the city. 5-minute walk from Hilton Shinjuku.
I like this place. Great big Japanese Style garden, I would like to go here again when its warmer!! Its a bit chilly now

A park with an Awesome view. It's a huge park. but it gave people a very peaceful feel. The autumn colours made the scenery really awesome. took many beautiful pictures there. Though it costs 200yen, it is totally worth the money. Strongly recommend this place. Take a leisure walk and take many nice pics there!

Oasis in the middle of the city. Beautiful park with 4 different gardens. Was so lost in the beauty of the gardens that I did not realize we'd been wandering through the grounds for 3 hours already. It was not crowded, lots of locals. We even saw kindergartners on what seemed like their field trip. There is also a beautiful greenhouse on the grounds worth visiting

Beautiful park in the heart of Tokyo. Make sure you check out the traditional garden. The park is a wonderful respite from busy and crowded Tokyo.
Lots of green areas to have a picnic on a sunny day. Also a great place to go for a run.

A building-free green oasis of large dimensions. It´s amazing to have such a large National Garden right next to one of Tokyo´s busiest sites. The Park is very nice and has beautiful sections, the skyline of Shinjukus high rises contrasts well with the garden. The park is rather flat and not as landscaped as e.g. Rikugien Garden, which is a lot smaller and intimate.Both Parks give you a 20% discount in showing the Tokyo Tourist Guide at the gate. This guide is available at tourist offices and I highly recommend it - available in several languages.

Peace full place in busy area. This is quite the peace full place in between the crowded streets of Shinjuku. There is an admitance fee of 200 yen, but is worth the money. Nice landscaping and views and you can visit the greenhouse in the park.
relaxing place. a must see when in tokyo. entrance fee is very minimal. the place is very well maintained. there is so much space, the trees, koi ponds and plants are all beautiful

Beautiful Garden!. There is an entry fee of 200 yen per pax but it was definitely worth it! The weather was cleared and the sky was so blue when we were there! A great place to have a picnic and photo taking as well! This place is huge so prepare to spend at least 2 to 3 hours exploring the entire place!

I've spent hours watching leaves . I have never thought that a visit to a park will take hours, and this park has proven me wrong. Beautiful trees, especially the Japanese maple, unique Japanese garden as well as French garden impressed me. This place is a gem hidden in a super busy Tokyo conurbation, and it is a hideaway place when you need a quiet and peaceful surroundings.

Amazing. I got lucky and wad there's during the sakura or cherry blossoms, so I got done great photos, but even with a garden so impressively large, with the cherry blossoms out so were thousands if people. People seemed to have camped to get a place to sit and arriving mid morning there was no where that someone could have found. Quite incredible, but an experience I would not have missed.
Beautiful!. Did not expect the park to be that busy but great place to relax and take pictures, especially in autumn.Will recommend highly!

Beautiful place in Tokyo in 4 seasons. It is a beautiful garden where you can enjoy in this international big city, Tokyo. You can jog along the river surrounding the garden and taste the fresh air in this clean city.

Beautiful . We visited this park whilst on our first honeymoon stop in Tokyo. I'm so glad we come here why a beautiful quiet and tranquil place in a busy city. We had such a lovely morning walking around and viewing all the landscape. This is one place I will remember in years to come

An oasis of calm. Shinjuku is so busy and this garden provides a calm escape. We took the train to Sendagaya, 2 stops from Shinjuku on the Chuo local line, and then walked through the garden to Shinjuku. The garden is peaceful and beautiful. The greenhouse is a must visit. There is a small entry fee and a coffee shop inside the garden.

Lovely garden, can be crowded. Went during the cherry blossom season - and while entertaining to see a lot of older Japanese people crowding around with giant cameras for the best picture of a blossom, there were quieter parks with just as lovely of things to see in Tokyo.

Nice quiet time.. I felt a little overwhelmed when I tried to get around the Shinjuku station, so I took a time out by coming here for a breather.It's a nice quiet garden with lots of flowers and a restaurant that sells bentos for a nice snack. The paths are easy to follow and they have map guides around the park so you don't get lost.By the time I was done, the Shinjuku station quieted down, so it was back to the city for more fun.
Simply beautiful!. We were there while the Sakura (cherry blossom) trees were still in full bloom. It was simply beautiful! The Japanese certainly know how to design their gardens!

Another Wonderful Park in Japan. I made a small 4K Video of the park if you want to have a quick pick before going https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gn6hpf_2780Credited as one of the most beautiful parks in Tokyo, Shinjuku Gyoen is definitely another place to enjoy when visiting Tokyo. The garden was completed in 1772 and was the original residence of the Naitō family during the Edo era. It became a botanical garden in 1906 until it went through a complete reconstruction in 1949. Unfortunately you must pay a small entry fee to access Shinjuku Gyoen but it features many interesting activities. These include a French formal garden, an English landscaped garden with a stunning view of Shinjuku and Tokyo Tower, a greenhouse, a tea house, and a traditional Japanese garden. Last but not least, the park is home to and four magnificent ponds : Shimo no Ike, Naka no ike, Kami no ike and Haha to ko no mori.Shinjuku Gyoen is just a gorgeous park and you will need several hours to fully enjoy it alone or with your loved ones!

Great walk in the park. Took my daughter on a overcast afternoon. Only 200yen to enter, easy to get to from the train station, and beautiful. Great paths, bathrooms available, food stops (simple stuff), aling the way. The greenhouse was really near, my 4 yr old loved the flowers. Great place to picnic in nice weather but no sporting equipment allowed. Great afternoon activity in nice weather.
a must visit park in tokyo. especially beautiful in the cherry blossoms season, this park is good to visit all year round. with friends or family, it's a great place outdoors.

Tranquility in city. Very nicely kept and well maintained gardens - bang in middle of a bustling city. Go in mornings to avoid queues- though its not much of bother anyway. Sometimes it is closed due to mosquito / dengue scare. Pls check in advance.

Beautiful, Peaceful Garden. Visited this garden which was close to our hotel. We spent a good three hours strolling through the grounds. There is a French garden, English garden and Japanese garden as well as a greenhouse with orchids and tropical plants. We visited in October when the leaves were beginning to turn and the chrysanthemums were on display. It was a most enjoyable experience!

Tranquil park in a busy city. We had a nice and quiet picnic here.While visiting, a Chrysanthemums exhibition was held here.We had a real eye opening show of the numerous type of Chrysanthemums which we have not seen before.With an entrance fee of 200 yen, it was good value for the money.

Autumn Color. My best friend had died while I was in Japan and when I knew I couldn't make it back for her Memorial Service, I went to Shinjuku Gyoen for peaceful reflection. I will always remember that visit, not just for the well thought out landscape or the chrysanthemum exhibits but for the Spiritual sense and happy families sharing it with me.

Beautiful Garden. This is one of the best parks I have ever been to. We loved the Japanese Garden and the lakes and Tea House. The Green house was great too. An oasis of tranquility in the centre of Shinjuku.

A Must Visit. It was our 1st stop on our 1st Day, we absolutely loved it! We could not believe that there is such a park in the middle of Metropolitan Tokyo, it's just like Central Park in New York. We went in late October and the trees were changing, the colors was just breathtaking. Very accessible via Tokyo Metro Midosuji line. Its quite a big place so give it a least half a day if you really want to enjoy. Best thing about the place is that its not too overcrowded with group tours. We are already planning to have a picnic lunch next time we go back.

A Beautiful Garden in the heart of Shinjuku. We visited Gyoen National Garden on our first day. It was worth the 12-15 minutes walk from our hotel. and the entrance fee of 200 JPYThis is such a beautiful garden right in the heart of Shinjuku. A perfect place to have family picnics or to ease away a stressful day at the office. I can just stay here the whole day and let time pass me by. The garden has four different inspired setting, a relaxing feel and picturesque landscapes. There is so much to see inside this garden. They have beautiful flowers cultivated with care and you can see from the looks of every pot how much time has been invested to make it look perfectly pleasing to the eyes.A great place with so much beauty in it, not to be missed!

Peace and tranquility. Shinjuku Gyoen is one of Tokyo's largest and most popular parks. It's a short walk from Shinjuku Station. It costs Adults Yen200, Elementary and junior high school students Yen50, Infants Free of charge to get in and appreciate this beautiful park.When we were there the chrysanthemums houses had just been built for viewing.. where a single chrysanthemum plant is grown in a special frame that supports every flower individually. This technique is called Ozukuri or a thousand blooms, was developed by Shinjuku Gyoen. When you see these you can appreciate how the Japanese aim for perfection in whatever they do!.After walking the park we left by the Sandagaya Gate and walked to the Meiji Shrine, about a 15 min walk.

Garden going wild. The Shinjuku Gyoen gets lots of raves. It is centrally located at Shinjuku and easily accessible. And it is a huge green space in the middle of a vibrant city. The current garden format was completed early in the 20th Century under the guidance of a French designer. Highlights of the garden include a classical Japanese garden along with a formal French and English landscape garden. The strength of the garden is its wild forest character rather than the faux French or English gardens which are either very run down or in a poor state of management. The Japanese garden is also very ordinary by domestic standards and does not compare with something like the Kenrokuen garden in Kanazawa. In fact the formal components of the Gyoen are a non event. But that said the wild chaotic nature of what remains is still a breath of fresh air.

Nature within reach . This garden is in Shinjuku, right underneath some of the tallest structures in Tokyo. Entrance is very cheap, less than USD 2 per person. The garden has a few main areas: the Japanese garden dominates majority of the area, while there is an English garden and a French garden as wellI spent most of my time in the Japanese garden. The English garden was just a vast expanse of manicured lawn. The French garden reminded me of the gardens of Versailles. A leisurely walk through the vast park took up about 90 mins. You can get to the park using the Tokyo Metro from almost anywhere in Tokyo. There are quite a number of restrooms scattered around the prk, as well as rest areas where u can sit and buy some snacks as well

An oasis surrounding by skycrapers. Shinjuku Gyoen located approximately a 10 minute walk from the New South Exist of JR Shinjuku Station or a 5 minute walk from Shinjukugyoenmae Station on the Marunouchi Subway Line. It is like an oasis surrounding by skyscrapers of Shinjuku. This park was originally constructed during the Edo Period as a feudal lord, Lord Naito’s private residence. It was converted into a botanical garden before being transferred to the Imperial Family as the imperial garden for recreation and entertaining guests, it was re-designated as a national garden after the Second World War and eventually reopened to the public. Since then, it is one of Tokyo’s largest and most popular parks. With 58.3 ha(144 acres) in size and a circumference of 3.5 km, it blends three distinct styles, French Formal Garden, English Landscape Garden and Japanese Traditional Garden. From late March to mid April, a large number of cherry trees blossom around the English garden turning the lawns into one of Tokyo’s most popular and pleasant hanami spots. It is also nice to visit during autumn when the leaves change colours around the park, especially the maple trees around the Japanese garden and Momijiyama on the eastern side of the park. We stayed in a hotel facing this beautiful park for a week in late March 2014 but only managed to visit this park once. This year, the cherry trees opened late but the views were still spectacular and like many visited the park, we brought bento and drinks from a departmental store nearby for hanami in the park, the experience was really unforgettable. If you happen to visit Tokyo during the Sakura period, you should really consider wondering around or simply resting/sleeping at the beautifully maintained lawns within this park. We were really glad we did so during our last visit. Admission: ¥200. Open 9am-4pm (Gates close at 4:30pm). Closed Mon (If Mon is a public holiday, close the following day) & 29 December to 3 January. No closure day during cherry blossom season from late March to late April.
A must-go. This is brilliant... I loved the layout and the place. MUST GO!!! Remember to try out the tea house too....

Specacular. We had a couple of hours before departing for the airport. This park was around the corner from our hotel so for 200 yen we gained admission. The park is stunning and 2 hours could easily have been doubled. From the Japanesse garden to the English rose garden the park was immaculate and very colourful. This was just. So much more than a walk in the park!

Beautiful and Serene. Just a short walk from the subway is the entrance way to the garden. After paying a small admission, you can walk around this beautiful area. It is quite serene compared to its surrounding area, with different garden themes throughout. i.e. -Japanese Traditional, English Traditional and French Rose Garden

Beautiful!. I expected to spend an hour in a "typical" Japanese garden (pond, koi, traditional Japanese style building in the background, etc) but ended up wandering around for over 3 hours - and I didn't even see everything! I highly recommend the Chrysanthemum Festival in early November (1st - 15th). And also wander around the roses in the French garden. If flowers aren't your thing, there are lots of places to just sit and enjoy life - lots of open grass, benches tucked away along walking trails and next to ponds, and food/beverage shops. Totally worth the 200 yen entrance fee. Bring a camera.

Perfect day in the rains. It has 3 components ie a traditional Japanese garden with a lake and a convex shaped bridge on it. The secon was a french garden with straight lined trees on either sides and a flower garden in the centre. The 3rd was a English garden , more like a green playfield with flowers on its borders. It was drizzling which made it a perfect romantic walk in the park.
Best chrysanthemum display. Extensive gardens, easily walkable from Shinjuku station.Amazing chrysanthemums, with signs explaining different varieties and growing techniques.

Peace in Shinjuku. If you feel Tokyo is just a steel and cement skyline, take a break from Shinjuku station and walk around this amazingly well groomed park in the heart of Tokyo. There's a nominal fee of 200 yen or so, but it's a wonderful park to bring a lunch from the nearby Isetan or Takashimaya basement food floors.

An absolutely beautiful park. this very large park is worth wandering. The large hot house is full of interesting plants and the various sections of the garden are beautifully landscaped. There are also ample places to sit and just take in the ambience.
Lovely little haven of tranquility. Beautiful park, and so tranquil and far removed from the hustle and bustle of central Tokyo! Its a must visit
amazing garden. Typical garden for Tokyo...everything is amazing and clean. Very peaceful place to visit and see a little bit of nature in the concrete jungle that is Tokyo

Lovely manicured gardens and oh, it's open again. In terms of ground area, Shinjuku Gyoen is probably the fourth-largest park in Tokyo after the gardens of the Imperial Palace and Akasaka/Togu Palace, as well as Yoyogi Park although the former two aren't really open to the public. With origins dating back to the 17th century, the current park was rebuilt right after World War 2. Paths crisscross manicured lawns and sculptured bushes or shrubs. Highlights include the Taiwan pavilion which is a part of the Japanese gardens, a French-style garden, and a tree-lined English garden. But this park is best known for being a hotspot during the annual cherry blossom season when it's packed. With the index cases for the current outbreak of dengue fever occurring at Yoyogi Park, located southwest from Shinjuku Gyoen, it's a pity that the park had to shut its gates in early-September. However, with the fumigation efforts completed, the park re-opened in mid-October to the benefit of all visitors. Just remember to avoid Mondays outside of cherry blossom season because it's closed.

Shinjuku Gyoen National Park Was Closed. We walked to the park on 10/13 and it was closed. Our tour guide told us it was closed due to the mosquitos. Hopefully it will be open for our next visit in 2015. The pictures are beautiful.
Beautiful. Beautiful and peaceful place right in the middle of Tokyo. We'll worth it. Lots of variety and places to rest.
Delightful park. This park was amazing - the most perfect garden settings. Easy to walk around or stop and picnic. Don't go there on Mondays as it is closed. Don't miss this park.

Park closed October 2014. I was hoping to get to this beautiful park as I had seen so many reviews however I walked to the park today (the 12th of October) and the park is still closed due to mosquitoes that may have contracted dengue fever so before you go, check to see if it's open as you don't want a wasted trip. It looks gorgeous from the pictures I've seen and from walking outside it, the sound of the birds and tall green tree's definitely makes it sound and look like a haven within such a busy city.
Simply stunning. The garden was absolutely stunning, so clean, and peaceful. A typical example of why Tokyo has to be the best capital in the world.

Refreshing!. Been to Shinjuku Gyoen on one of the days of sakura bloom in Tokyo this year. Admission isn't free, but the park is definitely worth it. I am particularly impressed by the views that are adjacent to the many ponds within the park, and the fact that sakura were plenty during my visit probably made the experience even better. Shinjuku Gyoen also offers a good view of some of the tallest structures in Shinjuku, the closest of which is the grand Docomo tower. The tropical greenhouse may also interest a few people especially those who haven't really experienced tropical flora.I have placed some of my shots of Shinjuku Gyoen within this post:http://intheeyesofanadiq.blogspot.jp/2014/04/in-photos-my-first-hanami.htmlHope it helps!

Park Closed Sept 2014. We stopped by the garden on Sept 19, 2014. But when we arrived there was a person outside the gate with a sign that said the park was closed due to the dengue fever mosquitoes that were found in the park. So check before you go to make sure the park is open.From outside the park it appeared to be lovely inside. Mature, large trees and lots of green in a very busy city. Looked like a lovely place to visit to get away from the madness of Tokyo.
beautiful garden. Wow love it here the views where beautiful make sure you take a umbrella as weather changes very quickly

Closed: Dengue Fever. Ensure that you check to see if it is still open!!! September 2014 - closed due to Dengue Mosquitos.
Looks amazing from the outside, but we couldn't enter due to the outbreak :(

My favorite park. I visit this park each time I visit Tokyo. My fave time is during Cherry Blossom season (March-April). The park is also beautiful in the Fall. There is an admission fee here but it is not much. Pay at the machines at the entrance. If you visit during Cherry Blossom season go early for a good spot. But if you plan to just walk around the park, anytime will work.

Beautiful, peaceful garden. We came to Shinjuku Gyoen in early autumn, before the leaves started changing. The garden was beautiful, peaceful and not crowded at all. Well worth a visit if you are in the area.
Beauty in the center of Shinjuku. What a peaceful place in the center of Tokyo.I love Shinjuku area. The place to be in Tokyo. The gardens are a art work in plants and landscaping. Awesome pics.

Check the website first, may be closed. The park's website says it is closed, starting on 07 September 2014. Apparently a few cases of Dengue fever were traced to mosquito bites that may have occurred in the park. It is being investigated, updates promised on the website (at top of this listing). This is not a review, although I did visit this wonderful park a few years ago, and was looking forward to a return visit next month.

Beautiful!. A great place to visit. Definitely worth your time if you're in the area, and if not you should make the journey! Was easily accessible from the hotel I was staying in and decided to visit.Some beautiful places in the park, and I was really impressed by the different areas on show (Traditional Japanese Garden, Rolling French Garden, English Flower Garden).
