There are large open areas and you can get some great views of the surrounding skyscrapers too! I was particularly impressed by the Japanese garden area that had bridges linking various islands in a lake filled with fish.The park is kept clean and orderly by the attendants, and everyone is very relaxed. Various people were walking around, lying in the grass, or painting flowers. There are lots of facilities as well such as toilets and places to purchase refreshments. The maps on display and signposts make navigation straight-forward too.I was only here for an hour or so, but wish I could/should have spent a bit longer. Definitely at least a half-day visit.

Worth it if you have time. We walked for about an hour to get here from our hotel. It was nice, gardens well maintained, reasonable facilities but we thought there would be more to see here. Liked: the greenery and view of the city Disliked: lack of things to see, would only recommend to go here if you have a lot of time
Great place in summer. Not the best place to go in winter, but I saw photos and looked beautiful in summer. Very serene place. Loved the tea house!

Great spot. Super cheap entrance fee and hugely spacious given Tokyo and the rest of Japan is tight on space. Lots of beautiful ponds and paths to walk around on. Really good break from the busy city and definitely would make a good picnic spot.

Great Value, good garden and good picnic spot. The price is cheap(200￥) area is large and it offers good places to chill and have a picnic. Traditional japanese garden-sights with good places to photo some weird trees and take a breather from the busy commotion of Shinjuku Tokyo
pretty but not a wow. good value and a nice thing to do but more like a UK park rather than anything too japanese! just a little disappointing
The best garden in Tokyo. This is the best garden in Tokyo by far, I think. It is is the perfect place to go after a nice sushi breakfast in Tsukiji

Perfect area for a relaxing walk. I had a late night and was just looking to get outside and do something relaxing. I am not the kind of person who normally finds gardens at all interesting, but since this was the top rated place on Trip Advisor I thought it was worth a try.This place far exceeded my expectations. In fact, I thought it was fantastic. It was pouring rain the majority of my time there, but I still enjoyed it. It is very scenic and is certainly a nice place to just walk around and relax. It is amazing how easy it is to forget you are in one of the largest cities in the world while walking through this place. Highly recommended.

Hidden beauty in a busy city. We went to the gardens to have a look and WOW! The absolute serenity in the middle of a busy city was amazing. There are so many aspects to the gardens that you could spend hours here and still not enjoy every part of it. Definitely worth the visit.

Wide, Open Space in the midst of Tokyo. It feels strange to see such a wide, open space in the middle of a metropolitan like Tokyo. The garden has different part with different theme, such as the Chinese garden, the English garden etc.

Beautiful Layout and Serene Garden. This was a beautiful garden with three different sections - traditional Japanese, French and English sections. There were plenty of places to sit (benches and buildings) and the layout of the garden was amazing. I unfortunately was not able to see the cherry blossom trees in bloom, but regardless this garden is a must see if you are in Tokyo! I also was able to sit and enjoy a good book while wandering the gardens which was very relaxing in a busy city.

Peaceful Greenery in Central Tokyo. Great place to escape from Tokyo's concrete jungle. You can grab something to eat from the basement of the nearby department store for a change from the normal convenience store grub, sit on the grass and people watch.

beautiful haven in the heart of the city. We visited Tokyo in June, when it was rather rainy in Japan. Luckily there were a couple of sunny days on our trip, so that we could visit this lovely park. There were many local families having a picnic, as well. Many types of gardens and a nice green house to visit. A beautiful place to rest your feet and eyes after walking the city streets.
Pretty & manicured. This is a very pretty outdoor space and worth seeing if you're in the neighborhood, but I preferred Yoyogi Park, which had more character and is equally beautiful.

Fascinating. The garden has spacious lawns; footpaths and how the greens were arranged were simply breathtaking. It houses three gardens and my favorite according to presentation is as follows: 1. Japanese, 2. French and 3. English.Seats for better viewing or just simply to enjoy the beauty of the surroundings are provided. Has a greenhouse, a restaurant, an art gallery. The best place to relax from the busy neighborhood due to the tranquil scenery.A must see place in Shinjuku.
Fantastic. If you intend to wisit Tokyo, you should see this fantastic place.Japanise know something The garden is magnific .The nature and the professional keeping the things, yeaahhh

A patch of green in rather gray neighbourhood. Shinjuku is known as the governmental centre of both Tokyo Prefecture and Japan as a whole. It's a rather gray neighbourhood with high-rise buildings and office workers everywhere. That might be why Shinujku Gyoen is so contrasting. The large open spaces of the front garden and the refined style of the French garden work together with the peaceful Japanese garden section to bring you a blast of nature right in the middle of Shinjuku.There is a small fee for entry, but it's well worth it, especially so on cherry blossom season, which seems to last nearly a month, due to different sorts of cherry trees.Access is quite easy with several subway stations nearby.

Oasis in the Urban Jungle. It's chill, it's peaceful, and you'll see a lot more greenery than you thought you could inside the core of Tokyo. I'm froma VERY small town and my first trip to Japan, this place was a lifesaver. Oh, and the "fee" is like $1, it's just a token amount to help with upkeep and keep bums out. It works well in both regards.Bring a book and maybe a drink (or treat yourself in one of their beautiful tea houses) and spend a few hours here unwinding.

Perfect for enjoying cherry blossoms. The park is lovely and provides some beautiful views of different colour cherry blossoms. Many wonderful photo opportunities. We visited the park the first weekend of the sakura season, and it was wonderful to experience it with all the Japanese, who spend the whole day under the cherry trees. We brought a picnic with us, but bento boxes and ice cream are available for purchase inside the park. No alcohol is permitted. It is a short walk from the Shinjuku station, where you can stop to buy some beautiful baked goods to bring to the park. Plan for a picnic and a scenic stroll along the river, and enjoy this fabulous piece of Japanese culture.

Beauty and serenity. Wow, just so beautiful and serene. The perfect place to escape the busy city. All the cliche's apply: it's an oasis, a quiet place for contemplation or just to appreciate the beauty of the park itself. Amazing colors in autumn. Don't miss it.
Beautiful and serene; an oasis. The park is beautiful and clean, an oasis in a busy urban area.The tropical indoor botanical garden was a treat. The only downside to the park is the bathrooms.

Serene and beautiful park. Where to go in busy, crowded Tokyo to get away from the crowds? Gyoen park of course. It's a beautiful park with lots to see. Walk around, explore and get lost. I went in August when it was extremely hot, I found having an umbrella to block the sun and a fan helped to keep me cool. Also, they have popsicles for sale at the snack bar - a life saver!

Loved it. Went there for autumn colours and was not dissapointed, one of the prettiest gardens we visited in autumn in Japan. Went to Kairaku-en and Koraku-en on the same trip, and this park was best. Very nice scenery, colours and quiet atmosphere, entrance fee is very cheap.Went there couple hours before closing time and there were hardly any people (for park this big). Highly recommended.

Worth a Brief Visit. We visited the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden in August, so it was very hot. In a more moderate climate, I could easily see myself spending a couple of hours taking in the scenery and relaxing. With the heat, however, one hour afforded us sufficient time to cover the grounds and take in some nice views. I would not consider the park a "must-do", but if you are close to the area I think that it is worth a visit.

Absolutely stunning. Visited this garden on a rainy and cold day, but nevertheless spent almost 4 hours walking around. The gardens, fields and ponds are very well maintained. Due to the weather there were hardly any people there which allowed me to take amazing photos of the surroundings.

A peaceful place to relax. A small entrance fee is required to access this garden and beware it also closes at 4:30! We arrived at 3:30 without knowing this so we did not have the time to make the most of the location.
In my opinion the Yoyogi park is more interesting and definitely has much more going on from a people watching perspective.

Great oasis in the middle of town.. For a mere 200 yen you get access to a beautiful Park that's hardly populated, plenty of space to be alone. I loved the view of a nearby skyscraper, the only building visible, it was a strange and wonderful contrast.

IF YOU ONLY SEE ONE GARDEN SEE THIS ONE. I visited this garden with my brother who was celebrating his 60th birthday and sister.There is an entry fee but worth Y200 after stopping for a quick lunch and just as we where leaving to explore the garden a Japanese gentleman who obviously overheard us talking presented my brother with 2 origami cranes that he had made and wished him well Again the welcoming of the Japanese people just has to be experience to be appreciated .On to the garden allow yourself time to explore and reflect.This garden has a lot to offer.French Formal ,English Landscape & Japanese Traditional Garden as well as Mother and Child Forest We opted to explore the Japanese Garden and was not disappointed bridges over streams coe swimming and one very large turtle all coming to the shoreline to welcome you .Various entry and exit points but so esay to navigate.So close to the city hub and yet so removed and peaceful.Unfortunately the tea houses where not open.

Well worth the 200 yen admission. The small admission charge clearly keeps out the riff raft and helps maintain the place to high standards. Besides the impressive greenhouse, check out the 2 Japanese style gardens. The larger one is newer and features a Chinese-style pavilion that was constructed to commemorate the Emperor's marriage. The plank has plenty of rest areas to sit in the shade and enjoy a refreshment. Not all the paths are paved.

Pleasant. This garden makes you think you aren't in Tokyo anymore. It is quiet and affordable. The staff is friendly and helpful. The garden is clean and a relaxing place to rest. We visited in August so we couldn't stay all day, but I would have liked to relax in the shade for an afternoon.

Peace in the middle of the city. . We enjoyed walking around in this peaceful garden. It was one of our first stops in Tokyo and it was a great way to see beautiful gardens. The signage is not great so we spent lots of time walking around in this very large park.

Lovely peaceful park in the centre of Tokyo. Park opens at 9am and costs 300yen to get in but it's worth it. I spent 2 hours walking around enjoying the garden. One thing I really enjoyed is the noise in the wooded areas, I thought it was building work but it was actually the sound of the insects. Wear bug spray as I got bitten a few times. This is a really nice place to spend a couple of hours relaxing. There are a couple of small places inside to get ice cream and drinks.

Beautiful and serene place to take relaxing break from busy metropolis. This was my favorite park in Tokyo. Very polished and beautiful green gem in the middle of busy city. Especially nice during the cherry blossom season. Park is pretty large, so some time and good shoes are needed. We were there when it suddenly started to rain, but for our delight park offers quite nice spots for shelter, for instance Taiwanese Pavillion.

Peace in the city. This was one of the first places we went in Tokyo. It was great! Cost a bit to get in, but strolling around and seeing the different gardens they have was wonderful. Worth the visit if you want to be outside.
Great Garden Among the Tokyo City. Great scenery, not crowded and very cheap excursion. Just be prepared to do some walking, totally worth it though.

Beautiful Japanese Garden. Close to Keio Plaza hotel where we stayed, we walked to the gardens. The most beautiful gardens we have seen and looked after so well.An older Japanese man was sitting behind us not sure if he understood what we talking about but we were there for my husbands 60th birthday we were so excited and were talking about this while we were eating our lunch. We finished tidied up then got up to walk on the Japanese gentleman sitting behind us came up to us said excuse he had made 2 origami cranes for my husband so beautiful, it made me cry, such a gesture we have a photo to always remember him, thank you for making this day for us so special.We thank him and wish him good luck - arigato
Decent. Great area, and location, concept is good, minute details not really taken care off. Weedy in some areas, could have done better.

A Large and Beautiful Garden in the Center of Tokyo. After our weeklong stay in Hakone, we went to Tokyo, the capital of Japan, for another week. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden (新宿御苑), one of the largest renowned gardens in Tokyo, is located on East side of Shinjuku. The garden has 58.3 hectares (144 acres) with a border of 3.5 km (2.17 mile) across Shinjuku and Shibuya. The original site of Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden was part of the Edo residence given to Kiyonari Naito in 1590. The current Shinjuku Gyoen was an Imperial garden completed in 1906. After World War II, the garden was opened to the public under jurisdiction of the Ministry of Health and Welfare. Today, the garden is under jurisdiction of the Ministry of the Environment. It was a welcome move because the people in the Greater Tokyo area now have a beautiful oasis and relaxing garden in the center of the city. One additional benefit is that the entrance fee is only ￥200, which was the cheapest entrance fees of our entire 2 week trip.We were there after lunch, and the weather was overcast. We entered the garden from Shinjuku Gate. The large map with or without your preferred language will let you better navigate and plan your route in the garden. Basically, they have four gardens: Japanese Traditional garden, English Landscape garden, French Formal gardens, and Mother and Child’s garden. You will get good exercise by just walking through all the gardens. Because we arrived in the afternoon and the garden closed at 4:30 pm, we picked the Japanese Traditional garden as our primary area to explore. Walking inside the garden was quite pleasant, and we spent some time in the Upper Pond (KAMINO-IKE, 上の池). The view was exceptional, especially in the center of Tokyo. Nearby, we found a Japanese teahouse - RAKUU-TE (楽羽亭) and decided to have some traditional Japanese tea. We were surprised to learn that we needed to purchase tickets for the “Green Tea with Japanese Sweet” from a machine. The price was expensive, ￥700 for a cup of tea and a small sweet. We then went to the Taiwan Pavilion (旧御凉亭, KYU-GORYO-TEI) where you can have a great view of the garden on the 2nd level. We really wanted to see the rest of the gardens, but the time was almost 4:30 pm. We went out from the Sendagaya Gate. Next time, if we visit Tokyo again, I certainly will come to completely visit the other gardens.The garden is famous for when the cherry blossoms in spring. Sinjuku Gyoen is an ideal place year round to get close to nature. You can enjoy the colorful leaves of autumn, greens of summer, and the snows in the winter. You can easily reach the garden via subway or bus. The ticket booth opens from 9 am to 4 pm except on Mondays and between December 1st to January 4th.
Nice landscape. Love the Japanese garden. That's all I saw. The park closes at 4:30 pm. Make sure to go in early to be able to see everything. Very accessible to trai.
Lovely Park. Strolling through the park is peaceful and interesting. If you like flowers this is the place for you.

One of the best parks in Tokyo. When we first went to Tokyo to see a cherry blossoms we were wondering what is the best place for it. So Shinjuku Gyoen is definitely the place where you should go and enjoy sakura. I believe it worth going at any season though. Very clean, very beautiful, so nice to walk there and enjoy marvelous nature around you. Must be!
Excellent place. An excellent experience. You can spend a whole afternoon. Take your own lunch box and relax and enjoy your drink (no alcohol allowed in the gardens). Do not miss

"huge garden within a huge city". we were here on the golden weekend and the entrance fee was waived, norm was 200 yen.very peaceful and beautiful garden within the mass city life of Shinjuku.bring your own bento and drinks is recommended.

A lovely break from the madness of Shinjuku. A lovely place to go to get away from the noise, traffic and crowds. The park is beautiful and well maintained. The Japanese gardens are especially worth seeing. It's a great place to bring a picnic and relax. Closed Mondays. Entry Y200.
Beautiful and calm. Beautiful gardens and enough places to sut down and to get drinks. Im here in juli and its quite refreshing underneath the large threes! Recommend everyone to go here :)
quiet and lovely~. A really beautiful and calm area. fun to just walk and watch the beautiful garden and sit from time to time. reccomended!

Solitude in the middle of 12 million people. It is Sunday morning and many places are closed in the city. we assumed that the park would be crowded, but it was nearly empty. Plan on about 2 hours for a casual walk around the park. It is now mid July so only a few flowers can be seen in the park, but if you walk through the greenhouse you will see an entire world of amazing flowers. All this for 2 yen.Park opens at 9am

Stunning gardens!. Impressive gardens, you could easily spend the entire day exploring! The gardens were complimented the Tokyo skyline also, an amazing place for stunning photos. But keep your eye on the time as it does shut around 4:30!
Great garden right in Shinjuku. Nice green space, lots of cherry tree blossoming, some nice ponds make for a green, relaxing oasis right among the hustle bustle of Shinjuku

Beautiful and Tranquil. We went to many different parks & gardens, but this was by far the most beautiful. Gorgeous Japanese garden, wonderful place to stroll and view the modern city against the tranquility of nature. (nice bathrooms throughout)
beautiful and relaxing. Beautiful park with lovely scenery and landscaping. It was a nice break from the busy streets of Tokyo.

Try to lie on the middle of the park. Beautiful park with a variety of gardens and lakes. A japan animation called 'Garden of words' has been made with this park for a background. If you have watched it, don't miss this place. Highly recommend to stop by when rainy day. You know what i mean.

Beautiful. The Shinjuku Gyoen National gardens were truly spectacular and give a wonderful break from the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku.Small fee to enter the park, but well worth it.Definitely a must visit attraction in Shinjuku.

Beautiful park, nice break from the city.. Definitely a good place to go if you need to give your wallet a break from shopping and your ears a break from the city noise. I'm not a huge garden fan but the park was huge and had so many interesting things to see, especially in the greenhouses. If you're lucky, you'll probably also spot some turtles and huge fish in the ponds.
Beautiful park in the city. Tokyo has lots of sightseeing but its kind of attraction you may not imagine in tokyo. My japanese friend brought me here and i enjoyed it

Park with a Green House. If you visited most attractions and wish to have a nice stress-free stroll in a park and garden, this place offers you serenity. There is a rest house where some locals sit to sketch/draw the landscape. Cross the bridge and it brings you to a different part of the park which features flat grassy landscape with the city skyline in the background. Before leaving the park, make a stop at the green house as well for a good host of flowers and plants... Look out for a rare almost extinct miniature flower. The green house has automated panels on the top that open up when the rain stops or when weather is conducive to the plants inside.Reachable by subway, entrance is only Yen 200 per adult

Not just for garden lovers. Bring a hat or umbrella (if raining) for a couple of hours strolling through the various path ways in this beautiful garden. We were there on a warm June afternoon and glad we brought along lots of water and sun protection. There are 2 major rest areas and toilet facilities scattered amongst the grounds. Unfortunately neither tea houses or restaurant were open on the day of our visit, but there are plenty of places to sit and take your own refreshments. The displays are nicely presented, although the French formal garden looked a little worse for wear. There were lots of people around penning or painting some of the scenery. Closing time is 4:30pm so don't leave it too late to visit if going in the afternoon. One of those places that is well worth a visit for the paltry fee of 200 yen.

Be dazzled by the flowers. It is a large park with 3 types of gardens, the French and Englsih landscapes in the north . and to the south a Japanese traditional garden. Do not miss visiting the greenhouse. You would be amazed by many types of flowers and trees. Bring a mat along to sit or lie down. You would be captivated by the gardens and the visitors to the park. Be it flower or people watching, time passes away meaningfully.

Beautiful. It really is a beautiful parkFor a small fen of 200 ye in admission, you can to see much greenery in a bustling town. It was too crowded, though cos it was sakura season, the crowds were around the sakura trees.Wonderful place to stroll around, picnic and relax.

Such a beautiful park! (but bring bug repellent). 200 yen to enter, but totally worth it. Beautifully maintained and makes you feel like you are in a forest in the middle of the busy city. The employees are very nice, helpful, and friendly, esp to foreign, non-Japanese speaking tourists. Wasn't too crowded when we went midday during the weekday. But remember to bring bug repellent -- I was bitten several times by mosquitoes (But at least a shop within the garden carried bug repellent wipes for just 350 yen).

American in Tokyo. Only $2 U.S. (200 yen) in admission. Several large gardens: Japanese, French, and English. Easy walk on paved pathway. Near subway stations. Seasonal flowers. Traditional Japanese Tea Room, easy to find toilets throughout. May want to take some insect repellant for few mosquitoes. Japanese mothers and toddlers having picnics.
Wow!. Great place to take a walk or an excellent run! Very nice and clean (like everything else in Japan) but wasn't open on Mondays when I planned for a record breaking run! ;)
beautiful park. In the middle of tokyo, beautiful , I went during cherry blossom and it was really pretty.. there are 3 different types of garden. french japanese and english
Excellent!. Excellent park, a nice paradise in the middle of busy Tokyo.The rose garden is wonderful with a variety I never saw before.If you have time to go and lay down is a great place to do!

Best thing in Tokyo. Honestly, we were overall a little disappointed in Tokyo, but this was the highlight of our 3 days there (Kyoto was much more interesting). The grounds are quite large with English, French, and Japanese style gardens (the latter were our favorite). Take your time - allot at least 3-4 hours to spend in the garden as there is a lot to see. There are plenty of shady benches to rest. Don't miss the greenhouse as well - it has a variety of beautiful, exotic plants.

Interesting and beautiful. A great place to spend a morning. The shrine is very interesting, the bonzai trees are awesome and the garden is beautiful. Be sure to see the irises in bloom - beautiful in June. A nice 10-15 minute walk from Shibuya station. Clean bathrooms.

Lovely and peaceful garden. A surprising place especially due to its proximity to the hectic Shinjuku area. Garden is beautiful and big. Many people were around and wee not felt. Well, most were Japanese and they are very quite and relaxing... anyway , we enjoyed our stroll the pond the painters around it.Pay attention:l it is closed on Mondays, like many museums are.
Nice Park. Clean, beautiful, green. A perfect place to stay and enjoy. Full of gardens, traditional tea houses and peace.

Nice stroll through the garden. I visited the National Garden on a rainy day, and even so, had a pretty good time.The grounds are really quite lovely to walk on, with small ponds scattered about, traditional tea houses, beautiful trees and flowers.Visited the green house and thought that was also quite nice.Worth visiting for a couple of hours for sure.

Nice even in the rain. It was raining so wasn't sure going to a garden would be a good idea. But well worth the trip, the gardens are beautiful, and the greenhouse although small was a welcome relief from the rain. Definitely visit regardless of weather.

Beautiful Scenery. I went to the National Gardens because I wanted to see the Summer House and other spots used in the anime film Garden of Words. I was blown away by how serene and beautiful the Gardens are as a whole. Friendly staff at the Entrance/Info center knew exactly where I wanted to go and circled the spots on the map. Stopped into the Tea House on my way out to enjoy the mini-tea ceremony and was good tea and Red Bean cake (I believe) for the 700 Yen price.

Huge collection of cherry blossom!. Great place for Hanami!This park have a huge variety of cherry blossoms, so if you come to Japan a little bit early or late, there is a high chance you still could enjoy watching sakura here.

garden oasis. Shinjuku Gyoen is a pleasurable and relaxing park. I have visited once, at thevtail end of sakura blossoms on a weekday morning in early April. The trees were beautiful, and must be a sight to behold at their peak. Possibly due to the small admission charge and no-alcohol policy, the park seemed mellow and uncrowded.

Peaceful and relaxing. It's been a good few years since I last visited, but I really should do so again. Maybe when I travel later this year....Was a little surprised on arrival that first time to find that a fee was charged for entering, albeit a nominal one. Nevertheless, I paid my way and entered. Oh, nice! I enjoy Japanese gardens, the way everything is set out 'just so', the little arched bridges over ponds and streams, the perfectly sculpted landscape. And I was not disappointed, here. The first thing I came upon was a set of little bridges....It's quite a large garden so do allow yourself plenty of time to explore. Take a picnic (just, take your waste away with you!). Although thronged with visitors, the garden nevertheless remains a most peaceful and relaxing location, and you never feel rushed to go or do anything else. Enjoy your walk as it could prove the only time for peace, solitude and tranquillity you find in vibrant Tokyo. It's a wonderful, wonderful garden to enjoy. The fee pales to insignificance given the attention the area will require to maintain. I certainly did not begrudge paying once inside.Nice!

Absolutely to visit during Sakura. I visited the parc in beginning of april during Sakura season and i was mind-blown.i would strongly recommend to visit the parc in the middle of the week as there not much people. the parc prohibits alcohol and it has a really calm and chilled out mood.Went back again there late April on a date, and it's a place i won't ever forget. Not as beautiful as in Sakura time but still the mood there is just perfect.

Solace in the middle of Shinjuku.. Why didn't I ever go there before? I visited there for a picnic with a meet up people. Had absolutely no prior knowledge of the functions of this place. Well it's essentially the Tokyo equivalent of Central Park, maybe little better. Sure there's a fee(200yen/adult) and the place closes early(gates close at 4:30pm), but it was so nice to discover that there's a big place to relax and hang out filled with vegetation in an absolute concrete jungle of Shinjuku. I'll go there every time I'm in Tokyo from now on.

Beautiful garden, well worth the visit. This garden is beautiful and very spacious, with multiple styles situated within the area. There is a small entrance fee. The greenhouse was incredible, with lots of various plants from around the world. There are lots of rose bushes of different varieties. There are a couple of traditional teahouses to visit if you wish. The garden is quite large, so be prepared to do some walking, but it is worthwhile, especially if you want to escape from the busyness of Tokyo for a while.

Amazing garden !!. It is the best garden in the world , if you like gardens you will find here the paradise.The garden is divided into four different gardens , the traditional Japanese garden which is the best , english landscape garden, french formal garden which contains the roses and so many other types of flowers, and the last garden is the mother and child forest.

Nature getaway in the middle of the city. Definitely worth a visit. Was there in the Spring, just as the cherry trees were blooming - fantastic! More types of cherry trees than I thought existed. Don't miss the fabulous green house.
A great afternoon walk. We enjoyed this garden. The roses were spectacular ,they were highlight. It was also a great place to people watch.
Perfect retreat from the concrete jungle.. A must see. The garden is maintained in such a way to preserve a natural feeling. Great place to go to get away from it all.

Nicest Garden in Tokyo. We visit the Shinjuki Gyoen National Garden at least once a month - cherry blossoms (very crowed on weekends), then azaleas, roses, irises, etc.Take a picnic and enjoy the park!
Beautiful garden. It's about 25 mins walk from Shinjuku metro and should not be missed especially with the flowers blooming in spring!

Nice park next door. This great park was 10 mins away from where we stayed in shinjuku .With a Japanese garden ,bald cider ,green house & a drop dead gorgeous French garden it's simply a must for visitors .the French garden has roses Of colors which are simply mind blowing . We enjoyed it immensely
A lovely park. Parts of this park are beautiful, while others are a little drab. Overall we had a really nice walk around the park. Didn't realise we had to pay to get in though!
Cherry Blossom. This is a japanese garden park. You can see the famous cherry blossom. Nature is different there, depending on the month you go. Color of trees changes, depending on the month you go.

A sight to behold. Me and my husband were very lucky to experience the start of the Sakura and Hanami last April. Sakura in Japan means cherry blossoms while Hanami means cherry blossoms viewing. It was a 10-15 mins walk from Washington Shinjuku hotel were we stayed. The park is so serene and very well maintained. Colorful cherry blossoms adorned you as you enter the park. It's a must to visit if you happen to be in Tokyo.

A beautiful place to visit. You have to pay to get into the garden, but it doesn't really cost much. There was a sign stating that entry was free in a couple of days time, so if you are budget concious this could be a good thing for you to check. The gardens are just beautiful, especially around the pond/lake area with a stunning view of the NTT Docomo Yoyogi Building. I would recommend packing a picnic lunch and taking some time to sit under a beautiful tree and soak in the fact you're at a real Japanese garden.
Beautiful garden. Loved the day I spent there. Had gone there to shoot some images and came back really impressed by the beauty present at that place
Blooming blossom. This was the best place I found in Tokyo for blossom in early April 2014. Simply beautiful. It is well worth a visit

Paradise within Tokyo's concrete jungle. Conveniently located within the city, this is the most beautiful refuge to go to when you think you've had enough of Tokyo's modern eclecticism and vibrancy. It's just a short walk from the JR Line Shinjuku Station and once your weary feet brings you to this patch of heaven, it is almost always assured that you will be recharged just by taking in sights of this masterpiece.Everything is just so serene and calm that you can't help but look for the nearest comfortable spot, take a seat back, kick off those walking shoes and relax and bask in such majestic beauty. Of course, you also have the option to roam around Japanese-, English- and French-style gardens to fully appreciate the layout and terrain and the well-manicured flowering trees and shrubs.Admission price is only around 200 yen or about 2 USD; you can not NOT go in. You deserve to see such beauty!!

Loveliest Park in Tokyo. Once the novelty of the size, noise and bustle of Tokyo has worn off you must pack a picnic lunch and plan on spending a few hours enjoying the different areas of the park, including a lovely greenhouse, expansive lawns, streams, ponds and teahouses. It does cost a few hundred yen for admittance. Note that while it boasts English and French style gardens in additional to Japanese, these are not really typical English or French layouts you would encounter in London or Paris but rather areas blended into the rest of the park which use non-Japanese plants.

Best garden to visit in area if little time. Spent about 4 hours here and it is lvely, although can get crowded on the weekend. There are hundreds of sih that come to the surface to see if you will feed them, and terrapins in the water too. The green house is worth a visit. A nice little Oasis in the madness of Shinjuju.
So relaxing. Just down the road from our hotel - Citadines. It is a beautiful oasis is a busy city with lovely gardens

A truly magnificient garden, go if you only have time for one garden to see or have kids.. The entrance itself is a little difficult to find and bags will be checked as alcohol is prohibited. But the garden is beautiful and breathtaking esp the juxtaposition of the clear lake with pink flowers and the huge ntt docomo building. I went during the cherry blossom season. It was pink and white everywhere. The garden itself has many varieties of gardens (french, english, etc). The field is also a great place to have a picnic or bring your kids. A Must see attraction in tokyo and shinjuku
Spring garden. A beautiful and grand traditional Japanese garden with easy walking paths and contrasting English garden to view. Very peaceful and colourful experience.

Not just during the Cherry Blossoms.... A recent trip to China found me joined by my wife. She asked if we could make a side trip to Tokyo for the Cherry blossom bloom. Well, happy wife, happy life, so we made the stopover. The Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is not the only place to enjoy the blossoms, but I think it may be the best! The well landscaped gardens were truly a sight to behold, made even more special by the clouds of blossoms above your head. Can't make the Cherry blossom season, give it a visit regardless.You won't regret it. Bring a lunch and relax in the varied and beautiful setting. A must see in Tokyo!

Sakura Blossom. My sole purpose of going to the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden was to see the famed cherry (sakura) blossom (a first time for me) and I was not disappointed. The garden is huge (58 acres) and it has over 3 km of walkway to stroll through its various sections. While the number of cherry trees is said to be 1,500, it did not show as overwhelming as many other sakura viewing spots in Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka where I also visited for the same purpose in this trip and where the cherry trees are more concentrated. However, the extremely nice setting of the Garden with more variety of other trees, especially the old and towering ones, and the presence of ponds here and there make the cherry trees stand out even more. Probably because of the cherry blossom season, there was plenty of tourists but even more locals who picnicked everywhere in the Garden under the shades of those lovely cherry trees. The scene was one of tranquility and peaceful coexistence of man and nature just steps from the reality of city life.I really admire the locals who find time to relax and enjoy life in such fashion and I started to realize that this is what life should be. A reminder about cherry blossom viewing: one can check on the internet the Country's forcast on the full blossom periods of each year for each locale which I presume last for two to three weeks only. That is how I decided on the time frame of my visit but of course inclement weather is never predictable and if not for rain and wind a couple of days before my arrival, my local friend said that I could have seen a even fuller blossom. That has to wait for my next time around which I think is definitely worth it! And do spend sometime in the Park and bring your own food to laze around and enjoy mother nature to its fullest.

Cherry blossoms in bloom!. We toured this garden and it was definitely worth the trip. We learned there are several varieties of cherry blossoms. They don't all bloom at the same time - so lucky us - we were able to still catch blooming cherry blossoms!

Very pretty worth a look. Very pretty and very clean ,as is all of Tokyo. The blossoms were still out and the vast area takes a good amount of time to view the entire area. Well worth the time and very relaxing.
Hanami. Hanami in Gyoen Park is the biggest fun during cherry blossoms　season.

A gem in a bustling city!. Walking into this garden we were not ready for what we were about to experience. Arriving at the gate we saw masses of people, our first thought was we were not going to find a spot to have our picnic lunch that we bought but we were so wrong. It's a huge garden and there's plenty of green grass for everyone! We found a nice quiet spot under a cherry blossom tree and spread out our picnic lunch bought from the food hall in Isetan a few blocks away.TIPS: grab some food, a blanket and have a picnic in the garden. Once inside, you would not feel like you are in the bustling city of Shinjuku!

Beautiful paradise within a huge metropolis. We spent a good couple of hours strolling through the beautiful gardens, taking in a visit to the green house, and enjoying the beautiful views of the city skyline. The park was pretty busy with tourists (mainly Japanese) and school-age groups. It was such a peaceful place and I would definitely encourage any one to spend a lazy afternoon here!

A good place for photography enthusiast. We missed the cherry blossoms but the place is still beautiful. There were a lot of different kind of flowers to see and also if you're tired, you can just sit under those big shady trees.A good place to take wonderful pictures...

Large park with many features. This park or garden in Shinjuku is very large and is a good couple of hours walk to get around. It has a very good glass house area with water fall and modern design. Also depending on time of year there are various colorful flower displays. Lots of little rest areas with food too, spread about. Easy to get to on foot from Shinjuku stations in general. Also has carp and a few turtles, and pretty areas for photos. Bridal photographs and so on. 200 yen to enter.

Central Park in Tokyo. I live right next to this park and I love this park. It's like an oasis in the centre of Tokyo and you can see high rise buildings around it which very much reminds me of Central Park in NY. Throughout the year, you can enjoy different flowers and trees here; Japanese apricot trees in March, cherry blossoms from beginning to the end of April, azalea and wisteria in May, roses in summer, then autumn forliage, etc. It also have a huge open area with nice green lawn where you can lie down or picnic.It uses to belong to Japanese royal family, so their rules are rather strict. It closes at 4:30PM, you cannnot bring alcohol and they check your bag during cherry blossom season (because Japanese people love to drink sake under cherry trees,) and no pets, bicycles, ball games.One thing you have to be careful:There are four gates; sendagaya gate, okido gate, sinjuku gate and main gate, but the main gate is almost always closed. I often see tourists who look lost in front of the main gate.sinjuku gate is near sinjuku san-chome station, okido gate is near sinjuku gyoen station, sendagaya gate is near sendagaya station.
A wonderful walk.. You must visit these gardens - they are so beautiful and peaceful and a break from the hubbub of the city. Put it on your do to list.

Late cherry Blossom viewing Tokyo. We went to Tokyo Japan , to catch Cherry Blossom time . Unfortunately we were late .we came second week of April . The best time to go is around April 6 we went April 11. There were no more Cherry Blossom in full Bloom in Tokyo . luckily we were able to catch the late Bloomers in Shijuku Goen national Garden . Cherry Blossoms in different colors pink , white ect. So Beauiful The park is open from 9am to 4:30 in the afternoon . You pay 200 yen per person and its worth it

spacious garden in the middle of city. beautiful garden to see sakura blooming, too bad when we went there, sakura begins to drop. In the hectic of Tokyo, especially shinjuku, the garden helps the city produce fresh air. you can go picnic, bring some food and open your mat... please no littering, cause the garden is too beautiful and clean to be littered.

Beautiful. I visited just before cherry blossom season was in full swing. There were a few trees beginning to bloom, but I can only imagine how wonderful it would've looked in full bloom. The gardens are landscaped to show traditional Japanese plants at their best. Bonsai and lotus, cherry blossoms and many varieties of pine trees. It was chucking it down with rain on the day I visited but even this did not dampen my experience there. With the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku just outside the gardens grounds, this serene respite made me feel relaxed and rejuvenated.

Beautiful cherry blossoms. Very relaxing and lively place to have a picnic lunch and spend the afternoon. We went during cherry blossom season and there were many hanami parties going on. Beautiful cherry blossoms, would go again!
One of my favourite quiet escapes in Tokyo. A beautiful park in the middle of the city. Great place to spend a couple of hours wandering around and looking at different gardens and things.

Beautiful!. Loved this park! Was very lucky to see the cherry blossoms and definitely recommend this park as a must see when visiting Tokyo. It was easy to locate and the perfect place to spend an entire day.

Relaxing place to spend the afternoon. Shinjuku Gyoen is an easy stroll from Shinjuku-Sanchome Station. We brought some food and drinks and set up a picnic mat under the shade of the cherry blossoms. It was very pleasant and we sat for a long time, watching kids run around and workers having corporate hanami lunches (yes, company lunches under the cherry blossoms!) There are many varieties of cherry blossoms in this park and it is a great place for families and kids as it is spacious. Shinjuku Gyoen is one of the best places to view cherry blossoms and other kinds of flowers in the heart of Tokyo.

Beautiful place to view the cherry blossoms. This large park in the southwestern portion of Tokyo's Shinjuku district is well-planned, well-maintained and lovely. I was here to see the cherry blossoms (sakura) in April 2014, and I was not disappointed. Many Japanese folks were having their sakura-viewing picnic (hanami) here. It was a beautiful setting, and a memorable day.

Cherry Blossoms galore!. If you came to Tokyo for the cherry blossoms, look no further and just visit the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. There are numerous cherry blossom trees of different varieties and the landscape is truly majestic (they have a traditional Japanese Garden, an English Garden, a classical French garden and a greenhouse). If you enjoy picnics, bring some food and non-alcoholic beverages and just relax for a few hours while soaking in the views or frolicking with your kids. Admission is 200 yen for adults which is not bad at all. The park is easily accessible and just a 5-minute walk from Shinjuku-gyoemmae station.
Sakura. Our vissit was near the end of the cherry blossoms but still it was lovely, many trees still had blooms.Interesting to see the picnics the Japanese hold there at the end of the sakura.
stunning during cherry blossom season. Beautiful park, incredible during cherry blossom season, nice greenhouse, plenty of open space! Rose garden wasn't in bloom but imagine its great in season.

Parks that feeds your Senses. April is definitely Sakura month. So it is without doubt that we had to visit at least one Japanese Park that features different Sakura blooms. This park was about 300 meters from where we stayed. It was a delight to see different trees with Sakura blooms. You can bring in your own food and drinks (non-alcoholic), set up a mat and eat under the trees. Too bad we did not know this beforehand or we would have done this.There were pocket gardens spread around the park. And there were stations where you can purchase food inside the park that ranges from about 350Yen to 500Yen for a bento box. Vendo machines for the drinks were also located in these parts.Restrooms can be quite a challenge. But it was clean and not smelly. It was properly maintained.Entrance fee for adults 500Yen and Children 350Yen if memory serves me correctly.
Worth a visit. Beautiful gardens especially when the cherry blossoms are in full bloom.Would highly recommend for when you need a break from the busy pace of Tokyo.

Our highlight in Tokyo. This park is an absolute joy and with many late flowering cherries there was an abundance of stunning views and photo opportunities. We took a rug and enjoyed some time in the sun overlooking a beautiful lake with blossoms all around. The casual and calm atmosphere is a delight. The different styled gardens means that there should be something for everyone throughout the year.

Depends if you like parks.... This is a medium-sized garden/park near Shibuya and Shinjuku. It has trees (some cherry trees), grass, lakes and walking paths, like other parks. There are several different areas to walk to, and lots of people sitting around on the grass and taking pictures. If you like walking through parks, this is quite a nice one and you'll probably enjoy it.If you're in Tokyo for more adventurous means, there's probably no reason to stop by. I don't regret my quick walk through the park but wouldn't recommend it and probably wouldn't go again.

Beautiful Park. I love the garden landscape and cherry blossom trees in bloom. I had fun taking pictures of the place and see young and old japanese people welcoming spring by putting picnic blankets all over the park and savoring the beauty of nature.

Fabulous. The place to go if you miss Tokyo's main cherry blossom season… as this was still lovely with many late flowering varieties, well after the main season of local trees was past it's best by date by a week or more. Lots of lovely things and beautiful Japanese and Chinese and english style gardens…

Nice place to see the cherry blossoms. We went to Shinjukugyoen to see the late-blooming cherry blossoms. Though it was already the 2nd week of April, the Japanese garden was full of cherry trees with pink and white blossoms, it was quite a beautiful sight. Entrance fee is ¥500/person. Garden is around 500 meters from Shinjuku station. Nice place also to picnic under the trees.

A must stop. Gorgeous.. I went on the last week of march, so it must be even better now.Just walk around and take pictures. I do recommend gong to the cypress sector. There are some funny looking " root-like" structures sprouting from the ground. Looks like zombie hands coming out of the ground. Very odd indeed.For food, there is limited good options. But not too bad in terms of price. Some small sandwiches, low budget sushi boxes.We did the tea ceremony. It's ok for 700 yen. You get a small sweet with a freshly brewed ma tcha tea cup. Nothing much going on. You don't actually witness a ceremony. It's basically just paying for tea. It's a good tea though. And yes, you buy the ticket from the machine first, then you walk in.Tip: - there are 2 entrances, one south and one north. Might save you the hassle of walking all around the park to get to the main entrance.- It's accessible by JR train, if you have the pass.- Also, forget the French garden. Horrible. Nothing to see.Overall, there is little to say about this park. It's just plain beautiful and pleasant to stroll around. you need to see to believe it.
Highlight of our trip. Came there to do cherry blossom viewing. gardens are well kept and nice themed gardens, the place looks magical especially with all the cherry blossoms

Amazing cherry blossoms. I was at the park during the height of the cherry blossoms. The park was beautiful. I stopped and had tea in the tea house which was very nice. I walked all through the park and was amazed by the beauty. If you are in Tokyo during the cherry blossom season , this park is a MUST visit!

Variety of splendid colours. I'm not a huge fan of gardens but this is no ordinary garden, people! Lots of different plant varieties and the beloved cherry blossom trees in their full glory. We were in Sakura heaven! For just 2 yen per person this was probably the best-value Japanese experience so far for us. Do try it!

Lovely Park. It's a lovely park that should not be miss. We went for the sakura viewing and was really amazed by the beautiful sakura in this park. The entrance fee is Yen200. We went through Shinjuku gates. At Shinjuku Station take south exit and walk around 10 mins. Many people bring food and drinks to picnic in the park. No alcohol drinks is allowed. There will be checks to prevent alcohol drinks being brought in at the entrance.

So beautiful. Shinjuku Gyoen is a welcome oasis in Tokyo with loads of cherry blossoms and beautiful walk ways. We managed to visit during Hanami and the park was just magical. Loads of people having picnics and enjoying themselves, kids laughing, people chatting. Nice and relaxing compared to the insanity of Tokyo!
Big and nice park. Nice big park in Shinjuku. Great for a walk and Hanami in spring, but you pay a small entrance fee like 2$.

Beautiful garden truly a photographers dream!. We had the opportunity to visit Gyoen national gardens when the Sakura were still in bloom. This place will take your breath away even if you're not a person that enjoys the outdoors. It's centrally located in Tokyo and very accessible. Walking around the gardens is relaxing and leaves you with a sense of awe. When you are tired with the hustle and bustle of the streets of Tokyo this is where you should go to recharge. It's simply beautiful!

beautiful garden worth a trip. we were lucky the sakura has started blooming earlier than expected in late march. we visited in a late morning on our last day in tokyo. there were no queuing at the ticket office but when we headed back around noon there was long queue. there were plenty of sakura trees mostly whites and pinks and all were so beautiful. the red one has just opened. many people were having picnic while enjoying the sakura. very interesting to experience "hanami". and when the wind blows the sakura petals were falling like snowflakes. the gardenhas beautiful landscapes as well like japanese garden and ponds then wide grass field with shinjuku skyscrappers background. there is small shop inside the garden which sell snacks souvenirs and lunchbox. also vending machine. from shinjuku JR station we took the marunouchi metro (red line) and get out at shinjuku gyoen mae station (only 2 stops) look for the exit to thegarden then walk cross the road, there is one indian restaurant in the intersection corner and one udon restaurant at the other corner. walk straight ahead then you will see the garden. then turn left walk straight ahead to the garden entrance. on our wayback we tried the hand made udon restaurant at the road corner across the subway station exit where you order your udon or soba then you can pick various side dishes andtempura yourself. it was delicious and looks quite popular among locals whenwe were there. no english. just point the type of udon from the picture

Must go if you haven't done Hanami yet.. It seemed Hanami season was over...but here you still have got a chance. Late April is the best season to visit Shinjuku Gyoen park. I visited there last weekend and there were so crowded but I thought the cherry blossoms hadn't not in full bloom yet. This weekend and the following weeks could be the best. Don't miss it if you were in Tokyo at this moment. Enjoy picnic under the cheery trees! The park itself is huge.Note: drinking alcoholic is not allowed in this park. The Shinjuku gate is often too crowded, especially spring Hanami season. I recommend to use the Okido gate.

Late blooming sakura. I was there on the weekend of 12 Apr Sat. There was some important event going on when I reached around 930am and was told to return at 1030am. It was my second time to the park to view sakura. Around the same time few years back, sakura was in full bloom. This time round, sakura season supposedly has ended even my Japanese friends said so. I was blessed to insist to come by myself as I read that the late blooming varieties are full bloom during that weekend. Although not as pretty as the first time I visited, it is still well worth the trip. Very pretty and neat park.

Cherry blossom. suggest to visit it during end of march and begin of april...lots of cherry blossom and nice garden to be relax...very close to shinjuku station.Nice shooting area and worth for 200 yen.suggest to get some food in for picnic because the carteen is just sell set lunch.no bread and no breakfast.

Spring or Autumn?. I have been fortunate enough to have visited this beautiful haven in both Springtime Sakura and in lovely colour blazen Autumn, and can't pick between the two. You will never go wrong in a decision to get out of the bedlam of Shinjuku streets, and into the tranquility of this huge park to help bring some peace back to your mind and body. Love this place a lot.

A nice place to spend an hour or two. Lovely quiet gardens, tucked away amongst the busy streets of Shinjuku. Not quite as beautiful as some gardens in places like Kyoto but still very nice to walk around on a sunny day in April.

Beautiful Park!. Was lucky enough to be here during cherry blossom season and this park was spectacular. Worth the 200 yen entrance fee to wander around and enjoy the scenery.Seemed to be a popular place for children to run around wide grassy areas while parents relaxed.
Cherry trees blossoming.. I loved walking around in thegarden [$ 2 entry fee). The cheery trees were blossoming and it was totally beautiful.

Wonderful place in Fall and Spring in particular, but any time is scenic and pleasant. Good place to go with friends for a picnic on the lawn. There is also a kind of Western tearoom at the entrance and a Japanese tea house on the grounds.
The entrance fee is well worth it. The display of Cherry Blossoms was incredible & there was a traditional Tea Ceremony available in the Japanese Tea Room
Cozy. Its nice to see the locals picknick. Beautiful cherry blossoms. We were there on a sunday and it was very busy but cheerful.

Sakura Hotspot - Relaxing stroll. A national garden so beautiful I didn't want to leave. It closes as early as 1600hrs in the afternoon. This garden is practically used within picnic groups especially during the peak season in Spring, simply bring your mat, buy your snacks & drinks to enjoy the scenery. The amount of sakura trees is massive & the view of them is just breath-taking. Really a place to visit during spring.A stroll along the garden is so calming. Should you be visiting Tokyo next Spring, put this on your to-do list! *Entrance Fee: 200Yen per adult.

Gorgeous scenery. Lots of walking through gorgeous landscaping in the midst of Tokyo Bring a camera.Interestingly, the "exotic" plants in the fabulous greenhouse were many that I grow in my California yard.

Sakura Hanami!! First experiance of Cherry Blossom Party. Tokyo becomes a divine place to be when Sakura arrives. Shinjuku Gyoen is the one of the most to be place at the time of Cherry Blossom. We went on a sunny Saturday afternoon for cherry blossom picnic. The cherry trees here are lined up and it’s fun to stand below one of them. Don’t forget to get your Tarp with food and drinks. Keep in mind; Alcoholic dreams are a big no no inside the park. They will check your bags and if they find it, they will not throw it, but ask you to stand and drink before entering!! Strange and funny :). Please keep this in mind that the park closes at 5 PM and don’t forget to take a walk by the lake.Get down at Shinjuku- San chome station on Shinjuku line and you can easily walk from there to the Park!!
Gorgeous. Nice walk through the park during cherry blossom season. Pretty trees, pond, old tea house, etcetera. Lots of people taking photos and having picnics.

Good spot for cherry blossom viewing. You can see all different types of Sakura in one place. The park is big, and lots of cherry blossom around it. The park is very clean and tidy, good place to have picnic or gateway from hectic city lifestyle.

Beautiful. Beautiful gardens, could have spent more time here, but on a busy schedule, can be very busy, with lots of tourist groups, so please be patient, but well worth it.The cherry blossom was fantastic, as was the greenhouse and other gardens.Allow yourself at least 3 hours to appreciate this garden, you cannot rush it.
Beautiful green spot in the middle of the buildings!. The garden is full of beautifully landscaped trees and ponds. A real tranquil place to relax in the middle of all the shopping!
Fantastic Cherry Blossoms. Great place to watch the cherry blossoms with a lovely lake. An island of tranquility in a busy city.

Really nice and beautiful garden. Another must visit place to go when visiting Tokyo. With the small fee of 200Yen, you get to spend time in this beautiful garden. The garden has a Japanese Garden whic is so beautiful.. We were there beginning of April and there was Sakura 'cherry blossom' everywhere. There is also a french garden which is well manicured and rose plants around and the boring english garden which is just a giant patch of lawn. My favorite was the Japanese garden and there is a lot of photos to take. Also don't forget to visit the tea house in the middle of the Japanese garden, for 700Yen, you get a bowl of sencha 'japanese green tea' and a mochi 'japanese sweet filled with bean paste'.. yumm..
sakura garden. Beautiful park, especially for the sakura season. There was quite a crowd when I went on a weekday. The entrance fee is 200 yen for adults.
Beautiful. Worth visiting, amazing garden , spring time is such a treat, beautiful cherry blossom. Peaceful, great to see people doing yoga, reading, having picnics or just walking around
Cherry blossom crowds. It was pretty crowded, but for good reason. Many trees in bloom, and different species of cherry blossoms make pictures more interesting

Shinjuku Gyoen national garden. We were there to see cherry blossoms and we were not disappointed. They were there and everywhere! Beautiful. Only minus point is the lack of park benches - very few and far between. Also signage in English could be improved.

Very good place. One the best places to view cherry blossoms, it is a huge place which has many different type of gardens in it... loads of cherry blossom trees everywhere and of different types as well.

Gorgeous park. I loved this park- so spacious and plenty of cherry blossoms out! Loads of places to sit and picnic too even if alone like I was. I lay down and enjoyed the sun too...so peaceful. A must if you're doing the cherry blossom rounds in Tokyo this time of year. Only 200 yen to get in.
Cherry blossom. Well worth the entry price, may it be for 10mn or 4hours. Great location in April for the cherry blossom...

Magnificent park. Along with many thousands of others, it was our pleasure to experience this delightful park with the added bonus of cherry blossom in full bloom. As you go in ask the staff for an English version of the map. There are many different areas to explore ... Japanese Traditional, French Formal, English Landscape and some authentic buildings. But the star of the show was the Cherry Blossom area .... magnificent. Note that during this peak time the Greenhouse was closed. Entrance fee of 200 yen each

Stunning!. The garden is within 10 minute walk from shinjuku station there a few signs pointing you in the right direction and most people know what you want.This place is just beautiful it was a sunny day and we loved the well kept gardens lovely lake with koi carp , there is a traditional tea house not in use which makes great photo shots.also there is a french, English and a Japanese styles of gardens.lovely place and one of the unexpected highlights of our trip
Cherry blossom season. 200 yen for the most beautiful visual experience and only two stops from Shinjuku station on the Maronouchi Line. Go in cherry blossom season.

Sakura viewing. Pleasant walk with different theme gardens. Cherry blossoms are in bloom. Different colors from white to pale and dark pink/ almost red. Try and get there early and continue on to local shopping beyond the park. Shinjuku train station is close by if coming from other parts of Tokyo.

Very Nice to Visit in Pre-Cherry Blossom season. This garden, besides everything else has a number of cherry trees of the kind that blossom a little before the official Sakura season. It was a pleasure to visit the place in late march and see those trees in bloom. Besides the place is very well organized with large well manicured lawns, ample signage for directions, restaurants, and visitor facilities. Overall a very visitor friendly place.Oh, I forgot to write very clean too.

early spring surprise. we went just as the early cherry was blooming, Plum was out, and magnolia was out. within a few days the place would be swamped. There were still so many beautiful views. the Japanese garden was fantastic. the Greenhouse was amazing as well. definitely worth some quiet time to take a stroll.

Oasis in Tokyo and cherry blossoms!!!. By far I felt that this park is the only and best place to watch the cherry blossoms in all it's colors and shapes in Tokyo.. At an entrance fee of ¥200 to the park, it's worth the pay. The park is big, and we could spend hours just strolling around embracing all the sights of gigantic cherry trees, shrugs, hedges or just sit on the lawn enjoying the sound of bustling Tokyo. So peaceful and calm, and the best, not crowded at all! Our guide book indicated that the park was open 24H, turns out that the closing time was 17.00, on a Friday, so didn't get to stroll to all corners of this green heaven. But can only highly recommend, if time is short. Ueno park is an alternative for cherry blossoms watching, but far more crowded, hustle and bustle.
Best sakura picture. Beautiful photos to be taken at this sakura park. My favourite spot is by the bridge on the lake.A small entrance fee to be paid but absolutely worth it.

Beautiful landscape. My favorite spot inside of the Shinjuku Gyoen was the japanese garden with the traditional tea house in the middle of a lake. Also there is a ticket in order to get in this National Garden

Beautiful and serene. Visited the park on a sunny day in March. The blossom was just coming out, can imagine it would be stunning in April. Was a very calming and picturesque interval in an otherwise hectic sightseeing day
A beautiful garden even during winter. The entrance fee of 200¥ is truly worth it the place is beautiful, you have lots of different birds to watch, ao visit

GREAT PART OF TOKYO. Went to visit in the month of June and the Formal French Garden is open and the flowers are in full bloom. Beautiful! Expansive park and excellent if you like taking long walks in a beautiful garden..

Expansive Park which is stunning in Spring and Autumn. I have now visited Shinjuku Gyoen twice- once in Spring during cherry blossom season and the second time during autumn. This park is very expansive and excellent for a stroll and is incredibly peaceful considering it is locating in the centre of Tokyo! It has large open grassed areas, Japanese styled sections with ponds and bridges, formal English and French Gardens and a greenhouse. For me the highlight is the pond with the lovely old Japanese teahouse overlooking it. This area is particularly stunning at cherry blossom time as there are some lovely cherry blossom trees that frame the lovely Japanese building beautifully for photo purposes! It is not uncommon to see bridal couples in their lovely traditional bridal dress having photos taken at this park. There is also another lovely bridge area right next to some cherry blossom trees which makes for more stunning photos during cherry blossom time. If you wander around the whole park you will also encounter a less formal part of the garden with small ponds and creeks and a lot of wildlife. This area was beautiful in autumn.In autumn, the range of colours is also fabulous especially the maple trees. Near the formal french and english gardens, the bed of fallen autumn leaves was almost knee deep!The park is easy to access from Shinjuku station and entry fee is 300 yen. Drink machines and toilets are available as well as a tearoom but limited food options are available so i would suggest bringing food like a bento box for a picnic if you are there are lunchtime.

Great Place for Hanami. This was the park at which we first experienced the wonderful Japanese tradition of viewing Cherry Blossoms. This was a great park at which to do this. The cherry trees were plentiful and the park was alive with the lovely pink color of the blossoms. This time of the year in Japan is an experience that everyone should have.

Extensive, relaxing park with themed gardens. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden has a modest admission fee payable at vending machines beside each entrance. This is actually an extensive park with an interesting and attractive tropical greenhouse, and English, French and Japanese themed gardens. It is a lovely expanse of green space -- a place to relax within urban Tokyo.

Serenity in the middle of chaos. We had a brilliant local guide who took us to the gardens and showed us how to perform the cleansing rituals etc which was ideal. There was a wedding taking place which was very traditional and a real treat for us. Would have liked to have spent more time here, just thinking about the garden makes me calm.

Great Garden. I went here in January, and even though it was winter, the Shinjuku Gyoen was still very nice. Its only ¥200 to get in, which is great. The Gyoen was very quiet, well maintained, and very clean. Like I said earlier, it's nice in the winter, but I just wish I could of seen it in the fall.

Very nice summer break from the city. Beautiful place in the summer. Lots of people just out for a picnic or some family time. Excellent place to bring the kids for a break to run around. Snack hut in the middle a little expensive, but still a nice stop. If you walk around the whole thing, it's a ways. Took around 3 hours at a leisurely pace with two 6 year olds

Beautiful. yes you have to pay to get in but it's only 200 yen, AND that include the entry to a brand new beautiful tropical botanic garden. Lovely when you're too cold to walk ages in the garden as it's hot and moist in there!

Nice garden, just don't go during winter time. Went there during winter. The garden was well kept but since it was winter time everything was quite barren.Bought myself a bento set from Isetan food departement and had a picnic on a grassy hilly area. I can definitely imagine it being more beautiful in summer or autumn. Otherwise, felt a bit regret paying 200 yen. Just skip this garden if going on winter and head to other "free" garden

Time out in Tokyo. The garden is the perfect place to start your day with an early morning stroll. There is an entry fee of approx .¥200. It is worth going to see the traditional Japanese garden but If you only have time for one garden/park, I believe Yoyogi Park in Shibuya is nicer.

Tranquil gardens and tea ceremony. Entry into the gardens is ¥200 for adults and ¥50 for a child. We enjoyed wandering around although as it was winter, everything was brown. You can still get a feel for the gardens and they must be lovely in spring. We did the traditional tea ceremony in one of the tea houses(close at 4.30pm) and this was ¥700. It was an experience, although the tea and cake were not to our liking as they are so different.

A perfect place on a sunny day. We went here a sunny January day. The golden grass was beautiful and the birds were singing in the trees. The gardens (some large and very cool and some small and so pretty) are very nice and the place is so peaceful. We were lying on the grass for an hour or so, and then we walked around. I wish we had brought some picnic.

A lovely formal garden. The Shinjuku Gyoen is perhaps the best garden in Tokyo, apart from the Imperial Garden itself. Well laid out and immaculate (even in winter), this is a place to get away from the hectic Tokyo hustle and bustle and reflect for an hour or two.

Loved it!!! So calm, relaxing and beautiful. Beautifully kept gardens, huge, and a token contribution to enter.
We spent time in the traditional Japanese garden seeing the koi, and also the English gardens. There is also a number of large grassy areas to picnic on.

BEAUTIFUL . This place is amazing. Gorgeous gardens and the green house was just breathtaking. Definitely not to be missed. Go in the morning for a nice relaxing stroll through the park. Don't forget your camera.

really lovely park. just relax and escape tokyo. walk around for an hour or two. very relaxing. everything looked clean, big grass field to relax and eat something. so big you won't bother anyone (i was there on a saterday) i think cherry blossom season will be very very very crouded
Great spot for leaf viewing. Visited in the fall when leaves were changing color. Absolutely beautiful! A great place to stroll, find colorful trees, and take pictures.

Calmness in Jungle City. Calmness and peacefulness imbedded in an unlikely highly densely populated prefecture. When the cherry trees are blooming then prep a picnic basket sit and be mindful of, i felt, old Japan. If you like city life treat yourself to a moment of tranquility before you return to it and lose your mind in both.

Breathtaking. This is probably the best park we have visited in Tokyo. The admission is not free, but the fee is a small amount compared to what you can see inside the park. The place is huge and is conveniently arranged depending on the types of gardens. The park is especially beautiful in spring, when the cherry blossoms are in bloom. You can spend hours just strolling around, taking photos, and sitting on park benches. You'd totally forget that you're in the middle of a bustling city, full of restaurants, shops, and crowds of people. It's like a silent sanctuary in Shinjuku.It's also an ideal place for cherry blossom spotting. They have lots of varieties of cherry trees here, some bloom earlier and some later than others, so it's possible to see some cherry blossoms even after the cherry blossom season. This is a must-visit when touring Tokyo.

Just beautiful.. Visited the garden on my 5-day trip to Tokyo early December 2013. The autumn colours were breathtaking, and I must say that it was one of my favourite parts of our trip. The admission fee was minimal and justified, we spent hours here -- taking photos, having a picnic, just strolling and enjoying the beauty.

Oasis in Shinjuku. My daily runs skirt pass this park during my short stay in Tokyo. On my last run, I decided to go into the park, and I was so glad I did. Could spend a couple of hours here. Beautiful fall foliage was a bonus!
Τέλεια Περιοχή. A beautiful park with great organization and a great city great detail the case for photography enthusiasts recommend it to anyone visiting the area

Sublime at any time of year. Last time I was in the National Garden, it was cherry blossom time, and what a show it was! Photographers everywhere angling for the best shot, locals and tourists alike enjoying the beauty of the new flowering season. This time, it was winter and the stark beauty revealed another side of this natural wonder: many aspects of the planning and layout are breath-taking. Be sure to visit the Greenhouse: it is an awesome collection, in the true sense of that word.The Garden is so restful and so distinctive that it is an unmissable component of any visit to Tokyo.

Serenity in a park. A beautiful park next to the city. It's about half a mile walk from all the major shops and malls. It's a great place to see the beautiful lakes, fields, trees, and do not forget to visit the awesome greenhouse.
perfect spot for a walk and an escape frothy hussle and bustle. amazing traditional park.. perfectly maintained and manicured gardens. plus a great running/walking track.

Beautiful Autumn Colours. I loved it here - I managed to find it on my own, walking from Shinjuku Station (I think it took me longer than it should, I followed road signs instead of maps!).I arrived with only an hour left to walk around the park, which was a real shame because I missed the Greenhouse and the tea traditions. I'd have loved to have dedicated a few hours to this parks, even in Autumn.I can appreciate that I was seeing the park at its worse - it was cold and there was no blossom, no green grass. It was beautiful though. There were trees that had beautiful colours on their leaves and lovely places to sit and watch the koi in the water. A great place to go to take photos, to sit and watch the world go by, perhaps not so much a place to adventurers looking for lots to do.I went around the park on my own and felt completely safe and content, but there were a number of lovely old couples sitting around the park, which was lovely. There was a fee to enter 200 yen - but all things considered, this relatively low fee was worth while.

Nice but not great. I loved that there were different sections like the traditional Japanese garden and the English garden. We went in winter however and so the formal garden was a bit of a let down. It was very nice considering the time of year but I preferred Hiroshima's shukkeien garden to this one

Beautiful anytime of the year. Do you need to take a breath and relax in a beautiful and peaceful place? If so, this is the place to go. Get there first thing in the morning for great photographs around every corner.
Amazing colours!. This park was particularly beautiful when we went! The autumn colours were absolutely amazing. Worth a visit.We went on 30th November.

Lovely and beautiful. Very lovely and beautiful garden! Actually you need to pass a path leading to the main entranceof the garden, and the best to visit this garden is in autumn when all the leaves are yellow and it extremely amazing!

Breath taking view everywhere. The place cant be missed in Tokyo and no matter what time you visit this place, it has something to offer I visited it during the Chrysanthemum display and felt really fortunate to visit it at that particular time. The whole place is spectacular and eye catching and the whole place is usually crowded with natives who seems to be enjoying the view and good strolls around the place and no doubt this place is the best place to enjoy good photography.

stunning in autumn. We happened to be there when the fall colors were on and the beauty of this park just takes your breath away. The variety of trees and plants, their composition plus lakes and points makes you realize that you begin to feel the need just sit, just look, just relax, just enjoy...yes, and atmosphere is extremely pleasant. we were amazed how few tourists we met - mostly locals, families. Very nice!
Beautiful!. Beautiful garden!Actually before you enter it there is a path leading to the main entrance, and since we went in autumn all the leaves were yellow and it was amazing!

Beautiful Garden. This is a must see IMHO. This garden is so peaceful and a wonderful place to see folks enjoying a lovely day. Visit on a weekend if you can, its a bit crowded but a great chance to see Tokyo residents enjoying life. The garden hot house is wonderful. It is very easy to access from the subway. We visited in November toward the end of the Chrysanthemum display. I can only imagine this place in spring and summer.
Amazing place. Amazingly beautiful park, a must visit when you're in Tokyo, Beautiful not only in its sites but also in sounds. Listen to it - it's alive!

Gorgeous stroll. A very romantic stroll for couples.Lots of picture moments and to enjoy the autumn view. November weather is such a comfortable and pleasant time to walk outdoor. Do come early to avoid the crowd.

Pleasant, large urban park. If you want a respite from the urban jungle of crowded buildings, especially in Shinjuku, this is the place to go. It's a 5-10 minute walk from Shinjuku station, but there are other subway stations that are a little closer to the entrance to the park. Note that the park does have a 200 yen entrance fee - and the park hours are a bit restrictive. It closes around 4:30 PM (1630) and the entrance into the park closes 30 minutes earlier. The greenhouse also closes earlier - I recall it was either 3:30 PM (1530) or 4:00 PM (1600), so you have to plan accordingly. It is also quite a big park so you'll need some time, around at least two hours, to have adequate time to traverse the park.One of the nice things about the park is the large number of families. During my trip in Tokyo, I didn't see too many families congregated in places other than a park like this, so you can do a little bit of people watching here as well. Unfortunately, I didn't get to go into the greenhouse so I do not know how it is. The park grounds were nicely kept - what do you expect from a Japanese garden/park? The Japanese traditional garden was serene and picturesque. The French formal garden seemed a little dull, but perhaps it was late fall. The ponds that dotted the park were especially beautiful. Of particular note were the chrysanthemum displays all around the park. Many were spectacular and beautiful.There are probably more memorable sights in Tokyo, but if you have time to visit this park, then I would highly recommend it.
