Nature Jungle in Concrete Jungle. When time allowed us to do so, worth to go for and nature view, enjoying the calming with fresh air from concrete jungle. Variety flower and plant in the garden.Try spend a time sit down to feels it. I had sat down in the middle with my love one, and took many photo there after Shinjuku Ginkgo Avenue, which is just 10 mins walk away from the Garden.In autumn, there is good place for leaf collectors, photographers, and always for couple.

Quality family time. Spent the last morning of my stay in Tokyo, and after plenty of walking at theme parks, shopping and climbing stairs of the metro, was quite happy to see the nature again.My wife snapped plenty of photos of the autumn colors. My daughter loved the ponds and the duck. The vast open space with the city as a backdrop is a great view indeed. There is no rush, no dust and noise from the traffic.Food and drinks at the stalls a bit limited.

One of the most beautiful parks. We didn't expect the garden to be so beautiful - especially with all the fall colours. (By contrast, we found the Imperial Palace East Gardens less beautiful). It's well tended and the weather made it absolutely enjoyable to spend some hours there. Thankfully, it wasn't that crowded (a weekday) so a morning here in this oasis of peace served to balance the busy shopping buzz at Shinjuku Station.There are drinking water fountains so no worries about thirst. Toilets too. Anyway, I highly recommend a visit here. You won't regret it.

AWESOME!!. It's really big and beautiful park... We really enjoyed our time here! If you are visiting Tokyo you must go there if at least just for a walk.. And it's really close to Shinjuku station :-)

A fantastic park. With a small cost of ¥200 for adults and ¥50 for children, the park exceeds expectations. One can spend hours strolling around the gardens with views of well-pruned trees and clear lakes with a city backdrop. Towards late autumn and early winter, the leaves are adorned with magnificent colours of red, yellow and orange, creating a picturesque view

A nice oasis in busy Shinjuku. I didn't discover Shinjuku Gyoen until my third stay in Shinjuku and I wish I would have known earlier. It's peaceful and beautiful. We walked through on a Sunday and there were many Japanese families enjoying the weekend outside. The park is large enough so you can find a bench and sit and watch people or read a book, find a nice picnic spot and throw a blanket down or just explore a more wooded area to meditate. It's very diverse in the way it's designed to give you the feel that there's something new area each turn. Yes, it's costs to enter, but it was well worth it. Don't forget to visit the greenhouse!

A must!. It will cost you 2,000 yen to get in (roughly $2.00), but the experience is worth a lot more. The Japanese gardens are a gem. You won't believe you're in the middle of a 41.5 million people. Spend a half day there to get away from the busy-ness of Shinjuku!

Well worth a visit..... A great place for a leisurely stroll around the various themed gardens - French, English and Japanese gardens. In late November, the autumn colours of the trees provide a kaleidoscope of colour that's popular with everyone, especially photographers who are out in force! Despite its popularity, it's large enough to still be a haven of serenity in the middle of Shinjuku. The Chrysanthemum flower exhibition is quite amazing. For JPY 200 it's a bargain. Recommended.

Simply beautiful if you pick the right time of year. This is a very large, well designed and maintained park in the heart of Shinjuku. It features a French as well as Japanese garden with several lakes. I was there on a cold Sunday afternoon as the colours were still changing for many trees. I think every amateur photographer in Tokyo had the same idea. The place was packed but still quiet and civilized. There was so much to see and the beauty of the place in the middle of a city like Tokyo was really something. That said, the place while pretty, would not be near as good without the colour I saw today.Make sure you get a shot across the lake with the reflection of the DoCoMo Tower as it looks like a modern version of one of Stalin's 7 sisters in Moscow!
Loved it. Amazing!!! great place !beautiful we just love it! you will need to pay to get your ticket but it worth it
Beautiful park. Great break from the city. Beautiful fall colors with great photo op. The Japanese garden was our favorite. Would definitely recommend.
Best for Families with Kids. The garden was ok. I went with my wife and the walk was nice, but I think it's best for families with kids. There is a large field for picnic and kids to run around.

In harmony with nature. Entrance fee is 200¥. But worth the visit. Check the weather/ season update for what to expect in certain months of the year.Also, take a free map at the entrance so that you are aware of how to navigate inside this huge park.Best to come is indeed when it has cherry blossoms in March and autumn leaves in November . You may bring food in or just buy some from the vending machine but make sure you clean after yourself. Recycle and throw away the leftovers in a combustible disposal bin near the exit.

A beautiful Garden. If you are tired by seeing the skyscraper in Tokyo and want to go to a peaceful place. It is none other than in the middle of the city "Shinjuku Gyoen National Park". Good place to spend time and speciailly for those who loves to do the photography. The entry fee is quite low. A good place to spend time with family.

Well worth the time. The chrysanthemums were the highlight of the garden at this time of the year. I would love to visit this garden during every season of the year to experience the calmness and refreshing of a stroll in such great green space. This is truly an exemplary national garden.
beautiful autumn colors. At the base of the Tokyo metropolitan government building, lots of people, babies and dogs, great community Park.

Low cost, very pretty, worth a short stroll. We came here on a rainy cool day so it wasn't the most beautiful way to see it but we're still glad we came by. The cost is low, but then again there's not a whole lot here. It was a nice stroll, I think we spent about an hour or maybe slightly more. We just wandered around along the various paths, went into the greenhouse, stopped by the tea house and generally just stepped out of the craziness that is Tokyo, and especially Shinjuku, for a little bit of calm.

Particularly nice in Spring and Autumn (but good in anytime of the year). On a fine day, if you have a couple of hours to spend for a quiet walk under the trees, through gardens, to sit or lie down on grass, or see tropical flowers in the glasshouse, do visit this place. Shinjuku Gyoen is particularly nice in Spring with different kinds of cherry trees and in Autumn with gingko and maple trees. The large gingko tree in front of the glasshouse was marvelously brightly yellow when I visited in late November 2013, a sight to remember. Shinjuku Gyoen started as a property of the Naito clan trusted by the Tokugawa Shogunate, then became an Imperial Garden, before it was donated to the city.In contrast to Yoyogi Park or Ueno Park (which is always open), this is an enclosed garden (which takes 200 yen for upkeeping). Taking food and drinks in is fine (and quite recommended), but no alcohol. No soundsystem to dance to. No pet entry or frisby/kites either here. Which is in fact good, because the lawns are maintained like carpets and when you lie down and close your eyes for a nap, you only hear the birds singing and kids playing about.Stroller friendly.Shinjuku Gyoen, and Rikugien (near JR Komagome Station on Yamanote Line), are gardens worth visiting, and paying a couple of coins for upkeeping, with thanks.The nearest access are provided by JR Sendagaya station (Chuo/Sobu Local Line), and Tokyo Metro Shinjuku Gyoen station (Marunouchi Line).

Tranquil and beautiful surroundings. My husband and I loved walking through Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. The fact that they have a traditional Japanese garden, a Frensh rose garden, diverse greenhouse and so many place so sit and just be in peace and enjoy was a welcome calm to a hectic and incredibly large city. It may be out of the way depending on where you are staying but partnering it with the Meiji Temple is a great 3-4hr trip and well worth it. Shibuya is also not that far away and it is a must see area so full of energy and the opposite of the tranquility you will feel at the garden. I highly recommend it for all ages!!

Gorgeous gardens in the heart of Tokyo. Gorgeous garden-leaves were starting to change when we were there and the garden is so meticulously cared for despite it's huge size! Great place to enjoy some scenery away from the hustle and bustle of a big city. Park opens at 9am and admission is 300 yen.
oasis. Its huge - & so easy to get lost after the rush of the maddening Shinjuku - like an oasis - its beautiful

City refuge. We walked the park on a cool windy day and didn't even notice. The kids loved it (4 and 6 yrs) and we just relaxed and enjoyed every moment in the park. We were surprised that there were several trees in bloom as it was early November but it was a nice perk. The Chrysanthemum Festival was interesting, the kids really enjoyed the displays. I'd also suggest a walk through the greenhouse, beautiful presentation and again, the kids loved it.

Kind of Oasis in Concret Dessert. The weather was perfect and so was the garden. The trees were beautiful and the air was so clean. I was so so relaxed. I spent 4-5 hrs in afternoon in this beautiful garden. If you are visiting Tokyo and pls do visit this park

Beautiful!!. This park was very very beautiful and surprisingly big. People had picnics and there were ponds and buildings and it was very well kept. No litter and butterflies were flying around. Very impressive.

A Must See in Tokyo!. Don't miss walking through the gardens while you're in Tokyo. A very peaceful park in the middle of a busy city. It has several sections for Oriental and Continental gardens, and a number of places with park benches to stop and absorb the views. We were there during the Chrysanthemum Festival, which is something you shouldn't miss each year.

A Great Escape. Exploring the gardens in the hour before closing time was magical. We knew we had enough time to walk to most of the major attractions and enjoy in the afternoon light. It is a magical place and easy to feel completely isolated from the city (except for a few high rise building on the horizon). The entry fee is completely worthwhile. The gardens offer many options and can be engaged in a variety of different ways. Following the route around the lakes/ponds allows you to interact with many of the gardens highlights.

Beautiful in sun (and rain). Visited twice - once in the sun and again in the rain. Lovely gardens with the Chrysanthemum exhibition on at the beginning of November. Inspiring if you want to created your own Japanese Garden.

CLOSED ON MONDAYS. We really wanted to visit this park and went to Shinjuku especially to visit it. But it was Closed! Whoever heard of a park being closed on a Monday?!! (while we're at it..whoever heard of a park charging an entrance fee?!) We were not the only ones to go there in vain - as during the 10 minutes we stood outside the gates, there were 4 other parties who showed up and left in amazement and disappointment. And to top it off..this was the only sunny, dry day in the week!

One of my two favourite gardens in Tokyo. The garden is in the middle of Shinjuku, 5 minutes by foot away from Shinjuku Station. Entry fee was 200 yen.The garden has many nice spots of different styles (e.g. English garden, Japanese garden, big trees) and a huge, impressive greenhouse, with it's own waterfall (entry fee included in the 200yen).Just look at the pics and decide yourself, if you want to visit or not!(PS: My other favourite garden in Tokyo is the Hamarikyu Garden.)

A huge, clean and peaceful Park. I think the park would be great if it's a cherry blossom season. We visited the park on mid October after reading so many good reviews on TripAdvisor. Another reason was due to most shops/attraction would not be open until after 10am, so a morning stroll in a park I thought would be very ideal before visiting the nearby attractions.Depends on what are you looking for.. if you wish to see a peaceful huge park or an escape from the busy city then this is something for you. However, Tokyo is not a right choice if this is what you looking for in your trip. Sorry but I think this is over-rated for me (IMHO). Don't come here just for the park. Do it only if you are an early riser.

Beautiful beyond description. The main purpose of our visit to Japan in May, was to see the cherry blossoms in full bloom but we were two weeks too late. However, thanks to the personnel at JTB, who recommended us to visit Gyoen National Garden, we managed to see the pink and white cherry blossoms, although at the end of their blossoming period, was still something to be admired. We were so enthralled by the beautifully landscaped and well maintained garden, and busily taking photos, of the myriads of flowers of different species, e.g various colours of tulips, poppies, roses etc. that we did not even notice that the weather was turning pretty chilly, until we felt our fingers getting numb. Apart from the flowers, there was a tranquil lake with lots of trees and flowers surrounding it. Took a photo of this and it now acts as my telephone wallpaper, a memento of my day at the Shinjuku Gyoen National Park. It was definitely worth the 200 Yen entrance fee.One could easily spend the whole day there just walking and appreciating the natural scenery in all its splendour and get away from the "hustle and bustle" of city life. One great aspect of the park is that, not only is it open to people but also to our "four legged" friends . I just loved watching all the cute little dogs, some in their best finery, trotting happily alongside their owners. Photos do not do justice to the park. We were fortunate to have visited the park at the right time and in my opinion, it was beautiful beyond description.

A place to enjoy the serenity of a large city. We were in the park while they had a flower display open. The traditional Japanese Garden was excellent. The whole park was immaculately maintained including all the facilities (plenty). You could meander all day in here. It was a stark contrast to be in the park and look up to a skyline of skyscrapers in the background. The Koi fish in the lakes are huge. A visit here is a must to contrast the hustle and bustle of the city areas.

Really enjoyed-pleasant surprise. Definitely worth planning to spend some time in this beautiful garden. A break from exploring the city streets, though there's lots of walking involved as the park is quite large and will take time to walk all of it, if you choose. The park is clean and well maintained, worth the 200 Yen entry fee. Lot's of different trees. Visited on a hot summer day, I like the heat, but some people may be uncomfortable to walk that much in the summer heat. Liked seeing some Tokyo skyscrapers rise above the trees, they seem so close. I'm writing this review because a friend of mine who frequents Tokyo said he has never heard of this place.

Perfect for spring!. We had the chance to catch the blooming of the cherry blossoms (sakura). It was a wonderful chance to see and view the blossoms up close. The park closes at 3 pm, it is suggested to plan to visit early to have plenty of time to explore the park.

Well-preserved and maintained park. This garden is huge! You can easily get lost. I have to give it to the Japanese in terms of their commitment and discipline. Tokyo is densely populated and land is scarce but when it comes to parks and garden - they had the discipline to keep it pristine and "untouched" by commercial development. If it had been in any other country, this garden/park would have been turned into a commercial district to generate income. The place is so beautiful and the contrast is stark. There are spots were its like you are in a forest, as in Lord-of-the-Rings-forest, with hundred-year old trees, with very dense and damp vegetation (actually gave me the creeps that we never passed through it again on our way back) then there are the very Zen Japanese gardens. In some parts of the garden, you have this very serene pond against skyscrapers. Picture-perfect. This place is great for family bonding and just chilling out. Not to be missed.

Peaceful. A nice getaway located in the city. Very peaceful and enjoyable getting out of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Alot of people doing paintings of the scenery which was very enjoyable to watch. If you look closely at all the lakes there are many terrapins which live there. They even come up to you and try get food from you.
Nice Park. Good location and beautiful park. Nice to go to the park and kick back and relax with friends. Tired of the masses, take a walk to the park and enjoy the view.
Nice garden. It's a lovely large garden in which you can wander around or just sit down and enjoy the views. If you're in the heart of the garden you'll almost forget you're in busy Tokyo.

Open space in the city.. After strolling Shibuya and Shinjuku during rush hour the night before, the quiet beauty of the garden was lovely. Bring a picnic and relax. Or go have some tea and snacks at the teahouse.I was hoping to be there for the autumn leaves, but they had not changed yet- should be 1-2nd week on November. There are countless varieties of maples so it will be an awesome site.
Beautiful park. Very nice park just in the middle of the city.. Try to go there on a sunny day and make picnic in the green grass. Its very a peacefull place..

Beautiful park in the city. We enjoyed this park very much after we visited Shinjuku (where we also bought a picnic). It was nice to eat our lunch in the park, to relax and take a nap on the grass. Then we walked around to discover the beautiful gardens. A real nice place to spend a couple of hours.
Peacful and relaxing. Take your time to unwind and relax in the park. Lovely gardens to walk around and admire. Within walking distance from Shinjulku hotels

Fantastic park in Central Tokyo. Possibly my favourite park in Central Tokyo for cherry blossom viewing, crowds permitting. Also November is a very good period to visit and see the vivid colours of autumn leaves. There are a very nice Japanese garden, Western style gardens, many paths, and huge picnic areas, all very well maintained. You must pay to get in, however the fee is really cheap. Bring your own food & drinks, get in, and just enjoy the park. This place is ideal for family outings and in general for anyone wanting to spend a relaxing day away from the noisy city without actually getting out of the city. Thumbs up.

Peaceful environment. I enjoyed going to the Gyoen Garden. It is peaceful and beautiful. It let you appreciated the nature we live in. The garden is prefect for family picnic and running. There is a fees to get inside, but it is only 200 yens. It is perfect place to visit, if you want to relax.

An oasis in bustling Shinjuku. Right in the middle of busy but wonderfully tidy and charming Shinjuku, this garden is ideal for a short stroll to see how the Japanese enjoy nature and to appreciate a lovely traditional Japanese garden, plus English and French gardens. Historically an experimental farm and a botanical garden, a great choice to relax after shopping and eating. Do not miss the superb greenhouse of tropical plants in a lovely modern building.

Stunning gardens in the heart of Tokyo. I enjoyed visiting these gardens immensely. They are beautiful- conveniently located in the heart of vibrant Shinjuku and by the look of it this is an incredibly popular picnic spots for the locals. Entry is not free but cheap- 200 yens at time of writing. Worth it.

Nice stroll in a Japanese park. We went here with my husband and my friend and her 3 year old daughter. Because it was a holiday there was no fee for us to enter but typically there is some small fee. The azaleas were in bloom at the time we went so those were nice to see. My friend's daughter enjoyed feeding the giant koi fish in the pond. It was near our hotel so it was easy to get to. (We stayed at the Park Hyatt).
Beauty of perfection. It’s very peaceful and beautiful. Every details in this garden is so perfect in zing-zang rules (I’ve learn some before). I think it’s a must in Tokyo. Very nice.

Beautiful gardens but closes early. Our party of three walked around all day in Tokyo and decided to take a nice break during the afternoon. It was 4'clock PM and they warned us that the park closed at 4:30pm. We paid and went in anyway so we had to rush from sight to sight. Too bad that they closed that early since the sunset pictures would have been beautiful. At the end we almost had to be chased down by a security guard so by 5pm we were back on our way to the traffic and congestion. A nice break and worth the small price.
Beautiful and quiet oasis. Great for morning stroll. It closes early evening. Beautifully landscaped and huge. It's worth 200 yet, for sure. The pond is full of koi fish.

Stunning gardens, especially for cherry blossoms. Shinjuku Gyoen Garden is the most beautiful garden in Tokyo. It is breathtaking, especially when the cherry blossoms are in bloom. Grab some food at the nearby depachika at Takashimaya and have a lovely picnic or have some green tea at one of their little tea houses. You can get a plastic table cloth that works find on the ground for JPY 200. Picnics are best during cherry blossom season. But, even outside of that season, the garden is lovely.

a very beautiful garden complex. A really peaceful spot in the middle of the city. It is 200 yen the entrance fee.Lovely park to relax in. The trees, leaves and the cherry is as attractive. In my opinion, picnic and napping here is very nice.The greenhouse was still under renovation. Gorgeous views of the skyline and a wonderful promenade. Good place to do some photographyHighly recommended if you get couples of hours free and want to relax!

Beautiful for cherry blossoms!. Our two young kids had a great time running through the cherry trees while the petals were just starting to fall. It was beautiful and much larger than I expected. The greenhouse is very well done too, it even had waterfalls. We easily could've spent 2 or more hours here just taking pictures and wandering around. If your kids are picky, I would recommend bringing some snacks with you. The option were limited inside.
A lovely garden walk.. A gem of a garden, the tea rooms are enchanting.Take a look at the French and English areas of the gardens.

a must see. Time spent wandering these wonderful gardens will not be wasted... amazing Japanese garden... cherry blossom time in March is the highlight but worth seeing all year round... sprawling English style lawn that you can actually sit on and a French rose garden if you are lucky enough to see the roses in bloom... don'T miss the Imperial comfort station... very Japanese insight into how the Emperor may have gone about his ablutions on a visit to the gardens...
Breathtaking and romantic place. They close the park at 5 p.m... So go there with time because it's huge. There's a lot of different types of "Sakuras."
Nothing special. It is a beautiful park but nothing special. Maybe not so attractive in the summer, not so big either. We had a nice time walking around though.

Trees and grass. I went in early august, weather was quite hot and not particularly pleasant to be standing around in the gardens under the sun. Overall it's a very nice looking garden in summer, but visitors should definitely come in the spring or fall for better weather and more interesting things to see. Quite a significant bit of walking required within the compound to see all that it offers as the garden is quite huge. I wouldn't fully recommend it for those not into nature watching.

Peaceful place right in the city centre. Shinjuku Park is a great place to take a walk when you need to slow down in Tokyo. During my visit it was quiet and peaceful. You can spend there half an hour or half a day. It has some great views of skyscrapers and photo opportinities. It may remind you a little bit of Central Park in New York.

Romantic and tranquile setting for relaxing time in the madness of Shinjuku. This garden will always hold good memories for me as my boyfriend proposed to me here! That being said its a nice place to get some peace and quiet, take in the natural sights and just get 30 minutes rest from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. I've been to a few gardens throughout Tokyo, but this one is definitely my favourite. Its enjoyable to observe Japanese people painting watercolours, taking photos and just enjoying the scenery.
Beautiful introduction to Tokyo. We visited this garden on our first full day in Japan and it was just beautiful. Such an oasis in the big city. Well worth a visit if in the Shinjuku area.

Amazing. Such a wonderfully designed park with a beautiful mix of traditional Japanese and European gardens. It was amazing to see the high rise buildings of Tokyo bursting out above the tree tops of the gardens. The healthy mix of modern civilisation with nature.

So beautiful. I always feel a bit resentful of when I have to pay money to go to a park, but the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden remains the stand out memory of my trip to Tokyo. It was beautiful. We were lucky enough to be there when the cherry blossoms were in full bloom (apologies, I am writing this review a few months after we visited) and the were amazing. Added to this, walking along the little ponds and lakes and seeing the wooden bridges across the water was so peaceful. I especially loved the areas of the garden where the skyscrapers peeked over the trees, because it just made it more amazing that you could have this oasis of nature amongst the bustling city. Highly recommended.

fantasctically peaceful place in the center of the city. A huge territory with lot of greenery and flowers. In the French garden you will see many kinds of roses. You can take some coverlet to take a rest there or buy it in the garden (300 yen). You can go barefoot because it is really clean, no garbage, no dirt. It is better that Gorky park in Moscow :) In the heart of the city you suddenly forget about where you are and relax.

A stroll around the botancial gardens, a green oasis. Enoyed walking around this rather large park while waiting for room to be ready in the nearby Shinjuku 3-chome area. Beautiful, massive trees adding some much needed shade in the super hot Aug Tokyo weather! Formerly named Imperial Botanical Gardens.

Beautiful, quiet, well maintained park. These gardens were terrific when we visited in April, the flowers were out, people wandered thoughtfully, an amazing indoor tropical garden too and a perfect way to get away from the busy area so close by. Definately recommend a trip here for an hour or two if you are in the area.

A nice place to see sakura. Although it is already end of sakura but we still can saw the late bloomer type of sakura which was lovely. It was nice to stroll in the garden considering busy city of Tokyo.

A relaxing oasis of green in the middle of bustling Tokyo. Just a few blocks from our hotel is this amazing park that is filled with interesting flora, nature trails, expansive, open grassy fields, a lovely Japanese lake, a large greenhouse for tropical plant species, a French-style garden, and even a little teahouse for some green tea sipping. When you need a break from congested city life, this is the perfect, tranquil respite. Great for picnics too.

Pretty, boring; pretty boring. Fascinating for botany fans, and a pretty, quiet place in the middle of Shinjuku, but with a ban on sports and other accessories (for lack of a better term), and a ¥‎200 entry fee, it's something worth looking at once, then moving on. (Perhaps I'm a bit bitter that I lived next to it for a year, and had to take my juggling clubs to Yoyogi Park).

Lovely peaceful place in this busy part of the city. This was just lovely and for a mere 200yen each. There are many different gardens within this park. There is also a Japanese Tea House where you can experience the tea ceremony - we didn't have time unfortunately. The greenhouse is spectacular and very modern.
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful quiet spot in the middle of the city - hard to believe it is so quiet. Was jet lagged and roasting when there but, nonetheless, still appreciated it!
Excellent Japanese, French and English gardens at one place. This is one of the best and quiet gardens in Tokyo. Has easy access and an excellent place to visit for an hour or two..
Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden. Great park for a change of pace from the city with a lovely glass house and tea shops. There is a charge to get in but it is peanuts

Peaceful oasis in Shinjuku. Beautiful garden for a tryst with nature in bustling Shinjuku. Especially worthwhile are the cherry blossom viewing and the autumn foliage. A stroll through this lovely garden soothes the soul and is a good break to experience the way Japanese juxtaposed daily life with touches of tranquility and peace.

Amazing value not to be missed. For 200 yen, this garden is an amazing find in the middle of the bustling city. The outside looks nondescript, but as you can see from posted photos, it had hidden beauty within. Around each quarter is a photo moment so you can take the memories with you. Its ponds and bridges are enchanting and the large expanses of lawn provide plenty of space to sit or lie down. There are hundreds of little areas to sit and contemplate or eat a picnic lunch. The greenhouse housed many many beautiful varieties and a wonderful design of water lilies. I would return to this park daily if I lived here. Plenty of resting places and bathrooms provide opportunity to stop and rest. The only downside includes the 16 mosquito bites I acquired when we sat down on a bench near the entrance (although I didn't notice mosquitoes in the park itself).

A tranquil oasis. This is a wonderful oasis to provide one with a break from the intensity of Tokyo. Stroll through the gardens, enjoy a picnic or a refreshing drink, soothe the body from the heat - a perfect interlude in the middle of the day.

Great place in hectic Tokyo. Entrance is 200 Yen. Very nice park, good for a walk, also great to just sit, look at other people or have lunch (small supermarkets 5 min away from the main entrance). Watch out for (big) ants, take a picnic cloth and have fun. Clean toilets, clean park (take your trash with you to the exit).

Beautiful. Great space for a wander, yes you need to pay an entry fee but it is only a small amount and the garden are beautiful so it is worth it. Lots of seating and lovely green grass to rest on, wish we had a bit more time to explore.
Must see. Absolutely gorgeous gardens. bring a blanket and have a picnic! pick up English map at the entrance. don't miss the view from Thai pavilion.
Great place to wander around.. You have to pay to enter this park but worth every penny. Beautiful gardens. Plenty of seating areas to view these gardens,

Very nice place to enjoy nature and serenity. Shinjuku Gyoen National Park has many different types of gardens. The flowers are beautiful. Make sure you visit the green house while you are there. It does cost 200 yen to enter the park. Patrons are not permitted to play sports. However, we saw many people drawing, painting, and taking pictures. You can take a picnic and blanket and enjoy a quiet afternoon.

a beautiful city escape!!. If you want to have a quick break from the hustle and bustle of the city this is the perfect place to go. The garden is so peaceful and big enough for you to find a place at a corner to enjoy silence and of course the scenery. It's one of the most beautiful garden I’ve seen in a city setting. If you love gardens…silence…and greenery then this is a must see when in Japan. There’s a minimal entrance fee though, ¥200 but it’s totally worth it.

A centralise & beautiful garden. Located right at Shinjuku district and a short walk from the subway, I visited Shinjuku Gyoen on the last day of my stay in Tokyo. The well-planned garden with awesome landscaping made a wonderful getaway from the hectic city. There's also a greenhouse inside and it's definitely a Must-Visit for nature lovers and photography buffs. As I visited during the cherry blossom period, Shinjuku Gyoen presented a wide variety of sakura & various flora to shoot. P.S: It's lovely to picnic or grab some food & watch the world goes by!

one of the most beautiful parks we've ever seen. gorgeous park! Awesome photo opportunities. Our favorite park in Tokyo.be aware - they are closed on Mondays. And they close the gates at 4pm on the days they are open.

Beautiful - even in winter. The Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is a Tokyo must-see. We were a little disappointed upon learning an admission fee is levied (JPY 200) to enter, but the price was worth it -- even in March, when much of the greenery was dead. The cherry trees were in full bloom, and professional and amateur photographers were out in force to capture their beauty. The two-story greenhouse was a deliciously warm escape from the chill outside. If we lived in Tokyo, I could see buying an annual pass to the garden.

An oasis in the city centre. The garden is divided into 3: Japanese, English and French. We especially liked the Japanese garden, as it is very tranquil and the shapes of the trees and reflections in the water were spectacular.
Beautiful garden in the heart of Tokyo. Quiet, lovely gardens. Traditional Japanese gardens, tea room,lots of blooms. Gorgeous views of the skyline and a wonderful promenade.

Green Oase in the middle of Tokyo. All of the trees and flowers are superb maintained, a right place to enjoy the silence and fresh air in the middle of Tokyo.
It could be better if there were information about the trees and flowers
Beautiful. A really beautiful garden. The garden is peaceful and quiet and you're able to take a break from the busy city. You're bound to take lots of photos so bring along your camera!
Beautiful. An oasis in the heart of the city, disappointed that the cherry blossom trees had bloomed too early this year. Well planned gardens. Loved the greenhouse.

Lovely garden, great for photos. Nice garden. Admission Fee 200 yen. Hours 9:00-16:00.There are 3 gates to this garden, Shinjuku Gate, Okido Gate and Sendagaya Gate. The most accessible should be Shinjuku Gate. 5 min walk from Shinjuku-Gyoenmae station (Exit 1) on the Marunouchi Line, or Shinjuku-Sanchrome station (Exit E5) on the Fukutoshin Line, or Shinjuku-Sanchrome station (Exit C1 or C5) on the Toei Shinjuku Line. 10 min walk from Shinjuku Station (South Exit)You can ask for a English brochure at from the counter when you enter the garden. Tickets are bought from ticketing machines. There's basically 3 main gardens, English Landscape Garden, French Formal Garden and Japanese Traditional Garden. It will take some time to walk the garden. You can buy some food and drinks (no alcohol) into the gardens. If you feel tired after walking, you can just sit down and have a picnic on the grounds or the rest areas. The garden is really a relaxing place where people can be away from the hustle and bustle of the city. You can see families there having picnics, lying around and relaxing and just enjoying the day. It is really a place to take photos and just enjoying the views. Worth a visit.

Awesome for Cherry Blossom viewing. About 10 mins walk from Shinjuku Gyoen station. Entrance fee is only 200 yen. We thought we were into the end of cherry blossom period (as it was 10 days earlier than the prediction). However we were delighted with the bloom in Shinjuku Gyoen as there were more than 60 varieties of cherry blossom here, so some varieties were still in the peak of the bloom. We can just take about 2 hours to walk and enjoy beautiful bloom. It was a sunny day and many family were having their hanami there.

Serenity amongst the madness. We visited just after Honami and I am sure the experience during is an even grander experience than we had. Luckily we had some trees with Cherry Blossoms although nothing like the stunning views I've seen in so many pictures. The Cherry Blossoms do add an extra dimension to the Gardens, but they are still very much worth a visit. Walking around, it is difficult to think that you're in the middle of the busiest city in the world. Indeed, the gardens are nowhere near the size of say Central Park which makes it even more extraordinary. The Gardens themselves are packed with wide-open spaces and plenty of tranquil spots to escape and conduct some zen-like meditation. Take your time wandering about - the constant rush that you feel elsewhere in Tokyo is not present here. Enjoy wandering, admiring the gardens and the backdrop against the skyline of Tokyo.

Truely Charming Experincae. There exist and away from the busy streets of Tokyo a beautiful and unique garden that represents a great example of the Japanese landscaping art .. only 5 minutes away from Shinjuku Station .. we spent around 2 hours and we loved it

Beautiful quiet park in the middle of Shinjuku. You can either walk from the Shinjuku station or take the Shinjukugyoenmae subway station. the entrance is 200 Yen. its beautiful, very large. there is a vast open grass area to kick back and get away from the city for a bit. lots of gardens and nature. recommend for those seeking a quiet spot in the city.

Amazing cherry blossoms. I went to Japan for Holiday and to see the Cherry Blossoms 2nd week of april. I was so lucky to see it. It's really amazing and the weather was just perfect to take pictures though very cold. A lot of tourist went there and enjoying the place, nice for a walk and relaxation.

Beautiful!. Shinjuku Gyoen is a big beautiful park! There's quite a bit to do here, and you'll find a lot of people spending time with their families or loved ones. It's 300yen for adults, and inside you'll find a tea house (maybe two, I don't remember), a traditional japanese garden, another large building that is great to take pictures of/in, and several gorgeous views to take pictures of...a must see!
Absolute must see. This park is wonderful, and there is a great coffee shop right near the entrance so you can get your Tully's coffee, and enter into a beautiful park. Views are gorgeous

Serenity among the hustle & bustle. Perfect venue for a picnic. It costs us about 200 yen to enter and it was well worth it. You'll need about 2 hours to explore the place as it is a huge park with plenty of photo opportunities! We visited 2 weeks after the peak cherry blossom and were relieved to see that the trees were still blanketed in pink fully bloomed flowers, although it probably would have been prettier in late march. The park was not crowded at all and very pleasant. It closes early at 4 or 4.30 pm so I'd recommend that you go in the early morning or 2pm onwards. A must-see for first time visitors to tokyo! :)

Beautiful serene parklands. This is a wonderful park, you think it will be a small green space but it is quiet expansive. Make sure you check out the rose garden area and the japanese traditional gardens. A wonderful place to wander for an hour.

Peacefullgarden in the center of city. This was our favorite park/garden in the Tokyo area (and we visited many). It costs a few hundred yen to get in but was worth the cost. We visited on a July morning. The park was almost empty and we enjoyed strolling through the gardens and admiring the different types of trees, many are very old and large. The park is divided into sections with different types of gardens. We enjoyed the Japanese garden section the best. It was very tranquil. The large open field on the other end of the park reminded me of central park in NYC as you can see the other large buildings above the trees. I think because they charge admission, there are no homeless people in the park and it was very well maintained. If you have limited time in Tokyo and want to see a garden, or if you need to escape the bustling streets this is your place to be.

Great Hanami Picnic Location. Met 35+ locals and fellow travelers for a Hanami Picnic here and it was incredible. The sights and sounds were amazing and the weather was great. Warm, sunny day with a light breeze to blow the blossoms out of the trees. The ground was covered in what looked like pink snow.

Beautiful and lots to look at!. Went here on May 4 which happened to be National Greenery Day so admission was free. PROS:Lots of space and beautiful gardensEasy to get to if you are in ShinjukuNice rest stops and facilitiesLots of green and good photo opportunitiesThe only real con is that since we didn't go in March/April, we didn't see any of the cherry blossoms. It would also be nice if it were free all the time :)If you're feeling a bit burnt out on Tokyo city life this would be a great place to go.

An Escape From Shinjuku. I guess when you live in a big city like Tokyo, you just need something to escape from your daily routine. Located about 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station (you can alight at Shinjuku san-chome station for a nearer walk). This park offers all sort of themes from traditional Japanese garden, English landscape garden, French landscape garden with rose beds and also a green house for some plants that only two-weather countries have. There's an admission fee, but if i'm not mistaken is only cost 200 yen per adult. You can see a lot of people picnicking here as well. A worth visit if you are rather tired from all the shopping malls in Tokyo.

A good place to see cherry blossoms. Walked through this garden on our first day in Tokyo. It was very popular with thousands of locals experiencing sakura (cherry blossoms) and enjoying themselves. If you are staying in Shinjuku its worth an hour or two exploring all the different themed areas in the garden.

Beautiful place in Tokyo. A must visit!. We only had a short, overnight stay in Tokyo, and this was one of the few, chosen places we planned to visit. Excellent decision! The park was beautiful. No more cherry blossoms (we visited early 2nd week of May) but it was still worth the walk from our hotel (or a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station). Unfortunately we only had an hour to spare, so we actually only got to see the Japanese gardens but every angle was a perfect picture opportunity. The place was huge and there were areas there where you can relax to draw, paint or eat sushi (like what we did). We do hope to visit this place again, this time to stay for at least half a day and hopefully see the cherry blossoms. So if you only have a day or two in Tokyo, and want to see or soak in the view of something out of a Japanese post card or tourist brochure, this is the place to visit. Highly recommended.

Japanese beauty.. The garden is very clean,quiet and calm.We visited there for 3 hours.İt was fascinating to sit across the pavillion by the lake.The park becomes more quiet after 2p.m till the closing time(16.30).Many natives have had picnic.There is also a good cafe for coffee break.

Spring time in the park. Excited to see the sakura blooming but unfortunately it has bloomed earlier in March... But during my stay there, we were lucky because it was the "Golden Week" in Japan. Many of the Japanese ween seen with their families just strolling & lazying around in the park...

A half day must!. We asked our hotel receptionist to suggest a park for us to visit on our last morning in Tokyo and this was the best recommendation we could possibly have been given. Ask for an English map at the entrance as there are many different sections and garden designs in this beautiful, huge park. We went to the greenhouse, and then enjoyed a walk through the extensive traditional Japanese garden. It is so very beautiful, even the most amateur photographer will leave with picture postcard images of the garden. We then walked to the opposite side, to the Azalea Hill, where we saw a gentle upward slope ablaze with Azaleas in full bloom. It was a sight to cherish! We were too late for the cherry blossom season, but the Azaleas more than made up for it.

Full Bloom Cherry Blossom in Shinjuku. After visiting Ueno Park on 29 Mar , we were sceptical that Shinjuku Gyoen is the best place to view cherry blossom in Tokyo. We were there on the 29 Mar and despite having to pay 200 yen it was worth it. Unlike Ueno Park the cherry blossom trees were scatter all around the large park (about twice the size of Ueno). However there were more varieties, its trees are bigger, taller and most has more and bigger flowers. You can easily touch the flowers as many trees has branches spreading towards the floor.

Sunday afternoon. Bought Bento Box lunch at Takashimaya food center at the basement and walked to Shinjuku-Gyoen Park. Had a nice lunch under the trees and walked around after. It was a really beautiful, big park---- a full day should be spent exploring it....

Traditional Japanese Garden - Great on Cherry Blossom Season. We unfortunately had to go there 2x since the park closes 430pm in the afternoon. On the 2nd day, we did find the cherry blossoms which was the purpose of our trip, different varieties to be found. Aside from those, plenty of other types of plants around the park. It also has various scenery since it does have small bridges around the lake inside the park.

Natural paradise in the city centre. Lots of greens, trees, grassland to enjoy the sunshine. Heard that it's a hot place during Sakura season, where friends and family come to picnic under all Sakura trees and flowers. The traditional Japanese garden is a must-visit place too. Totally relaxed and enjoyable there.

A must see!!!. A must see when in Shinjuku! Beauitful garden make sure you see the traditional japanease garden it is great. Ask for an english map at the ticket box and go first thing when they open at 9 am it gets buiser as the day goes on.

Cool place to spend half a day away from (but near) the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Just a few minutes walk from the busiest streets of Shinjuku, it's a huge park for casual strolls, with English-, French and Chinese-style gardens, Mother-and-Son Forest, tea house, restaurant, museum, a superb tropical greenhouse, ... The sakura season starts from approximately mid-March and lasts through early April, but even out of the sakura season it's a lovely place to visit. If you exit from Sendagaya Gate (south gate), Harajuku and Omotesando are just a 20-mn pleasant walk away so you can easily continue your exploration of Tokyo.

Large peaceful park and gardens in the middle of Tokyo. Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is a sprawling, beautifully landscaped park that is very serene in the midst of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. The entrance is 200Y, with tickets bought at a vending machine at the gate. Once in the park, you have a myriad of options in which direction to walk. Gardens with different themes and lakes surrounded by flowers await you! There is also a very large greenhouse with a variety of worldwide fauna.There are snacks and refreshments available in the park. Plan ahead as there are no trash cans that I found (which is common in Tokyo anyway). Also, if you're a smoker, only do so in the designated areas. The only ones I saw were near the gates.The open grassy areas are huge with plenty of room for you to picnic, or simply spread out and take in the ambiance.
Nice Park. We started after lunch and were in a good mood. :-) It is beautiful garden, very clean and calm. It was not a time for sakura but nevertheless we enjoied spent time there.

A very scenice beautiful park experience.. For those who want to get away from the buzz and chaos of the nearby Shinjuku, this park is perfect. It has different areas, based on international parks, such as an English park, french gardens, and traditional Japanese style. I'm not even a bit park person, but I found it very enjoyable (with company)

Beautiful park. We wandered through here at a very leisurely pace enjoying the late blooming cherry blossom.
Had a beautifully presented lunch at a restaurant within the park.

Beautiful big park. Good place to take a break. The park is a quiet spot in the middle of the city. There is an area with roses, Japanese-style ponds, and a greenhouse with tropical plants. This is a good place throughout the year. There is a 200 Yen admission fee for adults, 50 Yen for small children. It can be crowded on the weekends, but it is always very clean and safe.

Beautiful garden!. A place not to be missed during cherry blossom season! Most of them I would say are locals. Just unlucky of me to bump into uncivilised tourists who spit into the pond, with the intention to feed the fishes with her spit. Other than that, I really enjoyed walking around the garden, taking photos, watching how the locals having picnic, etc. We were lucky to see a couple taking wedding photos too. This garden opens from 9am to 4.30pm and is closed on Monday usually, unless it's the cherry blossom season. There's an entrance fee of 200 yen too.

Serenity in the middle of Shinjuku. I love it here. I don't really mind the fee entrance hence the beautifully kept garden.I specifically love the japanese garden. Perfect for just lazily hanging sitting around having a picnic. If you don't bring any food you don't have to worry because they even sell o-bento here.My 5 yos daughter couldn't be any happier, she was running around and having a blast.It is surely a serenity within a hectic city.

Oasis in bustling city. The park is beautiful, meticulously maintained complete with helpful staff. Well worth the entrance fee of 200 yen. i also had the traditional tea ceremony for 700 yen. My only gripe is the signs. On the way to the Greenhouse, I did not see a single sign until the Greenhouse was visible, then there was a sign. Same thing ffor the French Gardens and other attractions in the park. However people in the park are happy to point you in the right direction.
Beautiful garden. The greenhouse was warm and filled with plants to see. The garden was large, and we strolled around taking in the various cherry blossom varieties. Very pleasant.
Sakura. Beautiful large park with many cherry blossoms loved the special food sold during Sakura too! Loved the 300 year old trees and the Japanese garden.

Excellent Japanese Garden. The entrance fee was only 200 yen and it was a wonderful Japanese garden with a section of Western garden. It is so serene and wonderful relaxing experience to take in all the traditional element of a japanese garden.
Fantastic views. Not really a garden person but this was a fantastic place. If you are a keen photographer and the weather is good you might be here for some time the views are postcard material.

Like a deep calming breath of air. We're not really ones to visit botanical gardens while trips, especially short ones to places we may only visit once. But we are so glad we did as it refreshed our mind and spirit. Shinjuku Goyen is a well laid out former imperial botanical gardens. There are Japanese, general Asian and French gardens, with wide open lawns, woody areas and water features with bridges to cross. We intended to stay maybe 1 - 2 hours, but spent closer to 4 hours.Was a very refreshing afternoon and just what we needed.

A Wonderful "Central Park" of Tokyo. Even-thought there is a real central park in Tokyo (near Tokyo Observatory), I would like to say this amazing park will absolutely beat The Central Park of New York City when it comes to Sakura Blossoms season. You can also see The Empire State building from this park. The combination of ponds, cherry tree, pathway, and lovely grass make this park extremely wonderful. Don't forget to bring a camera (or at least pocket camera or iPhone) to come here. Because anytime you shot the shutter button to catch an image, I guarantee you will get a good picture, whatever the angle. :)It just cost JYP 200 to enter this place, and you can easily find a good spot for Hanami with your girlfriend, family or colleague. Also, I think it is perfect place for someone who want to purpose his girlfriend, in the lovely weather and freaking stunning scenery.If you ever come to Shinjuku, don't miss this place on your itinerary list!Here some pictures that I took while ago. Enjoy!--M!

Dont miss this park!. Sure glad this place was just east of hotel. Beautiful! Every turn and view you came upon was classic Japan like you envision. So peaceful with people walking around, familes. The whole city of Tokyo feels safe so this place was wonderful!!Dont miss it!

Lovely park, especially beautiful with the sakura. Well laid out, landscaped and luscious park. We spent many hours walking through. It was especially beautiful because it was the cherry blossoms season. Well worth the small entrance fee.

Eye Soothing!!. This is the first place we went in japan and what a start to our journey in japan. Simply astonishing. The perfect place for Hanamai (japanese terms for hang around at cheery tree during cheery blossoms).

So peaceful!. This garden is amazing. It's so big, and so varied, you'll find some part of it that you like. A nice place for a picnic or just to wander around and relax. Great for cherry blossom viewing. It costs 200 yen but it's well worth that. After the mayhem in Shinjuku station it's such a relief! I spent about 2.5 hours here just walking around, taking pictures, and relaxing. Don't rush through it! Enjoy it!

Sakura for latecomers. Beautiful park with Japanese, French and English gardens . Most of all when the most popular variety of cherry blossom is over in Tokyo , this park is still overflowing with several different varieties of cherry blossoms which bloom later . Pink, rose , white with many more petals . A sight for sore eyes, especially for those who thought they had missed the bus

A beautiful garden but where is the Tea House?. We loved this garden - so peaceful and pleasant. It's a photographer's paradise! The cherry blossom had almost ended (Monday 16 April...apparently not opened every Monday so check first if you're planning to go on a Monday); there was still enough to be quite stunning. We were looking forward to having tea at a traditional Japanese Tea House but one was closed and the other rather disappointing. We were able to buy quite a nice sandwich & a cold drink in the public rest area. We noticed many locals having their own picnics on the grass...in hindsight, that would have been a good idea as there are lots of takeaway options at the station food court nearby.

Beautiful, especially during cherry blossom season. A sprawling garden with pockets of themed gardens. I found this the most beautiful garden I went to in Japan. It's great for picnics and cherry blossom viewing with family, friends, and loved ones. It's especially beautiful when the sakura are in full bloom. Don't miss this when you're in Tokyo.

Late Sakura viewing. Sakura was at its peak blooming almost 2 weeks in Tokyo before we arrived on April 4, 2013. This is a year with a very early blooming which its peak around 20 March in Tokyo. However, we went to Shinjukugyoenmae, like many others, on April 5, and were very pleased that we could see lots of Cherry tree blooming.I heard that there are lots of varieties of Sakura and am not an expert on Sakura. But what I saw on April 5 at this garden is still a lots of Cherry tree at their peak blooming. Cannot imagine how beautiful this park was during mid March. Surely, I will come back to see with my eyes.
beautiful cherry blossoms. was still lucky to be able to enjoy the beautiful gardens of Shinjuku at a very minimal fee of 2oo yen. The park is huge and had great species of Sakura, Worth the visit
Beautiful garden, enchanting sakura trees. The sakura trees in bloom is what I would call paradise on earth. And this garden has hundreds of them. Really beautiful.

Pleasant Garden Walk. A nice walk on grass with lovely water presentation of trees & buildings.A good place to sit and contemplate your navel or to walk and soak in the atmosphere.Differently a place to take your children on a nice day in Tokyo.

Good during cherry blossom!. I was here during the cherry blossom season. Very nice. There were only a few homeless people around, but please....where should they go rather close to an official park. They are not inside the garden, just to mention that. As well the right side is good to shoot some nice pictures of families trying to catch shellfish. Left side is nicely arranged with little lakes. The entry is 200 Yen.
Touching. Well groomed park. Cherry blossoms in full bloom.. Petals fall along with breeze. So dramatic and dreamlike. Memory for life. Kids enjoy so much as well.

Cherry Blosssoms!. I was lucky enough to see tons of cherry blossoms in this park which was literally 10 minutes away from where I roomed. The park is split into 3 sections mainly... Japanese, English, and French. Obviously, the main attraction is the Japanese garden section because of the blossoms.They were already in full bloom (and some where falling) when I arrived. Plenty of spectacular and scenic spots for photos and just relaxing. I saw many locals sitting in areas around the park sketching what they saw. Lots of people were picnicking as well added a very light-hearted feel to the whole place.The temperature was very comfortable when I went (Early April) and the place wasn't overtly crowded so I got good footage and photos.If you're in Shinjuku, this is pretty much the only place where you can see tons of cherry blossoms. Outside of this, Kyoto Arashiyama park is your best bet.
lovely garden. awesome manicured lawns, beautiful trees and bushes. lots of sakura during season. a respite from the din of shinjuku just metres away

Cherry Blossom delight!. If you visit in April, then be sure to take time to stroll around the park to enjoy the cherry tree blossoms. Also walk about the small lakes and see the huge fish near the surface.Take a cup of green tea and cake in the japanese teahouse.An oasis in the centre of the Capital.
Lovely park in Shinjuku. Easy to walk to is you are staying close. Well worth a visit. A lovely botanical garden/greenhouse is a must. Great!
Sakura Viewing. We manage to catch a few of the last sakura blooms at the park and had our hanami there.. lucky us as sakura bloomed earlier than expected this year.
Spring sakura time!. This is a large park in the busy metropolis of Tokyo. Worth a visit if you are in the Shinjuku area, and one of the best parks to see spring cherry blossoms.
A wonderland during Cherry Blossom time.. Very popular with the Japanese this Park is well planned and varied. Especially wonderful during the cherry blossom period

Breathtaking. We went there during the sakura blossom season and it was a lovely walk with a fine breeze making all those pink petals fall down.
Take some time to walk around the park and you will find it breathtaking. It is very peculiar to have such a park in the middle of the busy shinjuku city filled with skyscrapers.

Possibly the best park in Tokyo. I live 5min walk from the park. I visit there regularly, at least once a month. In any month you can see various flowers and plants, not only the famous cherry blossom in April. The park is very well mainted thanks to the fact that the park is under the Ministry of Environment. If you are in Tokyo in October, don't miss their "Noh in the woods", a classical theatrical performance. Only the minus is there are admission fees but it is well worth it.

A great spot for a springtime picnic. My husband and I went here on our last day in Tokyo. The admission fee is about AUD$2 and you buy tickets from the vending machines just outside the entrance - no English but pretty straight forward (there are pictures for 1, 2, 3, 4 adults and the same for kids) - the garden itself is beautiful, and great people watching on a Sunday as the residents of Tokyo unwind and their kids run a muck. Lots of lovely cherry blossom trees and they will give you a map at the Entrance (English available on request) so that you can explore. We brought food from a nearby department store basement to eat (and it looked like everyone else had done this too) - FYI - you cannot consume alcohol in the park - big signs everywhere and they do a bag inspection. Loved this place. So clean and beautiful.

Great for cherry blossom viewing!. This was the highlight of my trip. Big vast spaces, lovely varieties of cherry blossoms and absolutely beautiful. It was so nice and relaxing to just stroll around the park and look at the blossoms. Only regret is that i didnt note the closing time. The park closes at 1630pm. Arrived at 1530 and had a good hour but would be great to spend a longer time there.

Springtime in Toyko. There were a lot of couples and families visiting the park. It was sunny but very windy. My family went there for a picnic and a stroll. The cherry blossoms were already fading away.

Great location for cherry blossoms. This park is a 10 minute walk from the Shinjuku train station. It's also a great place to see cherry blossoms in the right season (mid-March to mid-April). We were there March 30, 2013 and it was the peak of the cherry blossom season. The park is quite large with many places to visit, sit and enjoy nature, including a few sheltered areas which are handy in a rain shower. There are also vending machines and bathrooms near the south entrance, and probably elsewhere in the park as well. If you get tired of the bustle of Shinjuku, this is a great place to relax and get away for a while. The park is also very kid friendly, no stuffy rules about where to walk, go or sit. Entrance fee was 200 yen for adults and 50 yen for my son, and well worth it.

THE place to see cherry blossoms in Tokyo. Yes Ueno is fun and bustling, but in my opinion this park destroys it for cherry blossom viewing. This park has so many blossom set upon ponds and forests that its mind boggling. When they are in full bloom, it looks as if the trees have snow on them. There is plenty of room to to find your own peaceful spot, unlike Ueno park. The fact that there is no music allowed also ads to the quiet beauty of this Gyoen. DO NOT MISS if you are in Tokyo during sakura.It was in full bloom the last week of March in 2013.

Best cherry blossom in Tokyo. My wife and I were disappointed when we learned that we would arrive at Tokyo too late to view the cherry blossom. We were so happy when we saw the beautiful cherry blossoms in Shinjuku Gyeon. Shinjuku Gyeon is definitely the highlight of our Tokyo trip.

A must during cherry blossom season. It was amazing to be in this park during cherry blossom season and such a contrast to the frenetic energy and neon lights in Shinjuku in the evening. It was nice to see the locals enjoying spring through hanami.

Awesome place for hanami. We went during the cherry blossom season and it was so, so beautiful! We insisted on going there after learning that there are many different species of cherry blossoms there, just in case we miss the peak of some species as different species may bloom at different times. It was the right choice going there. It's clean and the grounds are simple perfect for picnics!

Peace in a busy city. Strange to be in the middle of such a busy city and to find such beauty and peacefull surroundings. A great park to escape to and especially wonderfull during Cherry Blossom season.
Amazing cherry blossom. Absolutely beautiful area to view the cherry blossoms from. Cannot recommend highly enough. My husband and I spend a beautiful afternoon here.

Cherry Blossoms!!. Went there with my girlfriend during the Cherry Blossom season and I have to say it is a stunningly beautiful place. The Japanese are very proud of the their culture and their traditions, and it shows. The park was full of people from all walks of life that have come to see the famous blossoms, take pictures and just simply enjoy a lovely day. It wasn't incredibly busy and you could still walk around, take in the sights and enjoy your time. I would recommend it to anyone who has some time to spend in Shinjuku on a nice day. For 200 yen it's the best bang-for-buck you'll get in the area.

The garden with a bit of everything. Shinjuku Gyoen is a really good park. Located about a 10 to minute walk from the major station of Shinjuku, it is a true suburban oasis. A very big park surrounded by a thick belt of trees, inside the park is usually a very quiet place (except during the busy seasons, like spring with the cherry blossoms).There are three gardens inisde, the English landscape, the French formal and the Japanese traditional. All of them are very good, especially the French formal and the Japanese traditional. The French Formal during autumn is very nice especially with the tree-lined avenues. When the leaves fall on the paths, it is very romantic. It also has a nice rose garden. The Japanese garden is great all year round with its central pond and tea house.In 2012 the new greenhouse opened. An all glass building it is very attractive with lots of beautiful flowers and plants inside (and very steamy so be careful if you have a camera, because it will fog up). The park also provides some great photo opportunities: the cherry blossoms in spring and in autumn the beautiful leaves. The other great photo shot, is to stand in the English landscape garden and look back towards Shinjuku. You can get some incredible shots with the skyscrapers soaring over the trees. It really is inspring.
Cherry Blossoms!. The cherry blossoms were superb. The park was pretty big so be prepared to spend a morning walking through them.

excellent japanese garden. this is one of the best places in tokyo to see japanese gardening and sakura. I was lucky to visit rigth when the cherry blossom start and the sigth anf the feeling are incredible. There are no words to describe it, and no way to photograph it. That is why we have to pack our bags and...travel !!

Sakura garden - many different types of sakura here. There are at least 4 different types of Cherry Blossoms that I found when I was there this sakura season. From the white, pinkish white and pink, you have it all! The park is also very large, so the visitors are not condensed in any one single area, allowing you to take awesome pictures. Take a walk near the lakes and water bodies, it is so serene, pretty and quiet (when there are not so many people around). You have to pay 200 Yen for the entrance fee. But heck that, best 200 yen spent in this trip!

Nice quiet place in the busy city. This place was very peaceful and a pleasure to visit, but it is MASSIVE ! If you have walked the city all day long I would wait until you are rested unless you just want to find a spot and relax.

The garden for sakura. This trip in tokyo just for sakura, we visited this garden and entrance ticket yen 200 per person, dont bring alcohol and beer inside the garden, will be check at the entrance gate and patrol inside too.The sakura here is must better compare to ueno garden, more sakura and we are able to be photograph with the sakura flower as the flower were down near to the land.It is a big garden, a very nice and beautiful garden it is a must for flower loverNext trip i will come again to this garden
A must!. Loved it. Cherry Blossoms in full bloom, nothing better than curling up for a snooze in the park.Highly recommended.

Sakura blossoms. Nice park, great landscaping. Visit coincided with the sakura blossoms. Map provided marks out apt he Sakura-centric areas, very helpful. Well groomed beautiful gardens with tranquil ponds and varying botanica for appreciation.
安価な都会のオアシス. 新宿とは思えない広大な敷地で、街歩きに疲れたら休憩に最適な場所。入場料が安いのも良い。Good place for taking a rest in the middle of Shinjuku area. Quiet & calm with reasonable fee.

Gorgeous gardens - perfect place to see sakura/cherry blossom. These gardens are wonderful. Japan is enjoying an early sakura season and you can view cloud after cloud of the beautiful blossoms here.Entrance to the park is ¥200 for adults and it closes at 4.30pm. The signal to leave is the repeated playing of "Auld Lang Syne" - everyone quietly makes their way out with no fuss... Wonderful!

The Best Place for Viewing Sakura!. Hands down, this is the BEST park for Hanami- Sakura viewing. On the weekend of 24-25 March the Sakura was full bloomed and we had the best picnic. Arriving at 10am, there was still lots of good picnic spots under cherry blossom trees. The best thing about Shinjuku Gyoen is that Alcohol and smoking is prohibited so the park is family friendly and clean. I been to Ueno Park for Hanami and although there were loads of sakura, the vibe was so different- it was fully packed and noisy and there were beer cans everywhere. The other good thing about Shinjuku Gyoen is that is has a variety of Sakura, with many colors and different types- the draping sakura branches is one of the best :) Plus they also have a nice traditional Japanese garden... a nice stroll around the japanese area feels so peaceful, with the tiny pond with ducklings. They also have a tea house too. Only 700 yen for a set of green tea and sweet! The park is closest from Shinjuku Sanchome station exit c1. Get a bento set from Isetan or Kinokuniya food store for a picnic at the park! The entry to the park is 200 yen per person. Such a cheap price to pay considering how beautiful and clean the park is! Definitely a must go!
Really enjoyed this!. Well worth the stop if you can make time. A beautiful set of gardens, right in the heart of bustling Tokyo.

Gorgeous garden/park, massive, could spend a full day here. Put you comfy shoes on, this garden is huge. We loved the beautiful Japanese garden. We visited in early march, before cherry blossom season. The place will look awesome during cherry blossom time for sure. Make sure to visit the glass house which is tucked away.

Beautiful formal Japanese garden. The park is lovely, French, English and Japanese gardens plus a wonderful hothouse. Don't miss the traditional tea houses where you can have tea if you are prepared to wait for a table and don't mind paying rather more than elsewhere (Y700 per person). NB closed on Mondays.

Wondeful Park. Visited the park on a Sunday when the cherry blossoms were just starting to come out early March (11th). A large park with what must be a fabulous cherrry blossom display in a few weeks. Full of families on Sunday. A lovely relaxing park about 10 minutes walk from Shinjiku station. However it is the first park in a major city I have ever had to pay to go into. Worth the visit to see the cherry blossoms.

Peaceful Haven in the Bustling City. tranquil park just off the main thoroughfare, some attractive traditional garden layouts, greenhouse full of exotic plants. Grass either dead or badly in need of watering both here and at other locations in the city.
Great walk. The place where we could escape the noisy from this crazy city. Walked around the path, could hear the sound of birds, coloful trees those made a great feeling. Try and enjoye it.!!

Gorgeous park! N I'm not normally a park guy. Great hour or so walk, would be a great place for a couples picnic. Plenty if picture ops, best park I've visited and it isn't in bloom fully yet, a month from now it'll look ridiculously awesome!

Great place to relax in the heart of Tokyo. If you've been to Central Park in New York City, you already have a good idea of what Shinjuku Gyoen is like: A big, gorgeous park hidden in the middle of a bustling metropolis. The place is enormous but serene, with plenty of space to have a get together, take a leisurely stroll, or simply take a peaceful nap--I definitely many people in deep slumbers. Families are plentiful, so expect a lot of children running around and having fun. Gardens, of course, are everywhere and there's even a French-style one. There is also a beautiful modern greenhouse with an abundant inventory of Japanese flora in exhibit. I would recommend coming here on a Sunday morning to just relax and recover after a busy week.

Beautiful garden-haven in the middle of the city. Absolutely beautiful garden location in the middle of the city.. we even saw a cherry blossum or two (a treat during winter). Was particularly lovely covered in snow. NB, not open Monday!

Beautiful garden in the middle of the city. if you are looking for a break from the hustle and bustle of the city then you need to visit the National Garden. The color of the trees were just amazing during our visit. I would highly spending a couple of hours here during your visit to Shinjuku.

Beautiful, tranquil garden within the bustling city.. Visited this park today and was completely stunned at what a hidden gem it is, who'd have thought there would be a place so beautiful and tranquil amidst the bustling sights and sounds of Shinjuku! Definitely worth a visit, only ¥200 entry, even at this time of year without the blossom or green grass. A must see on anyone's Shinjuku itinery.
Pretty. Where to go for peace and quiet in the middle of a crazy concrete jungle. It's like going into another world. Ride a bike to a teahouse and enjoy the cats.
Would be great in Spring / Summer. Lovely open space right near Shinjuku, but during the middle of winter not too much colour present. Still a lovely walk!

Awesome park any season. It's a great park to stroll through, especially when cherry blossoms are blooming. But even in December it's well worth your time. There were still some autumn leaves in mid December last year.
Admission is only 200yen which is a steal. Don't forget to check out newly renovated green house.

an oasis. A great escape from the very tempting shopping in shinjuku we spent several hours wandering through these beautiful gardens. Being Autumn the colourful trees were a standout. Lso loved the tropical garden in the hothouse and the French garden.

Cherry Blossom at its best. Lucky to be in Japan at Cherry Blossom time. Daily forecast plots the blossom from south to north. Crazy experience to see the office workers reserving the best plots for a lunchtime party. Sadly alcohol is not allowed but somehow seems to be able to be smuggled in, I suppose Sake is the same colour as water!

Beautiful Japanese gardens. If you've travelled to other parts of Japan, are staying in Tokyo for a while, and are in need for a little greenery, Shinjuku Gyoen is the place to visit. The Japanese gardens here are beautiful, and there is even a little traditional teahouse where you can stop for matcha and a sweet. We visited where the foliage was started to turn red, russet, bronze and gold, and it was stunning. There was also a rogue cherry blossom tree in bloom with plenty of Japanese crowding around it to capture an image! If you hail from a Western country, then the French and English gardens can be given a miss. The Japanese garden however is substantial and very lovely. There was a little shanty town set-up near the entrance, so perhaps visit later in the morning when there are more people about.

Beautiful in every season. Well worth the 200 JPY entry fee. You can easily spend an hour or two in this large park. The glasshouse is interesting in itself, but as a foreigner I mainly enjoyed the Japanese garden (but there are actually 4 different garden types). Great views of the cityscape, also.
Nice. Not as pretty as some of the other gardens in Tokyo, but a lovely peaceful place amongst the chaos of Shinjuku to have a picnic! :)

Very nice; though sometimes draconian. It's a beautiful park. A pleasure to walk around and relax, escaping the bustle, noise and crowds of Shinjuku. We made the mistake once of going during Sakura viewing season. At that time they were insisting on searching everyone's bags for alcohol prior to entry. This made me think of North Korea or some other police state. I will never go again during that season.We also attended the recently re-designed and renewed greenhouses. I find these a disappointment on the old greenhouses. The area of space is smaller, there is only information in Japanese (it is surprisingly retarded in this respect seeing that has just been totally replaced from scratch). The old ones had a charm and wildness that were more like Kew. The new greenhouse seems overly designed. I think that as long as you avoid the sakura season, it is a nice park to attend.

Beautiful. This park is very relaxing, we were there in April, so there were still a lot of cherry blossoms in the park. The Japanese garden was by far my favorite part. The 200 yen entry fare is worth it.

An oasis in the heart of Tokyo. The ¥200 entry fare is worthed, +-$2cnd. The park is a real oasis in the city, you could see the highrise buildings over the tree line, but you do not ear the city noises. We enjoy a walk a the park several mornings of our stay. We also used it as a shortcut to access other parts of Shinjuku

Peaceful spot in the middle of the city. A really peaceful spot in the middle of the city. The annual chrysanthemum display was on, and was an interesting addition to the park. Strolling through the autumn leaves was a lovely way to spend an hour or two on a Sunday morning.

Floral oasis in Shinjuku. The garden now known as Shinjuku Gyoen was once the home of the Imperial University's experimental farm and school of agriculture. The garden now is home to three different garden styles (English, French and Japanese) along with a healthy grove of native trees. Visiting Shinjuku Gyoen is a wonderful way to escape the urban density of the Shinjuku station district. The entrance fee is 200JPY, and goes toward the maintenance of the facilities. If you're feeling overwhelmed by Tokyo's mass urbanity, Shinjuku Gyoen is a wonderful oasis for temporary respite.
Great Garden. I liked much this immense Garden but I have seen much more beautiful gardens in Tokyo. They have a nice traditional restaurant and also 2 tea places.
Peaceful. Bummer. The greenhouse was still under renovation. Lovely park to relax in. Get a bento box lunch and enjoy the sun. Might be some mosquitoes there so take some spray.
Great place to start your day. A small charge to enter but spent a couple of hours enjoying the gardens an what was beautiful weather

Provided much-needed quiet. Beautiful gardens and a great place to wander and linger in silence. Take some time and laze on the big common lawn area while you munch on treats and enjoy the break from chimes, announcements, and music.

A beautiful garden complex. Just tips:It opens at 9:00 and closes at 4:30. You pay 200 yen generally (although today, it was only 100 yen).There are Japanese, English and French gardens, a forest, and tea rooms.I don't think you can bike in there.Best way is to come in close to 10:00 because the tea room opens at that time.
Had a great time. We had lots of fun from walking through the picturesque park to watching a show Can recommend it to visit for families
