beautiful oasis in the city. the gyoen national park is a beautiful oasis of serenity and green right in the shinjuku area of tokyo. its flanked by the skyscrapers on one side, shopping area including the flagship isetan, and the the flashy nightlife entertainment areas. its one train stop, but really just a 10minute walk from the shinjuku main train station wast exit.its a favorite place for cherry blossoms in april and chrysanthemum in november, and has well manicured lawns, lightly wooded areas, beautiful lake, a french garden. theres vending machines right after the entrance, and a rest building in the middle with small cafe. toilets are also dotted around and are typical japanese efficiently clean and working order. there are also some sprawling low wooden buildings which are apparently the old guesthouses of the imperial family. you can imagine yourself strolling in from theimposing french garden, across the park, as you make your way to visit the governor of edo, which this property used to be the residence of.theres an entrance fee of 200Y, and tickets are available at ticket vending machine at the entrance. the entrance fee means that, unlike other parks in the city like yoyogi and tokyo metropolitan, you will not find stacked in corners and neatly packed in blue tarpaulines and cardboxes, the worldly possesions of the homeless. there were many families there for a late afternoon picnic, and people taking their siesta on the beautiful lawns. there are all well dressed with many in full suits strolling along.overall a very beautiful park and a great place to spend an afternoon in the middle of busy tokyo.

The nicest gardens we visited in all of Japan. The nicest gardens we visited in all of Japan. Very pretty and relaxing. Unfortunately it closes at 16:30 so we didn't get to spend as long as we'd like there.

a lovely afternoon. We spent our last afternoon in Tokyo strolling around the park. It is tranquil and the gardens and ponds are wonderful. There were lots of families enjoying the sunshine and picnicking and playing games with children. There are a few restaurants and shops to buy drinks and icecream.

a beautiful walk. It was nice to escape the noise of the city and walk through the park. Paths were well maintained and easy to walk. I could only imagine how beautiful it would be to see during the spring with the Cherry Blossom trees..

Beautiful garden.. We had a lovely day in the garden with picnic japanese style.Went crazy in the food floor of the Takashima department store and bought lots of tasty food to enjoy in the park.. But don't buy alcoholic drinks to have with it, they are not allowed in the park. Peaceful oasis in Shinjuku.

Not necessarily THE thing to do but quiet place to change from the city hustle. Entrance fee : 200¥ and ok the park is nice but as every other park in cities. Of course it must be different if it is time for flower blooming or Koyo

Not bad for Tokyo. If you aren't going to be travelling to other cities or one of the more famous gardens around the country, then this one gives a nice glimpse at what you're missing. It's a nice break from the helter skelter of Tokyo, and very easy to find. If you want to just sit and take a few hours to relax, this is a good place to do it.

Peaceful and well maintained. Spent a morning here. It was quite nice and quiet. The landscape was well maintained. It was mostly shaded which was important during the very hot Tokyo summer. A very good place to relax, take some pictures as well as letting kids run around. It took us a little of walking to get to find the entrance.

Loved the Japanese gardens!. Initial thoughts as we paid our 200 yen to enter, were not the greatest. It was the first park we paid to get into whilst in Tokyo. So I had high expectations.We walked for a while and I kept thinking......it's a big open space which is very clean but that was it.....then we turned a corner and were in one of the largest and most beautiful style Japanese gardens I've ever seen. It was absolutely stunning.It was a very hot day when we were there so we spent a while just sitting on a bench, in the shade watching the world walk slowly past. There are plent of places to take some beautiful pictures and even watching the men trim the trees and bushes into well manicured shapes was a delight.I loved it here...my only disappointment was having to leave after only 1.5 hours. I wish we'd had longer as there was so much more to explore!

Pretty and Quiet. It was a nice garden area and surprisingly quiet for being in the middle of the city! But I've seen some other lovely Japanese style gardens in the US as well...and these weren't much different.

The Central Park of Tokyo. This is a great park to visit in Tokyo! Its not too far from the train station and it only costs 200 yen to enter. The park has a traditional tea house which will serve you green tea and a sweet for 700 yen. There is plenty to see - just follow the paths!

Great grass to lay down :). It is 200 yen the entrance fee. Was surprised but at least it is not crowded. They are open until 4h30 pm.It is a large garden, ideal to take a break from the city. I have simply enjoyed to walk around and then crashed in the fluffy grass and look at the sky and trees. Nice view from the surroundings too with the sounds of the insects.
Beautiful and diverse. Beautiful well kept garden. Good clean public toilets, map was given at entry. You have to pay to get in.
Average. Don't go out of the way for this.. I thought the garden was average. It was nice and pretty, but nothing special at all. I wouldn't go back.

Beautiful garden, but have to pay?!. While it's a token payment, it's a little alien for us to pay to enter a garden, being from New Zealand. However it was well kept and very pretty, and was a nice quiet place to sit in restfully when it was hot.
Good relaxed walk around the palace. I visited during the summer and I thought it was very nice, but not worth your day if it isn't spring.
Spacious oasis near Shinjuku. Wide expanse of lawn, lots and lots of trees and plants. Picnicing and napping here is so very nice. Peaceful, relaxing...

Nice quiet place to relax and clear the mind. I managed to get in 5 minutes before the last entry and found the cooling walk through the tall trees, and rose bushes relaxing and wonderful after a hectic two days of shopping! Loved the large and varied types of roses that I saw at the French garden and the tranquillity of the Japanese gardens even with the announcement bombarding my ears that the park is closed for the day.

My neighbourhood garden and I LOVE it!. Shinjuku Gyoen is a lovely garden an park right in the heart of the craziness of Shinjuku. Just a few minutes walk from Shinjuku Station, Shinjuku Gyoen is a great place to take a stroll or just sit and enjoy some relatively fresh air. Dogs are NOT allowed in the main garden, however, I walk my dog most days down a lovely promenade that runs all along one side of the garden. Lots shade, a love stream and a nice walking path make this an ideal spot for city-dwelling dog owners. Shinjuku Gyoen is especially popular during the Sakura Cherry Blossom Season. But remember, alcohol is officially not allowed in the garden so if you have it... you may loose it.
Beautiful!. Stunning gardens in the middle of bustling shinjuku. Only 200 yen entrance charge & an accurate free map in english. Great way to spend a couple of hours

Beautiful & well kept garden with all facilities and tranquil atmosphere. I didn't have too many expectations, and was frankly asking myself if I want to spend money to just see a garden, but I was thoroughly mistaken. This garden is one of the most beautiful and well maintained ones I have seen so far. They have a Japanese style garden, an English one, a couple of tea houses and a nice restaurant. There are also lots of restrooms and areas to get refreshed around the garden. Lots of well designed seating areas make it a pleasant experience. The greenhouse area is closed and under construction, and the chrysanthemum garden is also not open to public. Takes around 3 hours to leisurely walk around the place and eat at the restaurant. 200JPY is admission fee, and it's totally worth it!

Lovely place to walk around. The Shinjuku Goyen National Garden is a lovely place to stroll. It costs 200 yen for admission but the large carp, the trees, grounds, flowers, and peacefulness make it well worth the admission price. This garden is an oasis in the busy-ness of Tokyo
Beautiful park. A beautiful park in the middle of the city. If you like Japanese gardens, it's definitely worth a visit.

fantastic oasis in the middle of urban madness. a beautiful and peaceful garden. It is fabulous during cherry blossom season. Perfect for strolling and for a little bit of peace and quiet. The contrast with the big, noisy city is amazing.

walk in the garden. I enjoyed the beauty of the garden and enjoyed a tea at the tea house. There is a nominal charge to enter the park which the foreigners do not like...the place is clean and you need to carry the garbage with you...bring a lunch and bread for the fish

Peace at last. Just the ticket after the madness and fun of the city. You could happily spend a few hours or just drop by and re-charge prior to launching into the vast array of Shops and restraunts.
Great place and certainly on the "Must Go" list.
Nice and peaceful. Beautiful lake with big carp (i think thats what they were) and turtles. Nice and serene in the middle of Shinjuku.

Charming retreat in middle of busy area. Entry was inexpensive and it is a short walk from Shinjuku station or most of the hotels in the area. While it was charming and relaxing to walk through, it showed signs of needed maintenance and some areas were a bit dilapidated ( very surprising for Japan). The greenhouses are also under massive renovation and thus are closed off. All in all, a great way to spend a lazy afternoon if you are already in Shinjuku...but not a reason to come to Shinjuku.
Oasis. A beautiful area of peace in the middle of bustling Shinjuku. A complete antidote to the stress of trying - and regularly failing - to negotiate the rabbit warren of Shinjuku station
A lovely secluded area in Tokyo. A beautiful garden, make sure you check the opening times before you go - we got caught out as they are a little odd.

Pretty and Large Garden. We visited the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden primarily because it was just a short walk from the Shinjuku station. It is a large garden in the middle of bustling Shinjuku, so it is a nice contrast to the city, and has shade, benches, drinking fountains, and clean bathrooms. The grounds are lovely and it is worth seeing, but the Tonogaya Totei Park is actually my favorite park in Tokyo.
Beautiful place, just don't go when its too hot!. It just doesn't get more beautiful than this. Coming here was a great experience. It was relaxing, peaceful. If you never go, you're missing out!
Don't miss it during the Spring. Exactly how someplace could be this beautiful, I don't know. But it is and it is not to be missed during Sakura time. You'll hate your life if you do.
Nice place on a hot day. Lovely large garden with a variety of styles. Very nice on a hot day!

Beautiful!. and a very relaxing experience. We enjoyed the roses in the french garden and went by the tea-houses in the japanese part.
I think we paid 200 yen each to get in. So worth it!

Beautiful place!. I enjoyed my visit there a lot. Quiet place, not very crowded, beautiful gardens. I specially loved the contrast between the skyscrapers around the park and the peaceful nature that't in there. I've even got a chance to see a wedding photographic session at there! Very pleasant place!

Quiet in the city. This is a great and relaxing garden within the busy town. It is surprisingly quite in there, regardless of the numerous tall buildings and busy streets around. Really worth a visit.
Peaceful garden in Shinjuku. Wonderfully peaceful, traditional garden near Shinjuku station. There is also an English garden & greenhouses that we did not visit. Best garden that we visited.

Oasis in Shinjuku. I only went here because everyone I know told me that I had to go so I did it even though I wasn't very interested in doing so. It was surprisingly beautiful. My friend and I ended up staying in the park/gardens for more than two hours. We were there when a later blooming cherry blossom was in full-bloom so the scenes were brilliant. We were there on a national holiday and it didn't seem very crowded at all. Yes, there were many people but it still seemed like an escape from the much busier streets around Shinjuku. The place is huge so it must be able to absorb large numbers of people without cramming everyone together. It's definitely worth your while.

Awesome garden. Must visit!. There are many beautiful gardens in Japan and Shinjuku Gyoen is definitely one of them! The spacious 144 acres garden is landscaped by sections according to three themes, ie. French, English and Japanese. If you enjoy nature and the serenity it provides, visit this garden when you are in Shinjuku.My wife and I almost spent an entire day strolling through the vast garden during the cherry blossom season in April. It was drizzling on and off. The drizzle and cloudy sky provided a richness to the colours in the garden, a dream come true for photographers. Best of all, the cherry blossoms were in full bloom. As it was drizzling, the garden was not crowded and we enjoyed the garden at a leisurely pace.From expansive lawn to manicured landscaping and scenic ponds, great care has been taken to nurture the garden to its current beautiful form. Each tree and shrub, each pathway and bench seemed to have its own place in the garden. Viewed together, it's like an arrangement into a score of music. Ever so often, we would stop and just take in the scenery of nature before us!In the fast paced world we live in, this garden is a sanctuary.
Excellent park for a relaxing walk. Good place to go with the kid. Beautiful gardens. Very inspiring.

Magical. Our timing was perfect, a beautiful day and the blossoms were out. Lots of local families making the most of what is a really moving experience (and i am someone who normally does not get overly excited by gardens/flowers/etc). But there is more to it than that, it acknowledges the passing of time and change and transition, and the multi generational family groups are clearly appreciating that.
Just across the road. The grass looked like it has been left to go wild, how refreshing for Tokyo!

Large well maintained, worth a visit. I was at Shinjuku in early May. The Garden is quite large and the greenhouse was under restoration. I liked the part with the Japanese gardens, lakes and the bridges. There are two entrances which are close to the subway station. Really picture postcard stuff.

Flora paradise in the midst of concrete jungle. This park is a wonderful park, especially when you find such place in Shinjuku, probably the place with the most number of skyscrapers in Tokyo. I went to the park with my colleague on a Saturday, and we were granted free admission ;). Upon entering the park, I felt myself immersed in the pool of negative ions!! The body just relaxed in an instance. This must be contributed by the mass amount of plants and the centre lake. Each plant species is clearly labeled! I managed to spot cherry!!! No more sakura as it was June :) But, who cares! The trees, leaves and the cherry is as attractive. The lake gave a picturesque reflections of the beautiful flowers at the lakeside. The clear water gave us a chance to see the tortoises and koi swimming freely in the lake. Almost at the time of leaving the park, a strong fragrance of roses surrounded us at a corner of the park. There must have been hundreds of roses species and they are just marvelous. Seeing is believing. This park is something not to be missed!!

Peaceful and Beautiful. We visited the park on a rainy Friday afternoon, so there were not much people in the area. Nonetheless, the place was very beautiful and peaceful! We ended up sitting inside one of the huts beside the lake while adoring the view. Beautiful!Blogged about the experience here:http://www.tagofabic.com/2012/06/shinjuku-garden-inside-busy-tokyo.html
Lovely grounds. Nice place for a picnic, especially during spring when all trees and flowers are in blossom and it doesn't get too hot. Very picturesque. A slow stroll takes in all the sights.
Great for viewing cherry blossom. This large garden is one of the best sites in Tokyo for Hanami, Cherry Blossom Viewing, and attracts large numbers of ecstatic Japanese

Beautiful and relaxing. Finally a place to relax and enjoy after long travel and stress of a hugh language barrier. It is a beautiful place to explore, take great picures, and then lay back in the sun. Perfect place to people watch.

Beautiful place to relax e take wonderful pictures. The Gyoen National Garden is beautiful, the japanese gardening is unique. Enjoy the day, coming to Gyoen and bring a small lunch, spend the day taking pictures and relaxing with the view.
Peaceful and Quiet. Typical Japanese Garden, spacious, tidy, green, not colourful with many flowers.

WHAT A BLOSSOM!!!!!!. We were so lucky!!When I planned my mid April trip to Tokyo, my Japaneses friends told me that I'm going to miss the best time of the year as the blossom is in the very beginning of the month.Nature wanted to have an extremely cold March that postponed the SAKURA in two weeks. And who was there? Yep....Well, it did not start so good.. On my day off I came to the garden during closing time and they just didn't let me in. I was so sad, doing all the way, breaking my teeth on the metro.On my third day, I have taken the very early entrance with a suite and a tie and went to see the gardens. That was amazing. HUGE, HUGE white trees, 100's of them just posing for the camera.Every time there was a little wind you could here the SLR cameras working hard to capture the feather-like falling leaves giving you a snow atmosphere. Every time I tell a friend about this garden I get a goose skin. It is a phenomena.So, you need to pay a little, but is so worth it compared to the free entrance at the Ueno park.

Maybe during the cherry blossom?. Not sure why this joint is rated the no.1 thing to do in Tokyo??? is it because the cherry blossom season has just been? It's a very pretty park but just a park really.
Serenity now - in Shinjuku. Very pretty, quiet but quite crowded on the weekends. A nice break from the craziness of Shinjuku central.

My Favorite Park in Tokyo. I've been to Shinjuku Gyoen Garden on several instances, the best time maybe during spring (because of the cherry blossoms) but each season brings something different... that is why I never get tired of visiting this park.The park is divided into three - Japanese Traditional, English Landscape and French Formal gardens. My favorite is the French Formal where roses are in bloom during summer, maple trees are red/orange during autumn and very peaceful/relaxing during spring.
Sakura. Great place for pictures during Sakura and and super fun for a stroll
beautiful during Sakura season. Get there during Sakura season, it's so beautiful. Wonderful place for a picnic, so relaxing, and plenty of room for kids to run around.
Shinjuku Gyoen. Fantastic park to visit. Clean, and picturesque. Bring large memory card !!

Best place to relax in Shinjuku. A very good spot to just relax and enjoy a very nice garden...especially on cherry blossom season. We went there in mid April and still can see many cherry trees in bloom...so pretty and beautiful. A lot of people still enjoy Hanami with friends and families, and a lot of school children too.. A very heart-warming experience one can not easily forget.. Will go there again on our next trip to Tokyo...someday.. :)

Absolutely beautiful and immaculately tended gardens. One of the best manicured parks I've ever seen. There's an admission charge, and the place closes by 5pm, so there are no homeless people here. Its a fantastic place to go anytime of year, but especially during the cherry blossom season in early April.
Nice escape from the urban environment. Very scenic and relaxing park/gardens just a few minutes walk from Shinjuku station - a nice nature break from the city.

Beautiful gardens. Nice place to spend an afternoon. I was there the first day of Cherry Blossoom festival and the weather was cold and somewhat rainy and cherry blossoms were late this year, but it was still pretty. Good place to go for a nice walk. A little crowded. Good place to do some photography
WOW!. Fabulous garden and during our stay lots of cherry trees in bloom. We visited ALL the garden spaces; Japanese gardens were our faves!

Great. Good sized gardens with different layout styles. Liked the Japanese gardens & buildings. Good for cherry blossom. You could have traditional tea or sit in the rest area with a drink from the vending machines.

Gorgeous gardens, with both early and late blooming cherry blossoms. The garden is just beautiful. I stayed much longer than I had planned, and even then had to tear myself away. This is a brilliant place to experience the magic of cherry blossom season - they have many different varieties of cherry blossom that bloom at different times, so even if you're early or late for the peak you have a chance to view the blooms here (I believe from mid March to early May? I don't speak Japanese so couldn't say for sure). I missed the Tokyo peak by 10 days or so but the blooms were still going strong all over the gardens. A variety of different landscapes to see and beautifully curated. I'd recommend as a must-see and allow a few hours to soak it up. Wonderful!

Stunning gardens. Tokyo's version of central park. Amazing retreat from all the hustle and bustle of the city. Great place for kids as loads of room to run free and have a picnic. For those gardeners out there this is a taste of Japanese heaven

Cherry Blossom was amazing. My wife and I walked around the Gyoen garden and were lucky enough to be there the time of the Cherry Blossom. With the Japanese people believing that this brings good luck the gardens were very busy. But it is well worth a visit, the cherry blossom was an amazing sight to see.

Came here for Sakura. If you are going Hanami (cherry blossom viewing), I highly recommend this park. Amazing trees and without the big crowds, this is a much more peaceful than any of the major public parks in the city. Gorgeous! Beautiful at other times a year as well.
Beautiful Cherry Blossoms. Very clean and the throngs of visitors to the park were very orderly.
Memorable... really beautiful.. We visited while the cherry blossom was out... truly amazing. The Japanese traditional garden is a "must see".Its a walk of about 800 metres from the Keio Plaza Hotel.

Great for viewing late blooming Cherry Blossoms. The garden was a great place to view late blooming cherry blossom varieties and it was also right next to Shinjukugyoenmae Tokyo Metro Station which makes it very accessible. You pay a small entrance fee.
Wonderful Park. It's a beautiful park with beautiful sights, specially if you are keen in photography. Sakura season is wonderful in Shinjuku Gyoen!

Go early. We went on April 9 and 11, which was during the full bloom of Sakura season this year. Therefore, the park was perhaps a bit more crowded than usual. I highly recommend showing up when the park opens at 9 AM, as we did. By the time we left around 11, it was getting a bit too crowded for my tastes. At 9, it was still sparse enough to comfortably jog.When jogging, you can easily do a lap of the park under 30 minutes. If walking, I'd budget about an hour or two to see everything. Of the three main gardens, I'd prioritize the Japanese garden. The French garden was staid and sterile, and the English garden was barely noticeable.There are plenty of bathrooms within, and places that sell snacks. Cherry blossom season was absolutely gorgeous, with many varieties of cherry blossoms. If it's windy, you'll be occasionally blasted by sakura-fubuki (cherry blossom petal blizzard)!Highly recommended, and well worth the 200Y entrance fee, but again, go at 9 am.

A good place to view sakura. Medium size park in the city, but provide many scenic spot for sakura viewing. enjoyed the bridge and the ponds with japanese garden setting. Many big trees and the terrain are up and down which add some character and good spot for picture. Do allocate more than 2 hours to get a feel of the park. They close early, I think is around 4.30pm.. so do check the time to plan for the walk.
Lovely garden. One of the best places to see the cherry blossom in Japan, a lovely peacefully garden to stroll through and admire all the cherry blossom

Tranquility. Vast open spaces for picnics. Secluded benchs for intraspection. Beautiful landscapes for enjoyment. This garden is a must see while visiting Tokyo. Photographers looking to capture wide-sweeping shots should come early to avoid crowds. I also recommend visiting during the cherry blossom season (Mar - Apr) for the brightest blooms.
Beautiful.. An oasis in the city. Calm, peaceful. Lovely shrine to be found there, too.

Beautiful place to relax the day away. This was a beautiful park, a nice walk through Shinjuku to get there. I was there during Cherry Blossom season and it couldn't have been more beautiful. Many people were relaxing under the blossoms but there was room for all. My friend and I enjoyed it so much, we ended up dozing off under one of the enormous trees for a little while before heading back into the close-by downtown area for lunch. A perfect way to spend the morning. There were many other plants and trees as well, so should be beautiful anytime of year as others are in bloom.

must be one of the best gardens in the world. We visited here on a lovely sunny day during the cherry blossom time.It has three sections, formal French garden, English garden and Japanese garden.All were immaculate and very impressive

Like being in a painting!. Beautiful for cherry blossoms blooming! So peaceful and serene. It was quite crowded but it was never stuffy or uncomfortable. Definitely worth the 200 yen admittance to get in. About a 10 minute walk from the nearest subway stop.

One of the best cherry blossoms spot. Given that you visit this place before lunch hours (11:00) most likely you will be able to enjoy the famous Cherry Blossoms without the crowds. Very big and much much quieter than the Ueno Gyoen which has no entry price.

Picnic among the sakura trees!. We were lucky to experience Tokyo during the sakura blossom period. The garden was crowded with people with cameras, picnic mat and food when we went. Some even wore the traditional japanese costumes. Beautiful!!

Busy but nice cherry blossom viewing. Great place to have a walk around and see the hanami. Bring some lunch and a tarp and sit under a tree. Quite a big park, easy to spend a couple of hours there.200 yen to get in. No alcohol allowed while we were there (Weird!!!). Great little escape from the city and only a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station
Beautiful. Interested in Japanese style gardens? Lots of green, quite, great place for a walk.

Serenity in Tokyo. A short walk from Shinjuku Railway Station is the magnificant Gyoen National Garden. With the crowded hurly burly of the City all around this is truely a peaceful oasis. We were simply three blokes who decided to pay a quick visit early on a brisk February morning. To our suprise we ended up staying for almost 3 hours checking out the garden clearly wearing it's winter coat. Adding to the experience, we almost had the place to ourselves, apart from a handful of ground staff and gardeners. At every turn there seemed to be another photo opportunity. The men up tall ladders with their bodies poking above the trees while they carefully pruned were an amusing sight. The skyscraper back drop along some of the view lines was also eye catching, A highly recommended respite in the world's most populated MegaCity.

One of the most beautiful garden I have ever seen. I went to Tokyo on a business purpose, I just had 3 days to stay, and my friend told me that if I visit this garden I would for sure want to come back and next time I would stay much longer. I think he's right. This garden was fantastic. The trees, the lake and the total planning of the garden is just breath taking. I go in and for sure do not want to go out. It is a must for all nature fans and those who want to unwind and need some inspiration. I highly recommend this place.

Perhaps Tokyo's finest garden. This huge and beautiful garden is worth hours of exploration. It was beginning to rain when I was there, so I didn't do more than scratch the surface, but I could see that it's just plain gorgeous. It's just a stone's throw from horrifically busy Shinjuku Station, but it's so quiet you'd never guess it. Bravo!
Great place to visit. What a magic place this is, a must see if you go to Tokyo
Shijuku Gyoen a place to dream. It is just so beautiful in any season , you may dream of paradise!

Stunning escape in Shinjuku. The gardens are absolutely beautiful. My 18 months old son loved the koi fish in the pond. We had to drag him away. We were also lucky enough to see some cherry Blossom's a few days before the official season started. It was stunning. The ¥200 is worth it!
Greenery in Tokyo. Nothing special as a garden but pleasant green space in the middle of high rise.

The most beautiful trees. I visited at the very beginning of spring. Would love to see the gardens in either spring or autumn. Took photos of the bare trees as I could imagine how beatuiful they would be with blossom or leaves.
Make time for this.. This is a beautiful peaceful spot and totally worth devoting some time. Make sure to allow at least a few hours to enjoy it

Beautiful garden!. Visited this garden on a chilly morning, and was captivated by the beauty and serenity of its surroundings. I was just a little disturbed by the presence of really huge crows at certain parts of the garden, but nothing to worry about though. If I haven't been wrong, there's a greenhouse at one end of the park that is under the final phase of construction. I would like to check it out again when I get to visit again!

early march, first cherry blossom. What a cool park! Ofcourse the spectaculair skyscraper back drop adds to the experience, but this garden has enough credits in its own right. We mainly strolled around the japanse tradional garden. Enjoyed the Koi pound. The other visitors: mainly men (50+) with foto cameras taking pictures of the first signs of spring.

Shinjuku Gyoen Park in December. I went there on a Sunday afternoon when I was in Shinjuku. The park is really great, not to say awesome. I was very lucky to go there on a very great day (sunny 15-20°C in december), and it was quite crowded, although not so much that it was any kind of problem. There's a small entrance fee but once you pay you can stay as long as you want. Overall, if you have a few hours of spare time in Shinjuku on a nice sunny day and you want to get away from the speed and density of life in tokyo, don't hesitate and go spend some nice moments in Shinjuku Gyoen Park.

A beautiful (formerly imperial) Japanese garden on the edge of a major shopping district. I have been here so many times and never get tired of it. It can get crowded at times, so go early, but there are always beautiful plants in bloom and places to wander, sit, and contemplate.Rory

Oasis in Shinjuku. If you are in Shinjuku, let's go to the Shinjuku-Gyoen Park. The entrance fee is only 200yen. There are many kinds of tree and flower. They make us comfortable and relax. When the cherry blosomes are their best, I will visit to see them, again.
Lovely place to escape.. This is a large well kept garden with water features and bridges amoungst the lovely flower beds and trees. Well worth a visit.
Immaculately kept. Great place to relax at the weekend when the weather is nice. Popular, so can get busy at weekends.

A special place. This is a park with paid entry which makes it quieter than many. Do not be put off though. It is a lovely and very large open space with a variety of garden types (woodland, traditional Japanese, English and French formal). The restaurants are nothing special but it is a great place for a picnic. Crowded on weekends and holidays and empty at other times. Occasional free access days.

Pleasant and calming. Shinjuku Gardens was very near our hotel (Citadines) and we decided to include in our itinerary based on TA reviews. Although it was already winter, we could still see the maples and they were so, so beautiful. The garden is very big and we didn't have time to explore the entire place as our intention was to stroll through the park from Shinjuku enroute to the Meiji Shrine. It would have been good to spend a bit more time there leisurely as it is very serene and has a very calming effect.

Beautiful escape. Relieve yourself of the city stress with a quick jaunt to the park. Quiet, beautiful, lots of water and fish. Great for autumn leaves and hanami. Well maintained garden, very pretty.
One of the few big open spaces in Tokyo. And well-worth a visit, particularly during cherry blossom time.

Beautiful haven in skyscraper city. Although there is a small entrance fee for this garden (most others are free to enter) this park offers spectacular photo opportunities and beautiful gardens from traditional Japanese to English and French.
Lovely garden. Great place to stop for some peace and tranquility in Tokyo. I'd get a nice lunch from one of the big department store food sections and bring it here.

Fantastic. Super beautiful place! Really great!
Went with wife and daughter, and took a whole lot of photos, especially with all the autumn leaves.

A peaceful park in the middle of a very busy city. Because there is a small fee this park is relatively quiet. Or at least it was on the Saturday morning when we visited. The main entrance is on the Shinjuku Station side of the park. There are also other gates for exiting. We strolled around the grounds, just letting the sights guide us to our next stop. The trees and plants provide so much to see and enjoy. Photographers are innumerable. We saw at least one photography club.The grounds are much to hard to describe in words. Photographs are good, but you really need to see the park in person to get the complete sense of its beauty.
Pretty n peaceful. It's a very pretty place, don't miss the japanese garden.

Central Park ... in Tokyo. The park is located between Shinjuku and Sendagaya and although is in the very heart of the city, it is possible to enjoy a quiet atmosphere. There is a 300yen entrance fee. From the park you can admire the NTT State Building ... and even the new Sky Tree Tower. The park has different sections: (i) Traditional Japanese; (ii) French Formal; (iii) English Landscape. You can even try the experience of the tea ceremony in a traditional Japanese tea house.

A peaceful park. It was a lovely park to wander around as we waited to check in to our hotel. Lots of mosquitoes! We were a bit disappointed that the green house area was under construction at the time. (perhaps still is)

Always interesting, any time of year. A very good sized refuge right outside Shinjuku. Best time is in the spring, but any season there are some beautiful venues. Costs 200 yen to get in, but worth it. Check out the rose garden. You would not believe the number of varieties! Always full of fellow shutterbugs looking for nature shots in the middle of the city.

Absolutely stunning. Out of all the gardens I visited in Japan this was the most beautiful, enjoyable and welcoming. The English landscape part is great for picnics on the extensive lawns, while the Japanese and French gardens are just lovely to stroll through. My teenage son was rapt. Why don't we visit parks like this more often, he said. Sadly, there aren't too many as gorgeous as this.

Very beautiful and relaxing place. It had a western garden, we were very happy when we decided to go this garden. It is much bigger than any traditional garden i ever been. It has beautiful plant and decor, very worth to visit. If you are in Tokyo don't miss it.

Great place to relax. After a few days of endless walking at Disney and Puroland, this was a great place to get away and relax. There are very large very well kept grass areas for children to run around. However the Japanese Garden is quite disappointing. If Huntington Library rates a 10, then this park is only about 7.
Admission is $200 Yen.

We got there when it opened and enjoyed every minute.. You don't have to read the language to enjoy the attention displayed to detail in this beautiful place. We enjoyed every minute, every step and every sitting area. The fee you pay is nominal. You could stay a while and enjoy their little dining room or just plan to come back.
Lovely garden with beautiful autumn leaves. Nice garden. The autumn leaves were beautiful. Lots of space for the kids to run around.

Peaceful and beautifull. Great garden close of cool place like Shinjuku. Only at the south gate you will can hear some cars, otherwise this is a perfect place to walk and see trees, birds and extotic coloured flowers. Extremely clean and safe, is good for everyone. A good place to walk, sit, relax and forget for a while the crowd of Tokyo.

beautiful. this was one of the only gardens i got to see in tokyo and it was wonderful. the weather was sunny and nice, and the atmosphere was so tranquil and serene. it is the perfect place for a picnic or to relax with a good book!
Beautiful. Huge park, several diverse garden styles, japanese, french, ect. 200 yen to get in. Reminiscent of Central Park in New York City, ponds, people, and picnics.

Peaceful garden, well kept. On a recommendation of a local Tokyo resident friend, we spent a few hours walking around the Shinjuku Gyoen. It was really nice, and a large number of photos I took here made the cut for my Japan album.

Sanctuary in the City. This was our favorite park/garden in the Tokyo area (and we visited many). It costs a few hundred yen to get in but was worth the cost. We visited on a July morning. The park was almost empty and we enjoyed strolling through the gardens and admiring the different types of trees, many are very old and large. The park is divided into sections with different types of gardens. We enjoyed the Japanese garden section the best. It was very tranquil. The large open field on the other end of the park reminded me of central park in NYC as you can see the other large buildings above the trees. I think because they charge admission, there are no homeless people in the park and it was very well maintained. If you have limited time in Tokyo and want to see a garden, or if you need to escape the bustling streets this is your place to be.

beautiful relaxing garden. my first day in tokyo started with my visit to the shinjuku gyoen. The weather was perfect and so was the garden. The trees were beautiful and the air was so clean. I was so so relaxed. We had a afternoon picnic in this beautiful garden. If you are visiting Tokyo and pls do visit this park... and after that you can chop at the GAP... ehmmm interestin huh
